to the senate of the united states
 i have the honor to make the follow answer to a senate resolution of the 8th instant ask for information as to any interference by any military officer or any part of the army of the united states with the organization or proceeding of the general assembly of the state of louisiana or either branch thereof and also inquire in regard to the existence of armed organization in that state hostile to the government thereof and intent on overturn such government by force
 to say that lawlessness turbulence and bloodshed have characterize the political affair of that state since its reorganization under the reconstruction act be only to repeat what have become well know as a part of its unhappy history but it may be proper here to refer to the election of 1868 by which the republican vote of the state through fraud and violence be reduce to a few thousand and the bloody riot of 1866 and 1868 to show that the disorder there be not due to any recent cause or to any late action of the federal authority
 preparatory to the election of 1872 a shameful and undisguised conspiracy be form to carry that election against the republicans without regard to law or right and to that end the most glaring fraud and forgery be commit in the return after many colored citizen have be deny registration and other deter by fear from cast their ballot
 when the time come for a final canvass of the vote in view of the forego fact william p. kellogg the republican candidate for governor bring suit upon the equity side of the united states circuit court for louisiana and against warmoth and other who have obtain possession of the return of the election represent that several thousand voter of the state have be deprive of the elective franchise on account of their color and pray that step might be take to have say vote count and for general relief to enable the court to inquire as to the truth of these allegation a temporary restraining order be issue against the defendant which be at once wholly disregarded and treat with contempt by those to whom it be direct these proceeding have be widely denounce as an unwarrantable interference by the federal judiciary with the election of state officer but it be to be remember that by the fifteenth amendment to the constitution of the united states the political equality of colored citizen be secure and under the second section of that amendment provide that congress shall have power to enforce its provision by appropriate legislation an act be pass on the 31st of may 1870 and amend in 1871 the object of which be to prevent the denial or abridgment of suffrage to citizen on account of race color or previous condition of servitude and it have be hold by all the federal judge before whom the question have arise include justice strong of the supreme court that the protection afford by this amendment and these act extend to state as well as other election that it be the duty of the federal court to enforce the provision of the constitution of the united states and the law pass in pursuance thereof be too clear for controversy
 section 15 of say act after numerous provision therein to prevent an evasion of the fifteenth amendment provide that the jurisdiction of the circuit court of the united states shall extend to all case in law or equity arise under the provision of say act and of the act amendatory thereof congress seem to have contemplate equitable as well as legal proceeding to prevent the denial of suffrage to colored citizen and it may be safely assert that if kellogg&#39;s bill in the above name case do not present a case for the equitable interposition of the court that no such case can arise under the act that the court of the united states have the fight to interfere in various way with state election so as to maintain political equality and right therein irrespective of race or color be comparatively a new and to some seem to be a startling idea but it result as clearly from the fifteenth amendment to the constitution and the act that have be pass to enforce that amendment as the abrogation of state law uphold slavery result from the thirteenth amendment to the constitution while the jurisdiction of the court in the case of kellogg vs. warmoth and other be clear to my mind it seem that some of the order make by the judge in that and the kindre cause of antoine be illegal but while they be so held and consider it be not to be forget that the mandate of his court have be contemptuously defy and they be make while wild scene of anarchy be sweep away all restraint of law and order doubtless the judge of this court make grave mistake but the law allow the chancellor great latitude not only in punish those who contemn his order and injunction but in prevent the consummation of the wrong which he have judicially forbid whatever may be say or think of those matter it be only make known to i that process of the united states court be resist and as say act especially provide for the use of the army and navy when necessary to enforce judicial process arise thereunder i consider it my duty to see that such process be execute accord to the judgment of the court
 result from these proceeding through various controversy and complication a state administration be organize with william p. kellogg as governor which in the discharge of my duty under section 4 article iv of the constitution i have recognize as the government of the state
 it have be bitterly and persistently allege that kellogg be not elect whether he be or not be not altogether certain nor be it any more certain that his competitor mcenery be choose the election be a gigantic fraud and there be no reliable return of its result kellogg obtain possession of the office and in my opinion have more right to it than his competitor
 on the 20th of february 1873 the committee on privileges and elections of the senate make a report in which they say they be satisfied by testimony that the manipulation of the election machinery by warmoth and other be equivalent to 20,000 vote and they add that to recognize the mcenery government would be recognize a government base upon fraud in defiance of the wish and intention of the voter of the state assume the correctness of the statement in this report and they seem to have be generally accept by the country the great crime in louisiana about which so much have be say be that one be hold the office of governor who be cheat out of 20,000 vote against another whose title to the office be undoubtedly base on fraud and in defiance of the wish and intention of the voter of the state
 misinformed and misjudge as to the nature and extent of this report the supporter of mcenery proceed to displace by force in some county of the state the appointee of governor kellogg and on the 13th of april in an effort of that kind a butchery of citizen be commit at colfax which in bloodthirstiness and barbarity be hardly surpass by any act of savage warfare
 to put this matter beyond controversy i quote from the charge of judge woods of the united states circuit court to the jury in the case of the united states vs. cruikshank and other in new orleans in march 1874 he say
 in the case on trial there be many fact not in controversy i proceed to state some of they in the presence and hearing of counsel on both side and if i state as a concede fact any matter that be dispute they can correct i
 after state the origin of the difficulty which grow out of an attempt of white person to drive the parish judge and sheriff appointee of kellogg from office and their attempt protection by colored person which lead to some fighting in which quite a number of negro be kill the judge state
 most of those who be not kill be take prisoner fifteen or sixteen of the black have lift the board and take refuge under the floor of the court house they be all capture about thirty seven man be take prisoner the number be not definitely fix they be keep under guard until dark they be lead out two by two and shoot most of the man be shoot to death a few be wound not mortally and by pretend to be dead be afterwards during the night able to make their escape among they be the levi nelson name in the indictment
 the dead body of the negro kill in this affair be leave unburied until tuesday april 15 when they be bury by a deputy marshal and an officer of the militia from new orleans these person find fifty nine dead body they show pistol shot wound the great majority in the head and most of they in the back of the head in addition to the fifty nine dead body find some charred remain of dead body be discover near the court house six dead body be find under a warehouse all shoot in the head but one or two which be shoot in the breast
 the only white man injure from the beginning of these trouble to their close be hadnot and harris the court house and its content be entirely consume
 there be no evidence that anyone in the crowd of white bear any lawful warrant for the arrest of any of the black there be no evidence that either nash or cazabat after the affair ever demand their office to which they have set up claim but register continue to act as parish judge and shaw as sheriff
 these be fact in this case as i understand they to be admit
 to hold the people of louisiana generally responsible for these atrocity would not be just but it be a lamentable fact that insuperable obstruction be throw in the way of punish these murderer and the so call conservative paper of the state not only justify the massacre but denounce as federal tyranny and despotism the attempt of the united states officer to bring they to justice fierce denunciation ring through the country about office holding and election matter in louisiana while every one of the colfax miscreant go unwhipped of justice and no way can be find in this boasted land of civilization and christianity to punish the perpetrator of this bloody and monstrous crime
 not unlike this be the massacre in august last several northern young man of capital and enterprise have start the little and flourish town of coushatta some of they be republicans and officeholder under kellogg they be therefore doom to death six of they be seize and carry away from their home and murder in cold blood no one have be punish and the conservative press of the state denounce all effort to that end and boldly justify the crime
 many murder of a like character have be commit in individual ease which can not here be detail for example t. s. crawford judge and p. h. harris district attorney of the twelfth judicial district of the state on their way to court be shoot from their horse by man in ambush on the 8th of october 1873 and the widow of the former in a communication to the department of justice tell a piteous tale of the persecution of her husband because he be a union man and of the effort make to screen those who have commit a crime which to use her own language leave two widow and nine orphan desolate
 to say that the murder of a negro or a white republican be not consider a crime in louisiana would probably be unjust to a great part of the people but it be true that a great number of such murder have be commit and no one have be punish therefor and manifestly as to they the spirit of hatred and violence be strong than law
 representation be make to i that the presence of troop in louisiana be unnecessary and irritate to the people and that there be no danger of public disturbance if they be take away consequently early in last summer the troop be all withdraw from the state with the exception of a small garrison at new orleans barracks it be claim that a comparative state of quiet have supervene political excitement as to louisiana affair seem to be die out but the november election be approach and it be necessary for party purpose that the flame should be rekindle
 accordingly on the 14th of september d. p. penn claim that he be elect lieutenant governor in 1872 issue an inflammatory proclamation call upon the militia of the state to arm assemble and drive from power the usurper as he designate the officer of the state the white leagues armed and ready for the conflict promptly respond
 on the same day the governor make a formal requisition upon i pursuant to the act of 1795 and section 4 article iv of the constitution to aid in suppress domestic violence on the next day i issue my proclamation command the insurgent to disperse within five day from the date thereof but before the proclamation be publish in new orleans the organized and armed force recognize a usurping governor have take forcible possession of the statehouse and temporarily subvert the government twenty or more people be kill include a number of the police of the city the street of the city be stain with blood all that be desire in the way of excitement have be accomplish and in view of the step take to repress it the revolution be apparently though it be believe not really abandon and the cry of federal usurpation and tyranny in louisiana be renew with redoubled energy troop have be send to the state under this requisition of the governor and as other disturbance seem imminent they be allow to remain there to render the executive such aid as might become necessary to enforce the law of the state and repress the continue violence which seem inevitable the moment federal support should be withdraw
 prior to and with a view to the late election in louisiana white man associate themselves together in armed body call white leagues and at the same time threat be make in the democratic journal of the state that the election should be carry against the republicans at all hazard which very naturally greatly alarm the colored voter by section 8 of the act of february 28 1871 it be make the duty of united states marshal and their deputy at poll where vote be cast for representatives in congress to keep the peace and prevent any violation of the so call enforcement act and other offense against the law of the united states and upon a requisition of the marshal of louisiana and in view of say armed organization and other portentous circumstance i cause detachment of troop to be station in various locality in the state to aid he in the performance of his official duty that there be intimidation of republican voter at the election notwithstanding these precaution admit of no doubt the follow be specimen of the mean use
 on the 14th of october eighty person sign and publish the following at shreveport
 we the undersigned merchant of the city of shreveport in obedience to a request of the shreveport campaign club agree to use every endeavor to get our employee to vote the people&#39;s ticket at the ensue election and in the event of their refusal so to do or in case they vote the radical ticket to refuse to employ they at the expiration of their present contract
 on the same day another large body of person publish in the same place a paper in which they use the follow language
 we the undersigned merchant of the city of shreveport alive to the great importance of secure good and honest government to the state do agree and pledge ourselves not to advance any supply or money to any planter the come year who will give employment or rent land to laborer who vote the radical ticket in the come election
 i have no information of the proceeding of the return board for say election which may not be find in its report which have be publish but it be a matter of public information that a great part of the time take to canvass the vote be consume by the argument of lawyer several of whom represent each party before the board i have no evidence that the proceeding of this board be not in accordance with the law under which they act whether in exclude from their count certain return they be right or wrong be a question that depend upon the evidence they have before they but it be very clear that the law give they the power if they choose to exercise it of decide that way and prima facie the person whom they return as elect be entitle to the office for which they be candidate
 respect the alleged interference by the military with the organization of the legislature of louisiana on the 4th instant i have no knowledge or information which have not be receive by i since that time and publish my first information be from the paper of the morning of the 5th of january i do not know that any such thing be anticipate and no order nor suggestion be ever give to any military officer in that state upon that subject prior to the occurrence i be well aware that any military interference by the officer or troop of the united states with the organization of the state legislature or any of its proceeding or with any civil department of the government be repugnant to our idea of government i can conceive of no case not involve rebellion or insurrection where such interference by authority of the general government ought to be permit or can be justify but there be circumstance connect with the late legislative imbroglio in louisiana which seem to exempt the military from any intentional wrong in that matter know that they have be place in louisiana to prevent domestic violence and aid in the enforcement of the state law the officer and troop of the united states may well have suppose that it be their duty to act when call upon by the governor for that purpose
 each branch of a legislative assembly be the judge of the election and qualification of its own member but if a mob or a body of unauthorized person seize and hold the legislative hall in a tumultuous and riotous manner and so prevent any organization by those legally return as elect it might become the duty of the state executive to interpose if request by a majority of the member elect to suppress the disturbance and enable the person elect to organize the house
 any exercise of this power would only be justifiable under most extraordinary circumstance and it would then be the duty of the governor to call upon the constabulary or if necessary the military force of the state but with reference to louisiana it be to be bear in mind that any attempt by the governor to use the police force of that state at this time would have undoubtedly precipitate a bloody conflict with the white league as it do on the 14th of september
 there be no doubt but that the presence of the united states troop upon that occasion prevent bloodshed and the loss of life both party appear to have rely upon they as conservator of the public peace
 the first call be make by the democrats to remove person obnoxious to they from the legislative hall and the second be from the republicans to remove person who have usurped seat in the legislature without legal certificate authorize they to seat and in sufficient number to change the majority
 nobody be disturb by the military who have a legal right at that time to occupy a seat in the legislature that the democratic minority of the house undertake to seize its organization by fraud and violence that in this attempt they trample under foot law that they undertake to make person not return as elect member so as to create a majority that they act under a preconcerte plan and under false pretense introduce into the hall a body of man to support their pretension by force if necessary and that conflict disorder and riotous proceeding follow be fact that seem to be well establish and i be credibly inform that these violent proceeding be a part of a premeditate plan to have the house organize in this way recognize what have be call the mcenery senate then to depose governor kellogg and so revolutionize the state government
 whether it be wrong for the governor at the request of the majority of the member return as elect to the house to use such mean as be in his power to defeat these lawless and revolutionary proceeding be perhaps a debatable question but it be quite certain that there would have be no trouble if those who now complain of illegal interference have allow the house to be organize in a lawful and regular manner when those who inaugurate disorder and anarchy disavow such proceeding it will be time enough to condemn those who by such mean as they have prevent the success of their lawless and desperate scheme
 lieutenant general sheridan be request by i to go to louisiana to observe and report the situation there and if in his opinion necessary to assume the command which he do on the 4th instant after the legislative disturbance have occur at 9 o&#39;clock p.m. a number of hour after the disturbance no party motive nor prejudice can reasonably be impute to he but honestly convince by what he have see and hear there he have characterize the leader of the white leagues in severe term and suggest summary mode of procedure against they which though they can not be adopt would if legal soon put an end to the trouble and disorder in that state general sheridan be look at fact and possibly not think of proceeding which would be the only proper one to pursue in time of peace think more of the utterly lawless condition of society surround he at the time of his dispatch and of what would prove a sure remedy he never propose to do an illegal act nor express determination to proceed beyond what the law in the future might authorize for the punishment of the atrocity which have be commit and the commission of which can not be successfully deny it be a deplorable fact that political crime and murder have be commit in louisiana which have go unpunished and which have be justify or apologize for which must rest as a reproach upon the state and country long after the present generation have pass away
 i have no desire to have united states troop interfere in the domestic concern of louisiana or any other state
 on the 9th of december last governor kellogg telegraph to i his apprehension that the white league intend to make another attack upon the statehouse to which on the same day i make the follow answer since which no communication have be send to he
 your dispatch of this date just receive it be exceedingly unpalatable to use troop in anticipation of danger let the state authority be right and then proceed with their duty without apprehension of danger if they be then molest the question will be determine whether the united states be able to maintain law and order within its limit or not
 i have deplore the necessity which seem to make it my duty under the constitution and law to direct such interference i have always refuse except where it seem to be my imperative duty to act in such a manner under the constitution and law of the united states i have repeatedly and earnestly entreat the people of the south to live together in peace and obey the law and nothing would give i great pleasure than to see reconciliation and tranquillity everywhere prevail and thereby remove all necessity for the presence of troop among they i regret however to say that this state of thing do not exist nor do its existence seem to be desire in some locality and as to those it may be proper for i to say that to the extent that congress have confer power upon i to prevent it neither ku klux klans white leagues nor any other association use arm and violence to execute their unlawful purpose can be permit in that way to govern any part of this country nor can i see with indifference union man or republicans ostracize persecute and murder on account of their opinion as they now be in some locality
 i have heretofore urge the case of louisiana upon the attention of congress and i can not but think that its inaction have produce great evil
 to summarize in september last an armed organized body of man in the support of candidate who have be put in nomination for the office of governor and lieutenant governor at the november election in 1872 and who have be declare not elect by the board of canvasser recognize by all the court to which the question have be submit undertake to subvert and overthrow the state government that have be recognize by i in accordance with previous precedent the recognize governor be drive from the statehouse and but for his finding shelter in the united states custom house in the capital of the state of which he be governor it be scarcely to be doubt that he would have be kill
 from the statehouse before he have be drive to the custom house a call be make in accordance with the fourth section fourth article of the constitution of the united states for the aid of the general government to suppress domestic violence under those circumstance and in accordance with my sworn duty my proclamation of the 15th of september 1874 be issue this serve to reinstate governor kellogg to his position nominally but it can not be claim that the insurgent have to this day surrender to the state authority the arm belong to the state or that they have in any sense disarm on the contrary it be know that the same armed organization that exist on the 14th of september 1874 in opposition to the recognize state government still retain their organization equipment and commander and can be call out at any hour to resist the state government under these circumstance the same military force have be continue in louisiana as be send there under the first call and under the same general instruction i repeat that the task assume by the troop be not a pleasant one to they that the army be not compose of lawyer capable of judge at a moment&#39;s notice of just how far they can go in the maintenance of law and order and that it be impossible to give specific instruction provide for all possible contingency that might arise the troop be bind to act upon the judgment of the command officer upon each sudden contingency that arise or wait instruction which could only reach they after the threaten wrong have be commit which they be call on to prevent it should be recollect too that upon my recognition of the kellogg government i report the fact with the ground of recognition to congress and ask that body to take action in the matter otherwise i should regard their silence as an acquiescence in my course no action have be take by that body and i have maintain the position then mark out
 if error have be commit by the army in these matter it have always be on the side of the preservation of good order the maintenance of law and the protection of life their bearing reflect credit upon the soldier and if wrong have result the blame be with the turbulent element surround they
 i now earnestly ask that such action be take by congress as to leave my duty perfectly clear in deal with the affair of louisiana give assurance at the same time that whatever may be do by that body in the premise will be execute accord to the spirit and letter of the law without fear or favor
 i herewith transmit copy of document contain more specific information as to the subject matter of the resolution

to the senate of the united states
 senate bill no 1044 to provide for the resumption of specie payment be before i and this day receive my signature of approval
 i venture upon this unusual method of convey the notice of approval to the house in which the measure originate because of its great importance to the country at large and in order to suggest further legislation which seem to i essential to make this law effective
 it be a subject of congratulation that a measure have become law which fix a date when specie resumption shall commence and imply an obligation on the part of congress if in its power to give such legislation as may prove necessary to redeem this promise
 to this end i respectfully call your attention to a few suggestion
 first the necessity of an increase revenue to carry out the obligation of add to the sink fund annually 1 per cent of the public debt amount now to about $ 34,000,000 per annum and to carry out the promise of this measure to redeem under certain contingency eighty million of the present legal tender and without contingency the fractional currency now in circulation
 how to increase the surplus revenue be for congress to devise but i will venture to suggest that the duty on tea and coffee might be restore without permanently enhance the cost to the consumer and that the 10 per cent horizontal reduction of the tariff on article specify in the law of june 6 1872 be repeal the supply of tea and coffee already on hand in the united states would in all probability be advanced in price by adopt this measure but it be know that the adoption of free entry to those article of necessity do not cheapen they but merely add to the profit of the country produce they or of the middleman in those country who have the exclusive trade in they
 second the first section of the bill now under consideration provide that the fractional currency shall be redeem in silver coin as rapidly as practicable there be no provision prevent the fluctuation in the value of the paper currency with gold at a premium of anything over 10 per cent above the currency in use it be probable almost certain that silver would be buy up for exportation as fast as it be put out or until change would become so scarce as to make the premium on it equal to the premium on gold or sufficiently high to make it no long profitable to buy for export thereby cause a direct loss to the community at large and great embarrassment to trade
 as the present law command final resumption on the 1st day of january 1879 and as the gold receipt by the treasury be large than the gold payment and the currency receipt be small than the currency payment thereby make monthly sale of gold necessary to meet current currency expense it occur to i that these difficulty might be remedie by authorize the secretary of the treasury to redeem legal tender note whenever present in sum of not less than $ 100 and multiple thereof at a premium for gold of 10 per cent less interest at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent per annum from the 1st day of january 1875 to the date of put this law into operation and diminish this premium at the same rate until final resumption change the rate of premium demand from time to time as the interest amount to one quarter of 1 per cent i suggest this rate of interest because it would bring currency at par with gold at the date fix by law for final resumption i suggest 10 per cent as the demand premium at the beginning because i believe this rate would insure the retention of silver in the country for change
 the provision of the third section of the act will prevent combination be make to exhaust the treasury of coin
 with such a law it be presumable that no gold would be call for not require for legitimate business purpose when large amount of coin should be draw from the treasury correspondingly large amount of currency would be withdraw from circulation thus cause a sufficient stringency in currency to stop the outward flow of coin
 the advantage of a currency of a fix know value would also be reach in my opinion by the enactment of such a law business and industry would revive and the beginning of prosperity on a firm basis would be reach
 other mean of increase revenue than those suggest should probably be devise and also other legislation
 in fact to carry out the first section of the act another mint become a necessity with the present facility for coinage it would take a period probably beyond that fix by law for final specie resumption to coin the silver necessary to transact the business of the country
 there be now smelt furnace for extract the silver and gold from the ore bring from the mountain territory in chicago st. louis and omaha three in the former city and as much of the change require will be want in the mississippi valley states and as the metal to be coin come from west of those states and as i understand the charge for transportation of bullion from either of the city name to the mint in philadelphia or to new york city amount to $ 4 for each $ 1,000 worth with an equal expense for transportation back it would seem a fair argument in favor of adopt one or more of those city as the place or place for the establishment of new coining facility
 i have venture upon this subject with great diffidence because it be so unusual to approve a measure as i most heartily do this even if no further legislation be attainable at this time and to announce the fact by message but i do so because i feel that it be a subject of such vital importance to the whole country that it should receive the attention of and be discuss by congress and the people through the press and in every way to the end that the good and most satisfactory course may be reach of execute what i deem most beneficial legislation on a most vital question to the interest and prosperity of the nation

to the senate of the united states
 herewith i return senate bill no 172 entitle an act fix the salary of the president of the united states without my approval
 i be constrain to this course from a sense of duty to my successor in office to myself and to what be due to the dignity of the position of chief magistrate of a nation of more than 40,000,000 people
 when the salary of the president of the united states pursuant to the constitution be fix at $ 25,000 per annum we be a nation of but 3,000,000 people poor from a long and exhaustive war without commerce or manufacture with but few want and those cheaply supply the salary must then have be deem small for the responsibility and dignity of the position but justifiably so from the impoverished condition of the treasury and the simplicity it be desire to cultivate in the republic
 the salary of congressmen under the constitution be first fix at $ 6 per day for the time actually in session an average of about one hundred and twenty day to each session or $ 720 per year or less than one thirtieth of the salary of the president
 congress have legislate upon their own salary from time to time since until finally it reach $ 5,000 per annum or one fifth that of the president before the salary of the latter be increase
 no one have a knowledge of the cost of live at the national capital will contend that the present salary of congressmen be too high unless it be the intention to make the office one entirely of honor when the salary should be abolish a proposition repugnant to our republican idea and institution
 i do not believe the citizen of this republic desire their public servant to serve they without a fair compensation for their service twenty five thousand dollar do not defray the expense of the executive for one year or have not in my experience it be not now one fifth in value of what it be at the time of the adoption of the constitution in supply demand and want
 have no personal interest in this matter i have feel myself free to return this bill to the house in which it originate with my objection believe that in do so i meet the wish and judgment of the great majority of those who indirectly pay all the salary and other expense of government

to the senate and house of representatives in submit my seventh annual message to congress in this centennial year of our national existence as a free and independent people it afford i great pleasure to recur to the advancement that have be make from the time of the colony one hundred year ago we be then a people number only 3,000,000 now we number more than 40,000,000 then industry be confine almost exclusively to the tillage of the soil now manufactory absorb much of the labor of the country our liberty remain unimpaired the bondman have be free from slavery we have become possess of the respect if not the friendship of all civilized nation our progress have be great in all the art in science agriculture commerce navigation mining mechanic law medicine etc and in general education the progress be likewise encouraging our thirteen state have become thirty eight include colorado which have take the initiatory step to become a state and eight territories include the indian territory and alaska and exclude colorado make a territory extend from the atlantic to the pacific on the south we have extend to the gulf of mexico and in the west from the mississippi to the pacific one hundred year ago the cotton gin the steamship the railroad the telegraph the reaping sewing and modern printing machine and numerous other invention of scarcely less value to our business and happiness be entirely unknown in 1776 manufactory scarcely exist even in name in all this vast territory in 1870 more than 2,000,000 person be employ in manufactory produce more than $ 2,100,000,000 of product in amount annually nearly equal to our national debt from nearly the whole of the population of 1776 be engage in the one occupation of agriculture in 1870 so numerous and diversified have become the occupation of our people that less than 6,000,000 out of more than 40,000,000 be so engaged the extraordinary effect produce in our country by a resort to diversify occupation have build a market for the product of fertile land distant from the seaboard and the market of the world the american system of locate various and extensive manufactory next to the plow and the pasture and add connect railroad and steamboat have produce in our distant interior country a result noticeable by the intelligent portion all all commercial nation the ingenuity and skill of american mechanic have be demonstrate at home and abroad in a manner most flattering to their pride but for the extraordinary genius and ability of our mechanic the achievement of our agriculturist manufacturer and transporter throughout the country would have be impossible of attainment the progress of the miner have also be great of coal our production have small now many million of ton be mine annually so with iron which form scarcely an appreciable part of our product half a century ago we now produce more than the world consume at the beginning of our national existence lead zinc and copper from be article of import we may expect to be large exporter of in the near future the development of gold and silver mine in the united states and territories have not only be remarkable but have have a large influence upon the business of all commercial nation our merchant in the last hundred year have have a success and have establish a reputation for enterprise sagacity progress and integrity unsurpasse by people of old nationality this good name be not confine to their home but go out upon every sea and into every port where commerce enter with equal pride we can point to our progress in all of the learn profession as we be now about to enter upon our second centennial comment our manhood as a nation it be well to look back upon the past and study what will be good to preserve and advance our future greatness from the fall of adam for his transgression to the present day no nation have ever be free from threatened danger to its prosperity and happiness we should look to the danger threaten we and remedy they so far as lie in our power we be a republic whereof one man be as good as another before the law under such a form of government it be of the great importance that all should be possess of education and intelligence enough to cast a vote with a right understanding of its meaning a large association of ignorant man can not for any considerable period oppose a successful resistance to tyranny and oppression from the educate few but will inevitably sink into acquiescence to the will of intelligence whether direct by the demagogue or by priestcraft hence the education of the masse become of the first necessity for the preservation of our institution they be worth preserve because they have secure the great good to the great proportion of the population of any form of government yet devise all other form of government approach it just in proportion to the general diffusion of education and independence of thought and action as the primary step therefore to our advancement in all that have mark our progress in the past century i suggest for your earnest consideration and most earnestly recommend it that a constitutional amendment be submit to the legislature of the several states for ratification make it the duty of each of the several states to establish and forever maintain free public school adequate to the education of all the child in the rudimentary branch within their respective limit irrespective of sex color birthplace or religion forbid the teaching in say school of religious atheistic or pagan tenet and prohibit the granting of there be a few measure which seem to i important in this connection and which i commend to your earnest consideration a repeal of so much of the legal tender act as make these note receivable for debt probably $ 18,000,000 to the present amount receive from import and would in no way increase the price pay for those article by the consumer these article be the product of country collect revenue from export and as we the large consumer reduce the duty they proportionately increase they with this addition to the revenue many duty now collect and which give but an insignificant return for the cost of collection might be remit and to the direct advantage of consumer at home i would mention those article which enter into manufacture of all sort all duty pay upon such article go directly to the cost of the article when manufacture here and must be pay for by the consumer these duty not only come from the consumer at home but act as a protection to foreign manufacturer of the same complete article in our own and distant market i will suggest or mention another subject bearing upon the problem of how to enable the secretary of the treasury to accumulate balance it be to devise some well method of verify claim against the government than at present exist through the court of claims especially those claim grow out of the late war nothing be more certain than that a very large between the united states and any maritime power torpedo will be among if not the most effective and cheap auxiliary for the defense of harbor and also in aggressive operation that we can have hence it be advisable to learn by experiment their good construction and application as well as effect fifth a permanent organization for the signal service corps this service have now become a necessity of peace as well as war under the advancement make by the present able management sixth a renewal of the appropriation for compile the official record of the war etc the condition of our navy at this time be a subject of satisfaction it do not contain it be true any of the powerful cruise ironclad which make so much of the maritime strength of some other nation but neither our continental situation nor our foreign policy require that we should have a large number of ship of this character while this situation and the nature of our port combine to make those of other nation little dangerous to we under any circumstance our navy do contain however a considerable number of ironclad of the monitor class which though not properly cruiser be powerful and effective for harbor defense and for operation near our own shore of these all the single turrete one fifteen in number have be substantially rebuild their rotten wooden beam replace with iron their hull strengthen and their engine and machinery thoroughly repair so that they be now in the most efficient condition and ready for sea as soon as they can be man and put in commission the five double turrete ironclad belong to our navy by far the most powerful of our ship for fight purpose be also in hand undergo complete repair and could be ready for sea in period vary from four to six month with these complete accord to the present design and our two iron torpedo boat now ready our ironclad fleet will be for the purpose of defense at home equal to any force that can readily be bring against it of our wooden navy also cruiser of various size to the number of about forty include those now in commission be in the atlantic and could be ready for duty as fast as man could be enlist for those not already in commission of these one third be in effect new ship and though some of the remainder need considerable repair to their boiler and machinery they all be or can readily be make effective this constitute a fleet of more than fifty war ship of which fifteen be ironclad now in hand on the atlantic coast the navy have be bring to this condition by a judicious and practical application of what could be spare from the current appropriation of the last few year and from that make to meet the possible emergency of two year ago it have be do quietly without proclamation or display and though it have necessarily straiten the department in its ordinary expenditure and as far as the ironclad be concern have add nothing to the cruise force of the navy yet the result be not the less satisfactory because it be to our position relation and character and affect seriously the weight of our principle and policy throughout the whole sphere of national responsibility the estimate for the regular support of this monitor now undergo repair which must otherwise advance slowly and only as money can be spare from current expense supplement by these our navy arm with the destructive weapon of modern warfare man by our seaman and in charge of our instruct officer will present a force powerful for the home purpose of a responsible though peaceful nation the report of the postmaster general herewith transmit give to the house of representatives
 i have give very attentive consideration to a resolution of the house of representatives pass on the 3d of april request the president of the united states to inform the house whether any executive office act or duty and if any what have within a specify period be perform at a distance from the seat of government establish by law etc
 i have never hesitate and shall not hesitate to communicate to congress and to either branch thereof all the information which the constitution make it the duty of the president to give or which my judgment may suggest to i or a request from either house may indicate to i will be useful in the discharge of the appropriate duty confide to they i fail however to find in the constitution of the united states the authority give to the house of representatives one branch of the congress in which be vest the legislative power of the government to require of the executive an independent branch of the government coordinate with the senate and house of representatives an account of his discharge of his appropriate and purely executive office act and duty either as to when where or how perform
 what the house of representatives may require as a right in its demand upon the executive for information be limited to what be necessary for the proper discharge of its power of legislation or of impeachment
 the inquiry in the resolution of the house as to where executive act have within the last seven year be perform and at what distance from any particular spot or for how long a period at any one time etc do not necessarily belong to the province of legislation it do not profess to be ask for that object
 if this information be seek through an inquiry of the president as to his executive act in view or in aid of the power of impeachment vest in the house it be ask in derogation of an inherent natural right recognize in this country by a constitutional guaranty which protect every citizen the president as well as the humblest in the land from be make a witness against himself
 during the time that i have have the honor to occupy the position of president of this government it have be and while i continue to occupy that position it will continue to be my earnest endeavor to recognize and to respect the several trust and duty and power of the coordinate branch of the government not encroach upon they nor allow encroachment upon the proper power of the office which the people of the united states have confide to i but aim to preserve in their proper relation the several power and function of each of the coordinate branch of the government agreeably to the constitution and in accordance with the solemn oath which i have take to preserve protect and defend that instrument
 in maintenance of the right secure by the constitution to the executive branch of the government i be compel to decline any specific or detailed answer to the request of the house for information as to any executive office act or duty and if any what have be perform at a distance from the seat of government establish by law and for how long a period at any one time and in what part of the united states
 if however the house of representatives desire to know whether during the period of upward of seven year during which i have hold the office of president of the united states i have be absent from the seat of government and whether during that period i have perform or have neglect to perform the duty of my office i freely inform the house that from the time of my entrance upon my office i have be in the habit as be all of my predecessor with the exception of one who live only one month after assume the duty of his office and one whose continued presence in washington be necessary from the existence at the time of a powerful rebellion of absent myself at time from the seat of government and that during such absence i do not neglect or forego the obligation or the duty of my office but continue to discharge all of the executive office act and duty which be require of i as the president of the united states i be not aware that a failure occur in any one instance of my exercise the function and power of my office in every case require their discharge or of my exercise all necessary executive act in whatever part of the united states i may at the time have be fortunately the rapidity of travel and of mail communication and the facility of almost instantaneous correspondence with the office at the seat of government which the telegraph afford to the president in whatever section of the union he may be enable he in these day to maintain as constant and almost as quick intercourse with the departments at washington as may be maintain while he remain at the capital
 the necessity of the performance of executive act by the president of the united states exist and be devolve upon he wherever he may be within the united states during his term of office by the constitution of the united states
 his civil power be no more limited or capable of limitation as to the place where they shall be exercise than be those which he might be require to discharge in his capacity of commander in chief of the army and navy which latter power it be evident he might be call upon to exercise possibly even without the limit of the united states have the effort of those recently in rebellion against the government be successful in drive a late president of the united states from washington it be manifest that he must have discharge his function both civil and military elsewhere than in the place name by law as the seat of government
 no act of congress can limit suspend or confine this constitutional duty i be not aware of the existence of any act of congress which assume thus to limit or restrict the exercise of the function of the executive be there such act i should nevertheless recognize the superior authority of the constitution and should exercise the power require thereby of the president
 the act to which reference be make in the resolution of the house relate to the establishing of the seat of government and the providing of suitable building and removal thereto of the office attach to the government etc it be not understand at its date and by general washington to confine the president in the discharge of his duty and power to actual presence at the seat of government on the 30th of march 1791 shortly after the passage of the act refer to general washington issue an executive proclamation have reference to the subject of this very act from georgetown a place remote from philadelphia which then be the seat of government where the act refer to direct that all office attach to the seat of government should for the time remain
 that none of his successor have entertain the idea that their executive office could be perform only at the seat of government be evidence by the hundred upon hundred of such act perform by my predecessor in unbroken line from washington to lincoln a memorandum of the general nature and character of some of which act be submit herewith and no question have ever be raise as to the validity of those act or as to the right and propriety of the executive to exercise the power of his office in any part of the united states

 memorandum of absence of the president of the united states from the national capital during each of the several administrations and of public and executive act perform during the time of such absence
 president washington be frequently absent from the capital he appear to have be thus absent at least one hundred and eighty one day during his term
 during his several absence he discharge official and executive duty among them--
 in march 1791 he issue a proclamation date at georgetown in reference to run the boundary for the territory of the permanent seat of the government
 from mount vernon he sign an official letter to the emperor of morocco and from the same place the commission of oliver wolcott as comptroller of the treasury and the proclamation respect the whisky insurrection in pennsylvania also various sea letter the proclamation of the treaty of 1795 between the united states and spain the executive order of august 4 1792 relative to the duty on distilled spirit etc
 when at germantown he sign the commission of john breckenridge as attorney of the united states for kentucky and that of engineer of the united states mint
 he propose to have mr. yrujo officially present as envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary from spain to he at mount vernon but although mr. yrujo go there for the purpose the ceremony of presentation be prevent by mr. yrujo&#39;s having accidentally leave his credential
 president john adams be absent from the capital during his term of four year on various occasion three hundred and eighty five day he discharge official duty and perform the most solemn public act at quincy in the same manner as when at the seat of government in 1797 august 25 he forward to the secretary of state a number of passport which he have sign at quincy he issue at quincy commission to numerous officer of various grade civil and military on the 28th of september 1797 he forward to the secretary of state a commission for a justice of the supreme court sign in blank at quincy instruct the secretary to fill it with the name of john marshall if he would accept and if not bushrod washington he issue a proclamation opening trade with certain port of st. domingo and sign warrant for the execution of two soldier and for a pardon
 president jefferson be absent from the seat of government during his two term of office seven hundred and ninety six day more than one fourth of the whole official period during his absence he sign and issue from monticello seventy five commission one letter to the emperor of russia and nine letter of credence to diplomatic agent of the united states accredit to other government
 president madison be absent from the seat of government during his two presidential term six hundred and thirty seven day he sign and issue from montpelier during his absence from the capital seventy one commission one proclamation and nine letter of credence to minister accredit they to foreign government and as it appear transact generally all the necessary routine business incident to the executive office
 president monroe be absent from the capital during his presidential service of eight year seven hundred and eight day independent of the year 1824 and the two month of 1825 for which period no datum be find he transact public business wherever he happen to be sometimes at his farm in virginia again at his summer resort on the chesapeake and sometimes while travel he sign and issue from these several place away from the capital numerous commission to civil officer of the government exequatur to foreign consul letter of credence two letter to sovereign and thirty seven pardon
 president john q. adams be absent from the capital during his presidential term of four year two hundred and twenty two day during such absence he perform official and public act sign and issue commission exequatur pardon proclamation etc refer to his absence in august and september 1827 mr. adams in his memoir volume 8 page 75 say i leave with he the chief clerk some blank signature to be use when necessary for proclamation remission of penalty and commission of consul take of he a receipt for the number and kind of blank leave with he with direction to return to i when i come back all the sign blank remain unused and to keep and give i an account of all those that shall have be dispose of this have be my constant practice with respect to sign blank of this description i do the same with regard to patent and land grant
 president jackson be absent from the capital during his presidential service of eight year five hundred and two day he also perform executive duty and public act while absent he appear to have sign and issue while absent from the capital very many public paper embrace commission letter of credence exequatur pardon and among they four executive proclamation on the 26th of june 1833 he address a letter from boston to mr. duane secretary of the treasury give his view at large on the removal of the deposit from the united states bank and place they in the state bank direct that the change with all its arrangement should be if possible complete by the 15th september follow and recommend that amos kendall should be appoint an agent of the treasury department to make the necessary arrangement with the state bank soon after september 23 a paper sign by the president and purport to have be read to the cabinet be publish in the newspaper of the day early in the next session of congress a resolution pass the senate inquire of the president whether the paper be genuine or not and if it be publish by his authority and request that a copy be lay before that body the president reply avow the genuineness of the paper and that it be publish by his authority but decline to furnish a copy to the senate on the ground that it be purely executive business and that the request of the senate be an undue interference with the independence of the executive a coordinate branch of the government in january 1837 26th he refuse the privilege to a committee under a resolution of the house of representatives to make a general investigation of the executive departments without specific charge on the ground among other that the use of the book paper etc of the departments for such purpose would interfere with the discharge of the public duty devolve upon the head of the different department and necessarily disarrange and retard the public business
 president van buren be absent from the capital during his presidential term one hundred and thirty one day he discharge executive duty and perform official and public act during these absence among the paper sign by president van buren during his absence from the seat of government be commission one of these be for a united states judge of a district court pardon etc
 president tyler be absent from the capital during his presidential term one hundred and sixty three day and perform public act and duty during such absence sign public paper and document to the number of twenty eight in which be include commission exequatur letter of credence pardon and one proclamation make public the treaty of 1842 between the united states and ecuador
 president polk be absent from the capital during his presidential term thirty seven day and appear to have sign but two official public paper during such absence
 president taylor be absent from the capital during the time he serve as president thirty one day and while absent sign two commission three full power two exequatur and the proclamation of august 11 1849 relative to a threatened invasion of cuba or some of the provinces of mexico
 president fillmore be absent from the capital during the time he serve as president sixty day during such absence he sign pardon commission exequatur etc
 president pierce be absent from the capital in all during his presidential term fifty seven day the several period of absence which make up this aggregate be each brief and it do not appear that during these absence the president sign any public official document except one pardon
 president buchanan be absent front the capital during his presidential term fifty seven day and the official paper which he be show to have sign during such absence be three exequatur and one letter of credence
 in addition to the public document and paper execute by the several president during their absence from the seat of government constant official correspondence be maintain by each with the head of the different executive departments

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 the centennial anniversary of the day on which the people of the united states declare their right to a separate and equal station among the power of the earth seem to demand an exceptional observance
 the founder of the government at its birth and in its feebleness invoke the blessing and the protection of a divine providence and the thirteen colony and three million of people have expand into a nation of strength and number command the position which then be assert and for which fervent prayer be then offer
 it seem fitting that on the occurrence of the hundredth anniversary of our existence as a nation a grateful acknowledgment should be make to almighty god for the protection and the bounty which he have vouchsafe to our beloved country
 i therefore invite the good people of the united states on the approach 4th day of july in addition to the usual observance with which they be accustom to greet the return of the day far in such manner and at such time as in their respective locality and religious association may be most convenient to mark its recurrence by some public religious and devout thanksgiving to almighty god for the blessing which have be bestow upon we as a nation during the century of our existence and humbly to invoke a continuance of his favor and of his protection
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 26th day of june a. d. 1876 and of the independence of the united states of america the one hundredth

to the senate and house of representatives in submit my eighth and last annual message to congress it seem proper that i should refer to and in some degree recapitulate the event and official act of the past eight year it be my fortune or misfortune to be call to the office of chief executive without any previous political training from the age of 17 i have never even witness the excitement attend a presidential campaign but twice antecedent to my own candidacy and at but one of they be i eligible as a voter under such circumstance it be but reasonable to suppose that error of judgment must have occur even have they not difference of opinion between the executive bind by an oath to the strict performance of his duty and writer and debater must have arise it be not necessarily evidence of blunder on the part of the executive because there be these difference of view mistake have be make as all can see and i admit but it seem to i oftener in the selection make of the assistant appoint to aid in carry out the various duty of administer the government in nearly every case select without a personal acquaintance with the appointee but upon recommendation of the representative choose directly by the people it be impossible where so many trust be to be allot that the right party should be choose in every instance history show that no administration from the time of washington to the present have be free from these mistake but i leave comparison to history claim only that i have act in every instance from a conscientious desire to do what be right constitutional within the law and for the very good interest of the whole people failure have be error of judgment not of intent my civil career commence too at a most critical and difficult time less than four year before the country have emerge from a conflict such as no other nation have ever survive nearly one half of the states have revolt against the government and of those remain faithful to the union a large percentage of the population sympathize with the rebellion and make an enemy in the rear almost as dangerous as the more honorable enemy in the front the latter committed error of judgment but they maintain they openly and courageously the former receive the protection of the government they would see destroy and reap all the pecuniary advantage to be gain out of the then exist state of affair many of they by obtain contract and by swindle the government in the delivery of their good immediately on the cessation of hostility the then noble president who have carry the country so far through its peril fall a martyr to his patriotism at the hand of an assassin the intervene time to my first inauguration be fill up with wrangling between congress and the new executive as to the good mode of reconstruction or to speak plainly as to whether the control of the government should be throw immediately into the hand of those who have so recently and persistently try to destroy it or whether the victor should continue to have an equal voice with they in this control reconstruction as finally agree upon mean this and only this except that the late slave be enfranchised give an increase as be suppose to the union love and union support vote if free in the full sense of the word they would not disappoint this expectation hence at the beginning of my first administration the work of reconstruction much embarrassed by the long delay virtually commenced it be the work of the legislative branch of the government my province be wholly in approve their act which i do most heartily urge the legislature of states that have not yet do so to ratify the fifteenth amendment to the constitution the country be labor under an enormous debt contract in the suppression of rebellion and taxation be so oppressive as to discourage production another danger also threaten we a foreign war the last difficulty have to be adjust and be adjust without a war and in a manner highly honorable to all party concern taxis have be reduce within the last seven year nearly $ 300,000,000 and the national debt have be reduce in the same time over $ 435,000,000 by refund the 6 per cent bond debt for bond bear 5 and 4 1/2 per cent interest respectively the annual interest have be reduce from over $ 130,000,000 in 1869 to but little over $ 100,000,000 in 1876 the balance of trade have be change from over $ 130,000,000 against the united states in 1869 to more than $ 120,000,000 in our favor in 1876.it be confidently believe that the balance of trade in favor of the united states will increase not diminish and that the pledge of congress to resume specie payment in 1879 will be easily accomplish even in the absence of much desire further legislation on the subject a policy have be adopt toward the indian tribe inhabit a large portion of the territory of the united states which have be humane and have substantially end indian hostility in the whole land except in a portion of nebraska and dakota wyoming and montana territories the black hills region and approach thereto hostility there have grow out of the avarice of the white man who have violate our treaty stipulation in his search for gold the question might be ask why the government have not enforce obedience to the term of the treaty prohibit the occupation of the black hills region by white the answer be simple the first immigrant to the black hills be remove by troop but rumor of rich discovery of gold take into that region increase number gold have actually be find in pay quantity and an effort to remove the miner would only result in the desertion of the bulk of the troop that might be send there to remove they all difficulty in this matter have however be remove subject to the approval of congress by a treaty cede the black hills and approach to settlement by citizen the subject of indian policy and treatment be so fully set forth by the secretary of the interior and the commissioner of indian affairs and my view so fully express therein that i refer to their report and recommendation as my own the relation of the united states with foreign power continue on a friendly footing question have arise from time to time in the foreign relation of the government but the united states have be happily free during the past year from the complication and embarrassment which have surround some of the foreign power the diplomatic correspondence submit herewith contain information as to certain of the matter which have occupy the government the cordiality which attend our relation with the power of the earth have be plainly show by the general participation of foreign nation in the exhibition which have just close and by the exertion make by distant power to show their interest in and friendly feeling toward the united states in the commemoration of the centennial of the nation the government and people of the united states have not only fully appreciate this exhibition of kindly feeling but it may be justly and fairly expect that no small benefit will result both to ourselves and other nation from a well acquaintance and a well appreciation of our mutual advantage and mutual want congress at its last session see fit to reduce the amount usually appropriate for foreign intercourse by withhold appropriation for representative of the united states in certain foreign country and for certain consular officer and by reduce the amount usually appropriate for certain other diplomatic post and thus necessitate a change in the grade of the representative for these reason immediately upon the passage of the bill make appropriation for the diplomatic and consular service for the present fiscal year instruction be issue to the representative of the united states at bolivia ecuador and colombia and to the consular officer for whom no appropriation have be make to close their respective legation and consulate and cease from the performance of their duty and in like manner step be immediately take to substitute charge 's d'affaire for minister resident in portugal denmark greece switzerland and paraguay while thoroughly impressed with the wisdom of sound economy in the foreign service as in other branch of the government i can not escape the conclusion that in some instance the withholding of appropriation will prove an expensive economy and that the small retrenchment secure by a change of grade in certain diplomatic post be not an adequate consideration for the loss of influence and importance which will attend our foreign representative under this reduction i be of the opinion that a reexamination of the subject will cause a change in some instance in the conclusion reach on these subject at the last on the subject in former message i have call the attention of congress to the necessity of legislation with regard to fraudulent naturalization and to the subject of expatriation and the election of nationality the number of person of foreign birth seek a home in the united states the ease and facility with which the honest emigrant may after the lapse of a reasonable time become possessed of all the privilege of citizenship of the united states and the frequent occasion which induce such adopt citizen to return to the country of their birth render the subject of naturalization and the safeguard which experience have prove necessary for the protection of the honest naturalize citizen of paramount importance the very simplicity in the requirement of law on this question afford opportunity for fraud and the want of uniformity in the proceeding and record of the various court and in the form of the certificate of naturalization issue afford a constant source of difficulty i uniformity in the record and certificate and provide against the fraud which frequently take place and for the vacating of a record of naturalization obtain in fraud these provision be need in aid and to the senate of the united states
 i follow the example heretofore occasionally permit of communicate in this mode my approval of the act to provide for and regulate the counting of vote for president and vice president and the decision of question arise thereon for the term commence march 4 a. d. 1877 because of my appreciation of the imminent peril to the institution of the country from which in my judgment the act afford a wise and constitutional mean of escape
 for the first time in the history of our country under the constitution as it now be a dispute exist with regard to the result of the election of the chief magistrate of the nation
 it be understand that upon the disposition of dispute touch the electoral vote cast at the late election by one or more of the states depend the question whether one or the other of the candidate for the presidency be to be the lawful chief magistrate the importance of having clearly ascertain by a procedure regulate by law which of the two citizen have be elect and of have the right to this high office recognize and cheerfully agree in by all the people of the republic can not be overestimate and lead i to express to congress and to the nation my great satisfaction at the adoption of a measure that afford an orderly mean of decision of a gravely exciting question
 while the history of our country in its early period show that the president of the senate have count the vote and declare their standing our whole history show that in no instance of doubt or dispute have he exercise the power of decide and that the two houses of congress have dispose of all such doubt and dispute although in no instance hitherto have they be such that their decision could essentially have affect the result
 for the first time the government of the united states be now bring to meet the question as one vital to the result and this under condition not the well calculate to produce an agreement or to induce calm feeling in the several branch of the government or among the people of the country in a case where as now the result be involve it be the high duty of the lawmaking power to provide in advance a constitutional orderly and just method of execute the constitution in this most interesting and critical of its provision the do so far from be a compromise of right be an enforcement of right and an execution of power confer by the constitution on congress
 i think that this orderly method have be secure by the bill which appeal to the constitution and the law as the guide in ascertain right provide a mean of decide question of single return through the direct action of congress and in respect to double return by a tribunal of inquiry whose decision stand unless both houses of congress shall concur in determine otherwise thus secure a definite disposition of all question of dispute in whatever aspect they may arise with or without this law as all of the states have vote and as a tie vote be impossible it must be that one of the two candidate have be elect and it would be deplorable to witness an irregular controversy as to which of the two should receive or which should continue to hold the office in all period of history controversy have arise as to the succession or choice of the chief of state and no party or citizen love their country and its free institution can sacrifice too much of mere feeling in preserve through the upright course of law their country from the small danger to its peace on such an occasion and it can not be impress too firmly in the heart of all the people that true liberty and real progress can exist only through a cheerful adherence to constitutional law
 the bill purport to provide only for the settlement of question arise from the recent election the fact that such question can arise demonstrate the necessity which i can not doubt will before long be supply of permanent general legislation to meet case which have not be contemplate in the constitution or law of the country
 the bill may not be perfect and its provision may not be such as would be well applicable to all future occasion but it be calculate to meet the present condition of the question and of the country
 the country be agitate it need and it desire peace and quiet and harmony between all party and all section its industry be arrest labor unemployed capital idle and enterprise paralyze by reason of the doubt and anxiety attend the uncertainty of a double claim to the chief magistracy of the nation it want to be assure that the result of the election will be accept without resistance from the supporter of the disappointed candidate and that its high officer shall not hold his place with a question title of right believe that the bill will secure these end i give it my signature

fellow citizens

 we have assemble to repeat the public ceremonial begin by washington observe by all my predecessor and now a time honor custom which mark the commencement of a new term of the presidential office call to the duty of this great trust i proceed in compliance with usage to announce some of the lead principle on the subject that now chiefly engage the public attention by which it be my desire to be guide in the discharge of those duty i shall not undertake to lay down irrevocably principle or measure of administration but rather to speak of the motive which should animate we and to suggest certain important end to be attain in accordance with our institution and essential to the welfare of our country

 at the outset of the discussion which precede the recent presidential election it seem to i fitting that i should fully make known my sentiment in regard to several of the important question which then appear to demand the consideration of the country follow the example and in part adopt the language of one of my predecessor i wish now when every motive for misrepresentation have pass away to repeat what be say before the election trust that my countryman will candidly weigh and understand it and that they will feel assured that the sentiment declare in accept the nomination for the presidency will be the standard of my conduct in the path before i charge as i now be with the grave and difficult task of carry they out in the practical administration of the government so far as depend under the constitution and law on the chief executive of the nation

 the permanent pacification of the country upon such principle and by such measure as will secure the complete protection of all its citizen in the free enjoyment of all their constitutional right be now the one subject in our public affair which all thoughtful and patriotic citizen regard as of supreme importance
