 many of the calamitous effort of the tremendous revolution which have pass over the southern states still remain the immeasurable benefit which will surely follow soon or later the hearty and generous acceptance of the legitimate result of that revolution have not yet be realize difficult and embarrassing question meet we at the threshold of this subject the people of those states be still impoverished and the inestimable blessing of wise honest and peaceful local self government be not fully enjoy whatever difference of opinion may exist as to the cause of this condition of thing the fact be clear that in the progress of event the time have come when such government be the imperative necessity require by all the varied interest public and private of those states but it must not be forget that only a local government which recognize and maintain inviolate the right of all be a true self government

 with respect to the two distinct race whose peculiar relation to each other have bring upon we the deplorable complication and perplexity which exist in those states it must be a government which guard the interest of both race carefully and equally it must be a government which submit loyally and heartily to the constitution and the law the law of the nation and the law of the states themselves accept and obey faithfully the whole constitution as it be

 rest upon this sure and substantial foundation the superstructure of beneficent local government can be build up and not otherwise in furtherance of such obedience to the letter and the spirit of the constitution and in behalf of all that its attainment imply all so call party interest lose their apparent importance and party line may well be permit to fade into insignificance the question we have to consider for the immediate welfare of those states of the union be the question of government or no government of social order and all the peaceful industry and the happiness that belong to it or a return to barbarism it be a question in which every citizen of the nation be deeply interested and with respect to which we ought not to be in a partisan sense either republicans or democrats but fellow citizen and fellowman to whom the interest of a common country and a common humanity be dear

 the sweeping revolution of the entire labor system of a large portion of our country and the advance of 4,000,000 people from a condition of servitude to that of citizenship upon an equal footing with their former master could not occur without present problem of the grave moment to be deal with by the emancipate race by their former master and by the general government the author of the act of emancipation that it be a wise just and providential act fraught with good for all concern be not generally concede throughout the country that a moral obligation rest upon the national government to employ its constitutional power and influence to establish the right of the people it have emancipate and to protect they in the enjoyment of those right when they be infringe or assail be also generally admit

 the evil which afflict the southern states can only be remove or remedie by the united and harmonious effort of both race actuate by motive of mutual sympathy and regard and while in duty bind and fully determined to protect the right of all by every constitutional mean at the disposal of my administration i be sincerely anxious to use every legitimate influence in favor of honest and efficient local self government as the true resource of those states for the promotion of the contentment and prosperity of their citizen in the effort i shall make to accomplish this purpose i ask the cordial cooperation of all who cherish an interest in the welfare of the country trust that party tie and the prejudice of race will be freely surrender in behalf of the great purpose to be accomplish in the important work of restore the south it be not the political situation alone that merit attention the material development of that section of the country have be arrest by the social and political revolution through which it have pass and now need and deserve the considerate care of the national government within the just limit prescribe by the constitution and wise public economy

 but at the basis of all prosperity for that as well as for every other part of the country lie the improvement of the intellectual and moral condition of the people universal suffrage should rest upon universal education to this end liberal and permanent provision should be make for the support of free school by the state government and if need be supplement by legitimate aid from national authority

 let i assure my countryman of the southern states that it be my earnest desire to regard and promote their true interest the interest of the white and of the colored people both and equally and to put forth my good effort in behalf of a civil policy which will forever wipe out in our political affair the color line and the distinction between north andsouth to the end that we may have not merely a united north or a unitedsouth but a united country

 i ask the attention of the public to the paramount necessity of reform in our civil service a reform not merely as to certain abuse and practice of so call official patronage which have come to have the sanction of usage in the several departments of our government but a change in the system of appointment itself a reform that shall be thorough radical and complete a return to the principle and practice of the founder of the government they neither expect nor desire from public officer any partisan service they mean that public officer should owe their whole service to the government and to the people they mean that the officer should be secure in his tenure as long as his personal character remain untarnished and the performance of his duty satisfactory they hold that appointment to office be not to be make nor expect merely as reward for partisan service nor merely on the nomination of member of congress as be entitle in any respect to the control of such appointment

 the fact that both the great political party of the country in declare their principle prior to the election give a prominent place to the subject of reform of our civil service recognize and strongly urge its necessity in term almost identical in their specific import with those i have here employ must be accept as a conclusive argument in behalf of these measure it must be regard as the expression of the united voice and will of the whole country upon this subject and both political party be virtually pledge to give it their unreserved support

 the president of the united states of necessity owe his election to office to the suffrage and zealous labor of a political party the member of which cherish with ardor and regard as of essential importance the principle of their party organization but he should strive to be always mindful of the fact that he serve his party well who serve the country well

 in furtherance of the reform we seek and in other important respect a change of great importance i recommend an amendment to the constitution prescribe a term of six year for the presidential office and forbid a reelection

 with respect to the financial condition of the country i shall not attempt an extended history of the embarrassment and prostration which we have suffer during the past three year the depression in all our varied commercial and manufacturing interest throughout the country which begin in september 1873 still continue it be very gratifying however to be able to say that there be indication all around we of a come change to prosperous time

 upon the currency question intimately connect as it be with this topic i may be permit to repeat here the statement make in my letter of acceptance that in my judgment the feeling of uncertainty inseparable from an irredeemable paper currency with its fluctuation of value be one of the great obstacle to a return to prosperous time the only safe paper currency be one which rest upon a coin basis and be at all time and promptly convertible into coin

 i adhere to the view heretofore express by i in favor of congressional legislation in behalf of an early resumption of specie payment and i be satisfied not only that this be wise but that the interest as well as the public sentiment of the country imperatively demand it

 pass from these remark upon the condition of our own country to consider our relation with other land we be remind by the international complication abroad threaten the peace of europe that our traditional rule of noninterference in the affair of foreign nation have prove of great value in past time and ought to be strictly observe

 the policy inaugurate by my honored predecessor president grant of submit to arbitration grave question in dispute between ourselves and foreign power point to a new and incomparably the good instrumentality for the preservation of peace and will as i believe become a beneficent example of the course to be pursue in similar emergency by other nation

 if unhappily question of difference should at any time during the period of my administration arise between the united states and any foreign government it will certainly be my disposition and my hope to aid in their settlement in the same peaceful and honorable way thus secure to our country the great blessing of peace and mutual good office with all the nation of the world

 fellow citizen we have reach the close of a political contest mark by the excitement which usually attend the contest between great political party whose member espouse and advocate with earnest faith their respective creed the circumstance be perhaps in no respect extraordinary save in the closeness and the consequent uncertainty of the result

 for the first time in the history of the country it have be deem well in view of the peculiar circumstance of the case that the objection and question in dispute with reference to the counting of the electoral vote should be refer to the decision of a tribunal appoint for this purpose

 that tribunal establish by law for this sole purpose its member all of they man of long establish reputation for integrity and intelligence and with the exception of those who be also member of the supreme judiciary choose equally from both political party its deliberation enlighten by the research and the argument of able counsel be entitle to the full confidence of the american people its decision have be patiently wait for and accept as legally conclusive by the general judgment of the public for the present opinion will widely vary as to the wisdom of the several conclusion announce by that tribunal this be to be anticipate in every instance where matter of dispute be make the subject of arbitration under the form of law human judgment be never unerre and be rarely regard as otherwise than wrong by the unsuccessful party in the contest

 the fact that two great political party have in this way settle a dispute in regard to which good man differ as to the fact and the law no less than as to the proper course to be pursue in solve the question in controversy be an occasion for general rejoicing

 upon one point there be entire unanimity in public sentiment that conflict claim to the presidency must be amicably and peaceably adjust and that when so adjust the general acquiescence of the nation ought surely to follow

 it have be reserve for a government of the people where the right of suffrage be universal to give to the world the first example in history of a great nation in the midst of the struggle of oppose party fo rpower hush its party tumult to yield the issue of the contest to adjustment accord to the form of law

 look for the guidance of that divine hand by which the destiny of nation and individual be shape i call upon you senators representatives judge fellow citizen here and everywhere to unite with i in an earnest effort to secure to our country the blessing not only of material prosperity but of justice peace and union a union depend not upon the constraint of force but upon the love devotion of a free people and that all thing may be so ordered and settle upon the good and sure foundation that peace and happiness truth and justice religion and piety may be establish among we for all generation

sir i desire to call your attention to the follow paragraph in a letter address by i to the secretary of the treasury on the conduct to be observe by officer of the general government in relation to the election
 no officer should be require or permit to take part in the management of political organization caucus convention or election campaign their right to vote and to express their view on public question either orally or through the press be not deny provide it do not interfere with the discharge of their official duty no assessment for political purpose on officer or subordinate should be allow
 this rule be applicable to every department of the civil service it should be understand by every officer of the general government that he be expect to conform his conduct to its requirement
 very respectfully
 r.b. hayes


 by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas it be provide in the constitution of the united states that the united states shall protect every state in this union on application of the legislature or of the executive when the legislature can not be convene against domestic violence and
 whereas the governor of the state of west virginia have represent that domestic violence exist in say state at martinsburg and at various other point along the line of the baltimore and ohio railroad in say state which the authority of say state be unable to suppress and
 whereas the law of the united states require that in all case of insurrection in any state or of obstruction to the law thereof whenever it may be necessary in the judgment of the president he shall forthwith by proclamation command such insurgent to disperse and retire peaceably to their respective abode within a limited time
 now therefore i rutherford b. hayes president of the united states do hereby admonish all good citizen of the united states and all person within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states against aid countenancing abetting or take part in such unlawful proceeding and i do hereby warn all person engage in or connect with say domestic violence and obstruction of the law to disperse and retire peaceably to their respective abode on or before 12 o'clock noon of the 19th day of july instant
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 18th day of july a. d. 1877 and of the independence of the united states of america the one hundred and second
 r. b. hayes
 by the president
 f. w. seward acting secretary of state


with devout gratitude to the bountiful giver of all good i congratulate you that at the beginning of your first regular session you find our country bless with health and peace and abundant harvest and with encouraging prospect of an early return of general prosperity

 to complete and make permanent the pacification of the country continue to be and until it be fully accomplished must remain the most important of all our national interest the earnest purpose of good citizen generally to unite their effort in this endeavor be evident it find decide expression in the resolution announce in 1876 by the national convention of the lead political party of the country there be a widespread apprehension that the momentous result in our progress as a nation mark by the recent amendment to the constitution be in imminent jeopardy that the good understanding which prompt their adoption in the interest of a loyal devotion to the general welfare might prove a barren truce and that the two section of the country once engage in civil strife might be again almost as widely sever and disunite as they be when array in arm against each other

 the course to be pursue which in my judgment seem wisest in the presence of this emergency be plainly indicate in my inaugural address it point to the time which all our people desire to see when a genuine love of our whole country and of all that concern its true welfare shall supplant the destructive force of the mutual animosity of race and of sectional hostility opinion have differ widely as to the measure well calculate to secure this great end this be to be expect the measure adopt by the administration have be subject to severe and varied criticism any course whatever which might have be enter upon would certainly have encounter distrust and opposition these measure be in my judgment such as be most in harmony with the constitution and with the genius of our people and well adapt under all the circumstance to attain the end in view beneficent result already apparent prove that these endeavor be not to be regard as a mere experiment and should sustain and encourage we in our effort already in the brief period which have elapse the immediate effectiveness no less than the justice of the course pursue be demonstrate and i have an abide faith that time will furnish its ample vindication in the mind of the great majority of my fellow citizen the discontinuance of the use of the army for the purpose of uphold local government in two states of the union be no less a constitutional duty and requirement under the circumstance exist at the time than it be a much need measure for the restoration of local self government and the promotion of national harmony the withdrawal of the troop from such employment be effect deliberately and with solicitous care for the peace and good order of society and the protection of the property and person and every right of all class of citizen

 the result that have follow be indeed significant and encouraging all apprehension of danger from remit those state to local self government be dispel and a most salutary change in the mind of the people have begin and be in progress in every part of that section of the country once the theater of unhappy civil strife substitute for suspicion distrust and aversion concord friendship and patriotic attachment to the union no unprejudiced mind will deny that the terrible and often fatal collision which for several year have be of frequent occurrence and have agitate and alarm the public mind have almost entirely cease and that a spirit of mutual forbearance and hearty national interest have succeed there have be a general reestablishment of order and of the orderly administration of justice instance of remain lawlessness have become of rare occurrence political turmoil and turbulence have disappear useful industry have be resume public credit in the southern states have be greatly strengthen and the encourage benefit of a revival of commerce between the section of the country lately embroil in civil war be fully enjoy such be some of the result already attain upon which the country be to be congratulate they be of such importance that we may with confidence patiently await the desire consummation that will surely come with the natural progress of event

 it may not be improper here to say that it should be our fixed and unalterable determination to protect by all available and proper mean under the constitution and the law the lately emancipate race in the enjoyment of their right and privilege and i urge upon those to whom heretofore the colored people have sustain the relation of bondman the wisdom and justice of humane and liberal local legislation with respect to their education and general welfare a firm adherence to the law both national and state as to the civil and political right of the colored people now advance to full and equal citizenship the immediate repression and sure punishment by the national and local authority within their respective jurisdiction of every instance of lawlessness and violence toward they be require for the security alike of both race and be justly demand by the public opinion of the country and the age in this way the restoration of harmony and good will and the complete protection of every citizen in the full enjoyment of every constitutional right will surely be attain whatever authority rest with i to this end i shall not hesitate to put forth

 whatever belong to the power of congress and the jurisdiction of the court of the union they may confidently be rely upon to provide and perform and to the legislature the court and the executive authority of the several states i earnestly appeal to secure by adequate appropriate and seasonable mean within their border these common and uniform right of a united people which love liberty abhor oppression and revere justice these object be very dear to my heart i shall continue most earnestly to strive for their attainment the cordial cooperation of all class of all section of the country and of both race be require for this purpose and with these blessing assure and not otherwise we may safely hope to hand down our free institution of government unimpaire to the generation that will succeed we

 among the other subject of great and general importance to the people of this country i can not be mistake i think in regard as preeminent the policy and measure which be design to secure the restoration of the currency to that normal and healthful condition in which by the resumption of specie payment our internal trade and foreign commerce may be bring into harmony with the system of exchange which be base upon the precious metal as the intrinsic money of the world in the public judgment that this end should be seek and compass as speedily and securely as the resource of the people and the wisdom of their government can accomplish there be a much great degree of unanimity than be find to concur in the specific measure which will bring the country to this desire end or the rapidity of the step by which it can be safely reach

 upon a most anxious and deliberate examination which i have feel it my duty to give to the subject i be but the more confirm in the opinion which i express in accept the nomination for the presidency and again upon my inauguration that the policy of resumption should be pursue by every suitable mean and that no legislation would be wise that should disparage the importance or retard the attainment of that result i have no disposition and certainly no right to question the sincerity or the intelligence of oppose opinion and would neither conceal nor undervalue the considerable difficulty and even occasional distress which may attend the progress of the nation toward this primary condition to its general and permanent prosperity i must however adhere to my most earnest conviction that any wavering in purpose or unsteadiness in method so far from avoid or reduce the inconvenience inseparable from the transition from an irredeemable to a redeemable paper currency would only tend to increase and prolong disturbance in value and unless retrieve must end in serious disorder dishonor and disaster in the financial affair of the government and of the people

 the mischief which i apprehend and urgently deprecate be confine to no class of the people indeed but seem to i most certainly to threaten the industrious masse whether their occupation be of skilled or common labor to they it seem to i it be of prime importance that their labor should be compensate in money which be itself fix in exchangeable value by be irrevocably measure by the labor necessary to its production this permanent quality of the money of the people be seek for and can only be gain by the resumption of specie payment the rich the speculative the operating the money deal class may not always feel the mischief of or may find casual profit in a variable currency but the misfortune of such a currency to those who be pay salary or wage be inevitable and remediless

 closely connect with this general subject of the resumption of specie payment be one of subordinate but still of grave importance i mean the readjustment of our coinage system by the renewal of the silver dollar as an element in our specie currency endow by legislation with the quality of legal tender to a great or less extent

 as there be no doubt of the power of congress under the constitution to coin money and regulate the value thereof and as this power cover the whole range of authority applicable to the metal the rate value and the legal tender quality which shall be adopt for the coinage the consideration which should induce or discourage a particular measure connect with the coinage belong clearly to the province of legislative discretion and of public expediency without intrude upon this province of legislation in the least i have yet think the subject of such critical importance in the actual condition of our affair as to present an occasion for the exercise of the duty impose by the constitution on the president of recommend to the consideration of congress such measure as he shall judge necessary and expedient

 hold the opinion as i do that neither the interest of the government nor of the people of the united states would be promote by disparage silver as one of the two precious metal which furnish the coinage of the world and that legislation which look to maintain the volume of intrinsic money to as full a measure of both metal as their relative commercial value will permit would be neither unjust nor inexpedient i must ask your indulgence to a brief and definite statement of certain essential feature in any such legislative measure which i feel it my duty to recommend

 i do not propose to enter the debate represent on both side by such able disputant in congress and before the people and in the press as to the extent to which the legislation of any one nation can control this question even within its own border against the unwritten law of trade or the positive law of other government the wisdom of congress in shape any particular law that may be present for my approval may wholly supersede the necessity of my enter into these consideration and i willingly avoid either vague or intricate inquiry it be only certain plain and practical trait of such legislation that i desire to recommend to your attention

 in any legislation provide for a silver coinage regulate its value and impart to it the quality of legal tender it seem to i of great importance that congress should not lose sight of its action as operate in a twofold capacity and in two distinct direction if the united states government be free from a public debt its legislative deal with the question of silver coinage would be purely sovereign and governmental under no restraint but those of constitutional power and the public good as affect by the propose legislation but in the actual circumstance of the nation with a vast public debt distribute very widely among our own citizen and hold in great amount also abroad the nature of the silver coinage measure as affect this relation of the government to the holder of the public debt become an element in any propose legislation of the high concern the obligation of the public faith transcend all question of profit or public advantage otherwise its unquestionable maintenance be the dictate as well of the high expediency as of the most necessary duty and will ever be carefully guard by congress and people alike

 the public debt of the united states to the amount of $ 729,000,000 bear interest at the rate of 6 per cent and $ 708,000,000 at the rate of 5 percent and the only way in which the country can be relieve from the payment of these high rate of interest be by advantageously refund the indebtedness whether the debt be ultimately pay in gold or in silver coin be of but little moment compare with the possible reduction of interest one third by refund it at such reduce rate if the united states have the unquestione right to pay its bond in silver coin the little benefit from that process would be greatly overbalance by the injurious effect of such payment if make or propose against the honest conviction of the public creditor

 all the bond that have be issue since february 12 1873 when gold become the only unlimited legal tender metallic currency of the country be justly payable in gold coin or in coin of equal value during the time of these issue the only dollar that could be or be receive by the government in exchange for bond be the gold dollar to require the public creditor to take in repayment any dollar of less commercial value would be regard by they as a repudiation of the full obligation assume the bond issue prior to 1873 be issue at a time when the gold dollar be the only coin in circulation or contemplate by either the government or the holder of the bond as the coin in which they be to be pay it be far well to pay these bond in that coin than to seem to take advantage of the unforeseen fall in silver bullion to pay in a new issue of silver coin thus make so much less valuable the power of the united states to coin money and to regulate the value thereof ought never to be exercise for the purpose of enable the government to pay its obligation in a coin of less value than that contemplate by the party when the bond be issue any attempt to pay the national indebtedness in a coinage of less commercial value than the money of the world would involve a violation of the public faith and work irreparable injury to the public credit

 it be the great merit of the act of march 1869 in strengthen the public credit that it remove all doubt as to the purpose of the united states to pay their bond debt in coin that act be accept as a pledge of public faith the government have derive great benefit from it in the progress thus far make in refund the public debt at low rate of interest an adherence to the wise and just policy of an exact observance of the public faith will enable the government rapidly to reduce the burden of interest on the national debt to an amount exceed $ 20,000,000 per annum and effect an aggregate saving to the united states of more than $ 300,000,000 before the bond can be fully pay

 in adapt the new silver coinage to the ordinary use of currency in the everyday transaction of life and prescribe the quality of legal tender to be assign to it a consideration of the first importance should be so to adjust the ratio between the silver and the gold coinage which now constitute our specie currency as to accomplish the desire end of maintain the circulation of the two metallic currency and keep up the volume of the two precious metal as our intrinsic money it be a mixed question for scientific reasoning and historical experience to determine how far and by what method a practical equilibrium can be maintain which will keep both metal in circulation in their appropriate sphere of common use

 an absolute equality of commercial value free from disturb fluctuation be hardly attainable and without it an unlimited legal tender for private transaction assign to both metal would irresistibly tend to drive out of circulation the clear coinage and disappoint the principal object propose by the legislation in view i apprehend therefore that the two condition of a near approach to equality of commercial value between the gold and silver coinage of the same denomination and of a limitation of the amount for which the silver coinage be to be a legal tender be essential to maintain both in circulation if these condition can be successfully observe the issue from the mint of silver dollar would afford material assistance to the community in the transition to redeemable paper money and would facilitate the resumption of specie payment and its permanent establishment without these condition i fear that only mischief and misfortune would flow from a coinage of silver dollar with the quality of unlimited legal tender even in private transaction

 any expectation of temporary ease from an issue of silver coinage to pass as a legal tender at a rate materially above its commercial value be i be persuade a delusion nor can i think that there be any substantial distinction between an original issue of silver dollar at a nominal value materially above their commercial value and the restoration of the silver dollar at a rate which once be but have cease to be its commercial value certainly the issue of our gold coinage reduce in weight materially below its legal tender value would not be any the less a present debasement of the coinage by reason of its equaling or even exceed in weight a gold coinage which at some past time have be commercially equal to the legal tender value assign to the new issue

 in recommend that the regulation of any silver coinage which may be authorize by congress should observe these condition of commercial value and limited legal tender i be govern by the feeling that every possible increase should be give to the volume of metallic money which can be keep in circulation and thereby every possible aid afford to the people in the process of resume specie payment it be because of my firm conviction that a disregard of these condition would frustrate the good result which be desire from the propose coinage and embarrass with new element of confusion and uncertainty the business of the country that i urge upon your attention these consideration

 i respectfully recommend to congress that in any legislation provide for a silver coinage and imparting to it the quality of legal tender there be impress upon the measure a firm provision exempt the public debt heretofore issue and now outstanding from payment either of principal or interest in any coinage of less commercial value than the present gold coinage of the country

 the organization of the civil service of the country have for a number of year attract more and more of the public attention so general have become the opinion that the method of admission to it and the condition of remain in it be unsound that both the great political party have agree in the most explicit declaration of the necessity of reform and in the most emphatic demand for it i have fully believe these declaration and demand to be the expression of a sincere conviction of the intelligent masse of the people upon the subject and that they should be recognize and follow by earnest and prompt action on the part of the legislative and executive department of the government in pursuance of the purpose indicate

 before my accession to office i endeavor to have my own view distinctly understand and upon my inauguration my accord with the public opinion be state in term believe to be plain and unambiguous my experience in the executive duty have strongly confirm the belief in the great advantage the country would find in observe strictly the plan of the constitution which impose upon the executive the sole duty and responsibility of the selection of those federal officer who by law be appoint not elect and which in like manner assign to the senate the complete right to advise and consent to or to reject the nomination so make whilst the house of representatives stand as the public censor of the performance of official duty with the prerogative of investigation and prosecution in all case of dereliction the blemish and imperfection in the civil service may as i think be trace in most case to a practical confusion of the duty assign to the several departments of the government my purpose in this respect have be to return to the system establish by the fundamental law and to do this with the heartiest cooperation and most cordial understanding with the senate and house of representatives

 the practical difficulty in the selection of numerous officer for post of widely vary responsibility and duty be acknowledge to be very great no system can be expect to secure absolute freedom from mistake and the beginning of any attempt change of custom be quite likely to be more embarrassed in this respect than any subsequent period it be here that the constitution seem to i to prove its claim to the great wisdom accord to it it give to the executive the assistance of the knowledge and experience of the senate which when act upon nomination as to which they may be disintereste and impartial judge secure as strong a guaranty of freedom from error of importance as be perhaps possible in human affair

 in addition to this i recognize the public advantage of make all nomination as nearly as possible impersonal in the sense of be free from mere caprice or favor in the selection and in those office in which special training be of greatly increase value i believe such a rule as to the tenure of office should obtain as may induce man of proper qualification to apply themselves industriously to the task of become proficient bear these thing in mind i have endeavor to reduce the number of change in subordinate place usually make upon the change of the general administration and shall most heartily cooperate with congress in the well systematizing of such method and rule of admission to the public service and of promotion within it as may promise to be most successful in make thorough competency efficiency and character the decisive test in these matter

 i ask the renew attention of congress to what have already be do by the civil service commission appoint in pursuance of an act of congress by my predecessor to prepare and revise civil service rule in regard to much of the departmental service especially at washington it may be difficult to organize a well system than that which have thus be provide and it be now be use to a considerable extent under my direction the commission have still a legal existence although for several year no appropriation have be make for defray its expense believe that this commission have render valuable service and will be a most useful agency in improve the administration of the civil service i respectfully recommend that a suitable appropriation to be immediately available be make to enable it to continue its labor

 it be my purpose to transmit to congress as early as practicable a report by the chairman of the commission and to ask your attention to such measure on this subject as in my opinion will far promote the improvement of the civil service

 during the past year the united states have continue to maintain peaceful relation with foreign power

 the outbreak of war between russia and turkey though at one time attend by grave apprehension as to its effect upon other european nation have have no tendency to disturb the amicable relation exist between the united states and each of the two contend power an attitude of just and impartial neutrality have be preserve and i be gratified to state that in the midst of their hostility both the russian and the turkish government have show an earnest disposition to adhere to the obligation of all treaty with the united states and to give due regard to the right of american citizen

 by the term of the treaty define the right immunity and privilege of consul between italy and the united states ratify in 1868 either government may after the lapse of ten year terminate the existence of the treaty by give twelve months&#39 notice of its intention the government of italy avail itself of this faculty have now give the require notice and the treaty will accordingly end on the 17th of september 1878 it be understand however that the italian government wish to renew it in its general scope desire only certain modification in some of its article in this disposition i concur and shall hope that no serious obstacle may intervene to prevent or delay the negotiation of a satisfactory treaty

 numerous question in regard to passport naturalization and exemption from military service have continue to arise in case of emigrant from germany who have return to their native country the provision of the treaty of february 22 1868 however have prove to be so ample and so judicious that the legation of the united states at berlin have be able to adjust all claim arise under it not only without detriment to the amicable relation exist between the two government but it be believe without injury or injustice to any duly naturalize american citizen it be desirable that the treaty originally make with the north german union in 1868 should now be extend so as to apply equally to all the states of the empire of germany

 the invitation of the government of france to participate in the exposition of the products of agriculture industry and the fine arts to be hold at paris during the come year be submit for your consideration at the extra session it be not doubted that its acceptance by the united states and a well select exhibition of the product of american industry on that occasion will tend to stimulate international commerce and emigration as well as to promote the traditional friendship between the two country

 a question arise some time since as to the proper meaning of the extradition article of the treaty of 1842 between the united states and great britain both government however be now in accord in the belief that the question be not one that should be allow to frustrate the end of justice or to disturb the friendship between the two nation no serious difficulty have arise in accomplish the extradition of criminal when necessary it be probable that all point of disagreement will in due time be settle and if need be more explicit declaration be make in a new treaty

 the fishery commission under articles xviii to xxv of the treaty of washington have conclude its session at halifax the result of the deliberation of the commission as make public by the commissioner will be communicate to congress

 a treaty for the protection of trade mark have be negotiate with great britain which have be submit to the senate for its consideration

 the revolution which recently occur in mexico be follow by the accession of the successful party to power and the installation of its chief general porfirio diaz in the presidential office it have be the custom of the united states when such change of government have heretofore occur in mexico to recognize and enter into official relation with the de facto government as soon as it should appear to have the approval of the mexican people and should manifest a disposition to adhere to the obligation of treaty and international friendship in the present case such official recognition have be defer by the occurrence on the rio grande border the record of which have be already communicate to each house of congress in answer to their respective resolution of inquiry assurance have be receive that the authority at the seat of the mexican government have both the disposition and the power to prevent and punish such unlawful invasion and depredation it be earnestly to be hope that event may prove these assurance to be well rounded the good interest of both country require the maintenance of peace upon the border and the development of commerce between the two republics

 it be gratify to add that this temporary interruption of official relation have not prevent due attention by the representative of the united states in mexico to the protection of american citizen so far as practicable nor have it interfere with the prompt payment of the amount due from mexico to the united states under the treaty of july 4 1868 and the award of the joint commission while i do not anticipate an interruption of friendly relation with mexico yet i can not but look with some solicitude upon a continuance of border disorder as expose the two country to initiation of popular feeling and mischance of action which be naturally unfavorable to complete amity firmly determined that nothing shall be want on my part to promote a good understanding between the two nation i yet must ask the attention of congress to the actual occurrence on the border that the life and property of our citizen may be adequately protect and peace preserve

 another year have pass without bring to a close the protract contest between the spanish government and the insurrection in the island of cuba while the united states have sedulously abstain from any intervention in this contest it be impossible not to feel that it be attend with incident affect the right and interest of american citizen apart from the effect of the hostility upon trade between the united states and cuba their progress be inevitably accompany by complaint have more or less foundation of search arrest embargo and oppressive taxis upon the property of american resident and of unprovoked interference with american vessel and commerce it be due to the government of spain to say that during the past year it have promptly disavow and offer reparation for any unauthorized act of unduly zealous subordinate whenever such act have be bring to its attention nevertheless such occurrence can not but tend to excite feeling of annoyance suspicion and resentment which be greatly to be deprecate between the respective subject and citizen of two friendly power

 much delay consequent upon accusation of fraud in some of the award have occur in respect to the distribution of the limited amount receive from venezuela under the treaty of april 25 1866 applicable to the award of the joint commission create by that treaty so long as these matter be pende in congress the executive can not assume either to pass upon the question present or to distribute the fund receive it be eminently desirable that definite legislative action should be take either affirm the award to be final or provide some method for reexamination of the claim our relation with the republics of central and south america and with the empire of brazil have continue without serious change far than the temporary interruption of diplomatic intercourse with venezuela and with guatemala amicable relation have already be fully restore with venezuela and it be not doubted that all ground of misunderstanding with guatemala will speedily be remove from all these country there be favorable indication of a disposition on the part of their government and people to reciprocate our effort in the direction of increase commercial intercourse

 the government of the samoan islands have send an envoy in the person of its secretary of state to invite the government of the united states to recognize and protect their independence to establish commercial relation with their people and to assist they in their step toward regulated and responsible government the inhabitant of these island having make considerable progress in christian civilization and the development of trade be doubtful of their ability to maintain peace and independence without the aid of some strong power the subject be deem worthy of respectful attention and the claim upon our assistance by this distant community will be carefully consider

 the long commercial depression in the united states have direct attention to the subject of the possible increase of our foreign trade and the method for its development not only with europe but with other country and especially with the states and sovereignty of the western hemisphere instruction from the department of state be issue to the various diplomatic and consular officer of the government ask they to devote attention to the question of method by which trade between the respective country of their official residence and the united states could be most judiciously foster in obedience to these instruction examination and report upon this subject have be make by many of these officer and transmit to the department and the same be submit to the consideration of congress

 the annual report of the secretary of the treasury on the state of the finance present important question for the action of congress upon some of which i have already remark

 the revenue of the government during the fiscal year end june 30 1877 be $ 269,000,586.62 the total expenditure for the same period be $ 238,660,008.93 leave a surplus revenue of $ 30,340,577.69 this have substantially supply the requirement of the sink fund for that year the estimate revenue of the current fiscal year be $ 265,500,000 and the estimate expenditure for the same period be $ 232,430,643.72 if these estimate prove to be correct there will be a surplus revenue of $ 33,069,356.28 -an amount nearly sufficient for the sink fund for that year the estimate revenue for the next fiscal year be $ 269,250,000 it appear from the report that during the last fiscal year the revenue of the government compare with the previous year have largely decrease this decrease amount to the sum of $ 18,481,452.54 be mainly in custom duty cause partly by a large fall off of the amount of import dutiable good and partly by the general fall of price in the market of production of such article as pay ad valorem taxis

 while this be feel injuriously in the diminution of the revenue it have be accompany with a very large increase of exportation the total export during the last fiscal year include coin have be $ 658,637,457 and the import have be $ 492,097,540 leave a balance of trade in favor of the united states amount to the sum of $ 166,539,917 the beneficial effect of which extend to all branch of business

 the estimate revenue for the next fiscal year will impose upon congress the duty of strictly limit appropriation include the requisite sum for the maintenance of the sink fund within the aggregate estimate receipt

 while the aggregate of taxis should not be increase amendment might be make to the revenue law that would without diminish the revenue relieve the people from unnecessary burden a tax on tea and coffee be show by the experience not only of our own country but of other country to be easily collect without loss by undervaluation or fraud and largely bear in the country of production a tax of 10 cent a pound on tea and 2 cent a pound on coffee would produce a revenue exceed $ 12,000,000 and thus enable congress to repeal a multitude of annoying taxis yield a revenue not exceed that sum the internal revenue system grow out of the necessity of the war and most of the legislation impose taxis upon domestic product under this system have be repeal by the substitution of a tax on tea and coffee all form of internal taxation may be repeal except that on whisky spirit tobacco and beer attention be also call to the necessity of enact more vigorous law for the protection of the revenue and for the punishment of fraud and smuggling this can well be do by judicious provision that will induce the disclosure of attempt fraud by undervaluation and smuggling all revenue law should be simple in their provision and easily understand so far as practicable the rate of taxation should be in the form of specific duty and not ad valorem require the judgment of experienced man to ascertain value and expose the revenue to the temptation of fraud

 my attention have be call during the recess of congress to abuse exist in the collection of the custom and strenuous effort have be make for their correction by executive order the recommendation submit to the secretary of the treasury by a commission appoint to examine into the collection of custom duty at the port of new york contain many suggestion for the modification of the custom law to which the attention of congress be invite

 it be matter of congratulation that notwithstanding the severe burden cause by the war the public faith with all creditor have be preserve and that as the result of this policy the public credit have continuously advance and our public security be regard with the high favor in the market of the world i trust that no act of the government will cast a shadow upon its credit

 the progress of refund the public debt have be rapid and satisfactory under the contract exist when i enter upon the discharge of the duty of my office bond bear interest at the rate of 4 1/2 percent be be rapidly sell and within three month the aggregate sale of these bond have reach the sum of $ 200,000,000 with my sanction the secretary of the treasury enter into a new contract for the sale of 4 per cent bond and within thirty day after the popular subscription for such bond be open subscription be have amount to $ 75,496,550 which be pay for within ninety day after the date of subscription by this process within but little more than one year the annual interest on the public debt be reduce in the sum of $ 3,775,000

 i recommend that suitable provision be make to enable the people to easily convert their saving into government security as the good mode in which small saving may be well secured and yield a moderate interest it be an object of public policy to retain among our own people the security of the united states in this way our country be guard against their sudden return from foreign country cause by war or other disturbance beyond our limit

 the commerce of the united states with foreign nation and especially the export of domestic production have of late year largely increase but the great portion of this trade be conduct in foreign vessel the importance of enlarge our foreign trade and especially by direct and speedy interchange with country on this continent can not be overestimate and it be a matter of great moment that our own shipping interest should receive to the utmost practical extent the benefit of our commerce with other land these consideration be forcibly urge by all the large commercial city of the country and public attention be generally and wisely attract to the solution of the problem they present it be not doubt that congress will take they up in the broad spirit of liberality and respond to the public demand by practical legislation upon this important subject

 the report of the secretary of war show that the army have be actively employ during the year and have render very important service in suppress hostility in the indian country and in preserve peace and protect life and property in the interior as well as along the mexican border a long and arduous campaign have be prosecute with final complete success against a portion of the nez perce&#39 tribe of indians a full account of this campaign will be find in the report of the general of the army it will be see that in its course several severe battle be fight in which a number of gallant officer and man lose their life i join with the secretary of war and the general of the army in award to the officer and man employ in the long and toilsome pursuit and in the final capture of these indians the honor and praise which be so justly their due

 the very serious riot which occur in several of the states in july last render necessary the employment of a considerable portion of the army to preserve the peace and maintain order in the states of west virginia maryland pennsylvania and illinois these disturbance be so formidable as to defy the local and state authority and the national executive be call upon in the mode provide by the constitution and law to furnish military aid i be gratified to be able to state that the troop send in response to these call for aid in the suppression of domestic violence be able by the influence of their presence in the disturbed region to preserve the peace and restore order without the use of force in the discharge of this delicate and important duty both officer and man act with great prudence and courage and for their service deserve the thank of the country

 disturbance along the rio grande in texas to which i have already refer have render necessary the constant employment of a military force in that vicinity a full report of all recent military operation in that quarter have be transmit to the house of representatives in answer to a resolution of that body and it will therefore not be necessary to enter into detail i regret to say that these lawless incursion into our territory by armed band from the mexican side of the line for the purpose of robbery have be of frequent occurrence and in spite of the most vigilant effort of the commander of our force the marauder have generally succeed in escape into mexico with their plunder in may last i give order for the exercise of the utmost vigilance on the part of our troop for the suppression of these raid and the punishment of the guilty party as well as the recapture of property steal by they general ord command in texas be direct to invite the cooperation of the mexican authority in effort to this end and to assure they that i be anxious to avoid give the least offense to mexico at the same time he be direct to give notice of my determination to put an end to the invasion of our territory by lawless band intent upon the plunder of our peaceful citizen even if the effectual punishment of the outlaws should make the crossing of the border by our troop in their pursuit necessary it be believe that this policy have have the effect to check somewhat these depredation and that with a considerable increase of our force upon that frontier and the establishment of several additional military post along the rio grande so as more effectually to guard that extensive border peace may be preserve and the life and property of our citizen in texas fully protect

 prior to the 1st day of july last the army be in accordance with law reduce to the maximum of 25,000 enlist man be a reduction of 2,500 below the force previously authorize this reduction be make as require by law entirely from the infantry and artillery branch of the service without any reduction of the cavalry under the law as it now stand it be necessary that the cavalry regiment be recruit to 100 man in each company for service on the mexican and indian frontier the necessary effect of this legislation be to reduce the infantry and artillery arm of the service below the number require for efficiency and i concur with the secretary of war in recommend that authority be give to recruit all company of infantry to at least 50 man and all battery of artillery to at least 75 man with the power in case of emergency to increase the former to 100 and the latter to 122 man each

 i invite your special attention to the follow recommendation of the secretary of war

 first that provision be make for supply to the army a more abundant and well supply of reading matter

 second that early action be take by congress look to a complete revision and republication of the army regulations

 third that section 1258 of the revised statutes limit the number of officer on the retired list be repeal

 fourth that the claim arise under the act of july 4 1864 for supply take by the army during the war be take from the office of the quartermaster and commissary generals and transfer to the southern claims commission or some other tribunal have more time and well facility for their prompt investigation and decision than be possess by these officer

 fifth that congress provide for an annuity fund for the family of deceased soldier as recommend by the paymaster general of the army

 the report of the secretary of the navy show that we have six squadron now engage in the protection of our foreign commerce and other duty pertain to the naval service the condition and operation of the department be also show the total expenditure for the fiscal year end june 30 1877 be $ 16,077,974.54 there be unpaid claim against the department chargeable to the last year which be present to the consideration of congress by the report of the secretary the estimate for the fiscal year commence july 1 1878 be $ 16,233,234.40 exclusive of the sum of $ 2,314,231 submit for new building repair and improvement at the several navy yard the appropriation for the present fiscal year commence july 1 1877 be $ 13,592,932.90 the amount draw from the treasury from july 1 to november 1 1877 be $ 5,343,037.40 of which there be estimate to be yet available $ 1,029,528.30 show the amount of actual expenditure during the first four month of the present fiscal year to have be $ 4,313,509.10

 the report of the postmaster general contain a full and clear statement of the operation and condition of the post office department the ordinary revenue of the department for the fiscal year end june 30 1877 include receipt from the money order business and from official stamp and stamp envelope amount to the sum of $ 27,531,585.26 the additional sum of $ 7,013,000 be realize from appropriation from the general treasury for various purpose make the receipt from all source $ 34,544,885.26 the total expenditure during the fiscal year amount to $ 33,486,322.44 leave an excess of total receipt over total expenditure of $ 1,058,562.82 and an excess of total expenditure over ordinary receipt of $ 5,954,737.18 deduct from the total receipt the sum of $ 63,261.84 receive from international money order of the precede fiscal year and deduct from the total expenditure the sum of $ 1,163,818.20 pay on liability incur in previous fiscal year the expenditure and receipt appertain to the business of the last fiscal year be as follow

 expenditure $ 32,322,504.24
 receipts ordinary from money order business and from official postage stamp $ 27,468,323,420
 excess of expenditure $ 4,854,180.82

 the ordinary revenue of the post office department for the year end june 30 1879 be estimate at an increase of 3 per cent over those of 1877 make $ 29,034,098.28 and the expenditure for the same year be estimate at $ 36,427,771 leave an estimate deficiency for the year 1879 of $ 7,393,672.72 the additional legislation recommend by the postmaster general for improvement of the mail service and to protect the postal revenue from the abuse practice under exist law be respectfully commend to the careful consideration of congress

 the report of the attorney general contain several suggestion as to the administration of justice to which i invite your attention the pressure of business in the supreme court and in certain circuit court of the united states be now such that serious delay to the great injury and even oppression of suitor occur and a remedy should be seek for this condition of affair whether it will be find in the plan briefly sketch in the report of increase the number of judge of the circuit court and by mean of this addition to the judicial force of create an intermediate court of error and appeal or whether some other mode can be devise for obviate the difficulty which now exist i leave to your mature consideration

 the present condition of the indian tribe in the territory of the united states and our relation with they be fully set forth in the report of the secretary of the interior and the commissioner of indian affairs after a series of most deplorable conflicts&mdash;the successful termination of which while reflect honor upon the brave soldier who accomplish it can not lessen our regret at their occurrence&mdash;we be now at peace with all the indian tribe within our border to preserve that peace by a just and humane policy will be the object of my earnest endeavor whatever may be say of their character and savage propensity of the difficulty of introduce among they the habit of civilized life and of the obstacle they have offer to the progress of settlement and enterprise in certain part of the country the indians be certainly entitle to our sympathy and to a conscientious respect on our part for their claim upon our sense of justice they be the aboriginal occupant of the land we now possess they have be drive from place to place the purchase money pay to they in some case for what they call their own have still leave they poor in many instance when they have settle down upon land assign to they by compact and begin to support themselves by their own labor they be rudely jostle off and thrust into the wilderness again many if not most of our indian war have have their origin in broken promise and act of injustice upon our part and the advance of the indians in civilization have be slow because the treatment they receive do not permit it to be fast and more general we can not expect they to improve and to follow our guidance unless we keep faith with they in respect the right they possess and unless instead of deprive they of their opportunity we lend they a help hand

 i cordially approve the policy regard the management of indian affair outline in the report of the secretary of the interior and of the commissioner of indian affairs the faithful performance of our promise be the first condition of a good understanding with the indians i can not too urgently recommend to congress that prompt and liberal provision be make for the conscientious fulfillment of all engagement enter into by the government with the indian tribe to withhold the mean necessary for the performance of a promise be always false economy and be apt to prove disastrous in its consequence especial care be recommend to provide for indians settle on their reservation cattle and agricultural implement to aid they in whatever effort they may make to support themselves and by the establishment and maintenance of school to bring they under the control of civilized influence i see no reason why indians who can give satisfactory proof of have by their own labor support their family for a number of year and who be willing to detach themselves from their tribal relation should not be admit to the benefit of the homestead act and the privilege of citizenship and i recommend the passage of a law to that effect it will be an act of justice as well as a measure of encouragement earnest effort be be make to purify the indian service so that every dollar appropriate by congress shall redound to the benefit of the indians as intend those effort will have my firm support with an improved service and every possible encouragement hold out to the indians to better their condition and to elevate themselves in the scale of civilization we may hope to accomplish at the same time a good work for they and for ourselves

 i invite the attention of congress to the importance of the statement and suggestion make by the secretary of the interior concern the depredation commit on the timber land of the united states and the necessity for the preservation of forest it be believe that the measure take in pursuance of exist law to arrest those depredation will be entirely successful if congress by an appropriation for that purpose render their continue enforcement possible the experience of other nation teach we that a country can not be strip of its forest with impunity and we shall expose ourselves to the grave consequence unless the wasteful and improvident manner in which the forest in the united states be destroy be effectually check i earnestly recommend that the measure suggest by the secretary of the interior for the suppression of depredation on the public timber land of the united states for the selling of timber from the public land and for the preservation of forest be embody in a law and that consider the urgent necessity of enable the people of certain states and territories to purchase timber from the public land in a legal manner which at present they can not do such a law be pass without unavoidable delay i would also call the attention of congress to the statement make by the secretary of the interior concern the disposition that might be make of the desert land not irrigable west of the one hundredth meridian these land be practically unsalable under exist law and the suggestion be worthy of consideration that a system of leasehold tenure would make they a source of profit to the united states while at the same time legalize the business of cattle raise which be at present carry on upon they

 the report of the commissioner of agriculture contain the gratify announcement of the extraordinary success which have reward the agricultural industry of the country for the past year with the fair price which obtain for the product of the soil especially for the surplus which our people have to export we may confidently turn to this as the most important of all our resource for the revival of the depressed industry of the country the report show our agricultural progress during the year and contain a statement of the work do by this department for the advancement of agricultural industry upon which the prosperity of our people so largely depend matter of information be include of great interest to all who seek by the experience of other to improve their own method of cultivation the effort of the department to increase the production of important article of consumption will it be hope improve the demand for labor and advance the business of the country and eventually result in save some of the many million that be now annually pay to foreign nation for sugar and other staple product which habitual use have make necessary in our domestic everyday life

 the board on behalf of the united states executive departments at the international exhibition of 1876 have conclude its labor the final report of the board be transmit to congress by the president near the close of the last session as these paper be understand to contain interesting and valuable information and will constitute the only report emanating from the government on the subject of the exhibition i invite attention to the matter and recommend that the report be publish for general information

 congress be empower by the constitution with the authority of exclusive legislation over the district of columbia in which the seat of government of the nation be locate the interest of the district have no direct representation in congress be entitle to especial consideration and care at the hand of the general government the capital of the united states belong to the nation and it be natural that the american people should take pride in the seat of their national government and desire it to be an ornament to the country much have be do to render it healthful convenient and attractive but much remain to be do which its permanent inhabitant be not able and ought not to be expect to do to impose upon they a large proportion of the cost require for public improvement which be in a great measure plan and execute for the convenience of the government and of the many thousand of visitor from all part of the country who temporarily reside at the capital of the nation be an evident injustice special attention be ask by the commissioners of the district in their report which be herewith transmit to the importance of a permanent adjustment by congress of the financial relation between the united states and the district involve the regular annual contribution by the united states of its just proportion of the expense of the district government and of the outlay for all need public improvement and such measure of relief from the burden of taxation now rest upon the people of the district as in the wisdom of congress may be deem just

 the report of the commissioners show that the affair of the district be in a condition as satisfactory as could be expect in view of the heavy burden of debt rest upon it and its very limited mean for necessary expense

 the debt of the district be as follow

 old fund debt $ 8,379,691.96
 3.65 bond guarantee by the united states $ 13,743,250.00
 total bond debt $ 22,122,941.96
 to which should be add certain outstanding claim as explain
 in the report of the commissioners $ 1,187,204.52
 make the total debt of the district $ 23,310,146.48

 the commissioners also ask attention to the importance of the improvement of the potomac river and the reclamation of the marsh border the city of washington and their view upon this subject be concur in by the member of the board of health whose report be also herewith transmit both the commercial and sanitary interest of the district will be greatly promote i doubt not by this improvement

 your attention be invite to the suggestion of the commissioners and of the board of health for the organization of a board of charity to have supervision and control of the disbursement of all money for charitable purpose from the district treasury i desire also to ask your especial attention to the need of add to the efficiency of the public school of the district by supplemental aid from the national treasury this be especially just since so large a number of those attend these school be child of employee of the government i earnestly commend to your care the interest of the people of the district who be so intimately associate with the government establishment and to whose enterprise the good order and attractiveness of the capital be largely due and i ask your attention to the request of the commissioners for legislation in behalf of the interest intrust to their care the appropriation ask for the care of the reservation belong to the government within the city by the commissioner of public buildings and grounds be also commend to your favorable consideration

 the report of the joint commission create by the act approve 2d of august 1876 entitle an act provide for the completion of the washington monument be also herewith transmit with accompany document the board of engineer officer detail to examine the monument in compliance with the second section of the act have report that the foundation be insufficient no authority exist for make the expenditure necessary to secure its stability i therefore recommend that the commission be authorize to expend such portion of the sum appropriate by the act as may be necessary for the purpose the present unfinished condition of the monument begin so long ago be a reproach to the nation it can not be doubt that the patriotic sense of the country will warmly respond to such prompt provision as may be make for its completion at an early day and i urge upon congress the propriety and necessity of immediate legislation for this purpose

 the wisdom of legislation upon the part of congress in aid of the states for the education of the whole people in those branch of study which be teach in the common school of the country be no long a question the intelligent judgment of the country go still far regard it as also both constitutional and expedient for the general government to extend to technical and high education such aid as be deem essential to the general welfare and to our due prominence among the enlightened and cultured nation of the world the ultimate settlement of all question of the future whether of administration or finance or of true nationality of sentiment depend upon the virtue and intelligence of the people it be vain to hope for the success of a free government without the mean of insure the intelligence of those who be the source of power no less than one seventh of the entire vote population of our country be yet unable to read and write

 it be encouraging to observe in connection with the growth of fraternal feeling in those states in which slavery formerly exist evidence of increase interest in universal education and i shall be glad to give my approval to any appropriate measure which may be enact by congress for the purpose of supplement with national aid the local system of education in those states and in all the states and having already invite your attention to the need of the district of columbia with respect to its public school system i here add that i believe it desirable not so much with reference to the local want of the district but to the great and lasting benefit of the entire country that this system should be crown with a university in all respect in keep with the national capital and thereby realize the cherished hope of washington on this subject

 i also earnestly commend the request of the regents of the smithsonian institution that an adequate appropriation be make for the establishment and conduct of a national museum under their supervision

 the question of provide for the preservation and growth of the library of congress be also one of national importance as the depository of all copyright publication and record this library have outgrow the provision for its accommodation and the erection on such site as the judgment of congress may approve of a fireproof library building to preserve the treasure and enlarge the usefulness of this valuable collection be recommend i recommend also such legislation as will render available and efficient for the purpose of instruction so far as be consistent with the public service the cabinet or museum of invention of surgery of education and of agriculture and other collection the property of the national government

 the capital of the nation should be something more than a mere political center we should avail ourselves of all the opportunity which providence have here place at our command to promote the general intelligence of the people and increase the condition most favorable to the success and perpetuity of our institution
to the house of representatives
 after a very careful consideration of the house bill no 1093 entitle an act to authorize the coinage of the standard silver dollar and to restore its legal tender character i feel compel to return it to the house of representatives in which it originate with my objection to its passage
 hold the opinion which i express in my annual message that neither the interest of the government nor of the people of the united states would be promote by disparage silver as one of the two precious metal which furnish the coinage of the world and that legislation which look to maintain the volume of intrinsic money to as full a measure of both metal as their relative commercial value will permit would be neither unjust nor inexpedient it have be my earnest desire to concur with congress in the adoption of such measure to increase the silver coinage of the country as would not impair the obligation of contract either public or private nor injuriously affect the public credit it be only upon the conviction that this bill do not meet these essential requirement that i feel it my duty to withhold from it my approval
 my present official duty as to this bill permit only an attention to the specific objection to its passage which seem to i so important as to justify i in ask from the wisdom and duty of congress that further consideration of the bill for which the constitution have in such case provide
 the bill provide for the coinage of silver dollar of the weight of 412 1/2 grain each of standard silver to be a legal tender at their nominal value for all debt and due public and private except where otherwise expressly stipulate in the contract it be well know that the market value of that number of grain of standard silver during the post year have be from 90 to 92 cent as compare with the standard gold dollar thus the silver dollar authorize by this bill be worth 8 to 10 per cent less than it purport to be worth and be make a legal tender for debt contract when the law do not recognize such coin as lawful money
