 the right to pay duty in silver or in certificate for silver deposit will when they be issue in sufficient amount to circulate put an end to the receipt of revenue in gold and thus compel the payment of silver for both the principal and interest of the public debt one billion one hundred and forty three million four hundred and ninety three thousand four hundred dollar of the bond debt now outstanding be issue prior to february 1873 when the silver dollar be unknown in circulation in this country and be only a convenient form of silver bullion for exportation $ 583,440,350 of the funded debt have be issue since february 1873 when gold alone be the coin for which the bond be sell and gold alone be the coin in which both party to the contract understand that the bond would be pay these bond enter into the market of the world they be pay for in gold when silver have greatly depreciate and when no one would have buy they if it have be understand that they would be pay in silver the sum of $ 225,000,000 of these bond have be sell during my administration for gold coin and the united states receive the benefit of these sale by a reduction of the rate of interest to 4 per cent during the progress of these sale a doubt be suggest as to the coin in which payment of these bond would be make the public announcement be thereupon authorize that it be not to be anticipate that any future legislation of congress or any action of any department of the government would sanction or tolerate the redemption of the principal of these bond or the payment of the interest thereon in coin of less value than the coin authorize by law at the time of the issue of the bond be the coin exact by the government in exchange for the same in view of these fact it will be justly regard as a grave breach of the public faith to undertake to pay these bond principal or interest in silver coin worth in the market less than the coin receive for they
 it be say that the silver dollar make a legal tender by this bill will under its operation be equivalent in value to the gold dollar many supporter of the bill believe this and would not justify an attempt to pay debt either public or private in coin of inferior value to the money of the world the capital defect of the bill be that it contain no provision protect from its operation preexist debt in case the coinage which it create shall continue to be of less value than that which be the sole legal tender when they be contract if it be now propose for the purpose of take advantage of the depreciation of silver in the payment of debt to coin and make a legal lender a silver dollar of less commercial value than any dollar whether of gold or paper which be now lawful money in this country such measure it will hardly be question will in the judgment of mankind be an act of bad faith as to all debt heretofore contract the silver dollar should be make a legal tender only at its market value the standard of value should not be change without the consent of both party to the contract national promise should be keep with unflinche fidelity there be no power to compel a nation to pay its just debt its credit depend on its honor the nation owe what it have lead or allow its creditor to expect i can not approve a bill which in my judgment authorize the violation of sacred obligation the obligation of the public faith transcend all question of profit or public advantage its unquestionable maintenance be the dictate as well of the high expediency as of the most necessary duty and should ever be carefully guard by the executive by congress and by the people
 it be my firm conviction that if the country be to be benefit by a silver coinage it can be do only by the issue of silver dollar of full value which will defraud no man a currency worth less than it purport to be worth will in the end defraud not only creditor but all who be engage in legitimate business and none more surely than those who be dependent on their daily labor for their daily bread

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives our heartfelt gratitude be due to the divine being who hold in his hand the destiny of nation for the continued bestowal during the last year those who till the soil our manufacturing industry be revive and it be believe that general prosperity which have be so long anxiously look for be at last within our reach the enjoyment of health by our people generally have however be interrupt during the past season by the prevalence of a fatal pestilence the yellow fever in some portion of the southern states create an emergency which call for prompt and extraordinary measure of relief the disease appear as an epidemic at new orleans and at other place on the lower mississippi soon after midsummer it be rapidly spread by fugitive from the infect city and town and do not disappear until early in november the states of louisiana mississippi and tennessee have suffer severely about 100,000 case be believe to have occur of which about 20,000 accord to intelligent estimate prove fatal it be impossible to estimate with any approach to accuracy the loss to the country occasion by this epidemic it be to be reckon by the hundred million of dollar the suffering and destitution that result excited the deep sympathy in all part of the union physicians and nurse hasten from every quarter to the assistance of the afflict community voluntary contribution of money and supply in every need form be speedily and generously furnish the government be able to respond in some measure to the call for help by provide tent medicine and food for the sick and destitute the requisite direction for the purpose be give in the confident expectation that this action of the executive would receive the sanction of congress about 1,800 tent and ration of the value of about $ 25,000 be send to city and town which apply for they full detail of which will be furnish to congress by the proper department the fearful spread of this pestilence have awaken a very general public sentiment in favor of national sanitary administration which shall not only control quarantine but have the sanitary supervision of internal commerce in time of epidemic and hold an advisory relation to the state and municipal health authority with power to deal with whatever endanger the public health and which the municipal and state authority be unable to interior and of the commissioner of indian affairs present an elaborate account of the present condition of the indian tribe and of that branch of the public service which minister to their interest while the conduct of the indians generally have be orderly and their relation with their neighbor friendly and peaceable two local disturbance have occur which be deplorable in their character but remain happily confine to a comparatively small number of indians the discontent among the bannocks which lead first to some act of violence on the part of some member of the tribe and finally to the outbreak appear to have be cause by an insufficiency of food on the reservation and this insufficiency to have be owe to the inadequacy of the appropriation make by congress to the want of the indians at a time when the indians be prevent from supply the deficiency by hunting after an arduous pursuit by the troop of the united states and several engagement the hostile indians be reduce to subjection and the large part of they surrender themselves as prisoner in this connection i desire to call attention to the recommendation make by the secretary of the interior that a sufficient fund be place at the disposal of the executive to be use with proper accountability at discretion in sudden emergency of the indian service the other case of disturbance be that of a band of northern cheyennes who suddenly leave their reservation in the indian territory and march rapidly through the states of kansas and nebraska in the direction of their old hunting ground commit murder and other crime on their way from document accompany the report of the secretary of the interior it appear that this disorderly band be as fully supply with the necessary of life as the 4,700 other indians who remain quietly on the reservation and that the disturbance be cause by man of a restless and mischievous disposition among the indians themselves almost the whole of this band have surrender to the military authority and it be a gratifying fact that when some of they have take refuge in the camp of the red cloud sioux with whom they have be in friendly relation the sioux hold they as prisoner and readily give they up to the officer of the united states thus give new proof of the loyal spirit which alarm rumor to the contrary notwithstanding they have uniformly show ever since the wish they express at the council of september 1877 have be comply with both the secretary of the interior and the secretary of war unite in the recommendation that provision be make by congress for the organization of a corps of mount indian auxiliary to be under the control of the army and to be use for the purpose of keep the indians on their reservation and prevent or repress disturbance on their part i earnestly concur in this recommendation it be believe that the organization of such a body of indian cavalry receive a moderate pay from the government would considerably weaken the restless element among the indians by withdraw from it a number of young man and give they congenial employment under the government it be a matter of experience that indians in our service almost without exception be faithful in the performance of the duty assign to they such an organization would materially aid the army in the accomplishment of a task for which its numerical strength be sometimes find insufficient but while the employment of force for the prevention or repression of indian trouble be of occasional necessity and wise preparation should be make to that end great reliance must be place on humane and civilize agency for the ultimate solution of what be call the indian problem it may be very difficult and require much patient effort to curb the unruly spirit of the savage indian to the restraint of civilized life but experience show that it be not impossible many of the tribe which be now quiet and orderly and self support be once as savage as any that at present roam over the plain or in the mountain of the far west and be then consider inaccessible to civilize influence it may be impossible to raise they fully up to the level of the white population of the united states but we should not forget that they be the aborigine of the country and call the soil their own on which our people have grow rich powerful and happy we owe it to they as a moral duty to help they in attain at least that degree of civilization which they may be able to reach it be not only our duty it be also our interest to do so indians who have become agriculturist or herdsman and feel an interest in property will thenceforth cease to be a warlike and disturbing element it be also a well authenticate fact that indians be apt to be peaceable and quiet when their child be at school and i be gratified to know from the expression of indians themselves and from many concurring report that there be a steadily increase desire even among indians belong to comparatively wild tribe to have their child educate i invite attention to the report of the secretary of the interior and the commissioner of indian affairs touch the experiment recently inaugurate in take fifty indian child of our agricultural production have be acknowledge and urge upon the attention of congress and the people as the sure and readiest mean of increase our substantial and endure prosperity the word of washington be as applicable to day as when in his eighth annual message he say it will not be doubt that with reference either to individual or national welfare agriculture be of primary importance in the agricultural over any other interest in the united states entitle it to all the consideration claim for it by washington about one half of the population of the united states be engage in agriculture the value of the agricultural product of the united states for the year 1878 be estimate at $ 3,000,000,000 the export of agricultural product for the year 1877 as appear from the report necessary but most of the luxury that be consume in civilized country yet notwithstanding our advantage of soil climate and inter communication it appear from the statistical statement in the report of the commissioner of agriculture that we import annually from foreign land many million of dollar worth of agricultural product which could be raise in our own country numerous question arise in the practice of advanced agriculture which can only be answer by experiment often costly and sometimes fruitless which be beyond the mean of private individual and be a just and proper charge on the whole to the house of representatives
 after a very careful consideration of house bill 2423 entitle an act to restrict the immigration of chinese to the united states i herewith return it to the house of representatives in which it originate with my objection to its passage
 the bill as it be send to the senate from the house of representatives be confine in its provision to the object name in its title which be that of an act to restrict the immigration of chinese to the united states the only mean adopt to secure the propose object be the limitation on the number of chinese passenger which might be bring to this country by any one vessel to fifteen and as this number be not fix in any proportion to the size or tonnage of the vessel or by any consideration of the safety or accommodation of these passenger the simple purpose and effect of the enactment be to repress this immigration to an extent fall but little short of its absolute exclusion
 the bill as amend in the senate and now present to i include an independent and additional provision which aim at and in term require the abrogation by this government of articles v and vi of the treaty with china commonly call the burlingame treaty through the action of the executive enjoin by this provision of the act
 the burlingame treaty of which the ratification be exchange at peking november 23 1869 recite as the occasion and motive of its negotiation by the two government that since the conclusion of the treaty between the united states of america and the ta tsing empire china of the 18th of june 1858 circumstance have arise show the necessity of additional article thereto and proceed to an agree merit as to say additional article these negotiation therefore end by the signature of the additional article july 28 1868 have for their object the completion of our treaty right and obligation toward the government of china by the incorporation of these new article as thenceforth part of the principal treaty to which they be make supplemental upon the settle rule of interpretation applicable to such supplemental negotiation the text of the principal treaty and of these additional article thereto constitute one treaty from the conclusion of the new negotiation in all part of equal and concurrent force and obligation between the two government and to all intent and purpose as if embrace in one instrument
 the principal treaty of which the ratification be exchange august 16 1859 recite that the united states of america and the ta tsing empire desire to maintain firm lasting and sincere friendship have resolve to renew in a manner clear and positive by mean of a treaty or general convention of peace amity and commerce the rule which shall in future be mutually observe in the intercourse of their respective country and proceed in its thirty article to lay out a careful and comprehensive system for the commercial relation of our people with china the main substance of all the provision of this treaty be to define and secure the right of our people in respect of access to residence and protection in and trade with china the actual provision in our favor in these respect be frame to be and have be find to be adequate and appropriate to the interest of our commerce and by the conclude article we receive the important guaranty that--
 should at any time the ta tsing empire grant to any nation or the merchant or citizen of any nation any right privilege or favor connect either with navigation commerce political or other intercourse which be not confer by this treaty such right privilege and favor shall at once freely inure to the benefit of the united states its public officer merchant and citizen
 against this body of stipulation in our favor and this permanent engagement of equality in respect of all future concession to foreign nation the general promise of permanent peace and good office on our part seem to be the only equivalent for this the first article undertake as follow
 there shall be as there have always be peace and friendship between the united states of america and the ta tsing empire and between their people respectively they shall not insult or oppress each other for any trifling cause so as to produce an estrangement between they and if any other nation should act unjustly or oppressively the united states will exert their good office on be inform of the case to bring about an amicable arrangement of the question thus show their friendly feeling
 at the date of the negotiation of this treaty our pacific possession have attract a considerable chinese emigration and the advantage and the inconvenience feel or fear therefrom have become more or less manifest but they dictate no stipulation on the subject to be incorporate in the treaty the year 1868 be mark by the striking event of a spontaneous embassy from the chinese empire head by an american citizen anson burlingame who have relinquish his diplomatic representation of his own country in china to assume that of the chinese empire to the united states and the european nation by this time the fact of the chinese immigration and its nature and influence present and prospective have become more noticeable and be more observe by the population immediately affect and by this government the principal feature of the burlingame treaty be its attention to and its treatment of the chinese immigration and the chinese as form or as they should form a part of our population up to this time our uncovenante hospitality to immigration our fearless liberality of citizenship our equal and comprehensive justice to all inhabitant whether they abjure their foreign nationality or not our civil freedom and our religious toleration have make all comer welcome and under these protection the chinese in considerable number have make their lodgment upon our soil
 the burlingame treaty undertake to deal with this situation and its fifth and sixth article embrace its most important provision in this regard and the main stipulation in which the chinese government have secure an obligatory protection of its subject within our territory they read as follow
 art v. the united states of america and the emperor of china cordially recognize the inherent and inalienable right of man to change his home and allegiance and also the mutual advantage of the free migration and emigration of their citizen and subject respectively from the one country to the other for purpose of curiosity of trade or as permanent resident the high contracting party therefore join in reprobate any other than an entirely voluntary emigration for these purpose they consequently agree to pass law make it a penal offense for a citizen of the united states or chinese subject to take chinese subject either to the united states or to any other foreign country or for a chinese subject or citizen of the united states to take citizen of the united states to china or to any other foreign country without their free and voluntary consent respectively
 art vi citizen of the united states visit or reside in china shall enjoy the same privilege immunity or exemption in respect to travel or residence as may there be enjoy by the citizen or subject of the most favored nation and reciprocally chinese subject visit or reside in the united states shall enjoy the same privilege immunity and exemption in respect to travel or residence as may there be enjoy by the citizen or subject of the most favored nation but nothing herein contain shall be hold to confer naturalization upon citizen of the united states in china nor upon the subject of china in the united states
 an examination of these two article in the light of the experience then influential in suggest their necessity will show that the fifth article be frame in hostility to what seem the principal mischief to be guard against to wit the introduction of chinese laborer by method which should have the character of a forced and servile importation and not of a voluntary emigration of freeman seek our shore upon motive and in a manner consonant with the system of our institution and approve by the experience of the nation unquestionably the adhesion of the government of china to these liberal principle of freedom in emigration with which we be so familiar and with which we be so well satisfied be a great advance toward open that empire to our civilization and religion and give promise in the future of great and great practical result in the diffusion throughout that great population of our art and industry our manufacture our material improvement and the sentiment of government and religion which seem to we so important to the welfare of mankind the first clause of this article secure this acceptance by china of the american doctrine of free migration to and fro among the people and race of the earth
 the second clause however in its reprobation of any other than an entirely voluntary emigration by both the high contracting party and in the reciprocal obligation whereby we secure the solemn and unqualified engagement on the part of the government of china to pass law make it a penal offense for a citizen of the united states or chinese subject to take chinese subject either to the united states or to any other foreign country without their free and voluntary consent constitute the great force and value of this article its importance both in principle and in its practical service toward our protection against servile importation in the guise of immigration can not be overestimate it commit the chinese government to active and efficient measure to suppress this iniquitous system where those measure be most necessary and can be most effectual it give to this government the footing of a treaty right to such measure and the mean and opportunity of insist upon their adoption and of complaint and resentment at their neglect the fifth article therefore if it fall short of what the pressure of the later experience of our pacific states may urge upon the attention of this government as essential to the public welfare seem to be in the right direction and to contain important advantage which once relinquish can not be easily recover
 the second topic which interest the two government under the actual condition of thing which prompt the burlingame treaty be adequate protection under the solemn and definite guaranty of a treaty of the chinese already in this country and those who should seek our shore this be the object and form the subject of the sixth article by whose reciprocal engagement the citizen and subject of the two government respectively visit or reside in the country of the other be secure the same privilege immunity or exemption there enjoy by the citizen or subject of the most favor nation the treaty of 1858 to which these article be make supplemental provide for a great amount of privilege and protection both of person and property to american citizen in china but it be upon this sixth article that the main body of the treaty right and security of the chinese already in this country depend its abrogation be the rest of the treaty leave in force would leave they to such treatment as we should voluntarily accord they by our law and custom any treaty obligation would be want to restrain our liberty of action toward they or to measure or sustain the right of the chinese government to complaint or redress in their behalf
 the lapse of ten year since the negotiation of the burlingame treaty have exhibit to the notice of the chinese government as well as to our own people the working of this experiment of immigration in great number of chinese laborer to this country and their maintenance here of all the trait of race religion manner and custom habitation mode of life segregation here and the keeping up of the tie of their original home which stamp they as stranger and sojourner and not as incorporate element of our national life and growth this experience may naturally suggest the reconsideration of the subject as deal with by the burlingame treaty and may properly become the occasion of more direct and circumspect recognition in renew negotiation of the difficulty surround this political and social problem it may well be that to the apprehension of the chinese government no less than our own the simple provision of the burlingame treaty may need to be replace by more careful method secure the chinese and ourselves against a large and more rapid infusion of this foreign race than our system of industry and society can take up and assimilate with ease and safety this ancient government rule a polite and sensitive people distinguish by a high sense of national pride may properly desire an adjustment of their relation with we which would in all thing confirm and in no degree endanger the permanent peace and amity and the grow commerce and prosperity which it have be the object and the effect of our exist treaty to cherish and perpetuate
 i regard the very grave discontent of the people of the pacific states with the present working of the chinese immigration and their still graver apprehension therefrom in the future as deserve the most serious attention of the people of the whole country and a solicitous interest on the part of congress and the executive if this be not my own judgment the passage of this bill by both houses of congress would impress upon i the seriousness of the situation when a majority of the representative of the people of the whole country have think fit to justify so serious a measure of relief
 the authority of congress to terminate a treaty with a foreign power by express the will of the nation no long to adhere to it be as free from controversy under our constitution as be the further proposition that the power of make new treaty or modify exist treaty be not lodge by the constitution in congress but in the president by and with the advice and consent of the senate as show by the concurrence of two third of that body a denunciation of a treaty by any government be confessedly justifiable only upon some reason both of the high justice and of the high necessity the action of congress in the matter of the french treaty in 1798 if it be regard as an abrogation by this nation of a subsist treaty strongly illustrate the character and degree of justification which be then think suitable to such a proceeding the preamble of the act recite that the--
 treaty conclude between the united states and france have be repeatedly violate on the part of the french government and the just claim of the united states for reparation of the injury so committed have be refuse and their attempt to negotiate an amicable adjustment of all complaint between the two nation have be repel with indignity
 and that--
 under authority of the french government there be yet pursue against the united states a system of predatory violence infract the say treaty and hostile to the right of a free and independent nation
 the enactment as a logical consequence of these recited fact declares--
 that the united states be of right freed and exonerate from the stipulation of the treaty and of the consular convention heretofore conclude between the united states and france and that the same shall not henceforth be regard as legally obligatory on the government or citizen of the united states
 the history of the government show no other instance of an abrogation of a treaty by congress
 instance have sometimes occur where the ordinary legislation of congress have by its conflict with some treaty obligation of the government toward a foreign power take effect as an infraction of the treaty and be judicially declare to be operative to that result but neither such legislation nor such judicial sanction of the same have be regard as an abrogation even for the moment of the treaty on the contrary the treaty in such case still subsist between the government and the casual infraction be repair by appropriate satisfaction in maintenance of the treaty
 the bill before i do not enjoin upon the president the abrogation of the entire burlingame treaty much less of the principal treaty of which it be make the supplement as the power of modify an exist treaty whether by add or strike out provision be a part of the treaty make power under the constitution its exercise be not competent for congress nor would the assent of china to this partial abrogation of the treaty make the action of congress in thus procure an amendment of a treaty a competent exercise of authority under the constitution the importance however of this special consideration seems supersede by the principle that a denunciation of a part of a treaty not make by the term of the treaty itself separable from the rest be a denunciation of the whole treaty as the other high contracting party have enter into no treaty obligation except such as include the part denounce the denunciation by one party of the part necessarily liberate the other party from the whole treaty
 i be convinced that whatever urgency might in any quarter or by any interest be suppose to require an instant suppression of further immigration from china no reason can require the immediate withdrawal of our treaty protection of the chinese already in this country and no circumstance can tolerate an exposure of our citizen in china merchant or missionary to the consequence of so sudden an abrogation of their treaty protection fortunately however the actual recession in the flow of the emigration from china to the pacific coast show by trustworthy statistic relieve we from any apprehension that the treatment of the subject in the proper course of diplomatic negotiation will introduce any new feature of discontent or disturbance among the community directly affect be such delay fraught with more inconvenience than have ever be suggest by the interest most earnest in promote this legislation i can not but regard the summary disturbance of our exist treaty with china as greatly more inconvenient to much wide and more permanent interest of the country
 i have no occasion to insist upon the more general consideration of interest and duty which sacredly guard the faith of the nation in whatever form of obligation it may have be give these sentiment animate the deliberation of congress and pervade the mind of our whole people our history give little occasion for any reproach in this regard and in ask the renew attention of congress to this bill i be persuade that their action will maintain the public duty and the public honor

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas it have become know to i that certain evil dispose person have within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states begin and set on foot preparation for an organized and forcible possession of and settlement upon the land of what be know as the indian territory west of the state of arkansas which territory be designate recognize and describe by the treaty and law of the united states and by the executive authority as indian country and as such be only subject to occupation by indian tribe officer of the indian department military post and such person as may be privileged to reside and trade therein under the intercourse law of the united states and
 whereas those law provide for the removal of all person reside and trade therein without express permission of the indian department and agent and also of all person whom such agent may deem to be improper person to reside in the indian country
 now therefore for the purpose of properly protect the interest of the indian nation and tribe as well as of the united states in say indian territory and of duly enforce the law govern the same i rutherford b. hayes president of the united states do admonish and warn all such person so intend or prepare to remove upon say land or into said territory without permission of the proper agent of the indian department against any attempt to so remove or settle upon any of the land of said territory and i do far warn and notify any and all such person who may so offend that they will be speedily and immediately remove therefrom by the agent accord to the law make and provide and if necessary the aid and assistance of the military force of the united states will be invoke to carry into proper execution the law of the united states herein refer to
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 26th day of april a. d. 1879 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and third
 rutherford b. hayes
 by the president
 wm m. evarts secretary of state

to the house of representatives
 i have maturely consider the important question present by the bill entitle an act make appropriation for the support of the army for the fiscal year end june 30 1880 and for other purpose and i now return it to the house of representatives in which it originate with my objection to its approval
 the bill provide in the usual form for the appropriation require for the support of the army during the next fiscal year if it contain no other provision it would receive my prompt approval it include however further legislation which attach as it be to appropriation which be requisite for the efficient performance of some of the most necessary duty of the government involve question of the grave character the sixth section of the bill be amendatory of the statute now in force in regard to the authority of person in the civil military and naval service of the united states at the place where any general or special election be hold in any state this statute be adopt february 25 1865 after a protract debate in the senate and almost without opposition in the house of representatives by the concurrent vote of both of the lead political party of the country and become a law by the approval of president lincoln it be reenact in 1874 in the revised statutes of the united states section 2002 and 5528 which be as follow
 sec 2002 no military or naval officer or other person engage in the civil military or naval service of the united states shall order bring keep or have under his authority or control any troop or armed man at the place where any general or special election be hold in any state unless it be necessary to repel the armed enemy of the united states or to keep the peace at the poll
 sec 5528 every officer of the army or navy or other person in the civil military or naval service of the united states who order bring keep or have under his authority or control any troop or armed man at any place where a general or special election be hold in any state unless such force be necessary to repel armed enemy of the united states or to keep the peace at the poll shall be fine not more than $ 5,000 and suffer imprisonment at hard labor not less than three month nor more than five year
 the amendment propose to this statute in the bill before i omit from both of the foregoing section the word or to keep the peace at the poll the effect of the adoption of this amendment may be considered--
 first upon the right of the united states government to use military force to keep the peace at the election for member of congress and
 second upon the right of the government by civil authority to protect these election from violence and fraud
 in addition to the section of the statute above quote the follow provision of law relate to the use of the military power at the election be now in force
 sec 2003 no officer of the army or navy of the united states shall prescribe or fix or attempt to prescribe or fix by proclamation order or otherwise the qualification of voter in any state or in any manner interfere with the freedom of any election in any state or with the exercise of the free right of suffrage in any state
 sec 5529 every officer or other person in the military or naval service who by force threat intimidation order advice or otherwise prevent or attempt to prevent any qualified voter of any state from freely exercise the right of suffrage at any general or special election in such state shall be fine not more than $ 5,000 and imprison at hard labor not more than five year
 sec 5530 every officer of the army or navy who prescribe or fix or attempt to prescribe or fix whether by proclamation order or otherwise the qualification of voter at any election in any state shall be punish as provide in the precede section
 sec 5531 every officer or other person in the military or naval service who by force threat intimidation order or otherwise compel or attempt to compel any officer hold an election in any state to receive a vote from a person not legally qualified to vote or who impose or attempt to impose any regulation for conduct any general or special election in a state different from those prescribe by law or who interfere in any manner with any officer of an election in the discharge of his duty shall be punish as provide in section 5529
 sec 5532 every person convict of any of the offense specify in the five precede section shall in addition to the punishment therein severally prescribe be disqualify from hold any office of honor profit or trust under the united states but nothing in those section shall be construe to prevent any officer soldier sailor or marine from exercise the right of suffrage in any election district to which he may belong if otherwise qualified accord to the law of the state in which he offer to vote
 the foregoing enactment would seem to be sufficient to prevent military interference with the election but the last congress to remove all apprehension of such interference add to this body of law section 15 of an act entitle an act make appropriation for the support of the army for the fiscal year end june 30 1879 and for other purpose approve june 18 1878 which be as follow
 sec 15 from and after the passage of this act it shall not be lawful to employ any part of the army of the united states as a posse comitatus or otherwise for the purpose of execute the law except in such case and under such circumstance as such employment of say force may be expressly authorize by the constitution or by act of congress and no money appropriate by this act shall be use to pay any of the expense incur in the employment of any troop in violation of this section and any person willfully violate the provision of this section shall be deem guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction thereof shall be punish by fine not exceed $ 10,000 or imprisonment not exceed two year or by both such fine and imprisonment
 this act pass the senate after full consideration without a single vote record against it on its final passage and by a majority of more than two third it be concur in by the house of representatives
 the purpose of the section quote be state in the senate by one of its supporter as follow
 therefore i hope without get into any controversy about the past but act wisely for the future that we shall take away the idea that the army can be use by a general or special deputy marshal or any marshal merely for election purpose as a posse order they about the poll or order they anywhere else when there be an election go on to prevent disorder or to suppress disturbance that should be suppress by the peace officer of the state or if they must bring other to their aid they should summon the unorganized citizen and not summon the officer and man of the army as a posse comitatus to quell disorder and thus get up a feeling which will be disastrous to peace among the people of the country
 in the house of representatives the object of the act of 1878 be state by the gentleman who have it in charge in similar term he say
 but these be all minor point and insignificant question compare with the great principle which be incorporate by the house in the bill in reference to the use of the army in time of peace the senate have already concede what they call and what we might accept as the principle but they have stricken out the penalty and have stricken out the word expressly so that the army might be use in all case where imply authority might be infer the house committee plant themselves firmly upon the doctrine that rather than yield this fundamental principle for which for three year this house have struggle they would allow the bill to fail notwithstanding the reform which we have secure regard these reform as of but little consequence alongside the great principle that the army of the united states in time of peace should be under the control of congress and obedient to its law after a long and protracted negotiation the senate committee have concede that principle in all its length and breadth include the penalty which the senate have stricken out we bring you back therefore a report with the alteration of a single word which the lawyer assure i be proper to be make restore to this bill the principle for which we have contend so long and which be so vital to secure the right and liberty of the people
 thus have we this day secure to the people of this country the same great protection against a stand army which cost a struggle of two hundred year for the commons of england to secure for the british people
 from this brief review of the subject it sufficiently appear that under exist law there can be no military interference with the election no case of such interference have in fact occur since the passage of the act last refer to no soldier of the united states have appear under order at any place of election in any state no complaint even of the presence of united states troop have be make in any quarter it may therefore be confidently state that there be no necessity for the enactment of section 6 of the bill before i to prevent military interference with the election the law already in force be all that be require for that end

 section 4 of article i of the constitution declares--
 the time place and manner of hold election for senator and representatives shall be prescribe in each state by the legislature thereof but the congress may at any time by law make or alter such regulation except as to the place of choose senator
 the fifteenth amendment of the constitution be as follow
 sec 1 the right of citizen of the united states to vote shall not be deny or abridge by the united states or by any state on account of race color or previous condition of servitude
 sec 2 the congress shall have power to enforce this article by appropriate legislation
 the supreme court have hold that this amendment invest the citizen of the united states with a new constitutional right which be within the protect power of congress that right the court declare to be exemption from discrimination in the exercise of the elective franchise on account of race color or previous condition of servitude the power of congress to protect this right by appropriate legislation be expressly affirm by the court
 national legislation to provide safeguard for free and honest election be necessary as experience have show not only to secure the right to vote to the enfranchised race at the south but also to prevent fraudulent voting in the large city of the north congress have therefore exercise the power confer by the constitution and have enact certain law to prevent discrimination on account of race color or previous condition of servitude and to punish fraud violence and intimidation at federal election attention be call to the follow section of the revised statutes of the united states viz
 section 2004 which guarantee to all citizen the right to vote without distinction on account of race color or previous condition of servitude

 section 5522 which provide for the punishment of the crime of interfere with the supervisor of election and deputy marshal in the discharge of their duty at the election of representatives in congress

to the house of representatives
 after a careful consideration of the bill entitle an act to prohibit military interference at election i return it to the house of representatives in which it originate with the follow objection to its approval
 in the communication send to the house of representatives on the 29th of last month return to the house without my approval the bill entitle an act make appropriation for the support of the army for the fiscal year end june 30 1880 and for other purpose i endeavor to show by quotation from the statute of the united states now in force and by a brief statement of fact in regard to recent election in the several states that no additional legislation be necessary to prevent interference with the election by the military or naval force of the united states the fact be present in that communication that at the time of the passage of the act of june 18 1878 in relation to the employment of the army as a posse comitatus or otherwise it be maintain by its friend that it would establish a vital and fundamental principle which would secure to the people protection against a stand army the fact be also refer to that since the passage of this act congressional state and municipal election have be hold throughout the union and that in no instance have complaint be make of the presence of united states soldier at the poll
 holding as i do the opinion that any military interference whatever at the poll be contrary to the spirit of our institution and would tend to destroy the freedom of election and sincerely desire to concur with congress in all of its measure it be with very great regret that i be force to the conclusion that the bill before i be not only unnecessary to prevent such interference but be a dangerous departure from long settle and important constitutional principle
 the true rule as to the employment of military force at the election be not doubtful no intimidation or coercion should be allow to control or influence citizen in the exercise of their right to vote whether it appear in the shape of combination of evil dispose person or of armed body of the militia of a state or of the military force of the united states
 the election should be free from all forcible interference and as far as practicable from all apprehension of such interference no soldier either of the union or of the state militia should be present at the poll to take the place or to perform the duty of the ordinary civil police force there have be and will be no violation of this rule under order from i during this administration but there should be no denial of the right of the national government to employ its military force on any day and at any place in case such employment be necessary to enforce the constitution and law of the united states the bill before i be as follow
 be it enact etc that it shall not be lawful to bring to or employ at any place where a general or special election be be hold in a state any part of the army or navy of the united states unless such force be necessary to repel the armed enemy of the united states or to enforce section 4 article iv of the constitution of the united states and the law make in pursuance thereof on application of the legislature or executive of the state where such force be to be use and so much of all law as be inconsistent herewith be hereby repeal
 it will be observe that the bill exempt from the general prohibition against the employment of military force at the poll two specify case these exception recognize and concede the soundness of the principle that military force may properly and constitutionally be use at the place of election when such use be necessary to enforce the constitution and the law but the excepted case leave the prohibition so extensive and far reach that its adoption will seriously impair the efficiency of the executive department of the government
 the first act expressly authorize the use of military power to execute the law be pass almost as early as the organization of the government under the constitution and be approve by president washington may 2 1792 it be as follow
 sec 2 and be it far enact that whenever the law of the united states shall be oppose or the execution thereof obstruct in any state by combination too powerful to be suppress by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding or by the power vest in the marshal by this act the same be notify to the president of the united states by an associate justice or the district judge it shall be lawful for the president of the united states to call forth the militia of such state to suppress such combination and to cause the law to be duly execute and if the militia of a state where such combination may happen shall refuse or be insufficient to suppress the same it shall be lawful for the president if the legislature of the united states be not in session to call forth and employ such number of the militia of any other state or states most convenient thereto as may be necessary and the use of militia so to be call forth may be continue if necessary until the expiration of thirty day after the commencement of the ensue session
 in 1795 this provision be substantially reenact in a law which repeal the act of 1792 in 1807 the following act become the law by the approval of president jefferson
 that in all case of insurrection or obstruction to the law either of the united states or of any individual state or territory where it be lawful for the president of the united states to call forth the militia for the purpose of suppress such insurrection or of cause the law to be duly execute it shall be lawful for he to employ for the same purpose such part of the land or naval force of the united states as shall be judge necessary having first observe all the prerequisite of the law in that respect
 by this act it will be see that the scope of the law of 1795 be extend so as to authorize the national government to use not only the militia but the army and navy of the united states in cause the law to be duly execute
 the important provision of the act of 1792 1795 and 1807 modify in its term from time to time to adapt it to the exist emergency remain in force until by an act approve by president lincoln july 29 1861 it be reenact substantially in the same language in which it be now find in the revised statutes viz
 sec 5298 whenever by reason of unlawful obstruction combination or assemblage of person or rebellion against the authority of the government of the united states it shall become impracticable in the judgment of the president to enforce by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding the law of the united states within any state or territory it shall be lawful for the president to call forth the militia of any or all the states and to employ such part of the land and naval force of the united states as he may deem necessary to enforce the faithful execution of the law of the united states or to suppress such rebellion in whatever state or territory thereof the law of the united states may be forcibly oppose or the execution thereof forcibly obstruct
 this ancient and fundamental law have be in force from the foundation of the government it be now propose to abrogate it on certain day and at certain place in my judgment no fact have be produce which tend to show that it ought to be repeal or suspend for a single hour at any place in any of the states or territories of the union all the teaching of experience in the course of our history be in favor of sustain its efficiency unimpaired on every occasion when the supremacy of the constitution have be resist and the perpetuity of our institution imperil the principle of this statute enact by the father have enable the government of the union to maintain its authority and to preserve the integrity of the nation at the most critical period of our history my predecessor in the executive office have rely on this great principle it be on this principle that president washington suppress the whisky rebellion in pennsylvania in 1794
 in 1806 on the same principle president jefferson break up the burr conspiracy by issue order for the employment of such force either of the regular or of the militia and by such proceeding of the civil authority as might enable they to suppress effectually the further progress of the enterprise and it be under the same authority that president jackson crush nullification in south carolina and that president lincoln issue his call for troop to save the union in 1861 on numerous other occasion of less significance under probably every administration and certainly under the present this power have be usefully exert to enforce the law without objection by any party in the country and almost without attract public attention
 the great elementary constitutional principle which be the foundation of the original statute of 1792 and which have be its essence in the various form it have assume since its first adoption be that the government of the united states possess under the constitution in full measure the power of self protection by its own agency altogether independent of state authority and if need be against the hostility of state government it should remain embody in our statute unimpaire as it have be from the very origin of the government it should be regard as hardly less valuable or less sacred than a provision of the constitution itself

 another grave objection to the bill be its discrimination in favor of the state and against the national authority the presence or employment of the army or navy of the united states be lawful under the term of this bill at the place where an election be be hold in a state to uphold the authority of a state government then and there in need of such military intervention but unlawful to uphold the authority of the government of the united states then and there in need of such military intervention under this bill the presence or employment of the army or navy of the united states would be lawful and might be necessary to maintain the conduct of a state election against the domestic violence that would overthrow it but would be unlawful to maintain the conduct of a national election against the same local violence that would overthrow it this discrimination have never be attempt in any previous legislation by congress and be no more compatible with sound principle of the constitution or the necessary maxim and method of our system of government on occasion of election than at other time in the early legislation of 1792 and of 1795 by which the militia of the states be the only military power resort to for the execution of the constitutional power in support of state or national authority both function of the government be put upon the same footing by the act of 1807 the employment of the army and navy be authorize for the performance of both constitutional duty in the same term

 under the sweeping term of the bill the national government be effectually shut out from the exercise of the right and from the discharge of the imperative duty to use its whole executive power whenever and wherever require for the enforcement of its law at the place and time when and where its election be hold the employment of its organized armed force for any such purpose would be an offense against the law unless call for by and therefore upon permission of the authority of the state in which the occasion arise what be this but the substitution of the discretion of the state government for the discretion of the government of the united states as to the performance of its own duty in my judgment this be an abandonment of its obligation by the national government a subordination of national authority and an intrusion of state supervision over national duty which amount in spirit and tendency to state supremacy
 though i believe that the exist statute be abundantly adequate to completely prevent military interference with the election in the sense in which the phrase be use in the title of this bill and be employ by the people of this country i shall find no difficulty in concur in any additional legislation limit to that object which do not interfere with the indispensable exercise of the power of the government under the constitution and law

 the bill before i itself recognize the principle that the congressional election be not state election but national election it leave in full force the exist statute under which supervisor be still to be appoint by national authority to observe and witness the congressional election whenever due application be make by citizen who desire say election to be guard and scrutinize if the power to supervise in any respect whatever the congressional election exist under section 4 article 1 of the constitution it be a power which like every other power belong to the government of the united states be paramount and supreme and include the right to employ the necessary mean to carry it into effect
 the statute of the united states which regulate the election of member of the house of representatives an essential part of which it be propose to repeal by this bill have be in force about eight year four congressional election have be hold under they two of which be at the presidential election of 1872 and 1876 numerous prosecution trial and conviction have be have in the court of the united states in all part of the union for violation of these law in no reported case have their constitutionality be call in question by any judge of the court of the united states the validity of these law be sustain by the uniform course of judicial action and opinion
 if it be urge that the united states election law be not necessary an ample reply be furnish by the history of their origin and of their result they be especially prompt by the investigation and exposure of the fraud commit in the city and state of new york at the election of 1868 committee represent both of the lead political party of the country have submit report to the house of representatives on the extent of those fraud a committee of the fortieth congress after a full investigation reach the conclusion that the number of fraudulent vote cast in the city of new york alone in 1868 be not less than 25,000 a committee of the forty fourth congress in their report submit in 1877 adopt the opinion that for every 100 actual voter of the city of new york in 1868 108 vote be cast when in fact the number of lawful vote cast could not have exceed 88 per cent of the actual voter of the city by this statement the number of fraudulent vote at that election in the city of new york alone be between thirty and forty thousand these fraud completely reverse the result of the election in the state of new york both as to the choice of governor and state officer and as to the choice of elector of president and vice president of the united states they attract the attention of the whole country it be plain that if they could be continue and repeat with impunity free government be impossible a distinguished senator in oppose the passage of the election law declare that he have for a long time believe that our form of government be a comparative failure in the large city to meet these evil and to prevent these crime the united states law regulate congressional election be enact
 the framer of these law have not be disappoint in their result in the large city under their provision the election have be comparatively peaceable orderly and honest even the opponent of these law have bear testimony to their value and efficiency and to the necessity for their enactment the committee of the forty fourth congress compose of member a majority of whom be oppose to these law in their report on the new york election of 1876 say
 the committee would commend to other portion of the country and to other city this remarkable system develop through the agency of both local and federal authority act in harmony for an honest purpose in no portion of the world and in no era of time where there have be an expression of the popular will through the form of law have there be a more complete and thorough illustration of republican institution whatever may have be the previous habit or conduct of election in those city or howsoever they may conduct themselves in the future this election of 1876 will stand as a monument of what good faith honest endeavor legal form and just authority may do for the protection of the electoral franchise
 this bill recognize the authority and duty of the united states to appoint supervisor to guard and scrutinize the congressional election but it deny to the government of the united states all power to make its supervision effectual the great body of the people of all party want free and fair election they do not think that a free election mean freedom from the wholesome restraint of law or that the place of election should be a sanctuary for lawlessness and crime on the day of an election peace and good order be more necessary than on any other day of the year on that day the humblest and feeble citizen the aged and the infirm should be and should have reason to feel that they be safe in the exercise of their most responsible duty and their most sacred right as member of society their duty and their right to vote the constitutional authority to regulate the congressional election which belong to the government of the united states and which it be necessary to exert to secure the right to vote to every citizen possess the requisite qualification ought to be enforce by appropriate legislation so far from public opinion in any part of the country favor any relaxation of the authority of the government in the protection of election from violence and corruption i believe it demand great vigor both in the enactment and in the execution of the law frame for that purpose any oppression any partisan partiality which experience may have show in the working of exist law may well engage the careful attention both of congress and of the executive in their respective sphere of duty for the correction of these mischief as no congressional election occur until after the regular session of congress will have be hold there seem to be no public exigency that would preclude a seasonable consideration at that session of any administrative detail that might improve the present method design for the protection of all citizen in the complete and equal exercise of the right and power of the suffrage at such election but with my view both of the constitutionality and of the value of the exist law i can not approve any measure for their repeal except in connection with the enactment of other legislation which may reasonably be expect to afford wise and more efficient safeguard for free and honest congressional election


 june 23 1879
 hayes veto this appropriation bill designate by democrats which exclude implementation of election law fund



 to the house of representatives
 after careful examination of the bill entitle an act make appropriation for certain judicial expense i return it herewith to the house of representatives in which it originate with the follow objection to its approval
 the general purpose of the bill be to provide for certain judicial expense of the government for the fiscal year end june 30 1880 for which the sum of $ 2,690,000 be appropriate these appropriation be require to keep in operation the general function of the judicial department of the government and if this part of the bill stand alone there would be no objection to its approval it contain however other provision to which i desire respectfully to ask your attention
 at the present session of congress a majority of both house favor a repeal of the congressional election law embrace in title 26 of the revised statutes pass a measure for that purpose as part of a bill entitle an act make appropriation for the legislative executive and judicial expense of the government for the fiscal year end june 30 1880 and for other purpose unable to concur with congress in that measure on the 29th of may last i return the bill to the house of representatives in which it originate without my approval for that further consideration for which the constitution provide on reconsideration the bill be approve by less than two third of the house and fail to become a law the election law therefore remain valid enactment and the supreme law of the land bind not only upon all private citizen but also alike and equally binding upon all who be charge with the duty and responsibility of the legislative the executive and the judicial department of the government
 it be not seek by the bill before i to repeal the election law its object be to defeat their enforcement the last clause of the first section be as follow
 and no part of the money hereby appropriate be appropriate to pay any salary compensation fee or expense under or in virtue of title 26 of the revised statutes or of any provision of say title
 title 26 of the revised statutes refer to in the forego clause relate to the elective franchise and contain the law now in force regulate the congressional election
 the second section of the bill reach much far it be as follow
 sec 2 that the sum appropriate in this act for the person and public service embrace in its provision be in full for such person and public service for the fiscal year end june 30 1880 and no department or officer of the government shall during say fiscal year make any contract or incur any liability for the future payment of money under any of the provision of title 26 of the revised statutes of the united states authorize the appointment or payment of general or special deputy marshal for service in connection with election or on election day until an appropriation sufficient to meet such contract or pay such liability shall have first be make by law
 this section of the bill be intend to make an extensive and essential change in the exist law the follow be the provision of the statute on the same subject which be now in force
 sec 3679 no department of the government shall expend in any one fiscal year any sum in excess of appropriation make by congress for that fiscal year or involve the government in any contract for the future payment of money in excess of such appropriation
 sec 3732 no contract or purchase on behalf of the united states shall be make unless the same be authorize by law or be under an appropriation adequate to its fulfillment except in the war and navy departments for clothing subsistence forage fuel quarter or transportation which however shall not exceed the necessity of the current year
 the object of these section of the revised statutes be plain it be first to prevent any money from be expend unless appropriation have be make therefor and second to prevent the government from be bind by any contract not previously authorize by law except for certain necessary purpose in the war and navy departments
 under the exist law the failure of congress to make the appropriation require for the execution of the provision of the election law would not prevent their enforcement the right and duty to appoint the general and special deputy marshal which they provide for would still remain and the executive department of the government would also be empower to incur the requisite liability for their compensation but the second section of this bill contain a prohibition not find in any previous legislation its design be to render the election law inoperative and a dead letter during the next fiscal year it be seek to accomplish this by omit to appropriate money for their enforcement and by expressly prohibit any department or officer of the government from incur any liability under any of the provision of title 26 of the revised statutes authorize the appointment or payment of general or special deputy marshal for service on election day until an appropriation sufficient to pay such liability shall have first be make
 the president be call upon to give his affirmative approval to positive enactment which in effect deprive he of the ordinary and necessary mean of execute law still leave in the statute book and embrace within his constitutional duty to see that the law be execute if he approve the bill and thus give to such positive enactment the authority of law he participate in the curtailment of his mean of see that the law be faithfully execute while the obligation of the law and of his constitutional duty remain unimpaired
 the appointment of special deputy marshal be not make by the statute a spontaneous act of authority on the part of any executive or judicial officer of the government but be accord as a popular right of the citizen to call into operation this agency for secure the purity and freedom of election in any city or town have 20,000 inhabitant or upward section 2021 of the revised statutes put it in the power of any two citizen of such city or town to require of the marshal of the district the appointment of these special deputy marshal thereupon the duty of the marshal become imperative and its nonperformance would expose he to judicial mandate or punishment or to removal from office by the president as the circumstance of his conduct might require the bill now before i neither revoke this popular right of the citizen nor relieve the marshal of the duty impose by law nor the president of his duty to see that this law be faithfully execute
 i forbear to enter again upon any general discussion of the wisdom and necessity of the election law or of the dangerous and unconstitutional principle of this bill that the power vest in congress to originate appropriation involve the right to compel the executive to approve any legislation which congress may see fit to attach to such bill under the penalty of refuse the mean need to carry on essential function of the government my view on these subject have be sufficiently present in the special message send by i to the house of representatives during their present session what be say in those message i regard as conclusive as to my duty in respect to the bill before i the argument urge in those communication against the repeal of the election law and against the right of congress to deprive the executive of that separate and independent discretion and judgment which the constitution confer and require be equally cogent in opposition to this bill this measure leave the power and duty of the supervisor of election untouched the compensation of those officer be provide for under permanent law and no liability for which an appropriation be now require would therefore be incur by their appointment but the power of the national government to protect they in the discharge of their duty at the poll would be take away the states may employ both civil and military power at the election but by this bill even the civil authority to protect congressional election be deny to the united states the object be to prevent any adequate control by the united states over the national election by forbid the payment of deputy marshal the officer who be clothe with authority to enforce the election law
 the fact that these law be deem objectionable by a majority of both houses of congress be urge as a sufficient warrant for this legislation
 there be two lawful way to overturn legislative enactment one be their repeal the other be the decision of a competent tribunal against their validity the effect of this bill be to deprive the executive department of the government of the mean to execute law which be not repeal which have not be declare invalid and which it be therefore the duty of the executive and of every other department of government to obey and to enforce
 i have in my former message on this subject express a willingness to concur in suitable amendment for the improvement of the election law but i can not consent to their absolute and entire repeal and i can not approve legislation which seek to prevent their enforcement

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives the member of the forty sixth congress have assemble in their first regular session under circumstance call for mutual congratulation and last annual message to congress be connect with the financial operation of the government directly affect the business interest of the country i congratulate congress on the successful execution of the resumption act at the time fix and in the manner contemplate by law united states note begin to be redeem in coin since the 1st of january last they have be promptly redeem on presentation and in all business transaction public and private in all part of the country they be receive and pay out as the equivalent of coin the demand upon the treasury for gold and silver in exchange for united states note have be comparatively small and the voluntary deposit of coin and bullion in exchange for note have be very large the excess of the precious metal deposit or exchange for united states note over the amount of united states note redeem be about $ 40,000,000.the resumption of specie payment have be follow by a very great revival of business with a currency equivalent in value to the money of the commercial world we be enable to enter upon an equal competition with other nation in trade and production the increase foreign demand for our manufacture and agricultural product have the number of our citizen now hold the public security be much great than ever before the amount of the national debt which mature within less than two year be $ 792,121,700 of which $ 500,000,000 bear interest at the rate of 5 per cent and the balance be in bond bear 6 per cent interest it be believe that this part of the public debt can be refund by the issue of 4 per cent bond and by the legislation be require which it be hope will be provide by congress during its present session the coinage of gold by the mint of the united states during the last fiscal year be $ 40,986,912 the 32,300,506 be still in the possession of the government the pendency of the proposition for unity of action between the united states and the principal commercial nation of europe to effect a permanent system for the equality of gold and silver in the recognize money of the world lead i to recommend that congress refrain from new legislation on the general subject the great revival of trade internal and foreign will supply during the come year its own instruction which may well be await before attempt further experimental measure with the coinage i would however strongly urge upon less than the market value of the gold dollar it be obviously impracticable to maintain they at par with each other if both be coin without limit if the cheap coin be force into circulation it will if coin without limit soon become the sole standard of value and thus defeat the desire object which be a currency of both gold and silver which shall be of equivalent value dollar for dollar with the universally recognize money of the world the retirement from circulation of united states note with the capacity of legal tender in private contract be a step to be take in our progress toward a safe and stable currency which should be accept as the policy and duty of the government and the interest and security of the people it be my firm conviction that the issue of legal tender paper money base wholly upon the authority and credit of the government except in extreme emergency be without warrant in the constitution and a violation of sound financial principle the issue of united states note paper money for any protract period of time after the accomplishment of this purpose be not contemplate by the framer of the law under which they be issue they anticipate the redemption and withdrawal of these note at the early practicable period consistent with the attainment of the object for which they be provide the policy of the united states steadily adhere to from the adoption of the constitution have be to avoid the creation of a national debt and when from necessity in time of war debt have be create they have be pay off on the return of peace as rapidly as possible with this view and for this purpose it be recommend that the exist law for the accumulation of a sink fund sufficient to extinguish the public debt within a limited period be maintain if any change of the consumer and which will add several million of dollar annually to the treasury the continued deliberate violation by a large number of the prominent and influential citizen of the territory of utah of the law of the united states for the prosecution and punishment of polygamy demand the attention of every department of the government this territory have a population sufficient to entitle it to admission as a state and the general interest of the nation as well as the welfare of the citizen of the territory require its advance from the territorial form of government to the responsibility and privilege of a state this important change will not however be approve by the country while the citizen of utah in very considerable number uphold a practice which be condemn as a crime by the law of all civilized community throughout the world the law for the suppression of this offense be enact with great unanimity by congress more than seventeen year ago but have remain until recently a dead
