guaranty of religious freedom this objection be now remove the supreme court of the united states have decide the law to be within the legislative power of congress and bind as a rule of action for all who reside within the territories there be no long any reason for delay or hesitation in its enforcement it should be firmly and effectively execute if not sufficiently stringent in its provision it should be amend and in aid of the purpose in view i recommend that more comprehensive and more searching method for prevent as well as punish this crime be provide if necessary to secure obedience to the law the enjoyment and exercise of the right and privilege of citizenship in the territories of the united states may be withhold or withdraw from those who violate or oppose the enforcement of the law on this subject the election of the past year though occupy only with state officer have not fail to elicit in the political discussion which attend they all over the country new and decisive evidence of the deep interest which the great body of citizen take in the progress of the country toward a more general and complete establishment at whatever cost of universal security and freedom in the exercise of the elective franchise while many topic of political concern demand great attention from our people both in the sphere of national and state authority i find no reason to qualify the opinion i express in my last annual message that no temporary or administrative interest of government however urgent or weighty will ever displace the zeal of our people in defense of the primary right of citizenship and that the power of public opinion will override all political prejudice and all sectional and state attachment in demand that all over our wide territory the name and character of citizen of the united states shall mean one and the same thing and carry with they unchallenged security and respect i earnestly appeal to the intelligence and patriotism of all good citizen of every part of the country however much they maybe divide in opinion on other political subject to unite in compelling obedience to exist law aim at the protection of the right of suffrage i respectfully urge upon congress to supply any defect in these law which experience have show and which it be within its power to remedy i again invoke the cooperation of the executive and legislative authority of the states in this great purpose i be fully convinced that if the public mind can be set at rest on this paramount question of popular right no serious obstacle will thwart or delay the complete pacification of the country or retard the general diffusion of prosperity in a former message i invite the attention of congress to the subject of the reformation of the civil service of the government and express the intention of transmit to congress as early as practicable a report upon this subject by the chairman of the civil service commission in view of the fact that during a considerable period the government of great britain have be deal with administrative problem and abuse in various particular analogous to those present in this country and that in recent year the measure adopt be understand to have be effective and in every respect highly satisfactory i think it desirable to have full information upon the subject and accordingly request the chairman of the civil service commission to make a thorough investigation for this purpose the result have be an elaborate and comprehensive report the report set forth the history of the partisan spoil system in great britain and of the rise and fall of the parliamentary patronage and of official interference with the freedom of election it show that after long trial of various kind of examination those which be competitive and open on equal term to all and which be carry on under the superintendence of a single commission have with great advantage be establish as condition of admission to almost every official place in the subordinate administration of that country and of british india the completion of the report owe to the extent of the labor involve in its preparation and the omission of congress to make any provision either for the compensation or the expense of the commission have be postpone until the present time it be herewith transmit to congress while the reform measure of another government be of no authority for we they be entitle to influence to the extent to which their intrinsic wisdom and their adaptation to our institution and social life may commend they to our consideration the view i have heretofore express concern the defect and abuse in our civil administration remain unchanged except in so far as an enlarged experience have deepen my sense of the duty both of officer and of the people themselves to cooperate for their removal the grave evil and peril of a partisan spoil system of appointment to office and of office tenure be now generally recognize in the resolution of the great party in the report of departments in the debate and proceeding of congress in the message of executive the gravity of these evil have be point out and the need of their reform have be admit to command the necessary support every measure of reform must be base on common right and justice and must be compatible with the healthy existence of great party which be inevitable and essential in a free state when the people have approve a policy at a national election confidence on the part of the officer they have select and of the adviser who in accordance with our political institution should be consult in the policy which it be their duty to carry into effect be indispensable it be eminently proper that they should explain it before the people as well as illustrate its spirit in the performance of their official duty very different consideration apply to the great number of those who fill the subordinate place in the civil service their responsibility be to their superior in official position it be their duty to obey the legal instruction of those upon whom that authority be devolve and their good public service consist in the discharge of their function irrespective of partisan politic their duty be the same whatever party be in power and whatever policy prevail as a consequence it follow that their tenure of office should not depend on the prevalence of any policy or the supremacy of any party but should be determine by their capacity to serve the people most usefully quite irrespective of partisan interest the same consideration that should govern the tenure should also prevail in the appointment discipline and removal of these subordinate the authority of appointment and removal be not a perquisite which may be use to aid a friend or reward a partisan but be a trust to be exercise in the public interest under all the sanction which attend the obligation to apply the public fund only for public purpose every citizen have an equal right to the honor and profit of enter the public service of his country the only just ground of discrimination be the measure of character and capacity he have to make that service most useful to the people except in case where upon just and recognize principle as upon the theory of pension office and promotion be bestow as reward for past service their bestowal upon any theory which disregard personal merit be an act of injustice to the citizen as well as a breach of that trust subject to which the appointing power be hold in the light of these principle it become of great importance to provide just and adequate mean especially for every department and large administrative office where personal discrimination on the part of its head be not practicable for ascertain those qualification to which appointment and removal should have reference to fail to provide such mean be not only to deny the opportunity of ascertain the fact upon which the most righteous claim to office depend but of necessity to discourage all worthy aspirant by hand over appointment and removal to mere influence and favoritism if it be the right of the worthy claimant to gain the appointment and the interest of the people to bestow it upon he it would seem clear that a wise and just method of ascertain personal fitness for office must be an important and permanent function of every just and wise government it have long since become impossible in the great office for those have the duty of nomination and appointment to personally examine into the individual qualification of more than a small proportion of those seek office and with the enlargement of the civil service that proportion must continue to become less in the early year of the government the subordinate office be so few in number that it be quite easy for those make appointment and promotion to personally ascertain the merit of candidate party manager and method have not then become powerful agency of coercion hostile to the free and just exercise of the appoint power a large and responsible part of the duty of restore the civil service to the desire purity and efficiency rest upon the president and it be my purpose to do what be within my power to advance such prudent and gradual measure of reform as will most surely and rapidly bring about that radical change of system essential to make our accept theory of party and demand change in the method of departments be not the work of a day their permanent foundation must be lay in sound principle and in an experience which demonstrate their wisdom and expose the error of their adversary every worthy officer desire to make his official action a gain and an honor to his country but the people themselves far more than their officer in public station be interested in a pure economical and vigorous administration by law enact in 1853 and 1855 and now in substance incorporate in the revised statutes the practice of arbitrary appointment to the several subordinate grade in the great departments be condemn and examination as to capacity to be conduct by departmental board of examiner be provide for and make condition of examination in practice these examination have not always be open to worthy person generally who might wish to be examine official favoritism and partisan influence as a rule appear to have designate those who alone be permit to go before the examine board subject even the examiner to a pressure from the friend of the candidate very difficult to resist as a consequence the standard of admission service of the united states and promote the efficiency thereof give the necessary authority to the executive to inaugurate a civil service reform act under this statute which be interpret as intend to secure a system of just and effectual examination under uniform supervision a number of eminently competent person be select for the purpose who enter with zeal upon the discharge of their duty involve in discharge the duty of the commission the report be transmit to congress by special message of april 18 1874 with the follow favorable comment upon the labor of the commission if sustain by congress i have no doubt the rule can after the experience gain be so improved and enforce as to still more materially benefit the public service and relieve the executive member of congress and the executive departments in washington and in a number of the custom house and post office of the principal city of the country with a view to far test their effect and in every instance they have be find to be as salutary as they be state to have be under the administration of my predecessor i think the economy purity and efficiency of the public service would be greatly promote by their uniform justice report from the secretary of the interior from the postmaster general from the postmaster in the city of new york where such examination have be some time on trial and also from the collector of the port the naval officer and the surveyor in that city and from the postmaster and collector in several of the other large city show that the competitive system where apply have in various way contribute to improve the public service the report show that the result have be salutary in a marked degree and that the general application of similar rule can not fail to be of decide benefit to the service the report of the government officer in the city of new york especially bear decide testimony to the utility of open competitive examination in their respective office show that these examination and the excellent qualification of those admit to the service through they have have a marked incidental effect upon the person previously in the service and particularly upon those aspire to promotion there have be on the part of these latter an increase interest in the work and a desire to extend acquaintance with it beyond the particular desk occupy and thus the morale of the result and those visitor have without exception approve the method employ and several of they have publicly attest their favorable opinion upon such consideration i deem it my duty to renew the recommendation contain in my annual message of december 1877 request congress to make the necessary appropriation for the resumption of the work of the civil service commission economy will be promote by authorize a moderate compensation to person in the public service who may perform extra labor upon or under the commission as the executive may direct i be convinced that if a just and adequate test of merit be enforce for admission to the public service and in make promotion such abuse as removal without good cause and partisan and official interference with the proper exercise of the appoint power will in large measure disappear there be other administrative abuse to which the attention of congress should be ask in this connection mere partisan appointment and the constant peril of removal without cause very naturally lead to an absorbing and mischievous political activity on the part of those thus appoint which not only interfere with the due discharge of official duty but be incompatible with the freedom of election not without warrant in the view of several of my predecessor in the presidential office and directly within the law of 1871 already cite i endeavor by regulation make on the 22d day of june 1877 to put some reasonable limit to such abuse it may not be easy and it may never perhaps be necessary to define with precision the proper limit of political action on the part of federal officer but while their right to hold and freely express their opinion can not be question it be very plain that they should neither be allow to devote to other subject the time need for the proper discharge of their official duty nor to use the authority of their office to enforce their own opinion or to coerce the political action of those who hold different opinion reason of justice and public policy quite analogous to those which forbid the use of official power for the oppression of the private citizen impose upon the government the duty of protect its officer and agent from arbitrary exaction in whatever aspect consider the practice of make levy for party purpose upon the salary of officer be highly demoralize to the public service and discreditable to the country though an officer should be as free as any other citizen to give his own money in aid of his opinion or his party he should also be as free as any other citizen to refuse to make such gift if salary be but a fair compensation for the time and labor of the officer it be gross injustice to levy a tax upon they if they be make excessive in order that they may bear the tax the excess be an indirect robbery of the public fund i recommend therefore such a revision and extension of present statute as shall secure to those in every grade of official life or public to meet this urgent need a number of the building now use for school purpose be rent and be in important particular unsuited for the purpose the cause of popular education in the district of columbia be surely entitle to the same consideration at the hand of the national government as in the several states and territories to which munificent grant of the public land have be make for the endowment to the senate
 i transmit herewith the report of the secretary of state and the accompany paper in response to the resolution adopt by the senate on the 11th day of february last request copy of all correspondence between this government and any foreign government since february 1869 respect a ship canal across the isthmus between north america and south america together with copy of any projet of treaty respect the same which the department of state may have propose or submit since that date to any foreign power or its diplomatic representative
 in further compliance with the resolution of the senate i deem it proper to state briefly my opinion as to the policy of the united states with respect to the construction of an interoceanic canal by any route across the american isthmus
 the policy of this country be a canal under american control the united states can not consent to the surrender of this control to any european power or to any combination of european power if exist treaty between the united states and other nation or if the right of sovereignty or property of other nation stand in the way of this policy a contingency which be not apprehend suitable step should be take by just and liberal negotiation to promote and establish the american policy on this subject consistently with the right of the nation to be affect by it
 the capital invest by corporation or citizen of other country in such an enterprise must in a great degree look for protection to one or more of the great power of the world no european power can intervene for such protection without adopt measure on this continent which the united states would deem wholly inadmissible if the protection of the united states be rely upon the united states must exercise such control as will enable this country to protect its national interest and maintain the right of those whose private capital be embark in the work
 an interoceanic canal across the american isthmus will essentially change the geographical relation between the atlantic and pacific coast of the united states and between the united states and the rest of the world it would be the great ocean thoroughfare between our atlantic and our pacific shore and virtually a part of the coast line of the united states our merely commercial interest in it be great than that of all other country while its relation to our power and prosperity as a nation to our mean of defense our unity peace and safety be matter of paramount concern to the people of the united states no other great power would under similar circumstance fail to assert a rightful control over a work so closely and vitally affect its interest and welfare
 without urge far the ground of my opinion i repeat in conclusion that it be the right and the duty of the united states to assert and maintain such supervision and authority over any interoceanic canal across the isthmus that connect north and south america as will protect our national interest this i be quite sure will be find not only compatible with but promotive of the wide and most permanent advantage to commerce and civilization

to the senate of the united states
 after mature consideration of the bill entitle an act regulate the pay and appointment of deputy marshal i be constrain to withhold from it my approval and to return it to the senate in which it originate with my objection to its passage
 the law now in force on the subject of the bill before i be contain in the follow section of the revised statutes
 sec 2021 whenever an election at which representative or delegates in congress be to be choose be hold in any city or town of 20,000 inhabitant or upward the marshal for the district in which the city or town be situate shall on the application in writing of at least two citizen reside in such city or town appoint special deputy marshal whose duty it shall be when require thereto to aid and assist the supervisor of election in the verification of any list of person who may have register or vote to attend in each election district or voting precinct at the time and place fix for the registration of voter and at all time or place when and where the registration may by law be scrutinize and the name of register voter be mark for challenge and also to attend at all time for hold election the poll in such district or precinct
 sec 2022 the marshal and his general deputy and such special deputy shall keep the peace and support and protect the supervisor of election in the discharge of their duty preserve order at such place of registration and at such poll prevent fraudulent registration and fraudulent voting thereat or fraudulent conduct on the part of any officer of election and immediately either at the place of registration or polling place or elsewhere and either before or after register or voting to arrest and take into custody with or without process any person who commits or attempt or offer to commit any of the act or offense prohibit herein or who commit any offense against the law of the united states but no person shall be arrest without process for any offense not commit in the presence of the marshal or his general or special deputy or either of they or of the supervisor of election or either of they and for the purpose of arrest or the preservation of the peace the supervisor of election shall in the absence of the marshal&#39; deputy or if require to assist such deputy have the same duty and power as deputy marshal nor shall any person on the day of such election be arrest without process for any offense commit on the day of registration
 sec 2023 whenever any arrest be make under any provision of this title the person so arrest shall forthwith be bring before a commissioner judge or court of the united states for examination of the offense allege against he and such commissioner judge or court shall proceed in respect thereto as authorize by law in case of crime against the united states
 sec 2024 the marshal or his general deputy or such special deputy as be thereto specially empower by he in writing and under his hand and seal whenever he or either or any of they be forcibly resist in execute their duty under this title or shall by violence threat or menace be prevent from execute such duty or from arrest any person who have commit any offense for which the marshal or his general or his special deputy be authorize to make such arrest be and each of they be empower to summon and call to his aid the bystander or posse comitatus of his district
 sec 2028 no person shall be appoint a supervisor of election or a deputy marshal under the precede provision who be not at the time of his appointment a qualified voter of the city town county parish election district or voting precinct in which his duty be to be perform
 sec 5521 if any person be appoint a supervisor of election or a special deputy marshal under the provision of title the elective franchise and have take the oath of office as such supervisor of election or such special deputy marshal and thereafter neglect or refuse without good and lawful excuse to perform and discharge fully the duty obligation and requirement of such office until the expiration of the term for which he be appoint he shall not only be subject to removal from office with loss of all pay or emolument but shall be punish by imprisonment for not less than six month nor more than one year or by a fine of not less than $ 200 and not more than $ 500 or by both fine and imprisonment and shall pay the cost of prosecution
 sec 5522 every person whether with or without any authority power or process or pretended authority power or process of any state territory or municipality who obstruct hinder assault or by bribery solicitation or otherwise interfere with or prevent the supervisor of election or either of they or the marshal of his general or special deputy or either of they in the performance of any duty require of they or either of they or which he or they or either of they may be authorize to perform by any law of the united states in the execution of process or otherwise or who by any of the mean before mention hinder or prevent the free attendance and presence at such place of registration or at such poll of election or full and free access and egress to and from any such place of registration or poll of election or in go to and from any such place of registration or poll of election or to and from any room where any such registration or election or canvass of vote or of make any return or certificate thereof may be have or who molest interfere with remove or eject from any such place of registration or poll of election or of canvass vote cast thereat or of make return or certificate thereof any supervisor of election the marshal or his general or special deputy or either of they or who threaten or attempt or offer so to do or refuse or neglect to aid and assist any supervisor of election or the marshal or his general or special deputy or either of they in the performance of his or their duty when require by he or they or either of they to give such aid and assistance shall be liable to instant arrest without process and shall be punish by imprisonment not more than two year or by a fine of not more than $ 3,000 or by both such fine and imprisonment and shall pay the cost of the prosecution
 the supreme court of the united states in the recent case of ex parte siebold and other decide at the october term 1879 on the question raise in the case as to the constitutionality of the section of the revised statutes above quote use the follow language
 these portion of the revised statutes be take from the act commonly know as the enforcement act approve may 31 1870 and entitle an act to enforce the right of citizen of the united states to vote in the several states of this union and for other purpose and from the supplement to that act approve february 28 1871 they relate to election of member of the house of representatives and be an assertion on the part of congress of a power to pass law for regulate and superintending say election and for secure the purity thereof and the right of citizen to vote thereat peaceably and without molestation
 it must be concede to be a most important power and of a fundamental character in the light of recent history and of the violence fraud corruption and irregularity which have frequently prevail at such election it may easily be conceive that the exertion of the power if it exist may be necessary to the stability of our form of government
 the great difficulty in come to a just conclusion arise from mistaken notion with regard to the relation which subsist between the state and national governments
 it seem to be often overlook that a national constitution have be adopt in this country establish a real government therein operate upon person and territory and thing and which moreover be or should be as dear to every american citizen as his state government be whenever the true conception of the nature of this government be once concede no real difficulty will arise in the just interpretation of its power but if we allow ourselves to regard it as a hostile organization oppose to the proper sovereignty and dignity of the state government we shall continue to be vex with difficulty as to its jurisdiction and authority no great jealousy be require to be exercise toward this government in reference to the preservation of our liberty than be proper to be exercise toward the state government its power be limit in number and clearly define and its action within the scope of those power be restrain by a sufficiently rigid bill of right for the protection of its citizen from oppression the true interest of the people of this country require that both the national and state government should be allow without jealous interference on either side to exercise all the power which respectively belong to they accord to a fair and practical construction of the constitution state right and the right of the united states should be equally respect both be essential to the preservation of our liberty and the perpetuity of our institution but in endeavor to vindicate the one we should not allow our zeal to nullify or impair the other
 the true doctrine as we conceive be this that while the states be really sovereign as to all matter which have not be grant to the jurisdiction and control of the united states the constitution and constitutional law of the latter be as we have already say the supreme law of the land and when they conflict with the law of the states they be of paramount authority and obligation this be the fundamental principle on which the authority of the constitution be base and unless it be concede in practice as well as theory the fabric of our institution as it be contemplate by its founder can not stand the question involve have respect not more to the autonomy and existence of the states than to the continued existence of the united states as a government to which every american citizen may look for security and protection in every part of the land
 why do we have marshal at all if they can not physically lay their hand on person and thing in the performance of their proper duty what function can they perform if they can not use force in execute the process of the court must they call on the near constable for protection must they rely on he to use the requisite compulsion and to keep the peace while they be solicit and entreat the party and bystander to allow the law to take its course this be the necessary consequence of the position that be assume if we indulge in such impracticable view as these and keep on refining and re refining we shall drive the national government out of the united states and relegate it to the district of columbia or perhaps to some foreign soil we shall bring it back to a condition of great helplessness than that of the old confederation
 the argument be base on a strained and impracticable view of the nature and power of the national government it must execute its power or it be no government it must execute they on the land as well as on the sea on thing as well as on person and to do this it must necessarily have power to command obedience preserve order and keep the peace and no person or power in this land have the right to resist or question its authority so long as it keep within the bound of its jurisdiction
 i have deem it fitting and proper to quote thus largely from an important and elaborate opinion of the supreme court because the bill before i proceed upon a construction of the constitution as to the power of the national government which be in direct conflict with the judgment of the high judicial tribunal of our country
 under the section of the present law above quote officer of the united states be authorize and it be their duty in the case of congressional election to keep the peace at the poll and at the place of registration to arrest immediately any person who be guilty of crime against the united states election law to protect all officer of election in the performance of their duty and whenever an arrest be make to bring the person so arrest before a commissioner judge or court of the united states for examination of the offense allege against he such special deputy marshal as be specially empower thereto by the marshal in writing if forcibly resist may call to their aid the bystander or posse comitatus it be make a crime punishable with fine or imprisonment to hinder assault or otherwise interfere with the marshal or his special deputy or to threaten or to attempt so to do if any person appoint such special deputy marshal have take the oath of office and thereafter neglect or refuse to fully discharge the duty of such office he be punishable not only by removal from office but by fine and imprisonment the function of the special deputy marshal now provide for by law be executive they be place under the authority of the well know chief executive officer of the court of the united states they be in fact and not merely in name the deputy of the marshal and he and his bondsman be responsible for they a civil force for the execution of the law be thus institute in accordance with long establish and familiar usage which be simple effective and under a responsible head the necessity for the possession of these power by appropriate officer will not be call in question by intelligent citizen who appreciate the importance of peaceable orderly and lawful election similar power be confer and exercise under state law with respect to state election the executive officer of the united states under the exist law have no other or great power to supervise and control the conduct of the congressional election than the state executive officer exercise in regard to state election
 the bill before i change completely the present law by substitute for the special deputy marshal of the exist statute new officer hitherto unknown to the law and who lack the power responsibility and protection which be essential to enable they to act efficiently as executive officer
 the bill under consideration be as follow
 be it enact by the senate and house of representatives of the united states america in congress assemble that from and after the passage of this act the pay of all deputy marshal for service in reference to any election shall be $ 5 for each day of actual service and no more
 sec 2 that all deputy marshal to serve in reference to any election shall be appoint by the circuit court of the united states for the district in which such marshal be to perform their duty in each year and the judge of the several circuit court of the united states be hereby authorize to open their respective court at any time for that purpose and in case the circuit court shall not be open for that purpose at least ten day prior to a registration if there be one or if no registration be require then at east ten day before such election the judge of the district court of the united states be hereby respectively authorize to cause their court to be open for the purpose of appoint such deputy marshal who shall be appoint by the say district court and the officer so appoint shall be in equal number from the different political party and shall be well know citizen of good moral character and actual resident of the voting precinct in which their duty be to be perform and shall not be candidate for any office at such election and all law and part of law inconsistent with this act be hereby repeal provide that the marshal of the united states for whom deputy shall be appoint by the court under this act shall not be liable for any of the act of such deputy
 it will be observe that the deputy marshal propose by the bill before i be distinctly different officer from the special deputy of the marshal as such officer be now provide for in the statute this bill do not connect the new officer with the exist law relate to special deputy marshal so as to invest the propose deputy marshal with the same power to impose upon they the same duty and to give they the same protection by mean of the criminal law when new officer be create distinct in character and appoint by different authority although similar in name to officer already provide for such officer be not hold by similar responsibility to the criminal law do not possess the same power and be not similarly protect unless it be expressly so provide by legislation
 the so call deputy marshal provide for in this bill will have no executive head the marshal can neither appoint nor remove they he can not control they and he be not responsible for they they will have no authority to call to their aid if resist the posse comitatus they be protect by no criminal statute in the performance of their duty an assault upon one of these deputy with the intent to prevent a lawful election will be no more than an ordinary assault upon any other citizen they can not keep the peace they can not make arrest when crime be commit in their presence whatever power they have be confine to the precinct in which they reside outside of the precinct for which they be appoint the deputy marshal of this bill can not keep the peace make arrest hold prisoner take prisoner before a proper tribunal for hearing nor perform any other duty no oath of office be require of they and they give no bond they have no superior who be responsible for they and they be not punishable for neglect of duty or misconduct in office in all these respect this bill make a radical change between the power of the united states officer at national election and the power uniformly possess and exercise by state officer at state election this discrimination against the authority of the united states be a departure from the usage of the government establish by precedent begin with the early statute on the subject and violate the true principle of the constitution the supreme court in the decision already refer to say
 it be argue that the preservation of peace and good order in society be not within the power confide to the government of the united states but belong exclusively to the states here again we be meet with the theory that the government of the united states do not rest upon the soil and territory of the country we think that this theory be found on an entire misconception of the nature and power of that government we hold it to be an incontrovertible principle that the government of the united states may by mean of physical force exercise through its official agent execute on every foot of american soil the power and function that belong to it this necessarily involve the power to command obedience to its law and hence the power to keep the peace to that extent
 this power to enforce its law and to execute its function in all place do not derogate from the power of the state to execute its law at the same time and in the same place the one do not exclude the other except where both can not be execute at the same time in that case the word of the constitution itself show which be to yield this constitution and all law which shall be make in pursuance thereof shall be the supreme law of the land
 in conclusion it be proper to say that no objection would be make to the appointment of officer to act with reference to the election by the court of the united states and that i be in favor of appoint officer to supervise and protect the election without regard to party but the bill before i while it recognize the power and duty of the united states to provide officer to guard and scrutinize the congressional election fail to adapt its provision to the exist law so as to secure efficient supervision and protection it be therefore return to the senate in which it originate for that further consideration which be contemplate by the constitution

i congratulate you on the continued and increase prosperity of our country by the favor of divine providence we have be bless during the past year with health with abundant harvest with profitable employment for all our people and with contentment at home and with peace and friendship with other nation the occurrence of the twenty fourth election of chief magistrate have afford another opportunity to the people of the united states to exhibit to the world a significant example of the peaceful and safe transmission of the power and authority of government from the public servant whose term of office be about to expire to their newly choose successor this example can not fail to impress profoundly thoughtful people of other country with the advantage which republican institution afford the immediate general and cheerful acquiescence of all good citizen in the result of the election give gratify assurance to our country and to its friend throughout the world that a government base on the free consent of an intelligent and patriotic people possess element of strength stability and permanency not find in any other form of government

 continue opposition to the full and free enjoyment of the right of citizenship confer upon the colored people by the recent amendment to the constitution still prevail in several of the late slaveholding state it have perhaps not be manifest in the recent election to any large extent in act of violence or intimidation it have however by fraudulent practice in connection with the ballot with the regulation as to the place and manner of voting and with counting return and canvass the vote cast be successful in defeat the exercise of the right preservative of all rights&mdash;the right of suffrage&mdash;which the constitution expressly confer upon our enfranchised citizen

 it be the desire of the good people of the whole country that sectionalism as a factor in our politic should disappear they prefer that no section of the country should be unite in solid opposition to any other section the disposition to refuse a prompt and hearty obedience to the equal right amendment to the constitution be all that now stand in the way of a complete obliteration of sectional line in our political contest as long as either of these amendment be flagrantly violate or disregard it be safe to assume that the people who place they in the constitution as embody the legitimate result of the war for the union and who believe they to be wise and necessary will continue to act together and to insist that they shall be obey the paramount question still be as to the enjoyment of the fight by every american citizen who have the requisite qualification to freely cast his vote and to have it honestly count with this question rightly settle the country will be relieve of the contention of the past bygone will indeed be bygone and political and party issue with respect to economy and efficiency of administration internal improvement the tariff domestic taxation education finance and other important subject will then receive their full share of attention but resistance to and nullification of the result of the war will unite together in resolute purpose for their support all who maintain the authority of the government and the perpetuity of the union and who adequately appreciate the value of the victory achieve this determination proceed from no hostile sentiment or feel to any part of the people of our country or to any of their interest the inviolability of the amendment rest upon the fundamental principle of our government they be the solemn expression of the will of the people of the united states

 the sentiment that the constitutional right of all our citizen must be maintain do not grow weak it will continue to control the government of the country happily the history of the late election show that in many part of the country where opposition to the fifteenth amendment have heretofore prevail it be diminish and be likely to cease altogether if firm and well consider action be take by congress i trust the house of representatives and the senate which have the right to judge of the election return and qualification of their own member will see to it that every case of violation of the letter or spirit of the fifteenth amendment be thoroughly investigate and that no benefit from such violation shall accrue to any person or party it will be the duty of the executive with sufficient appropriation for the purpose to prosecute unsparingly all who have be engage in deprive citizen of the right guarantee to they by the constitution

 it be not however to be forget that the good and sure guaranty of the primary right of citizenship be to be find in that capacity for self protection which can belong only to a people whose right to universal suffrage be support by universal education the mean at the command of the local and state authority be in many case wholly inadequate to furnish free instruction to all who need it this be especially true where before emancipation the education of the people be neglect or prevent in the interest of slavery firmly convinced that the subject of popular education deserve the earnest attention of the people of the whole country with a view to wise and comprehensive action by the government of the united states i respectfully recommend that congress by suitable legislation and with proper safeguard supplement the local educational fund in the several states where the grave duty and responsibility of citizenship have be devolve on uneducated people by devote to the purpose grant of the public land and if necessary by appropriation from the treasury of the united states whatever government can fairly do to promote free popular education ought to be do wherever general education be find peace virtue and social order prevail and civil and religious liberty be secure

 in my former annual message i have ask the attention of congress to the urgent necessity of a reformation of the civil service system of the government my view concern the danger of patronage or appointment for personal or partisan consideration have be strengthen by my observation and experience in the executive office and i believe these danger threaten the stability of the government abuse so serious in their nature can not be permanently tolerate they tend to become more alarming with the enlargement of administrative service as the growth of the country in population increase the number of officer and placeman employ

 the reason be imperative for the adoption of fix rule for the regulation of appointment promotion and removal establish a uniform method have exclusively in view in every instance the attainment of the good qualification for the position in question such a method alone be consistent with the equal right of all citizen and the most economical and efficient administration of the public business

 competitive examination in aid of impartial appointment and promotion have be conduct for some year past in several of the executive departments and by my direction this system have be adopt in the custom house and post office of the large city of the country in the city of new york over 2,000 position in the civil service have be subject in their appointment and tenure of place to the operation of publish rule for this purpose during the past two year the result of these practical trial have be very satisfactory and have confirm my opinion in favor of this system of selection all be subject to the same test and the result be free from prejudice by personal favor or partisan influence it secure for the position apply for the good qualification attainable among the compete applicant it be an effectual protection from the pressure of importunity which under any other course pursue largely exact the time and attention of appoint officer to their great detriment in the discharge of other official duty prevent the abuse of the service for the mere furtherance of private or party purpose and leave the employee of the government free from the obligation impose by patronage to depend solely upon merit for retention and advancement and with this constant incentive to exertion and improvement

 these invaluable result have be attain in a high degree in the office where the rule for appointment by competitive examination have be apply

 a method which have so approve itself by experimental test at point where such test may be fairly consider conclusive should be extend to all subordinate position under the government i believe that a strong and grow public sentiment demand immediate measure for securing and enforce the high possible efficiency in the civil service and its protection from recognize abuse and that the experience refer to have demonstrate the feasibility of such measure

 the examination in the custom house and post office have be hold under many embarrassment and without provision for compensation for the extra labor perform by the officer who have conduct they and whose commendable interest in the improvement of the public service have induce this devotion of time and labor without pecuniary reward a continuance of these labor gratuitously ought not to be expect and without an appropriation by congress for compensation it be not practicable to extend the system of examination generally throughout the civil service it be also highly important that all such examination should be conduct upon a uniform system and under general supervision section 1753 of the revised statutes authorize the president to prescribe the regulation for admission to the civil service of the united states and for this purpose to employ suitable person to conduct the requisite inquiry with reference to the fitness of each candidate in respect to age health character knowledge and ability for the branch of service into which he seek to enter but the law be practically inoperative for want of the requisite appropriation

 i therefore recommend an appropriation of $ 25,000 per annum to meet the expense of a commission to be appoint by the president in accordance with the term of this section whose duty it shall be to devise a just uniform and efficient system of competitive examination and to supervise the application of the same throughout the entire civil service of the government i be persuade that the facility which such a commission will afford for test the fitness of those who apply for office will not only be as welcome a relief to member of congress as it will be to the president and head of departments but that it will also greatly tend to remove the cause of embarrassment which now inevitably and constantly attend the conflict claim of patronage between the legislative and executive department the most effectual check upon the pernicious competition of influence and official favoritism in the bestowal of office will be the substitution of an open competition of merit between the applicant in which everyone can make his own record with the assurance that his success will depend upon this alone

 i also recommend such legislation as while leave every officer as free as any other citizen to express his political opinion and to use his mean for their advancement shall also enable he to feel as safe as any private citizen in refuse all demand upon his salary for political purpose a law which should thus guarantee true liberty and justice to all who be engage in the public service and likewise contain stringent provision against the use of official authority to coerce the political action of private citizen or of official subordinate be greatly to be desire

 the most serious obstacle however to an improvement of the civil service and especially to a reform in the method of appointment and removal have be find to be the practice under what be know as the spoil system by which the appointing power have be so largely encroach upon by member of congress the first step in the reform of the civil service must be a complete divorce between congress and the executive in the matter of appointment the corrupting doctrine that to the victor belong the spoil be inseparable from congressional patronage as the establish rule and practice of party in power it come to be understand by applicant for office and by the people generally that representatives and senators be entitle to disburse the patronage of their respective district and state it be not necessary to recite at length the evil result from this invasion of the executive function the true principle of government on the subject of appointment to office as state in the national convention of the lead party of the country have again and again be approve by the american people and have not be call in question in any quarter these authentic expression of public opinion upon this all important subject be the statement of principle that belong to the constitutional structure of the government

 under the constitution the president and head of departments be to make nomination for office the senate be to advise and consent to appointment and the house of representatives be to accuse and prosecute faithless officer the good interest of the public service demand that these distinction be respect that senators and representatives who may be judge and accuser should not dictate appointment to office
 to this end the cooperation of the legislative department of the government be require alike by the necessity of the case and by public opinion member of congress will not be relieve from the demand make upon they with reference to appointment to office until by legislative enactment the pernicious practice be condemn and forbid

 it be therefore recommend that an act be pass define the relation of member of congress with respect to appointment to office by the president and i also recommend that the provision of section 1767 and of the section follow of the revised statutes comprise the tenure of office act of march 2 1867 be repeal

 believe that to reform the system and method of the civil service in our country be one of the high and most imperative duty of statesmanship and that it can be permanently do only by the cooperation of the legislative and executive department of the government i again commend the whole subject to your considerate attention

 it be the recognize duty and purpose of the people of the united states to suppress polygamy where it now exist in our territories and to prevent its extension faithful and zealous effort have be make by the united states authority in utah to enforce the law against it experience have show that the legislation upon this subject to be effective require extensive modification and amendment the long action be delay the more difficult it will be to accomplish what be desire prompt and decide measure be necessary the mormon sectarian organization which uphold polygamy have the whole power of make and execute the local legislation of the territory by its control of the grand and petit jury it possess large influence over the administration of justice exercise as the head of this sect do the local political power of the territory they be able to make effective their hostility to the law of congress on the subject of polygamy and in fact do prevent its enforcement polygamy will not be abolish if the enforcement of the law depend on those who practice and uphold the crime it can only be suppress by take away the political power of the sect which encourage and sustain it

 the power of congress to enact suitable law to protect the territories be ample it be not a case for halfway measure the political power of the mormon sect be increase it control now one of our wealthy and most populous territories it be extend steadily into other territories wherever it go it establish polygamy and sectarian political power the sanctity of marriage and the family relation be the corner stone of our american society and civilization religious liberty and the separation of church and state be among the elementary idea of free institution to reestablish the interest and principle which polygamy and mormonism have imperil and to fully reopen to intelligent and virtuous immigrant of all creed that part of our domain which have be in a great degree close to general immigration by intolerant and immoral institution it be recommend that the government of the territory of utah be reorganize

 i recommend that congress provide for the government of utah by a governor and judge or commissioner appoint by the president and confirm by the senate&mdash;a government analogous to the provisional government establish for the territory northwest of the ohio by the ordinance of 1787 if however it be deem good to continue the exist form of local government i recommend that the right to vote hold office and sit on jury in the territory of utah be confine to those who neither practice nor uphold polygamy if thorough measure be adopt it be believe that within a few year the evil which now afflict utah will be eradicate and that this territory will in good time become one of the most prosperous and attractive of the new states of the union

 our relation with all foreign country have be those of undisturbed peace and have present no occasion for concern as to their continued maintenance

 my anticipation of an early reply from the british government to the demand of indemnity to our fisherman for the injury suffer by that industry at fortune bay in january 1878 which i express in my last annual message be disappoint this answer be receive only in the latter part of april in the present year and when received exhibit a failure of accord between the two government as to the measure of the inshore fishing privilege secure to our fisherman by the treaty of washington of so serious a character that i make it the subject of a communication to congress in which i recommend the adoption of the measure which seem to i proper to be take by this government in maintenance of the right accord to our fisherman under the treaty and toward secure an indemnity for the injury these interest have suffer a bill to carry out these recommendation be under consideration by the house of representatives at the time of the adjournment of congress in june last

 within a few week i have receive a communication from her majesty&#39;s government renew the consideration of the subject both of the indemnity for the injury at fortune bay and of the interpretation of the treaty in which the previous correspondence have show the two government to be at variance upon both these topic the disposition toward a friendly agreement be manifest by a recognition of our right to an indemnity for the transaction at fortune bay leave the measure of such indemnity to further conference and by an assent to the view of this government present in the previous correspondence that the regulation of conflict interest of the shore fishery of the provincial seacoast and the vessel fishery of our fisherman should be make the subject of conference and concurrent arrangement between the two government

 i sincerely hope that the basis may be find for a speedy adjustment of the very serious divergence of view in the interpretation of the fishery clause of the treaty of washington which as the correspondence between the two government stand at the close of the last session of congress seem to be irreconcilable

 the relation between this government and that of the united states of colombia have engage public attention during the past year mainly by reason of the project of an interoceanic canal across the isthmus of panama to be build by private capital under a concession from the colombian government for that purpose the treaty obligation subsist between the united states and colombia by which we guarantee the neutrality of the transit and the sovereignty and property of colombia in the isthmus make it necessary that the condition under which so stupendous a change in the region embrace in this guaranty should be effected&mdash;transforming as it would this isthmus from a barrier between the atlantic and pacific ocean into a gateway and thoroughfare between they for the navy and the merchant ship of the world&mdash;should receive the approval of this government as be compatible with the discharge of these obligation on our part and consistent with our interest as the principal commercial power of the western hemisphere the view which i express in a special message to congress in march last in relation to this project i deem it my duty again to press upon your attention subsequent consideration have but confirm the opinion that it be the right and duty of the united states to assert and maintain such supervision and authority over any interoceanic canal across the isthmus that connect north and south america as will protect our national interest

 the effort of the department of state to enlarge the trade and commerce of the united states through the active agency of consular officer and through the dissemination of information obtain from they have be unrelaxed the interest in these effort as develop in our commercial community and the value of the information secure by this mean to the trade and manufacture of the country be recognize by congress at its last session and provision be make for the more frequent publication of consular and other report by the department of state the first issue of this publication have now be prepare and subsequent issue may regularly be expect the importance and interest attach to the report of consular officer be witness by the general demand for they by all class of merchant and manufacturer engage in our foreign trade it be believe that the system of such publication be deserve of the approval of congress and that the necessary appropriation for its continuance and enlargement will commend itself to your consideration

 the prosperous energy of our domestic industry and their immense production of the subject of foreign commerce invite and even require an active development of the wish and interest of our people in that direction especially important be it that our commercial relation with the atlantic and pacific coast of south america with the west indies and the gulf of mexico should be direct and not through the circuit of european system and should be carry on in our own bottom the full appreciation of the opportunity which our front on the pacific ocean give to commerce with japan china and the east indies with australia and the island group which lie along these route of navigation should inspire equal effort to appropriate to our own shipping and to administer by our own capital a due proportion of this trade whatever modification of our regulation of trade and navigation may be necessary or useful to meet and direct these impulse to the enlargement of our exchange and of our carry trade i be sure the wisdom of congress will be ready to supply one initial measure however seem to i so dearly useful and efficient that i venture to press it upon your earnest attention it seem to be very evident that the provision of regular steam postal communication by aid from government have be the forerunner of the commercial predominance of great britain on all these coast and sea a great share in whose trade be now the desire and the intent of our people it be also manifest that the effort of other european nation to contend with great britain for a share of this commerce have be successful in proportion with their adoption of regular steam postal communication with the market whose trade they seek mexico and the states of south america be anxious to receive such postal communication with this country and to aid in their development similar cooperation may be look for in due time from the eastern nation and from australia it be difficult to see how the lead in this movement can be expect from private interest in respect of foreign commerce quite as much as in internal trade postal communication seem necessarily a matter of common and public administration and thus pertain to government i respectfully recommend to your prompt attention such just and efficient measure as may conduce to the development of our foreign commercial exchange and the building up of our carry trade

 in this connection i desire also to suggest the very great service which might be expect in enlarge and facilitate our commerce on the pacific ocean be a transmarine cable lay from san francisco to the sandwich islands and thence to japan at the north and australia at the south the great influence of such mean of communication on these route of navigation in develop and secure the due share of our pacific coast in the commerce of the world need no illustration or enforcement it may be that such an enterprise useful and in the end profitable as it would prove to private investment may need to be accelerate by prudent legislation by congress in its aid and i submit the matter to your careful consideration

 an additional and not unimportant although secondary reason for foster and enlarge the navy may be find in the unquestionable service to the expansion of our commerce which would be render by the frequent circulation of naval ship in the sea and port of all quarter of the globe ship of the proper construction and equipment to be of the great efficiency in case of maritime war might be make constant and active agent in time of peace in the advancement and protection of our foreign trade and in the nurture and discipline of young seaman who would naturally in some number mix with and improve the crew of our merchant ship our merchant at home and abroad recognize the value to foreign commerce of an active movement of our naval vessel and the intelligence and patriotic zeal of our naval officer in promote every interest of their countryman be a just subject of national pride

 the condition of the financial affair of the government as show by the report of the secretary of the treasury be very satisfactory it be believe that the present financial situation of the united states whether consider with respect to trade currency credit grow wealth or the extent and variety of our resource be more favorable than that of any other country of our time and have never be surpass by that of any country at any period of its history all our industry be thrive the rate of interest be low new railroad be be construct a vast immigration be increase our population capital and labor new enterprise in great number be in progress and our commercial relation with other country be improve

 it be fortunate that this large surplus revenue occur at a period when it may be directly apply to the payment of the public debt soon to be redeemable no public duty have be more constantly cherish in the united states than the policy of pay the nation&#39;s debt as rapidly as possible

 the debt of the united states less cash in the treasury and exclusive of accruing interest attain its maximum of $ 2,756,431,571.43 in august 1865 and have since that time be reduce to $ 1,886,019,504.65 of the principal of the debt $ 108,758,100 have be pay since march 1 1877 effect an annual saving of interest of $ 6,107,593 the burden of interest have also be diminish by the sale of bond bear a low rate of interest and the application of the proceed to the redemption of bond bear a high rate the annual saving thus secure since march 1 1877 be $ 14,290,453.50 within a short period over six hundred million of 5 and 6 per cent bond will become redeemable this present a very favorable opportunity not only to far reduce the principal of the debt but also to reduce the rate of interest on that which will remain unpaid i call the attention of congress to the view express on this subject by the secretary of the treasury in his annual report and recommend prompt legislation to enable the treasury department to complete the refunding of the debt which be about to mature

 the continuance of specie payment have not be interrupt or endanger since the date of resumption it have contribute greatly to the revival of business and to our remarkable prosperity the fear that precede and accompanied resumption have prove groundless no considerable amount of united states note have be present for redemption while very large sum of gold bullion both domestic and import be take to the mint and exchange for coin or note the increase of coin and bullion in the united states since january 1 1879 be estimate at $ 227,399,428

 there be still in existence uncanceled $ 346,681,016 of united states legal tender note these note be authorize as a war measure make necessary by the exigency of the conflict in which the united states be then engage the preservation of the nation&#39;s existence require in the judgment of congress an issue of legal tender paper money that it serve well the purpose for which it be create be not question but the employment of the note as paper money indefinitely after the accomplishment of the object for which they be provide be not contemplate by the framer of the law under which they be issue these note long since became like any other pecuniary obligation of the government a debt to be pay and when pay to be cancel as mere evidence of an indebtedness no long exist i therefore repeat what be say in the annual message of last year that the retirement from circulation of united states note with the capacity of legal tender in private contract be a step to be take in our progress toward a safe and stable currency which should be accept as the policy and duty of the government and the interest and security of the people

 at the time of the passage of the act now in force require the coin age of silver dollar fix their value and give they legal tender character it be believe by many of the supporter of the measure that the silver dollar which it authorize would speedily become under the operation of the law of equivalent value to the gold dollar there be other supporter of the bill who while they doubt as to the probability of this result nevertheless be willing to give the propose experiment a fair trial with a view to stop the coinage if experience should prove that the silver dollar authorize by the bill continue to be of less commercial value than the standard gold dollar

 the coinage of silver dollar under the act refer to begin in march 1878 and have be continue as require by the act the average rate per month to the present time have be $ 2,276,492 the total amount coin prior to the 1st of november last be $ 72,847,750 of this amount $ 47,084,450 remain in the treasury and only $ 25,763,291 be in the hand of the people a constant effort have be make to keep this currency in circulation and considerable expense have be necessarily incur for this purpose but its return to the treasury be prompt and sure contrary to the confident anticipation of the friend of the measure at the time of its adoption the value of the silver dollar contain 412 1/2 grain of silver have not increase during the year prior to the passage of the bill authorize its coinage the market value of the silver which it contain be from 90 to 92 cent as compare with the standard gold dollar during the last year the average market value of the silver dollar have be 88 1/2 cent

 it be obvious that the legislation of the last congress in regard to silver so far as it be base on an anticipated rise in the value of silver as a result of that legislation have fail to produce the effect then predict the long the law remain in force require as it do the coinage of a nominal dollar which in reality be not a dollar the great become the danger that this country will be force to accept a single metal as the sole legal standard of value in circulation and this a standard of less value than it purport to be worth in the recognize money of the world

 the constitution of the united states sound financial principle and our good interest all require that the country should have as its legal tender money both gold and silver coin of an intrinsic value as bullion equivalent to that which upon its face it purport to possess the constitution in express term recognize both gold and silver as the only true legal tender money to banish either of these metal from our currency be to narrow and limit the circulate medium of exchange to the disparagement of important interest the united states produce more silver than any other country and be directly interested in maintain it as one of the two precious metal which furnish the coinage of the world it will in my judgment contribute to this result if congress will repeal so much of exist legislation as require the coinage of silver dollar contain only 412 1/2 grain of silver and in its stead will authorize the secretary of the treasury to coin silver dollar of equivalent value as bullion with gold dollar this will defraud no man and will be in accordance with familiar precedent congress on several occasion have alter the ratio of value between gold and silver in order to establish it more nearly in accordance with the actual ratio of value between the two metal

 in financial legislation every measure in the direction of great fidelity in the discharge of pecuniary obligation have be find by experience to diminish the rate of interest which debtor be require to pay and to increase the facility with which money can be obtain for every legitimate purpose our own recent financial history show how surely money become abundant whenever confidence in the exact performance of moneyed obligation be establish

 the secretary of war report that the expenditure of the war department for the fiscal year end june 30 1880 be $ 39,924,773.03 the appropriation for this department for the current fiscal year amount to $ 41,993,630.40

 with respect to the army the secretary invite attention to the fact that its strength be limit by statute u. s. revised statutes sec 1115 to not more than 30,000 enlisted man but that provisos contain in appropriation bill have limit expenditure to the enlistment of but 25,000 it be believe the full legal strength be the least possible force at which the present organization can be maintain have in view efficiency discipline and economy while the enlistment of this force would add somewhat to the appropriation for pay of the army the saving make in other respect would be more than an equivalent for this additional outlay and the efficiency of the army would be largely increase

 the rapid extension of the railroad system west of the mississippi river and the great tide of settler which have flow in upon new territory impose on the military an entire change of policy the maintenance of small post along wagon and stage route of travel be no long necessary permanent quarter at point select of a more substantial character than those heretofore construct will be require under exist law permanent building can not be erect without the sanction of congress and when sale of military site and building have be authorize the money receive have revert to the treasury and could only become available through a new appropriation it be recommend that provision be make by a general statute for the sale of such abandon military post and building as be find to be unnecessary and for the application of the proceed to the construction of other post while many of the present post be of but slight value for military purpose owe to the change condition of the country their occupation be continue at great expense and inconvenience because they afford the only available shelter for troop

 the absence of a large number of officer of the line in active duty from their regiment be a serious detriment to the maintenance of the service the constant demand for small detachment each of which should be command by a commission officer and the various detail of officer for necessary service away from their command occasion a scarcity in the number require for company duty with a view to lessen this drain to some extent it be recommend that the law authorize the detail of officer from the active list as professor of tactic and military science at certain college and university be so amend as to provide that all such detail be make from the retired list of the army

 attention be ask to the necessity of provide by legislation for organize arming and discipline the active militia of the country and liberal appropriation be recommend in this behalf the report of the adjutant general of the army and the chief of ordnance touch this subject fully set forth its importance

 the report of the officer in charge of education in the army show that there be 78 school now in operation in the army with an aggregate attendance of 2,305 enlisted man and child the secretary recommend the enlistment of 150 schoolmaster with the rank and pay of commissary sergeant an appropriation be need to supply the judge advocate of the army with suitable library and the secretary recommend that the corps of judge advocates be place upon the same footing as to promotion with the other staff corps of the army under exist law the bureau of military justice consist of one officer the judge advocate general and the corps of judge advocate of eight officer of equal rank major with a provision that the limit of the corps shall remain at four when reduce by casualty or resignation to that number the consolidation of the bureau of military justice and the corps of judge advocates upon the same basis with the other staff corps of the army would remove an unjust discrimination against deserve officer and subserve the good interest of the service

 especial attention be ask to the report of the chief of engineers upon the condition of our national defense from a personal inspection of many of the fortification refer to the secretary be able to emphasize the recommendation make and to state that their incomplete and defenseless condition be discreditable to the country while other nation have be increase their mean for carry on offensive warfare and attack maritime city we have be dormant in preparation for defense nothing of importance have be do toward strengthen and finish our casemate work since our late civil war during which the great gun of modern warfare and the heavy armor of modern fortification and ship come into use among the nation and our earthwork leave by a sudden failure of appropriation some year since in all stage of incompletion be now be rapidly destroy by the element

 the two great river of the north american continent the mississippi and the columbia have their navigable water wholly within the limit of the united states and be of vast importance to our internal and foreign commerce the permanency of the important work on the south pass of the mississippi river seem now to be assure there have be no failure whatever in the maintenance of the maximum channel during the six month end august 9 last this experiment have open a broad deep highway to the ocean and be an improvement upon the permanent success of which congratulation may be exchange among people abroad and at home and especially among the community of the mississippi valley whose commercial exchange float in an unobstructed channel safely to and from the sea

 a comprehensive improvement of the mississippi and its tributary be a matter of transcendent importance these great waterway comprise a system of inland transportation spread like network over a large portion of the united states and navigable to the extent of many thousand of mile producer and consumer alike have a common interest in such unequaled facility for cheap transportation geographically commercially and politically they be the strong tie between the various section of the country these channel of communication and interchange be the property of the nation its jurisdiction be paramount over their water and the plain principle of public interest require their intelligent and careful supervision with a view to their protection improvement and the enhancement of their usefulness

 the channel of the columbia river for a distance of about 100 mile from its mouth be obstruct by a succession of bar which occasion serious delay in navigation and heavy expense for lighterage and towage a depth of at least 20 foot at low tide should be secure and maintain to meet the requirement of the extensive and grow inland and ocean commerce it subserve the most urgent need however for this great waterway be a permanent improvement of the channel at the mouth of the river
