 from columbia river to san francisco a distance of over 600 mile there be no harbor on our pacific coast which can be approach during stormy weather an appropriation of $ 150,000 be make by the forty fifth congress for the commencement of a breakwater and harbor of refuge to be locate at some point between the straits of fuca and san francisco at which the necessity of commerce local and general will be well accommodate the amount appropriate be think to be quite inadequate for the purpose intend the cost of the work when finish will be very great owe to the want of natural advantage for a site at any point on the coast between the designate limit and it have not be think to be advisable to undertake the work without a large appropriation i commend the matter to the attention of congress

 the completion of the new building for the war department be urgently need and the estimate for continue its construction be especially recommend

 the collection of book specimen and record constitute the army medical museum and library be of national importance the library now contain about 51,500 volume and 57,000 pamphlet relate to medicine surgery and ally topic the content of the army medical museum consist of 22,000 specimen and be unique in the completeness with which both military surgery and the disease of army be illustrate their destruction would be an irreparable loss not only to the united states but to the world there be file in the record and pension division over 16,000 bind volume of hospital record together with a great quantity of paper embrace the original record of the hospital of our army during the civil war aside from their historical value these record be daily search for evidence need in the settlement of large number of pension and other claim for the protection of the government against attempt fraud as well as for the benefit of honest claimant these valuable collection be now in a building which be peculiarly expose to the danger of destruction by fire it be therefore earnestly recommend that an appropriation be make for a new fireproof building adequate for the present need and reasonable future expansion of these valuable collection such a building should be absolutely fireproof no expenditure for mere architectural display be require it be believe that a suitable structure can be erect at a cost not to exceed $ 250,000

 i commend to the attention of congress the great service of the commander in chief of our army during the war for the union whose wise firm and patriotic conduct do so much to bring that momentous conflict to a close the legislation of the united states contain many precedent for the recognition of distinguished military merit authorize rank and emolument to be confer for eminent service to the country an act of congress authorize the appointment of a captain general of the army with suitable provision relate to compensation retirement and other detail would in my judgment be altogether fitting and proper and would be warmly approve by the country

 the report of the secretary of the navy exhibit the successful and satisfactory management of that department during the last fiscal year the total expenditure for the year be $ 12,916,639.45 leave unexpended at the close of the year $ 2,141,682.23 of the amount of available appropriation the appropriation for the present fiscal year end june 30 1881 be $ 15,095,061.45 and the total estimate for the next fiscal year end june 30 1882 be $ 15,953,751.61 the amount draw by warrant from july 1 1880 to november 1 1880 be $ 5,041,570.45

 the recommendation of the secretary of the navy that provision be make for the establishment of some form of civil government for the people of alaska be approve at present there be no protection of person or property in that territory except such as be afford by the officer of the united states ship jamestown this vessel be dispatch to sitka because of the fear that without the immediate presence of the national authority there be impend danger of anarchy the step take to restore order have be accept in good faith by both white and indian inhabitant and the necessity for this method of restraint do not in my opinion now exist if however the jamestown should be withdraw leave the people as at present without the ordinary judicial and administrative authority of organized local government serious consequence might ensue

 the law provide only for the collection of revenue the protection of public property and the transmission of the mail the problem be to supply a local rule for a population so scattered and so peculiar in its origin and condition the native be report to be teachable and self support and if properly instruct doubtless would advance rapidly in civilization and a new factor of prosperity would be add to the national life i therefore recommend the requisite legislation upon this subject

 the secretary of the navy have take step toward the establishment of naval coaling station at the isthmus of panama to meet the requirement of our commercial relation with central and south america which be rapidly grow in importance location eminently suitable both as regard our naval purpose and the use of commerce have be select one on the east side of the isthmus at chiriqui lagoon in the caribbean sea and the other on the pacific coast at the bay of golfito the only safe harbor sufficiently commodious on the isthmus be at these point and the distance between they be less than 100 mile the report of the secretary of the navy conclude with valuable suggestion with respect to the building up of our merchant marine service which deserve the favorable consideration of congress

 the report of the postmaster general exhibit the continual growth and the high state of efficiency of the postal service the operation of no department of the government perhaps represent with great exactness the increase in the population and the business of the country in 1860 the postal receipt be $ 8,518,067.40 in 1880 the receipt be $ 33,315,479.34 all the inhabitant of the country be directly and personally interested in have proper mail facility and naturally watch the post office very closely this careful oversight on the part of the people have prove a constant stimulus to improvement during the past year there be an increase of 2,134 post office and the mail route be extend 27,177 mile make an additional annual transportation of 10,804,191 mile the revenue of the postal service for the ensue year be estimate at $ 38,845,174.10 and the expenditure at $ 42,475,932 leave a deficiency to be appropriate out of the treasury of $ 3,630,757.90

 the universal postal union have receive the accession of almost all the country and colony of the world maintain organize postal service and it be confidently expect that all the other country and colony now outside the union will soon unite therewith thus realize the grand idea and aim of the founder of the union of form for purpose of international mail communication a single postal territory embrace the world with complete uniformity of postal charge and condition of international exchange for all description of correspondence to enable the united states to do its full share of this great work additional legislation be ask by the postmaster general to whose recommendation especial attention be call

 the suggestion of the postmaster general that it would be wise to encourage by appropriate legislation the establishment of american line of steamer by our own citizen to carry the mail between our own port and those of mexico central america south america and of transpacific country be commend to the serious consideration of congress

 the attention of congress be also invite to the suggestion of the postmaster general in regard to postal saving

 the necessity for additional provision to aid in the transaction of the business of the federal court become each year more apparent the docket of the supreme court and of the circuit court in the great number of the circuit be encumber with the constant accession of case in the former court and in many instance in the circuit court year intervene before it be practicable to bring case to hear

 the attorney general recommend the establishment of an intermediate court of error and appeal it be recommend that the number of judge of the circuit court in each circuit with the exception of the second circuit should be increase by the addition of another judge in the second circuit that two should be add and that an intermediate appellate court should be form in each circuit to consist of the circuit judge and the circuit justice and that in the event of the absence of either of these judge the place of the absent judge should be supply by the judge of one of the district court in the circuit such an appellate court could be safely invest with large jurisdiction and its decision would satisfy suitor in many case where appeal would still be allow to the supreme court the expense incur for this intermediate court will require a very moderate increase of the appropriation for the expense of the department of justice this recommendation be commend to the careful consideration of congress

 it be evident that a delay of justice in many instance oppressive and disastrous to suitor now necessarily occur in the federal court which will in this way be remedie

 the report of the secretary of the interior present an elaborate account of the operation of that department during the past year it give i great pleasure to say that our indian affair appear to be in a more hopeful condition now than ever before the indians have make gratifying progress in agriculture herding and mechanical pursuit many who be a few year ago in hostile conflict with the government be quietly settle down on farm where they hope to make their permanent home build house and engage in the occupation of civilized life the introduction of the freight business among they have be remarkably fruitful of good result in give many of they congenial and remunerative employment and in stimulate their ambition to earn their own support their honesty fidelity and efficiency as carrier be highly praised the organization of a police force of indians have be equally successful in maintain law and order upon the reservation and in exercise a wholesome moral influence among the indians themselves i concur with the secretary of the interior in the recommendation that the pay of this force be increase as an inducement to the good class of young man to enter it

 much care and attention have be devote to the enlargement of educational facility for the indians the mean available for this important object have be very inadequate a few additional boarding school at indian agency have be establish and the erection of building have be begin for several more but an increase of the appropriation for this interesting undertaking be greatly need to accommodate the large number of indian child of school age the number offer by their parent from all part of the country for education in the government school be much large than can be accommodate with the mean at present available for that purpose the number of indian pupil at the normal school at hampton va. under the direction of general armstrong have be considerably increase and their progress be highly encouraging the indian school establish by the interior department in 1879 at carlisle pa. under the direction of captain pratt have be equally successful it have now nearly 200 pupil of both sex represent a great variety of the tribe east of the rocky mountains the pupil in both these institution receive not only an elementary english education but be also instruct in housework agriculture and useful mechanical pursuit a similar school be establish this year at forest grove oreg for the education of indian youth on the pacific coast in addition to this thirty six indian boy and girl be select from the eastern cherokees and place in boarding school in north carolina where they be to receive an elementary english education and training in industrial pursuit the interest show by indian parent even among the so call wild tribe in the education of their child be very gratifying and give promise that the result accomplish by the effort now make will be of lasting benefit

 the expense of indian education have so far be draw from the permanent civilization fund at the disposal of the department of the interior but the fund be now so much reduce that the continuance of this beneficial work will in the future depend on specific appropriation by congress for the purpose and i venture to express the hope that congress will not permit institution so fruitful of good result to perish for want of mean for their support on the contrary an increase of the number of such school appear to i highly advisable

 the past year have be unusually free from disturbance among the indian tribe an agreement have be make with the utes by which they surrender their large reservation in colorado in consideration of an annuity to be pay to they and agree to settle in severally on certain land designate for that purpose as farmer hold individual title to their land in fee simple inalienable for a certain period in this way a costly indian war have be avoid which at one time seem imminent and for the first time in the history of the country an indian nation have give up its tribal existence to be settle in severally and to live as individual under the common protection of the law of the country

 the conduct of the indians throughout the country during the past year with but few noteworthy exception have be orderly and peaceful the guerrilla warfare carry on for two year by victoria and his band of southern apaches have virtually come to an end by the death of that chief and most of his follower on mexican soil the disturbance cause on our northern frontier by sitting bull and his man who have take refuge in the british dominion be also likely to cease a large majority of his follower have surrender to our military force and the remainder be apparently in progress of disintegration

 i concur with the secretary of the interior in express the earnest hope that congress will at this session take favorable action on the bill provide for the allotment of land on the different reservation in severally to the indians with patent confer fee simple title inalienable for a certain period and the eventual disposition of the residue of the reservation for general settlement with the consent and for the benefit of the indians place the latter under the equal protection of the law of the country this measure together with a vigorous prosecution of our educational effort will work the most important and effective advance toward the solution of the indian problem in prepare for the gradual merging of our indian population in the great body of american citizenship

 a large increase be report in the disposal of public land for settlement during the past year which mark the prosperous growth of our agricultural industry and a vigorous movement of population toward our unoccupied land as this movement proceed the codification of our land law as well as proper legislation to regulate the disposition of public land become of more pressing necessity and i therefore invite the consideration of congress to the report and the accompany draft of a bill make by the public lands commission which be communicate by i to congress at the last session early action upon this important subject be highly desirable

 the attention of congress be again ask to the wasteful depredation commit on our public timber land and the rapid and indiscriminate destruction of our forest the urgent necessity for legislation to this end be now generally recognize in view of the lawless character of the depredation commit and the disastrous consequence which will inevitably follow their continuance legislation have again and again be recommend to arrest the evil and to preserve for the people of our western states and territories the timber need for domestic and other essential use

 the report of the director of the geological survey be a document of unusual interest the consolidation of the various geological and geographical survey and explore enterprise each of which have heretofore operate upon an independent plan without concert can not fail to be of great benefit to all those industry of the country which depend upon the development of our mineral resource the labor of the scientific man of recognize merit who compose the corps of the geological survey during the first season of their field operation and inquiry appear to have be very comprehensive and will soon be communicate to congress in a number of volume the director of the survey recommend that the investigation carry on by his bureau which so far have be confine to the so call public land states and territories be extend over the entire country and that the necessary appropriation be make for this purpose this would be particularly beneficial to the iron coal and other mining interest of the mississippi valley and of the eastern and southern states the subject be commend to the careful consideration of congress

 the secretary of the interior ask attention to the want of room in the public building of the capital now exist and in progress of construction for the accommodation of the clerical force employ and of the public record necessity have compel the renting of private building in different part of the city for the location of public office for which a large amount of rent be annually pay while the separation of office belong to the same department impede the transaction of current business the secretary suggest that the block surround lafayette square on the east north and west be purchase as the site for new edifice for the accommodation of the government office leave the square itself intact and that if such building be construct upon a harmonious plan of architecture they would add much to the beauty of the national capital and would together with the treasury and the new state navy and war department building form one of the most impose group of public edifice in the world

 the commissioner of agriculture express the confident belief that his effort in behalf of the production of our own sugar and tea have be encouragingly reward the importance of the result attain have attract marked attention at home and have receive the special consideration of foreign nation the successful cultivation of our own tea and the manufacture of our own sugar would make a difference of many million of dollar annually in the wealth of the nation

 the report of the commissioner ask attention particularly to the continued prevalence of an infectious and contagious cattle disease know and dread in europe and asia as cattle plague or pleuro pneumonia a mild type of this disease in certain section of our country be the occasion of great loss to our farmer and of serious disturbance to our trade with great britain which furnish a market for most of our live stock and dressed meat the value of neat cattle export from the united states for the eight month end august 31 1880 be more than $ 12,000,000 and nearly double the value for the same period in 1879&mdash;an unexampled increase of export trade your early attention be solicit to this important matter

 the commissioner of education report a continue increase of public interest in educational affair and that the public school generally throughout the country be well sustained industrial training be attract deserved attention and college for instruction theoretical and practical in agriculture and mechanic art include the government school recently establish for the instruction of indian youth be gain steadily in public estimation the commissioner ask special attention to the depredation commit on the land reserve for the future support of public instruction and to the very great need of help from the nation for school in the territories and in the southern states the recommendation heretofore make be repeat and urge that an educational fund be set apart from the net proceed of the sale of the public land annually the income of which and the remainder of the net annual proceed to be distribute on some satisfactory plan to the states and the territories and the district of columbia

 the success of the public school of the district of columbia and the progress make under the intelligent direction of the board of education and the superintendent in supply the educational requirement of the district with thoroughly train and efficient teacher be very gratifying the act of congress from time to time donate public land to the several states and territories in aid of educational interest have prove to be wise measure of public policy result in great and lasting benefit it would seem to be a matter of simple justice to extend the benefit of this legislation the wisdom of which have be so fully vindicate by experience to the district of columbia

 i again commend the general interest of the district of columbia to the favorable consideration of congress the affair of the district as show by the report of the commissioners be in a very satisfactory condition

 in my annual message heretofore and in my special message of december 19 1879 i have urge upon the attention of congress the necessity of reclaim the marsh of the potomac adjacent to the capital and i be constrain by its importance to advert again to the subject these flat embrace an area of several hundred acre they be an impediment to the drainage of the city and seriously impair its health it be believe that with this substantial improvement of its river front the capital would be in all respect one of the most attractive city in the world aside from its permanent population this city be necessarily the place of residence of person from every section of the country engage in the public service many other reside here temporarily for the transaction of business with the government

 it should not be forget that the land acquire will probably be worth the cost of reclaim it and that the navigation of the river will be greatly improve i therefore again invite the attention of congress to the importance of prompt provision for this much need and too long delay improvement

 the water supply of the city be inadequate in addition to the ordinary use throughout the city the consumption by government be necessarily very great in the navy yard arsenal and the various departments and a large quantity be require for the proper preservation of the numerous park and the cleansing of sewer i recommend that this subject receive the early attention of congress and that in make provision for an increase supply such mean be adopt as will have in view the future growth of the city temporary expedient for such a purpose can not but be wasteful of money and therefore unwise a more ample reservoir with corresponding facility for keep it fill should in my judgment be construct i commend again to the attention of congress the subject of the removal from their present location of the depot of the several railroad enter the city and i renew the recommendation of my former message in behalf of the erection of a building for the congressional library the completion of the washington monument and of liberal appropriation in support of the benevolent reformatory and penal institution of the district
to the house of representatives
 having consider the bill entitle an act to facilitate the refunding of the national debt i be constrain to return it to the house of representatives in which it originate with the follow statement of my objection to its passage
 the imperative necessity for prompt action and the pressure of public duty in this closing week of my term of office compel i to refrain from any attempt to make a full and satisfactory presentation of the objection to the bill
 the importance of the passage at the present session of congress of a suitable measure for the refunding of the national debt which be about to mature be generally recognize it have be urge upon the attention of congress by the secretary of the treasury and in my last annual message if successfully accomplish it will secure a large decrease in the annual interest payment of the nation and i earnestly recommend if the bill before i shall fail that another measure for this purpose be adopt before the present congress adjourn
 while in my opinion it would be unwise to authorize the secretary of the treasury in his discretion to offer to the public bond bear 3 1/2 per cent interest in aid of refunding i should not deem it my duty to interpose my constitutional objection to the passage of the present bill if it do not contain in its fifth section provision which in my judgment seriously impair the value and tend to the destruction of the present national banking system of the country this system have now be in operation almost twenty year no safe or more beneficial banking system be ever establish its advantage as a business be free to all who have the necessary capital it furnish a currency to the public which for convenience and security of the bill holder have probably never be equal by that of any other banking system its note be secure by the deposit with the government of the interest bear bond of the united states
 the section of the bill before i which relate to the national banking system and to which objection be make be not an essential part of a refunding measure it be as follow
 sec 5 from and after the 1st day of july 1881 the 3 per cent bond authorize by the first section of this act shall be the only bond receivable as security for national bank circulation or as security for the safe keeping and prompt payment of the public money deposit with such bank but when any such bond deposit for the purpose aforesaid shall be designate for purchase or redemption by the secretary of the treasury the banking association deposit the same shall have the right to substitute other issue of the bond of the united states in lieu thereof provide that no bond upon which interest have cease shall be accept or shall be continue on deposit as security for circulation or for the safe keeping of the public money and in case bond so deposited shall not be withdraw as provide by law within thirty day after the interest have cease thereon the banking association deposit the same shall be subject to the liability and proceeding on the part of the comptroller provide for in section 5234 of the revised statutes of the united states and provide far that section 4 of the act of june 20 1874 entitle an act fix the amount of united states note provide for a redistribution of the national bank currency and for other purpose be and the same be hereby repeal and section 5159 and 5160 of the revised statutes of the united states be and the same be hereby reenacted
 under this section it be obvious that no additional bank will hereafter be organize except possibly in a few city or locality where the prevail rate of interest in ordinary business be extremely low no new bank can be organize and no increase of the capital of exist bank can be obtain except by the purchase and deposit of 3 per cent bond no other bond of the united states can be use for the purpose the one thousand million of other bond recently issue by the united states and bear a high rate of interest than 3 per cent and therefore a well security for the bill holder can not after the 1st of july next be receive as security for bank circulation this be a radical change in the banking law it take from the bank the right they have heretofore have under the law to purchase and deposit as security for their circulation any of the bond issue by the united states and deprive the bill holder of the good security which the bank be able to give by require they to deposit bond have the least value of any bond issue by the government
 the average rate of taxation of capital employ in banking be more than double the rate of taxation upon capital employ in other legitimate business under these circumstance to amend the banking law so as to deprive the bank of the privilege of secure their note by the most valuable bond issue by the government will it be believe in a large part of the country be a practical prohibition of the organization of new bank and prevent the exist bank from enlarge their capital the national banking system if continue at all will be a monopoly in the hand of those already engage in it who may purchase the government bond bear a more favorable rate of interest than the 3 per cent bond prior to next july
 to prevent the further organization of bank be to put in jeopardy the whole system by take from it that feature which make it as it now be a banking system free upon the same term to all who wish to engage in it even the exist bank will be in danger of be drive from business by the additional disadvantage to which they will be subject by this bill in short i can not but regard the fifth section of the bill as a step in the direction of the destruction of the national banking system
 our country after a long period of business depression have just enter upon a career of unexampled prosperity
 the withdrawal of the currency from circulation of the national bank and the enforce winding up of the bank in consequence would inevitably bring serious embarrassment and disaster to the business of the country bank of issue be essential instrument of modern commerce if the present efficient and admirable system of banking be break down it will inevitably be follow by a recurrence to other and inferior method of banking any measure look to such a result will be a disturbing element in our financial system it will destroy confidence and surely check the grow prosperity of the country
 believe that a measure for refund the national debt be not necessarily connect with the national banking law and that any refunding act would defeat its own object if it imperil the national banking system or seriously impair its usefulness and convince that section 5 of the bill before i would if it should become a law work great harm i herewith return the bill to the house of representatives for that further consideration which be provide for in the constitution

fellow citizens

 we stand to day upon an eminence which overlook a hundred year of national life a century crowd with peril but crown with the triumph of liberty and law before continue the onward march let we pause on this height for a moment to strengthen our faith and renew our hope bya glance at the pathway along which our people have travel

 it be now three day more than a hundred year since the adoption of the first write constitution of the united states the articles of confederation and perpetual union the new republic be then beset with danger on every hand it have not conquer a place in the family of nation the decisive battle of the war for independence whose centennial anniversary will soon be gratefully celebrate at yorktown have not yet be fight the colonist be struggle not only against the army of a great nation but against the settle opinion of mankind for the world do not then believe that the supreme authority of government could be safely intrust to the guardianship of the people themselves

 we can not overestimate the fervent love of liberty the intelligent courage and the sum of common sense with which our father make the great experiment of self government when they find after a short trial that the confederacy of states be too weak to meet the necessity of a vigorous and expand republic they boldly set it aside and in its stead establish a national union found directly upon the will of the people endow with full power of self preservation and ample authority for the accomplishment of its great object

 under this constitution the boundary of freedom have be enlarge the foundation of order and peace have be strengthen and the growth of our people in all the well element of national life have indicate the wisdom of the founder and give new hope to their descendant under this constitution our people long ago make themselves safe against danger from without and secure for their mariner and flag equality of right on all the sea under this constitution twenty five states have be add to the union with constitution and law frame and enforce by their own citizen to secure the manifold blessing of local self government

 the jurisdiction of this constitution now cover an area fifty time great than that of the original thirteen states and a population twenty time great than that of 1780

 the supreme trial of the constitution come at last under the tremendous pressure of civil war we ourselves be witness that the union emerge from the blood and fire of that conflict purify and make strong for all the beneficent purpose of good government

 and now at the close of this first century of growth with the inspiration of its history in their heart our people have lately review the condition of the nation pass judgment upon the conduct and opinion of political party and have register their will concern the future administration of the government to interpret and to execute that will in accordance with the constitution be the paramount duty of the executive

 even from this brief review it be manifest that the nation be resolutely face to the front resolve to employ its good energy in develop the great possibility of the future sacredly preserve whatever have be gain to liberty and good government during the century our people be determined to leave behind they all those bitter controversy concern thing which have be irrevocably settle and the further discussion of which can only stir up strife and delay the onward march

 the supremacy of the nation and its law should be no long a subject of debate that discussion which for half a century threaten the existence of the union be close at last in the high court of war by a decree from which there be no appeal that the constitution and the law make in pursuance there of be and shall continue to be the supreme law of the land bind alike upon the states and the people this decree do not disturb the autonomy of the states nor interfere with any of their necessary right of local self government but it do fix and establish the permanent supremacy of the union

 the will of the nation speak with the voice of battle and through the amend constitution have fulfil the great promise of 1776 by proclaiming"liberty throughout the land to all the inhabitant thereof

 the elevation of the negro race from slavery to the full right of citizenship be the most important political change we have know since the adoption of the constitution of 1787 no thoughtful man can fail to appreciate its beneficent effect upon our institution and people it have free we from the perpetual danger of war and dissolution it have add immensely to the moral and industrial force of our people it have liberate the master as well as the slave from a relation which wrong and enfeeble both it have surrender to their own guardianship the manhood of more than 5,000,000people and have open to each one of they a career of freedom and usefulness it have give new inspiration to the power of self help in both race by make labor more honorable to the one and more necessary to the other the influence of this force will grow great and bear rich fruit with the come year

 no doubt this great change have cause serious disturbance to our southern community this be to be deplore though it be perhaps unavoidable but those who resist the change should remember that under our institution there be no middle ground for the negro race between slavery and equal citizenship there can be no permanent disfranchise peasantry in the unitedstates freedom can never yield its fullness of blessing so long as the law or its administration place the small obstacle in the pathway of any virtuous citizen

 the emancipate race have already make remarkable progress with unquestione devotion to the union with a patience and gentleness not bear of fear they have follow the light as god give they to see the light they be rapidly lay the material foundation of self support widen their circle of intelligence and begin to enjoy the blessing that gather around the home of the industrious poor they deserve the generous encouragement of all good man so far as my authority can lawfully extend they shall enjoy the full and equal protection of the constitution and the law

 the free enjoyment of equal suffrage be still in question and a frank statement of the issue may aid its solution it be allege that in many community negro citizen be practically deny the freedom of the ballot in so far as the truth of this allegation be admit it be answer that in many place honest local government be impossible if the mass of uneducated negro be allow to vote these be grave allegation so far as the latter be true it be the only palliation that can be offer for oppose the freedom of the ballot bad local government be certainly a great evil which ought to be prevent but to violate the freedom and sanctity of the suffrage be more than an evil it be a crime which if persist in will destroy the government itself suicide be not a remedy if in other land it be high treason to compass the death of the king it shall be count no less a crime here to strangle our sovereign power and stifle its voice

 it have be say that unsettled question have no pity for the repose of nation it should be say with the utmost emphasis that this question of the suffrage will never give repose or safety to the states or to the nation until each within its own jurisdiction make and keep the ballot free and pure by the strong sanction of the law

 but the danger which arise from ignorance in the voter can not be deny it cover a field far wider than that of negro suffrage and the present condition of the race it be a danger that lurk and hide in the source and fountain of power in every state we have no standard by which to measure the disaster that may be bring upon we by ignorance and vice in the citizen when join to corruption and fraud in the suffrage

 the voter of the union who make and unmake constitution and upon whose will hang the destiny of our government can transmit their supreme authority to no successor save the come generation of voter who be the sole heir of sovereign power if that generation come to its inheritance blind by ignorance and corrupt by vice the fall of the republic will be certain and remediless

 the census have already sound the alarm in the appalling figure which mark how dangerously high the tide of illiteracy have rise among our voter and their child

 to the south this question be of supreme importance but the responsibility for the existence of slavery do not rest upon the south alone the nation itself be responsible for the extension of the suffrage and be under special obligation to aid in remove the illiteracy which it have add to the vote population for the north and south alike there be but one remedy all the constitutional power of the nation and of the states and all the volunteer force of the people should be surrender to meet this danger by the savory influence of universal education

 it be the high privilege and sacred duty of those now live to educate their successor and fit they by intelligence and virtue for the inheritance which await they

 in this beneficent work section and race should be forget and partisanship should be unknown let our people find a new meaning in the divine oracle which declare that a little child shall lead they for our own little child will soon control the destiny of the republic

 my countryman we do not now differ in our judgment concern the controversy of past generation and fifty year hence our child will not be divide in their opinion concern our controversy they will surely bless their father and their fathers&#39 god that the union be preserve that slavery be overthrow and that both race be make equal before the law we may hasten or we may retard but we can not prevent the final reconciliation be it not possible for we now to make a truce with time by anticipate and accept its inevitable verdict

 enterprise of the high importance to our moral and material well be unite we and offer ample employment of our good power let all our people leave behind they the battlefield of dead issue move forward and in their strength of liberty and the restore union win the grander victory of peace

 the prosperity which now prevail be without parallel in our history fruitful season have do much to secure it but they have not do all the preservation of the public credit and the resumption of specie payment so successfully attain by the administration of my predecessor have enable our people to secure the blessing which the season bring

 by the experience of commercial nation in all age it have be find that gold and silver afford the only safe foundation for a monetary system confusion have recently be create by variation in the relative value of the two metal but i confidently believe that arrangement can be make between the lead commercial nation which will secure the general use of both metal congress should provide that the compulsory coinage of silver now require by law may not disturb our monetary system by drive either metal out of circulation if possible such an adjustment should be make that the purchase power of every coin dollar will be exactly equal to its debt pay power in all the market of the world

 the chief duty of the national government in connection with the currency of the country be to coin money and declare its value grave doubt have be entertain whether congress be authorize by the constitution to make any form of paper money legal tender the present issue of unitedstates note have be sustain by the necessity of war but such paper should depend for its value and currency upon its convenience in use and its prompt redemption in coin at the will of the holder and not upon its compulsory circulation these note be not money but promise to pay money if the holder demand it the promise should be keep

 the refunding of the national debt at a low rate of interest should be accomplish without compel the withdrawal of the national banknote and thus disturb the business of the country

 i venture to refer to the position i have occupy on financial question during a long service in congress and to say that time and experience have strengthen the opinion i have so often express on these subject

 the finance of the government shall suffer no detriment which it maybe possible for my administration to prevent

 the interest of agriculture deserve more attention from the government than they have yet receive the farm of the united states afford home and employment for more than one half our people and furnish much the large part of all our export as the government light our coast for the protection of mariner and the benefit of commerce so it should give to the tiller of the soil the good light of practical science and experience

 our manufacturer be rapidly make we industrially independent and be open to capital and labor new and profitable field of employment their steady and healthy growth should still be mature our facility for transportation should be promote by the continue improvement of our harbor and great interior waterway and by the increase of our tonnage on the ocean

 the development of the world&#39;s commerce have lead to an urgent demand for shorten the great sea voyage around cape horn by construct ship canal or railway across the isthmus which unite the continent various plan to this end have be suggest and will need consideration but none of they have be sufficiently mature to warrant the united states in extend pecuniary aid the subject however be one which will immediately engage the attention of the government with a view to a thorough protection to american interest we will urge no narrow policy nor seek peculiar or exclusive privilege in any commercial route but in the language of my predecessor i believe it to be the right and duty of the united states to assert and maintain such supervision and authority over any interoceanic canal across the isthmus that connect north and south america as will protect our national interest

 the constitution guarantee absolute religious freedom congress be prohibit from make any law respect an establishment of religion or prohibit the free exercise thereof the territories of the unitedstates be subject to the direct legislative authority of congress and hence the general government be responsible for any violation of the constitution in any of they it be therefore a reproach to the government that in the most populous of the territories the constitutional guaranty be not enjoy by the people and the authority of congress be set at naught the mormonchurch not only offend the moral sense of manhood by sanction polygamy but prevent the administration of justice through ordinary instrumentality of law

 in my judgment it be the duty of congress while respect to the uttermost the conscientious conviction and religious scruple of every citizen to prohibit within its jurisdiction all criminal practice especially of that class which destroy the family relation and endanger social order nor can any ecclesiastical organization be safely permit to usurp in the small degree the function and power of the national government

 the civil service can never be place on a satisfactory basis until it be regulate by law for the good of the service itself for the protection of those who be intrust with the appoint power against the waste of time and obstruction to the public business cause by the inordinate pressure for place and for the protection of incumbent against intrigue and wrong i shall at the proper time ask congress to fix the tenure of the minor office of the several executive departments and prescribe the ground upon which removal shall be make during the term for which incumbent have be appoint

 finally act always within the authority and limitation of the constitution invade neither the right of the states nor the reserved right of the people it will be the purpose of my administration to maintain the authority of the nation in all place within its jurisdiction to enforce obedience to all the law of the union in the interest of the people to demand rigid economy in all the expenditure of the government and to require the honest and faithful service of all executive officer remember that the office be create not for the benefit of incumbent or their supporter but for the service of the government

 and now fellow citizen i be about to assume the great trust which you have commit to my hand i appeal to you for that earnest and thoughtful support which make this government in fact as it be in law a government of the people

 i shall greatly rely upon the wisdom and patriotism of congress and of those who may share with i the responsibility and duty of administration and above all upon our effort to promote the welfare of this great people and their government i reverently invoke the support and blessing of almightygod
for the fourth time in the history of the republic its chief magistrate have be remove by death all heart be fill with grief and horror at the hideous crime which have darken our land and the memory of the murder president his protract suffering his unyielding fortitude the example and achievement of his life and the pathos of his death will forever illumine the page of our history
 for the fourth time the officer elect by the people and ordain by the constitution to fill a vacancy so create be call to assume the executive chair the wisdom of our father foresee even the most dire possibility make sure that the government should never be imperil because of the uncertainty of human life man may die but the fabric of our free institution remain unshaken no higher or more assuring proof could exist of the strength and permanence of popular government than the fact that though the choose of the people be strike down his constitutional successor be peacefully instal without shock or strain except the sorrow which mourn the bereavement all the noble aspiration of my lamented predecessor which find expression in his life the measure devise and suggest during his brief administration to correct abuse to enforce economy to advance prosperity and to promote the general welfare to insure domestic security and maintain friendly and honorable relation with the nation of the earth will be garner in the heart of the people and it will be my earnest endeavor to profit and to see that the nation shall profit by his example and experience
 prosperity bless our country our fiscal policy be fix by law be well ground and generally approve no threatening issue mar our foreign intercourse and the wisdom integrity and thrift of our people may be trust to continue undisturbe the present assured career of peace tranquilly and welfare the gloom and anxiety which have enshroud the country must make repose especially welcome now no demand for speedy legislation have be hear no adequate occasion be apparent for an unusual session of congress the constitution define the function and power of the executive as clearly as those of either of the other two department of the government and he must answer for the just exercise of the discretion it permit and the performance of the duty it impose summon to these high duty and responsibility and profoundly conscious of their magnitude and gravity i assume the trust impose by the constitution rely for aid on divine guidance and the virtue patriotism and intelligence of the american people

to the senate and house of representatives of the united states

 an appalling calamity have befall the american people since their choose representative last meet in the hall where you be now assemble we might else recall with unalloye content the rare prosperity with which throughout the year the nation have be bless its harvest have be plenteous its varied industry have thriven the health of its people have be preserve it have maintain with foreign government the undisturbed relation of amity and peace for these manifestation of his favor we owe to he who hold our destiny in his hand the tribute of our grateful devotion

 to that mysterious exercise of his will which have take from we the loved and illustrious citizen who be but lately the head of the nation we bow in sorrow and submission

 the memory of his exalt character of his noble achievement and of his patriotic life will be treasure forever as a sacred possession of the whole people

 the announcement of his death draw from foreign government and people tribute of sympathy and sorrow which history will record as signal token of the kinship of nation and the federation of mankind

 the feeling of good will between our own government and that of great britain be never more marked than at present in recognition of this pleasing fact i direct on the occasion of the late centennial celebration at yorktown that a salute be give to the british flag

 save for the correspondence to which i shall refer hereafter in relation to the propose canal across the isthmus of panama little have occur worthy of mention in the diplomatic relation of the two country

 early in the year the fortune bay claim be satisfactorily settle by the british government pay in full the sum of 15,000 pound most of which have be already distribute as the term of the settlement include compensation for injury suffer by our fisherman at aspee bay there have be retain from the gross award a sum which be deem adequate for those claim

 the participation of americans in the exhibition at melbourne and sydney will be approvingly mention in the report of the two exhibition soon to be present to congress they will disclose the readiness of our country man to make successful competition in distant field of enterprise
 negotiation for an international copyright convention be in hopeful progress

 the surrender of sit bull and his force upon the canadian frontier have allay apprehension although body of british indians still cross the border in quest of sustenance upon this subject a correspondence have be open which promise an adequate understanding our troop have order to avoid meanwhile all collision with alien indians

 the presence at the yorktown celebration of representative of the frenchrepublic and descendant of lafayette and of his gallant compatriot who be our ally in the revolution have serve to strengthen the spirit of good will which have always exist between the two nation

 you will be furnish with the proceeding of the bimetallic conference hold during the summer at the city of paris no accord be reach but a valuable interchange of view be have and the conference will next year be renew

 at the electrical exhibition and congress also hold at paris this country be creditably represent by eminent specialist who in the absence of an appropriation generously lend their efficient aid at the instance of the state department while our exhibitor in this almost distinctively american field of achievement have win several valuable award i recommend that congress provide for the repayment of the personal expense incur in the public interest by the honorary commissioner and delegate

 no new question respect the status of our naturalized citizen in germany have arise during the year and the cause of complaint especially in alsace and lorraine have practically cease through the liberal action of the imperial government in accept our often express view on the subject the application of the treaty of 1868 to the lately acquire rhenish province have receive very earnest attention and a definite and lasting agreement on this point be confidently expect the participation of the descendant of baron von steuben in the yorktown festivity and their subsequent reception by their american kinsman strikingly evince the tie of good will which unite the german people and our own

 our intercourse with spain have be friendly an agreement conclude in february last fix a term for the labor of the spanish and americanclaims commission the spanish government have be request to pay the late award of that commission and will it be believe accede to the request as promptly and courteously as on former occasion

 by recent legislation onerous fine have be impose upon american shipping in spanish and colonial port for slight irregularity in manifest one ease of hardship be specially worthy of attention the bark masonic bind for japan enter manila in distress and be there seek to be confiscate under spanish revenue law for an alleged shortage in her transship cargo though effort for her relief have thus far prove unavaile it be expect that the whole matter will be adjust in a friendly spirit

 the senate resolution of condolence on the assassination of the czar alexander ii be appropriately communicate to the russian government which in turn have express its sympathy in our late national bereavement it be desirable that our cordial relation with russia should be strengthen by proper engagement assure to peaceable americans who visit the empire the consideration which be due to they as citizen of a friendly state this be especially needful with respect to american israelites whose classification with the native hebrews have evoke energetic remonstrance from this government

 a supplementary consular agreement with italy have be sanction and proclaim which put at rest conflict of jurisdiction in the case of crime on shipboard

 several important international conference have be hold in italy during the year at the geographical congress of venice the beneficencecongress of milan and the hygienic congress of turin this country be represent by delegate from branch of the public service or by private citizen duly accredit in an honorary capacity it be hope that congress will give such prominence to the result of their participation as they may seem to deserve

 the abolition of all discriminating duty against such colonial production of the dutch east indies as be import hither from holland have be already consider by congress i trust that at the present session the matter may be favorably conclude

 the insecurity of life and property in many part of turkey have give rise to correspondence with the porte look particularly to the well protection of american missionary in the empire the condemn murderer of the eminent missionary dr. justin w. parsons have not yet be execute although this government have repeatedly demand that exemplary justice be do

 the swiss government have again solicit the good office of our diplomatic and consular agent for the protection of its citizen in country where it be not itself represent this request have within proper limit be grant

 our agent in switzerland have be instruct to protest against the conduct of the authority of certain commune in permit the emigration to this country of criminal and other objectionable person several such person through the cooperation of the commissioner of emigration atnew york have be send back by the steamer which bring they a continuance of this course may prove a more effectual remedy than diplomatic remonstrance

 treaty of commerce and navigation and for the regulation of consular privilege have be conclude with roumania and servia since their admission into the family of european states

 as be natural with contiguous state have like institution and like aim of advancement and development the friendship of the united states and mexico have be constantly maintain this government have lose no occasion of encourage the mexican government to a beneficial realization of the mutual advantage which will result from more intimate commercial intercourse and from the opening of the rich interior of mexico to railway enterprise i deem it important that mean be provide to restrain the lawlessness unfortunately so common on the frontier and to suppress the foray of the reservation indians on either side of the rio grande

 the neighbor states of central america have preserve internal peace and their outward relation toward we have be those of intimate friendship there be encourage sign of their grow disposition to subordinate their local interest to those which be common to they by reason of their geographical relation

 the boundary dispute between guatemala and mexico have afford thisgovernment an opportunity to exercise its good office for prevent a rupture between those states and for procure a peaceable solution of the question i cherish strong hope that in view of our relation of amity with both country our friendly counsel may prevail

 a special envoy of guatemala have bring to i the condolence of hisgovernment and people on the death of president garfield

 the costa rican government lately frame an engagement with colombia for settle by arbitration the boundary question between those country provide that the post of arbitrator should be offer successively to the king of the belgians the king of spain and the president of the argentineconfederation the king of the belgians have decline to act but i be not as yet advise of the action of the king of spain as we have certain interest in the dispute territory which be protect by our treaty engagement with one of the party it be important that the arbitration should not without our consent affect our right and this government have accordingly think proper to make its view know to the party to the agreement as well as to intimate they to the belgian and spanish governments

 the question grow out of the propose interoceanic waterway across the isthmus of panama be of grave national importance this government have not be unmindful of the solemn obligation impose upon it by its compact of 1846 with colombia as the independent and sovereign mistress of the territory cross by the canal and have seek to render they effective by fresh engagement with the colombian republic look to their practical execution the negotiation to this end after they have reach what appear to be a mutually satisfactory solution here be meet in colombia by a disavowal of the power which its envoy have assume and by a proposal for renew negotiation on a modify basis

 meanwhile this government learn that colombia have propose to theeuropean power to join in a guaranty of the neutrality of the proposedpanama canal a guaranty which would be in direct contravention of our obligation as the sole guarantor of the integrity of colombian territory and of the neutrality of the canal itself my lamented predecessor feel it his duty to place before the european power the reason which makethe prior guaranty of the united states indispensable and for which the interjection of any foreign guaranty might be regard as a superfluous and unfriendly act

 foresee the probable reliance of the british government on the provision of the clayton bulwer treaty of 1850 as affording room for a share in the guaranty which the united states covenant with colombia four year before i have not hesitate to supplement the action of my predecessor by propose to her majesty 's government the modification of that instrument and the abrogation of such clause thereof as do not comport with the obligation of the united states toward colombia or with the vital need of the two friendly party to the compact

 this government see with great concern the continuance of the hostile relation between chile bolivia and peru an early peace between theserepublic be much to be desire not only that they may themselves be spare further misery and bloodshed but because their continued antagonism threaten consequence which be in my judgment dangerous to the interest of republican government on this continent and calculate to destroy the good element of our free and peaceful civilization

 as in the present excited condition of popular feeling in these country there have be serious misapprehension of the position of the united states and as separate diplomatic intercourse with each through independent minister be sometimes subject owe to the want of prompt reciprocal communication to temporary misunderstanding i have deem it judicious at the present time to send a special envoy accredit to all and each of they and furnish with general instruction which will i trust enable he to bring these power into friendly relation

 the government of venezuela maintain its attitude of warm friendship and continue with great regularity its payment of the monthly quota of the diplomatic debt without suggest the direction in which congress should act i ask its attention to the pende question affect the distribution of the sum thus far receive

 the relation between venezuela and france grow out of the same debt have be for some time past in an unsatisfactory state and this government as the neighbor and one of the large creditor of venezuela have interpose its influence with the french government with the view of produce a friendly and honorable adjustment

 i regret that the commercial interest between the united states andbrazil from which great advantage be hope a year ago have suffer from the withdrawal of the american line of communication between thebrazilian port and our own

 through the effort of our minister resident at buenos ayres and the united states minister at santiago a treaty have be conclude between the argentine republic and chile dispose of the long pende patagonian boundary question it be a matter of congratulation that our government have be afford the opportunity of successfully exert its good influence for the prevention of disagreement between these republic of the american continent

 i be glad to inform you that the treaty lately negotiate with china have be duly ratify on both side and the exchange make at peking legislation be necessary to carry their provision into effect the prompt and friendly spirit with which the chinese government at the request of the united states concede the modification of exist treaty should secure careful regard for the interest and susceptibility of that government in the enactment of any law relate to chinese immigration

 those clause of the treaty which forbid the participation of citizen or vessel of the united states in the opium trade will doubtless receive your approval they will attest the sincere interest which our people andgovernment feel in the commendable effort of the chinese government to put a stop to this demoralizing and destructive traffic

 in relation both to china and japan some change be desirable in our present system of consular jurisdiction i hope at some future time to lay before you a scheme for its improvement in the entire east

 the intimacy between our own country and japan the most advanced of the eastern nation continue to be cordial i be advise that the emperor contemplate the establishment of full constitutional government and that he have already summon a parliamentary congress for the purpose of effect the change such a remarkable step toward complete assimilation with thewestern system can not fail to bring japan into close and more beneficial relationship with ourselves as the chief pacific power

 a question have arise in relation to the exercise in that country of the judicial function confer upon our minister and consul the indictment trial and conviction in the consular court at yokohama of john ross a merchant seaman on board an american vessel have make it necessary for the government to institute a careful examination into the nature and method of this jurisdiction

 it appear that ross be regularly ship under the flag of the unitedstates but be by birth a british subject my predecessor feel it his duty to maintain the position that during his service as a regularly ship seaman on board an american merchant vessel ross be subject to the law of that service and to the jurisdiction of the united states consular authority

 i renew the recommendation which have be heretofore urge by the executive upon the attention of congress that after the deduction of such amount as may be find due to american citizen the balance of the indemnity fund heretofore obtain from china and japan and which be now in the hand of the state department be return to the government of those country

 the king of hawaii in the course of his homeward return after a journey around the world have lately visit this country while our relation with that kingdom be friendly this government have view with concern the effort to seek replenishment of the diminish population of the island from outward source to a degree which may impair the native sovereignty and independence in which the united states be among the first to testify a lively interest

 relation of unimpaired amity have be maintain throughout the year with the respective governments of austria hungary belgium denmark hayti paraguay and uruguay portugal and sweden and norway this may also be say of greece and ecuador although our relation with those states have for some year be sever by the withdrawal of appropriation for diplomatic representative at athens and quito it seem expedient to restore those mission even on a reduced scale and i decidedly recommend such a course with respect to ecuador which be likely within the near future to play an important part among the nation of the southern pacific

 at its last extra session the senate call for the text of the geneva convention for the relief of the wound in war i trust that this action foreshadow such interest in the subject as will result in the adhesion of the united states to that humane and commendable engagement

 i invite your attention to the propriety of adopt the new code of international rule for the prevention of collision on the high sea and of conform the domestic legislation of the united states thereto so that no confusion may arise from the application of conflict rule in the case of vessel of different nationality meeting in tidal water these international rule differ but slightly from our own they have be adopt by the navy department for the governance of the war ship of theunited states on the high sea and in foreign water and through the action of the state department in disseminate the rule and in acquainting shipmaster with the option of conform to they without the jurisdictional water of the united states they be now very generally know and obey

 the state department still continue to publish to the country the trade and manufacturing report receive from its officer abroad the success of this course warrant its continuance and such appropriation as may be require to meet the rapidly increase demand for these publication with special reference to the atlanta cotton exposition the october number of the report be devoted to a valuable collection of paper on the cotton good trade of the world

 the international sanitary conference for which in 1879 congress make provision assemble in this city early in january last and its session be prolong until march although it reach no specific conclusion affect the future action of the participant power the interchange of view prove to be most valuable the full protocol of the session have be already present to the senate

 as pertinent to this general subject i call your attention to the operation of the national board of health establish by act of congress approvedmarch 3 1879 its sphere of duty be enlarge by the act of june 2 in the same year by the last name act the board be require to institute such measure as might be deem necessary for prevent the introduction of contagious or infectious disease from foreign country into the unitedstates or from one state into another

 the execution of the rule and regulation prepare by the board and approve by my predecessor have do much to arrest the progress of epidemic disease and have thus render substantial service to the nation

 the international sanitary conference to which i have refer adopt a form of a bill of health to be use by all vessel seek to enter the port of the country whose representative participate in its deliberation this form have since be prescribe by the national board of health and incorporate with its rule and regulation which have be approve by i in pursuance of law

 the health of the people be of supreme importance all measure look to their protection against the spread of contagious disease and to the increase of our sanitary knowledge for such purpose deserve attention of congress

 the report of the secretary of the treasury present in detail a highly satisfactory exhibit of the state of the finance and the condition of the various branch of the public service administer by that department

 the requirement of the sink fund for the year amount to $ 90,786,064.02,which sum include a balance of $ 49,817,128.78 not provide for during the previous fiscal year the sum of $ 74,480,20l.05 be apply to this fund which leave a deficit of $ 16,305,873.47 the increase of the revenue for 1881 over those of the previous year be $ 29,352,901.10 it be estimate that the receipt during the present fiscal year will reach $ 400,000,000and the expenditure $ 270,000,000 leave a surplus of $ 130,000,000 applicable to the sink fund and the redemption of the public debt

 i approve the recommendation of the secretary of the treasury that provision be make for the early retirement of silver certificate and that the act require their issue be repeal they be issue in pursuance of the policy of the government to maintain silver at or near the gold standard and be accordingly make receivable for all custom taxis and public due about sixty six million of they be now outstanding they form an unnecessary addition to the paper currency a sufficient amount of which may be readily supply by the national bank

 in accordance with the act of february 28 1878 the treasury department have monthly cause at least two million in value of silver bullion to be coin into standard silver dollar one hundred and two million of these dollar have be already coin while only about thirty four million be in circulation

 for the reason which he specify i concur in the secretary 's recommendation that the provision for coinage of a fix amount each month be repeal and that hereafter only so much be coin as shall be necessary to supply the demand

 the secretary advise that the issue of gold certificate should not for the present be resume and suggest that the national bank may properly be forbid by law to retire their currency except upon reasonable notice of their intention so to do such legislation would seem to be justify by the recent action of certain bank on the occasion refer to in thesecretary 's report

 of the fifteen million of fractional currency still outstanding only about eighty thousand have be redeem the past year the suggestion that this amount may properly be drop from future statement of the public debt seem worthy of approval

 so also do the suggestion of the secretary as to the advisability of relieve the calendar of the united states court in the southern district of new york by the transfer to another tribunal of the numerous suit there pende against collector

 in the last annual report of the secretary of the treasury the attention of congress be call to the fact that $ 469,651,050 in 5 per cent bond and $ 203,573,750 in 6 per cent bond would become redeemable during the year and congress be ask to authorize the refunding of these bond at a low rate of interest the bill for such refunding having fail to become a law the secretary of the treasury in april last notify the holder of the $ 195,690,400 6 per cent bond then outstanding that the bond would be pay at par on the 1st day of july following or that they might be continue at the pleasure of the government to bear interest at the rate of 3 1/2 per cent per annum

 under this notice $ 178,055,150 of the 6 per cent bond be continue at the low rate and $ 17,635,250 be redeem

 in the month of may a like notice be give respect the redemption or continuance of the $ 439,841,350 of 5 per cent bond then outstanding and of these $ 401,504,900 be continue at 3 1/2 per cent per annum and$38,336,450 redeem

 the 6 per cent bond of the loan of february 8 1861 and of the oregon war debt amount together to $ 14,125,800 having mature during the year the secretary of the treasury give notice of his intention to redeem the same and such as have be present have be pay from the surplus revenue there have also be redeem at par $ 16,179,100 of the 3 1/2per cent continue bond make a total of bond redeem or which have cease to bear interest during the year of $ 123,969,650

 the reduction of the annual interest on the public debt through thesetransaction be as follow


 by reduction of interest to 3 1/2 per cent   $ 10,473,952.25
 by redemption of bond   6,352,340.00



 total   16,826,292.25


 the 3 1/2 per cent bond be payable at the pleasure of the government be available for the investment of surplus revenue without the payment of premium

 unless these bond can be fund at a much low rate of interest than they now bear i agree with the secretary of the treasury that no legislation respect they be desirable

 it be a matter for congratulation that the business of the country have be so prosperous during the past year as to yield by taxation a large surplus of income to the government if the revenue law remain unchanged this surplus must year by year increase on account of the reduction of the public debt and its burden of interest and because of the rapid increase of our population in 1860 just prior to the institution of our internal revenue system our population but slightly exceed 30,000,000 by the census of 1880 it be now find to exceed 50,000,000 it be estimate that even if the annual receipt and expenditure should continue as at present the entire debt could be pay in ten year

 in view however of the heavy load of taxation which our people have already bear we may well consider whether it be not the part of wisdom to reduce the revenue even if we delay a little the payment of the debt

 it seem to i that the time have arrive when the people may justly demand some relief from their present onerous burden and that by due economy in the various branch of the public service this may readily be afford

 i therefore concur with the secretary in recommend the abolitionof all internal revenue taxis except those upon tobacco in its variousform and upon distilled spirit and ferment liquor and except alsothe special tax upon the manufacturer of and dealer in such article the retention of the latter tax be desirable as afford the officersof the government a proper supervision of these article for the preventionof fraud i agree with the secretary of the treasury that the law imposinga stamp tax upon match proprietary article play card cheek and draft may with propriety be repeal and the law also by which banksand banker be assess upon their capital and deposit there seem tobe a general sentiment in favor of this course

 in the present condition of our revenue the tax upon deposit be especially unjust it be never impose in this country until it be demand by the necessity of war and be never exact i believe in any other country even in its great exigency bank be require to secure their circulation by pledge with the treasurer of the united states bond of the generalgovernment the interest upon these bond which at the time when the tax be impose be 6 per cent be now in most instance 3 1/2 per cent besides the entire circulation be originally limit by law and no increase be allowable when the exist bank have practically a monopoly of the business there be force in the suggestion that for the franchise to the favor grantee the government might very properly exact a tax on circulation;but for year the system have be free and the amount of circulation regulate by the public demand

 the retention of this tax have be suggest as a means of reimburse the government for the expense of printing and furnish the circulate note if the tax should be repeal it would certainly seem proper to require the national bank to pay the amount of such expense to the comptroller of the currency

 it be perhaps doubtful whether the immediate reduction of the rate of taxation upon liquor and tobacco be advisable especially in view of the drain upon the treasury which must attend the payment of arrear of pension a comparison however of the amount of taxis collect under the vary rate of taxation which have at different time prevail suggest the intimation that some reduction may soon be make without material diminution of the revenue

 the tariff law also need revision but that a due regard may be pay to the conflict interest of our citizen important change should be make with caution if a careful revision can not be make at this session a commission such as be lately approve by the senate and be now recommend by the secretary of the treasury would doubtless lighten the labor ofcongress whenever this subject shall be bring to its consideration

 the accompanying report of the secretary of war will make known to you the operation of that department for the past year

 he suggest measure for promote the efficiency of the army without add to the number of its officer and recommend the legislation necessary to increase the number of enlisted man to 30,000 the maximum allow bylaw
