 this he deem necessary to maintain quietude on our ever shift frontier;to preserve peace and suppress disorder and maraud in new settlements;to protect settler and their property against indians and indians against the encroachment of intruder and to enable peaceable immigrant to establish home in the most remote part of our country

 the army be now necessarily scatter over such a vast extent of territory that whenever an outbreak occur reenforcement must be hurry from many quarter over great distance and always at heavy cost for transportation of man horse wagon and supply

 i concur in the recommendation of the secretary for increase thearmy to the strength of 30,000 enlist man

 it appear by the secretary 's report that in the absence of disturbance on the frontier the troop have be actively employ in collect theindians hitherto hostile and locate they on their proper reservations;that sit bull and his adherent be now prisoner at fort randall;that the utes have be move to their new reservation in utah that during the recent outbreak of the apaches it be necessary to reenforce the garrison in arizona by troop withdraw from new mexico and that some of the apaches be now hold prisoner for trial while some have escape and the majority of the tribe be now on their reservation

 there be need of legislation to prevent intrusion upon the land set apart for the indians a large military force at great expense be now require to patrol the boundary line between kansas and the indian territory the only punishment that can at present be inflict be the forcible removal of the intruder and the imposition of a pecuniary fine which in most case it be impossible to collect there should be a penalty by imprisonment in such case

 the separate organization of the signal service be urge by the secretary of war and a full statement of the advantage of such permanent organization be present in the report of the chief signal officer a detailed account of the useful work perform by the signal corps and the weather bureau be also give in that report

 i ask attention to the statement of the secretary of war regard the requisition frequently make by the indian bureau upon the subsistencedepartment of the army for the casual support of band and tribe of indians whose appropriation be exhaust the war department should not be leave by reason of inadequate provision for the indian bureau to contribute for the maintenance of indians

 the report of the chief of engineers furnish a detailed account of the operation for the improvement of river and harbor

 i commend to your attention the suggestion contain in this report in regard to the condition of our fortification especially our coast defense and recommend an increase of the strength of the engineer battalion by which the efficiency of our torpedo system would be improve

 i also call your attention to the remark upon the improvement of thesouth pass of the mississippi river the propose free bridge over thepotomac river at georgetown the importance of complete at an early day the north wing of the war department building and other recommendation of the secretary of war which appear in his report

 the actual expenditure of that department for the fiscal year endingjune 30 1881 be $ 42,122,201.39 the appropriation for the year 1882were $ 44,889,725.42 the estimate for 1883 be $ 44,541,276.91

 the report of the secretary of the navy exhibit the condition of that branch of the service and present valuable suggestion for its improvement i call your especial attention also to the appended report of the advisoryboard which he convene to devise suitable measure for increase the efficiency of the navy and particularly to report as to the character and number of vessel necessary to place it upon a footing commensurate with the necessity of the government

 i can not too strongly urge upon you my conviction that every consideration of national safety economy and honor imperatively demand a thorough rehabilitation of our navy

 with a full appreciation of the fact that compliance with the suggestion of the head of that department and of the advisory board must involve a large expenditure of the public money i earnestly recommend such appropriation as will accomplish an end which seem to i so desirable

 nothing can be more inconsistent with true public economy than withhold the mean necessary to accomplish the object intrust by the constitution to the national legislature one of those object and one which be of paramount importance be declare by our fundamental law to be the provision for the common defense surely nothing be more essential to the defense of the united states and of all our people than the efficiency of our navy

 we have for many year maintain with foreign government the relation of honorable peace and that such relation may be permanent be desire by every patriotic citizen of the republic but if we heed the teaching of history we shall not forget that in the life of every nation emergency may arise when a resort to arm can alone save it from dishonor

 no danger from abroad now threaten this people nor have we any cause to distrust the friendly profession of other government but for avoid as well as for repel danger that may threaten we in the future we must be prepare to enforce any policy which we think wise to adopt

 we must be ready to defend our harbor against aggression to protect by the distribution of our ship of war over the highway of commerce the varied interest of our foreign trade and the person and property of our citizen abroad to maintain everywhere the honor of our flag and the distinguished position which we may rightfully claim among the nation of the world

 the report of the postmaster general be a gratifying exhibit of the growth and efficiency of the postal service

 the receipt from postage and other ordinary source during the past fiscal year be $ 36,489,816.58 the receipt from the money order business be $ 295,581.39 make a total of $ 36,785,397.97 the expenditure for the fiscal year be $ 39,251,736.46 the deficit supply out of the generaltreasury be $ 2,481,129.35 or 6.3 per cent of the amount expend the receipt be $ 3,469,918.63 in excess of those of the previous year and$4,575,397.97 in excess of the estimate make two year ago before the present period of business prosperity have fairly begin

 the whole number of letter mail in this country in the last fiscal year exceed 1,000,000,000

 the registry system be report to be in excellent condition having be remodel during the past four year with good result the amount of registration fee collect during the last fiscal year be $ 712,882.20,an increase over the fiscal year end june 30 1877 of $ 345,443.40

 the entire number of letter and package register during the year be 8,338,919 of which only 2,061 be lose or destroy in transit

 the operation of the money order system be multiply yearly under the impulse of immigration of the rapid development of the new states and territories and the consequent demand for additional mean of intercommunication and exchange

 during the past year 338 additional money order office have be establish make a total of 5,499 in operation at the date of this report

 during the year the domestic money order aggregate in value 105,075,769.35

 a modification of the system be suggest reduce the fee for money order not exceed $ 5 from 10 cent to 5 cent and make the maximum limit 100 in place of $ 50

 legislation for the disposition of unclaimed money order in the possession of the post office department be recommend in view of the fact that their total value now exceed $ 1,000,000

 the attention of congress be again invite to the subject of establish a system of saving depository in connection with the post office department

 the statistic of mail transportation show that during the past year railroad route have be increase in length 6,249 mile and in cost $ 1,114,382,while steamboat route have be decrease in length 2,182 mile and in cost $ 134,054 the so call star route have be decrease in length3,949 mile and in cost $ 364,144

 nearly all of the more expensive route have be supersede by railroad service the cost of the star service must therefore rapidly decrease in the western states and territories

 the postmaster general however call attention to the constantly increase cost of the railway mail service as a serious difficulty in the way of make the department self sustaining

 our postal intercourse with foreign country have keep pace with the growth of the domestic service within the past year several country and colony have declare their adhesion to the postal union it now include all those which have an organized postal service except bolivia costarica new zealand and the british colony in australia

 as have be already state great reduction have recently be make in the expense of the star route service the investigation of the department of justice and the post office department have result in the presentation of indictment against person formerly connect with that service accuse they of offense against the united states i have enjoin upon the official who be charge with the conduct of the case on the part of the government and upon the eminent counsel who before my accession to the presidency be call to their assistance the duty of prosecute with the utmost vigor of the law all person who may be find chargeable with fraud upon the postal service

 the acting attorney general call attention to the necessity of modify the present system of the court of the united states a necessity dueto the large increase of business especially in the supreme court litigation in our federal tribunal became greatly expand after the close of the late war so long as that expansion might be attributable to the abnormal condition in which the community find itself immediately after the return of peace prudence require that no change be make in the constitution of our judicial tribunal but it have now become apparent that an immense increase of litigation have directly result from the wonderful growth and development of the country there be no ground for belief that the business of the united states court will ever be less in volume than at present indeed that it be likely to be much great be generally recognize by the bench and bar

 in view of the fact that congress have already give much consideration to this subject i make no suggestion as to detail but express the hope that your deliberation may result in such legislation as will give early relief to our overburden court

 the acting attorney general also call attention to the disturbance of the public tranquillity during the past year in the territory of arizona a band of armed desperado know as cowboys probably number from fifty to one hundred man have be engage for month in commit act of lawlessness and brutality which the local authority have be unable to repress the depredation of these cowboys have also extend intomexico which the marauder reach from the arizona frontier with every disposition to meet the exigency of the case i be embarrass by lack of authority to deal with they effectually the punishment of crime commit within arizona should ordinarily of course be leave to the territorial authority but it be worthy consideration whether act which necessarily tend to embroil the united states with neighboring government should not be declare crime against the united states some of the incursion allude to may perhaps be within the scope of the law u. s. revised statutes sec 5286 forbid military expedition or enterprise against friendly state but in view of the speedy assembling of your body i have prefer to await such legislation as in your wisdom the occasion may seem to demand

 it may perhaps be think proper to provide that the setting on foot within our own territory of brigandage and armed marauding expedition against friendly nation and their citizen shall be punishable as an offense against the united states

 i will add that in the event of a request from the territorial government for protection by the united states against domestic violence this government would be powerless to render assistance

 the act of 1795 chapter 36 pass at a time when territorial government receive little attention from congress enforce this duty of the unitedstates only as to the state government but the act of 1807 chapter 39,applied also to territories this law seem to have remain in force until the revision of the statute when the provision for the territories be drop i be not advise whether this alteration be intentional or accidental but as it seem to i that the territories should be offer the protection which be accord to the staten by the constitution i suggest legislation to that end

 it seem to i too that whatever view may prevail as to the policy of recent legislation by which the army have cease to be a part of the posse comitatus an exception might well be make for permit the military to assist the civil territorial authority in enforce the law of the united states this use of the army would not seem to be within the allege evil against which that legislation be aim from sparseness of population and other circumstance it be often quite impracticable to summon a civil posse in place where officer of justice require assistance and where a military force be within easy reach

 the report of the secretary of the interior with accompany document present an elaborate account of the business of that department a summary of it would be too extended for this place i ask your careful attention to the report itself

 prominent among the matter which challenge the attention of congress at its present session be the management of our indian affair while this question have be a cause of trouble and embarrassment from the infancy of the government it be but recently that any effort have be make for its solution at once serious determined consistent and promise success

 it have be easy to resort to convenient makeshift for tide over temporary difficulty than to grapple with the great permanent problem and accordingly the easy course have almost invariably be pursue

 it be natural at a time when the national territory seem almost illimitable and contain many million of acre far outside the bound of civilized settlement that a policy should have be initiate which more than aught else have be the fruitful source of our indian complication

 i refer of course to the policy of deal with the various indian tribe as separate nationality of relegate they by treaty stipulation to the occupancy of immense reservation in the west and of encourage they to live a savage life undisturbe by any earnest and well direct effort to bring they under the influence of civilization

 the unsatisfactory result which have spring from this policy be become apparent to all

 as the white settlement have crowd the border of the reservation the indians sometimes contentedly and sometimes against their will have be transfer to other hunting ground from which they have again be dislodge whenever their new find home have be desire by the adventurous settler

 these removal and the frontier collision by which they have often be precede have lead to frequent and disastrous conflict between the race

 it be profitless to discuss here which of they have be chiefly responsible for the disturbance whose recital occupy so large a space upon the page of our history

 we have to deal with the appalling fact that though thousand of life have be sacrifice and hundred of million of dollar expend in the attempt to solve the indian problem it have until within the past few year seem scarcely near a solution than it be half a century ago but thegovernment have of late be cautiously but steadily feel its way to the adoption of a policy which have already produce gratifying result and which in my judgment be likely if congress and the executive accord in its support to relieve we ere long from the difficulty which have hitherto beset we

 for the success of the effort now make to introduce among the indians the custom and pursuit of civilized life and gradually to absorb they into the mass of our citizen share their right and holden to their responsibility there be imperative need for legislative action

 my suggestion in that regard will be chiefly such as have be already call to the attention of congress and have receive to some extent its consideration

 first i recommend the passage of an act make the law of the variousstate and territories applicable to the indian reservation within their border and extend the law of the state of arkansas to the portion of the indian territory not occupy by the five civilized tribes

 the indian should receive the protection of the law he should be allow to maintain in court his right of person and property he have repeatedly beg for this privilege its exercise would be very valuable to he in his progress toward civilization

 second of even great importance be a measure which have be frequently recommend by my predecessor in office and in furtherance of which several bill have be from time to time introduce in both houses of congress the enactment of a general law permit the allotment in severalty to such indians at least as desire it of a reasonable quantity of land secure to they by patent and for their own protection make inalienable for twenty or twenty five year be demand for their present welfare and their permanent advancement

 in return for such considerate action on the part of the government there be reason to believe that the indians in large number would be persuade to sever their tribal relation and to engage at once in agricultural pursuit many of they realize the fact that their hunting day be over and that it be now for their good interest to conform their manner of life to the new order of thing by no great inducement than the assurance of permanent title to the soil can they be lead to engage in the occupation of till it

 the well attest report of their increase interest in husbandry justify the hope and belief that the enactment of such a statute as i recommend would be at once attend with gratifying result a resort to the allotment system would have a direct and powerful influence in dissolve the tribal bond which be so prominent a feature of savage life and which tend so strongly to perpetuate it

 third i advise a liberal appropriation for the support of indian school because of my confident belief that such a course be consistent with the wise economy

 even among the most uncultivated indian tribe there be report to be a general and urgent desire on the part of the chief and old member for the education of their child it be unfortunate in view of this fact that during the past year the mean which have be at the command of the interior department for the purpose of indian instruction have prove to be utterly inadequate

 the success of the school which be in operation at hampton carlisle and forest grove should not only encourage a more generous provision for the support of those institution but should prompt the establishment of other of a similar character

 they be doubtless much more potent for good than the day school upon the reservation as the pupil be altogether separate from the surrounding of savage life and bring into constant contact with civilization

 there be many other phase of this subject which be of great interest but which can not be include within the become limit of this communication they be discuss ably in the report of the secretary of the interior and the commissioner of indian affairs

 for many year the executive in his annual message to congress have urge the necessity of stringent legislation for the suppression of polygamy in the territories and especially in the territory of utah the exist statute for the punishment of this odious crime so revolt to the moral and religious sense of christendom have be persistently and contemptuously violate ever since its enactment indeed in spite of commendable effort on the part of the authority who represent the united states in thatterritory the law have in very rare instance be enforce and for a cause to which reference will presently be make be practically a dead letter

 the fact that adherent of the mormon church which rest upon polygamy as its corner stone have recently be people in large number idaho arizona and other of our western territories be well calculate to excite the lively interest and apprehension it impose upon congress and theexecutive the duty of array against this barbarous system all the power which under the constitution and the law they can wield for its destruction

 reference have be already make to the obstacle which the united states officer have encounter in their effort to punish violation of law prominent among these obstacle be the difficulty of procure legal evidence sufficient to warrant a conviction even in the case of the most notorious offender

 your attention be call to a recent opinion of the supreme court of the united states explain its judgment of reversal in the case of miles who have be convict of bigamy in utah the court refer to the fact that the secrecy attend the celebration of marriage in that territory make the proof of polygamy very difficult and the propriety be suggest of modify the law of evidence which now make a wife incompetent to testify against her husband

 this suggestion be approve i recommend also the passage of an act provide that in the territories of the united states the fact that a woman have be marry to a person charge with bigamy shall not disqualify she as a witness upon his trial for that offense i far recommend legislation by which any person solemnize a marriage in any of the territories shall be require under stringent penalty for neglect or refusal to file a certificate of such marriage in the supreme court of the territory

 doubtless congress may devise other practicable measure for obviate the difficulty which have hitherto attend the effort to suppress this iniquity i assure you of my determined purpose to cooperate with you in any lawful and discreet measure which may be propose to that end

 although our system of government do not contemplate that the nation should provide or support a system for the education of our people no measure calculate to promote that general intelligence and virtue upon which the perpetuity of our institution so greatly depend have ever be regard with indifference by congress or the executive

 a large portion of the public domain have be from time to time devote to the promotion of education

 there be now a special reason why by set apart the proceed of its sale of public land or by some other course the government should aid the work of education many who now exercise the right of suffrage be unable to read the ballot which they cast upon many who have just emerge from a condition of slavery be suddenly devolve the responsibility of citizenship in that portion of the country most impoverish by war i have be pleased to learn from the report of the commissioner of education that there have lately be a commendable increase of interest and effort for their instruction but all that can be do by local legislation and private generosity should be supplement by such aid as can be constitutionally afford by the national government

 i would suggest that if any fund be dedicate to this purpose it maybe wisely distribute in the different states accord to the ratio of illiteracy as by this mean those locality which be most in need of such assistance will reap its special benefit

 the report of the commissioner of agriculture exhibit the result of the experiment in which that department have be engage during the past year and make important suggestion in reference to the agricultural development of the country

 the steady increase of our population and the consequent addition to the number of those engage in the pursuit of husbandry be give to this department a grow dignity and importance the commissioner 's suggestion touch its capacity for great usefulness deserve attention as it more and more commend itself to the interest which it be create to promote

 it appear from the report of the commissioner of pensions that since1860 789,063 original pension claim have be file 450,949 of these have be allow and inscribe on the pension roll 72,539 have be reject and abandon be 13 + per cent of the whole number of claim settle

 there be now pende for settlement 265,575 original pension claims,227,040 of which be file prior to july 1 1880 these when allow will involve the payment of arrear from the date of discharge in case of an invalid and from date of death or termination of a prior right in all other case

 from all the datum obtainable it be estimate that 15 per cent of the number of claim now pende will be reject or abandon this would show the probable rejection of 34,040 case and the probable admission of about 193,000 claim all of which involve the payment of arrear of pension

 with the present force employ the number of adjudication remain the same and no new business intervene this number of claim 193,000)could be act upon in a period of six year and take january 1 1884,as a near period from which to estimate in each case an average amount of arrear it be find that every case allow would require for the first payment upon it the sum of $ 1,350 multiply this amount by the whole number of probable admission give $ 250,000,000 as the sum require for first payment this represent the sum which must be pay upon claim which be file before july 1 1880 and be now pende and entitle to the benefit of the arrear act from this amount $ 250,000,000 may be deduct from ten to fifteen million for case where the claimant dying there be no person who under the law would be entitle to succeed to the pension leave $ 235,000,000 as the probable amount to be pay

 in these estimate no account have be take of the 38,500 case file since june 30 1880 and now pende which must receive attention as current business but which do not involve the payment of any arrear beyond the date of file the claim of this number it be estimate that 86 per cent will be allow

 as have be state with the present force of the pension bureau 675clerks it be estimate that it will take six year to dispose of the claim now pende

 it be state by the commissioner of pensions that by an addition of250 clerk increase the adjudicate force rather than the mechanical)double the amount of work could be accomplish so that these case could be act upon within three year

 aside from the consideration of justice which may be urge for a speedy settlement of the claim now on the file of the pension office it be no less important on the score of economy inasmuch as fully one third of the clerical force of the office be now wholly occupy in give attention to correspondence with the thousand of claimant whose case have be on the file for the past eighteen year the fact that a sum so enormous must be expend by the government to meet demand for arrear of pension be an admonition to congress and the executive to give cautious consideration to any similar project in the future the great temptation to the presentation of fictitious claim afford by the fact that the average sum obtain upon each application be $ 1,300 lead i to suggest the propriety of make some special appropriation for the prevention of fraud

 i advise appropriation for such internal improvement as the wisdom of congress may deem to be of public importance the necessity of improve the navigation of the mississippi river justify a special allusion to that subject i suggest the adoption of some measure for the removal of obstruction which now impede the navigation of that great channel of commerce

 in my letter accept the nomination for the vice presidency i state that in my judgment--

 no man should be the incumbent of an office the duty of which he be for any cause unfit to perform who be lack in the ability fidelity or integrity which a proper administration of such office demand this sentiment would doubtless meet with general acquiescence but opinion have be widely divide upon the wisdom and practicability of the various reformatory scheme which have be suggest and of certain propose regulation govern appointment to public office
 the efficiency of such regulation have be distrust mainly because they have seem to exalt mere educational and abstract test above general business capacity and even special fitness for the particular work in hand it seem to i that the rule which should be apply to the management of the public service may properly conform in the main to such as regulate the conduct of successful private business
 original appointment should be base upon ascertain fitness
 the tenure of office should be stable
 position of responsibility should so far as practicable be fill by the promotion of worthy and efficient officer
 the investigation of all complaint and the punishment of all official misconduct should be prompt and thorough
 the view express in the forego letter be those which will govern my administration of the executive office they be doubtless share by all intelligent and patriotic citizen however divergent in their opinion as to the good method of put they into practical operation
 for example the assertion that original appointment should be base upon ascertain fitness be not open to dispute

 but the question how in practice such fitness can be most effectually ascertained be one which have for year excited interest and discussion the measure which with slight variation in its detail have lately be urge upon the attention of congress and the executive have as its principal feature the scheme of competitive examination save for certain exception which need not here be specify this plan would allow admission to the service only in its low grade and would accordingly demand that all vacancy in high position should be fill by promotion alone in these particular it be in conformity with the exist civil service system of great britain and indeed the success which have attend that system in the country of its birth be the strong argument which have be urge for its adoption here

 the fact should not however be overlook that there be certain feature of the english system which have not generally be receive with favor in this country even among the foremost advocate of civil service reform

 among they be
 1 a tenure of office winch be substantially a life tenure
 2 a limitation of the maximum age at which an applicant can enter the service whereby all man in middle life or old be with some exception rigidly exclude
 3 a retire allowance upon go out of office

 these three element be as important factor of the problem as any of the other to eliminate they from the english system would effect a most radical change in its theory and practice

 the avow purpose of that system be to induce the educate young man of the country to devote their life to public employment by an assurance that having once enter upon it they need never leave it and that after voluntary retirement they shall be the recipient of an annual pension that this system as an entirety have prove very successful in great britain seem to be generally concede even by those who once oppose its adoption

 to a statute which should incorporate all its essential feature i should feel bound to give my approval but whether it would be for the good interest of the public to fix upon an expedient for immediate and extensive application which embrace certain feature of the english system but exclude or ignore other of equal importance may be seriously doubt even by those who be impressed as i be myself with the grave importance of correct the evil which inhere in the present method of appointment

 if for example the english rule which shut out person above the age of 25 year from a large number of public employment be not to be make an essential part of our own system it be questionable whether the attainment of the high number of mark at a competitive examination should be the criterion by which all application for appointment should be put to test and under similar condition it may also be question whether admission to the service should be strictly limit to its low rank

 there be very many characteristic which go to make a model civil servant prominent among they be probity industry good sense good habit good temper patience order courtesy tact self reliance manly deference to superior officer and manly consideration for inferior the absence of these trait be not supply by wide knowledge of book or by promptitude in answer question or by any other quality likely to be bring to light by competitive examination

 to make success in such a contest therefore an indispensable condition of public employment would very likely result in the practical exclusion of the old applicant even though they might possess qualification far superior to their young and more brilliant competitor

 these suggestion must not be regard as evince any spirit of opposition to the competitive plan which have be to some extent successfully employ already and which may hereafter vindicate the claim of its most earnest supporter but it ought to be seriously consider whether the application of the same educational standard to person of mature year and to young man fresh from school and college would not be likely to exalt mere intellectual proficiency above other quality of equal or great importance

 another feature of the propose system be the selection by promotion of all officer of the government above the low grade except such as would fairly be regard as exponent of the policy of the executive and the principle of the dominant party

 to afford encouragement to faithful public servant by exciting in their mind the hope of promotion if they be find to merit it be much to be desire

 but would it be wise to adopt a rule so rigid as to permit no other mode of supply the intermediate walk of the service

 there be many person who fill subordinate position with great credit but lack those quality which be requisite for high post of duty;and besides the mode of thought and action of one whose service in a governmental bureau have be long continue be often so cramp by routine procedure as almost to disqualify he from institute change require by the public interest an infusion of new blood from time to time into the middle rank of the service might be very beneficial in its result

 the subject under discussion be one of grave importance the evil which be complain of can not be eradicate at once the work must be gradual

 the present english system be a growth of year and be not create by a single stroke of executive or legislative action

 its beginning be find in an order in council promulgate in 1855,and it be after patient and cautious scrutiny of its working that fifteen year later it take its present shape

 five year after the issuance of the order in council and at a time when resort have be have to competitive examination as an experiment much more extensively than have yet be the case in this country a select committee of the house of commons make a report to that house which declare its approval of the competitive plan deprecate nevertheless any precipitancy in its general adoption as likely to endanger its ultimate success

 during this tentative period the result of the two method of pass examination and competitive examination be closely watch and compare it may be that before we confine ourselves upon this important question within the stringent bound of statutory enactment we may profitably await the result of further inquiry and experiment

 the submission of a portion of the nomination to a central board of examiner select solely for test the qualification of applicant may perhaps without resort to the competitive test put an end to the mischief which attend the present system of appointment and it may be feasible to vest in such a board a wide discretion to ascertain the characteristic and attainment of candidate in those particular which i have already refer to as be no less important than mere intellectual attainment

 if congress should deem it advisable at the present session to establish competitive test for admission to the service no doubt such as have be suggest shall deter i from give the measure my earnest support

 and i urgently recommend should there be a failure to pass any other act upon this subject that an appropriation of $ 25,000 per year may be make for the enforcement of section 1753 of the revised statutes

 with the aid thus afford i i shall strive to execute the provision of that law accord to its letter and spirit

 i be unwilling in justice to the present civil servant of the government to dismiss this subject without declare my dissent from the severe and almost indiscriminate censure with which they have be recently assail that they be as a class indolent inefficient and corrupt be a statement which have be often make and widely credit but when the extent variety delicacy and importance of their duty be consider the great majority of the employee of the government be in my judgment deserve of high commendation

 the continue decline of the merchant marine of the united states be greatly to be deplore in view of the fact that we furnish so large a proportion of the freight of the commercial world and that our shipment be steadily and rapidly increase it be cause of surprise that not only be our navigation interest diminishing but it be less than when our export and import be not half so large as now either in bulk or value there must be some peculiar hindrance to the development of this interest or the enterprise and energy of american mechanic and capitalist would have keep this country at least abreast of our rival in the friendly contest for ocean supremacy

 the substitution of iron for wood and of steam for sail have work great revolution in the carry trade of the world but these change could not have be adverse to america if we have give to our navigation interest a portion of the aid and protection which have be so wisely bestow upon our manufacture i commend the whole subject to the wisdom of congress with the suggestion that no question of great magnitude or far reach importance can engage their attention

 in 1875 the supreme court of the united states declare unconstitutional the statute of certain states which impose upon shipowner or consignee a tax of $ 1.50 for each passenger arrive from a foreign country or in lieu thereof require a bond to indemnify the state and local authority against expense for the future relief or support of such passenger since this decision the expense attend the care and supervision of immigrant have fall on the states at whose port they have land as a large majority of such immigrant immediately upon their arrival proceed to the inlandstates and the territories to seek permanent home it be manifestly unjust to impose upon the state whose shore they first reach the burden which it now bear for this reason and because of the national importance of the subject i recommend legislation regard the supervision and transitory care of immigrant at the port of debarkation

 i regret to state that the people of alaska have reason to complain that they be as yet unprovide with any form of government by which life or property can be protect while the extent of its population do not justify the application of the costly machinery of territorial administration there be immediate necessity for constitute such a form of government as will promote the education of the people and secure the administration of justice

 the senate at its last session pass a bill provide for the construction of a building for the library of congress but it fail to become a law the provision of suitable protection for this great collection of book and for the copyright department connect with it have become a subject of national importance and should receive prompt attention

 the report of the commissioners of the district of columbia herewith transmit will inform you fully of the condition of the affair of thedistrict

 they urge the vital importance of legislation for the reclamation and improvement of the marsh and for the establishment of the harbor line along the potomac river front

 it be represent that in their present condition these marsh seriously affect the health of the resident of the adjacent part of the city and that they greatly mar the general aspect of the park in which stand thewashington monument this improvement would add to that park and to the park south of the executive mansion a large area of valuable land and would transform what be now believe to be a dangerous nuisance into an attractive landscape extend to the river front

 they recommend the removal of the steam railway line from the surface of the street of the city and the location of the necessary depot in such place as may be convenient for the public accommodation and they call attention to the deficiency of the water supply which seriously affect the material prosperity of the city and the health and comfort of its inhabitant

 i commend these subject to your favorable consideration
 the importance of timely legislation with respect to the ascertainment and declaration of the vote for presidential elector be sharply call to the attention of the people more than four year ago

 it be to be hope that some well define measure may be devise before another national election which will render unnecessary a resort to any expedient of a temporary character for the determination of question upon contest return

 question which concern the very existence of the government and the liberty of the people be suggest by the prolonged illness of the late president and his consequent incapacity to perform the function of his office

 it be provide by the second article of the constitution in the fifth clause of its first section that in case of the removal of the president from office or of his death resignation or inability to discharge the power and duty of the said office the same shall devolve on the vice president

 what be the intendment of the constitution in its specification of inability to discharge the power and duty of the said office as one of the contingency which call the vice president to the exercise of presidential function

 be the inability limit in its nature to long continue intellectual incapacity or have it a broad import

 what must be its extent and duration

 how must its existence be establish

 have the president whose inability be the subject of inquiry any voice in determine whether or not it exist or be the decision of that momentous and delicate question confide to the vice president or be it contemplate by the constitution that congress should provide by law precisely what should constitute inability and how and by what tribunal or authority it should be ascertain

 if the inability prove to be temporary in its nature and during its continuance the vice president lawfully exercise the function of theexecutive by what tenure do he hold his office

 do he continue as president for the remainder of the four year term

 or would the elect president if his inability should cease in the interval be empower to resume his office

 and if have such lawful authority he should exercise it would thevice president be thereupon empower to resume his power and duty as such

 i can not doubt that these important question will receive your early and thoughtful consideration

 deeply impressed with the gravity of the responsibility which have so unexpectedly devolve upon i it will be my constant purpose to cooperate with you in such measure as will promote the glory of the country and the prosperity of its people

to the senate of the united states
 after careful consideration of senate bill no 71 entitle an act to execute certain treaty stipulation relate to chinese i herewith return it to the senate in which it originate with my objection to its passage
 a nation be justify in repudiate its treaty obligation only when they be in conflict with great paramount interest even then all possible reasonable mean for modify or change those obligation by mutual agreement should be exhaust before resort to the supreme fight of refusal to comply with they
 these rule have govern the united states in their past intercourse with other power as one of the family of nation i be persuade that if congress can feel that this act violate the faith of the nation as pledge to china it will concur with i in reject this particular mode of regulate chinese immigration and will endeavor to find another which shall meet the expectation of the people of the united states without come in conflict with the right of china
 the present treaty relation between that power and the united states spring from an antagonism which arise between our paramount domestic interest and our previous relation
 the treaty commonly know as the burlingame treaty confer upon chinese subject the right of voluntary emigration to the united states for the purpose of curiosity or trade or as permanent resident and be in all respect reciprocal as to citizen of the united states in china it give to the voluntary emigrant come to the united states the right to travel there or to reside there with all the privilege immunity or exemption enjoy by the citizen or subject of the most favored nation
 under the operation of this treaty it be find that the institution of the united states and the character of its people and their mean of obtain a livelihood might be seriously affect by the unrestricted introduction of chinese labor congress attempt to alleviate this condition by legislation but the act which it pass prove to be in violation of our treaty obligation and be return by the president with his objection fail to become a law
 diplomatic relief be then seek a new treaty be conclude with china without abrogate the burlingame treaty it be agree to modify it so far that the government of the united states might regulate limit or suspend the coming of chinese laborer to the united states or their residence therein but that it should not absolutely prohibit they and that the limitation or suspension should be reasonable and should apply only to chinese who might go to the united states as laborer other class not be include in the limitation this treaty be unilateral not reciprocal it be a concession from china to the united states in limitation of the right which she be enjoy under the burlingame treaty it leave we by our own act to determine when and how we will enforce those limitation china may therefore fairly have a right to expect that in enforce they we will take good care not to overstep the grant and take more than have be concede to we
 it be but a year since this new treaty under the operation of the constitution become part of the supreme law of the land and the present act be the first attempt to exercise the more enlarged power which it relinquish to the united states
 in its first article the united states be empower to decide whether the come of chinese laborer to the united states or their residence therein affect or threaten to affect our interest or to endanger good order either within the whole country or in any part of it the act recite that in the opinion of the government of the united states the coming of chinese laborer to this country endanger the good order of certain locality thereof but the act itself be much broad than the recital it act upon residence as well as immigration and its provision be effective throughout the united states i think it may fairly be accept as an expression of the opinion of congress that the coming of such laborer to the united states or their residence here affect our interest and endanger good order throughout the country on this point i should feel it my duty to accept the view of congress
 the first article far confer the power upon this government to regulate limit or suspend but not actually to prohibit the coming of such laborer to or their residence in the united states the negotiator of the treaty have record with unusual fullness their understanding of the sense and meaning with which these word be use
 as to the class of person to be affect by the treaty the americans insert in their draft a provision that the word chinese laborer signify all immigration other than that for teaching trade travel study and curiosity the chinese object to this that it operate to include artisan in the class of laborer whose immigration might be forbid the americans reply that they could not consent that artisan shall be exclude from the class of chinese laborer for it be this very competition of skilled labor in the city where the chinese labor immigration concentrate which have cause the embarrassment and popular discontent in the subsequent negotiation this definition drop out and do not appear in the treaty article ii of the treaty confer the right privilege immunity and exemption which be accord to citizen and subject of the most favored nation upon chinese subject proceed to the united states as teacher student merchant or from curiosity the american commissioner report that the chinese government claim that in this article they do by exclusion provide that nobody should be entitle to claim the benefit of the general provision of the burlingame treaty but those who might go to the united states in those capacity or for those purpose i accept this as the definition of the word laborer as use in the treaty
 as to the power of legislate respect this class of person the new treaty provide that we may not absolutely prohibit their coming or their residence the chinese commissioner give notice in the outset that they would never agree to a prohibition of voluntary emigration notwithstanding this the united states commissioner submit a draft in which it be provide that the united states might regulate limit suspend or prohibit it the chinese refuse to accept this the americans reply that they be willing to consult the wish of the chinese government in preserve the principle of free intercourse between the people of the two country as establish by exist treaty provide that the right of the united states government to use its discretion in guard against any possible evil of immigration of chinese laborer be distinctly recognize therefore if such concession remove all difficulty on the part of the chinese commissioner but only in that case the united states commissioner will agree to remove the word 39;prohibit&#39 from their article and to use the word 39;regulate limit or suspend "&#39 the chinese reply to this can only be infer from the fact that in the place of an agreement as propose by our commissioner that we might prohibit the coming or residence of chinese laborer there be insert in the treaty an agreement that we might not do it
 the remain word regulate limit and suspend first appear in the american draft when it be submit to the chinese they say
 we infer that of the phrase regulate limit suspend or prohibit the first be a general expression refer to the other we be entirely ready to negotiate with your excellency to the end that a limitation either in point of time or of number may be fix upon the emigration of chinese laborer to the united states
 at a subsequent interview they say that by limitation in number they mean for example that the united states have as they suppose a record of the number of immigrant in each year as well as the total number of chinese now there that no more should be allow to go in any one year in future than either the great number which have go in any year in the past or that the total number should never be allow to exceed the number now there as to limitation of time they mean for example that chinese should be allow to go in alternate year or every third year or for example that they should not be allow to go for two three or five year
 at a subsequent conference the americans say
 the chinese commissioner have in their project explicitly recognize the right of the united states to use some discretion and have propose a limitation as to time and number this be the right to regulate limit or suspend
 in one of the conference the chinese ask the americans whether they could give they any idea of the law which would be pass to carry the power into execution the americans answer that this could hardly be do that the united states government might never deem it necessary to exercise this power it would depend upon circumstance if chinese immigration concentrate in city where it threaten public order or if it confine itself to locality where it be an injury to the interest of the american people the government of the united states would undoubtedly take step to prevent such accumulation of chinese if on the contrary there be no large immigration or if there be section of the country where such immigration be clearly beneficial then the legislation of the united states under this power would be adapt to such circumstance for example there might be a demand for chinese labor in the south and a surplus of such labor in california and congress might legislate in accordance with these fact in general the legislation would be in view of and depend upon the circumstance of the situation at the moment such legislation become necessary the chinese commissioner say this explanation be satisfactory that they have not intend to ask for a draft of any special act but for some general idea how the power would be exercise what have just be say give they the explanation which they want
 with this entire accord as to the meaning of the word they be about to employ and the object of the legislation which might be have in consequence the party sign the treaty in article i of which-- the government of china agree that the government of the united states may regulate limit or suspend such coming or residence but may not absolutely prohibit it the limitation or suspension shall be reasonable and shall apply only to chinese who may go to the united states as laborer other class not be include in the limitation legislation take in regard to chinese laborer will be of such a character only as be necessary to enforce the regulation limitation or suspension of immigration
 the first section of the act provide that--
 from and after the expiration of sixty day next after the passage of this act and until the expiration of twenty year next after the passage of this act the coming of chinese laborer be and the same be hereby suspend and during such suspension it shall not be lawful for any chinese laborer to come or having so come after the expiration of say sixty day to remain within the united states
 the examination which i have make of the treaty and of the declaration which its negotiator have leave on record of the meaning of its language leave no doubt in my mind that neither contract party in conclude the treaty of 1880 contemplate the passage of an act prohibit immigration for twenty year which be nearly a generation or think that such a period would be a reasonable suspension or limitation or intend to change the provision of the burlingame treaty to that extent i regard this provision of the act as a breach of our national faith and be unable to bring myself in harmony with the view of congress on this vital point the honor of the country constrain i to return the act with this objection to its passage
 deeply convinced of the necessity of some legislation on this subject and concur fully with congress in many of the object which be seek to be accomplish i avail myself of the opportunity to point out some other feature of the present act which in my opinion can be modify to advantage
 the class of chinese who still enjoy the protection of the burlingame treaty be entitle to the privilege immunity and exemption accord to citizen and subject of the most favored nation we have treaty with many power which permit their citizen and subject to reside within the united states and carry on business under the same law and regulation which be enforce against citizen of the united states i think it may be doubt whether provision require personal registration and the taking out of passport which be not impose upon native can be require of chinese without express an opinion on that point i may invite the attention of congress to the fact that the system of personal registration and passport be undemocratic and hostile to the spirit of our institution i doubt the wisdom of put an enter wedge of this kind into our law a nation like the united states jealous of the liberty of its citizen may well hesitate before it incorporate into its polity a system which be fast disappear in europe before the progress of liberal institution a wide experience have show how futile such precaution be and how easily passport may be borrow exchange or even forge by person interested to do so
 if it be nevertheless think that a passport be the most convenient way for identify the chinese entitle to the protection of the burlingame treaty it may still be doubt whether they ought to be require to register it be certainly our duty under the burlingame treaty to make their stay in the united states in the operation of general law upon they as nearly like that of our own citizen as we can consistently with our right to shut out the laborer no good purpose be serve in require they to register
 my attention have be call by the chinese minister to the fact that the bill as it stand make no provision for the transit across the united states of chinese subject now reside in foreign country i think that this point may well claim the attention of congress in legislate on this subject
 i have say that good faith require we to suspend the immigration of chinese laborer for a less period than twenty year i now add that good policy point in the same direction
 our intercourse with china be of recent date our first treaty with that power be not yet forty year old it be only since we acquire california and establish a great seat of commerce on the pacific that we may be say to have break down the barrier which fence in that ancient monarchy the burlingame treaty naturally follow under the spirit which inspire it many thousand chinese laborer come to the united states no one can say that the country have not profit by their work they be largely instrumental in construct the railway which connect the atlantic with the pacific the states of the pacific slope be full of evidence of their industry enterprise profitable alike to the capitalist and to the laborer of caucasian origin would have lain dormant but for they a time have now come when it be suppose that they be not need and when it be think by congress and by those most acquainted with the subject that it be good to try to get along without they there may however be other section of the country where this specie of labor may be advantageously employ without interfere with the laborer of our own race in make the propose experiment it may be the part of wisdom as well as of good faith to fix the length of the experimental period with reference to this fact
 experience have show that the trade of the east be the key to national wealth and influence the opening of china to the commerce of the whole world have benefit no section of it more than the states of our own pacific slope the state of california and its great maritime port especially have reap enormous advantage from this source bless with an exceptional climate enjoy an unrivaled harbor with the rich of a great agricultural and mining state in its rear and the wealth of the whole union pour into it over its line of railway san francisco have before it an incalculable future if our friendly and amicable relation with asia remain undisturbed it need no argument to show that the policy which we now propose to adopt must have a direct tendency to repel oriental nation from we and to drive their trade and commerce into more friendly land it may be that the great and paramount interest of protect our labor from asiatic competition may justify we in a permanent adoption of this policy but it be wise in the first place to make a short experiment with a view hereafter of maintain permanently only such feature as time and experience may commend
 i transmit herewith copy of the paper relate to the recent treaty with china which accompany the confidential message of president hayes to the senate of the 10th january 1881 and also a copy of a memorandum respect the act herewith return which be hand to the secretary of state by the chinese minister in washington

to the senate and house of representatives
 i send herewith a copy of the circular invitation extend to all the independent country of north and south america to participate in a general congress to be hold in the city of washington on the 22d of november next for the purpose of consider and discuss the method of prevent war between the nation of america
 in give this invitation i be not unaware that there exist difference between several of the republics of south america which would militate against the happy result which might otherwise be expect from such an assemblage the difference indicate be such as exist between chile and peru between mexico and guatemala and between the states of central america
 it be hope that these difference would disappear before the time fix for the meeting of the congress this hope have not be realize
 having observe that the authority of the president to convene such a congress have be question i beg leave to state that the constitution confer upon the president the power by and with the advice and consent of the senate to make treaty and that this provision confer the power to take all requisite measure to initiate they and to this end the president may freely confer with one or several commissioner or delegate from other nation the congress contemplate by the invitation could only effect any valuable result by its conclusion eventually take the form of a treaty of peace between the states represent and besides the invitation to the states of north and south america be merely a preliminary act of which constitutionality or the want of it can hardly be affirm
 it have be suggest that while the international congress would have no power to affect the right of nationality there represent still congress might be unwilling to subject the exist treaty right of the united states on the isthmus and elsewhere on the continent to be cloud and render uncertain by the expression of the opinion of a congress compose largely of interested party
 i be glad to have it in my power to refer to the congress of the united states as i now do the propriety of convene the suggest international congress that i may thus be inform of its view which it will be my pleasure to carry out
 inquiry having be make by some of the republic invite whether it be intend that this international congress shall convene it be important that congress should at as early a day as be convenient inform i by resolution or otherwise of its opinion in the premise my action will be in harmony with such expression
 chester a. arthur
 department of state washington november 29 1881
 sir the attitude of the united states with respect to the question of general peace on the american continent be well know through its persistent effort for year past to avert the evil of warfare or these effort fail to bring positive conflict to an end through pacific counsel or the advocacy of impartial arbitration this attitude have be consistently maintain and always with such fairness as to leave no room for impute to our government any motive except the humane and disintereste one of save the kindre states of the american continent from the burden of war the position of the united states as the lead power of the new world might well give to its government a claim to authoritative utterance for the purpose of quiet discord among its neighbor with all of whom the most friendly relation exist nevertheless the good office of this government be not and have not at any time be tender with a show of dictation or compulsion but only as exhibit the solicitous good will of a common friend
 send under the same date mutatis mutandi to the united states minister in the argentine republic bolivia brazil central america chile colombia mexico paraguay and uruguay peru and venezuela also directly to the minister of foreign relation of ecuador in which country the united states have no diplomatic representative
 for some year past a grow disposition have be manifest by certain states of central and south america to refer dispute affect grave question of international relationship and boundary to arbitration rather than to the sword it have be on several such occasion a source of profound satisfaction to the government of the united states to see that this country be in a large measure look to by all the american power as their friend and mediator
 the just and impartial counsel of the president in such case have never be withhold and his effort have be reward by the prevention of sanguinary strife or angry contention between people whom we regard as brother
 the existence of this grow tendency convince the president that the time be ripe for a proposal .that shall enlist the good will and active cooperation of all the states of the western hemisphere both north and south in the interest of humanity and for the common weal of nation
 he conceive that none of the government of america can be less alive than our own to the danger and horror of a state of war and especially of war between kinsman he be sure that none of the chief of government on the continent can be less sensitive than he be to the sacred duty of make every endeavor to do away with the chance of fratricidal strife and he look with hopeful confidence to such active assistance from they as will serve to show the broadness of our common humanity and the strength of the tie which bind we all together as a great and harmonious system of american commonwealths
 impress by these view the president extend to all the independent country of north and south america an earnest invitation to participate in a general congress to be hold in the city of washington on the 24th day of november 1882 for the purpose of consider and discuss the method of prevent war between the nation of america he desire that the attention of the congress shall be strictly confine to this one great object that its sole aim shall be to seek a way of permanently avert the horror of cruel and bloody combat between country oftenest of one blood and speech or the even bad calamity of internal commotion and civil strife that it shall regard the burdensome and far reach consequence of such struggle the legacy of exhausted finance of oppressive debt of onerous taxation of ruined city of paralyzed industry of devastated field of ruthless conscription of the slaughter of man of the grief of the widow and the orphan of imbittered resentment that long survive those who provoke they and heavily afflict the innocent generation that come after
 the president be especially desirous to have it understand that in put forth this invitation the united states do not assume the position of counseling or attempt through the voice of the congress to counsel any determinate solution of exist question which may now divide any of the country of america such question can not properly come before the congress its mission be high it be to provide for the interest of all in the future not to settle the individual difference of the present for this reason especially the president have indicate a day for the assembling of the congress so far in the future as to leave good ground for hope that by the time name the present situation on the south pacific coast will be happily terminate and that those engage in the contest may take peaceable part in the discussion and solution of the general question affect in an equal degree the well being of all
 it seem also desirable to disclaim in advance any purpose on the part of the united states to prejudge the issue to be present to the congress it be far from the intent of this government to appear before the congress as in any sense the protector of its neighbor or the predestined and necessary arbitrator of their dispute the united states will enter into the deliberation of the congress on the same footing as the other power represent and with the loyal determination to approach any propose solution not merely in its own interest or with a view to assert its own power but as a single member among many coordinate and coequal states so far as the influence of this government may be potential it will be exert in the direction of conciliate whatever conflicting interest of blood or government or historical tradition may necessarily come together in response to a call embrace such vast and diverse element
 you will present these view to the minister of foreign relation of mexico enlarging if need be in such term as will readily occur to you upon the great mission which it be within the power of the propose congress to accomplish in the interest of humanity and upon the firm purpose of the united states to maintain a position of the most absolute and impartial friendship toward all you will thereupon in the name of the president of the united states tender to his excellency the president of the mexican republic a formal invitation to send two commissioner to the congress provide with such power and instruction on behalf of their government as will enable they to consider the question bring before that body within the limit of submission contemplate by this invitation
 the united states as well as the other power will in like manner be represent by two commissioner so that equality and impartiality will be amply secure in the proceeding of the congress
 in deliver this invitation through the minister of foreign affair you will read this dispatch to he and leave with he a copy intimate that an answer be desire by this government as promptly as the just consideration of so important a proposition will permit
 i be sir your obedient servant
 james g. blaine

to the house of representatives of the united states
 herewith i return house bill no 2744 entitle an act to regulate the carriage of passenger by sea without my approval in do this i regret that i be not able to give my assent to an act which have receive the sanction of the majority of both houses of congress
 the object propose to be secure by the act be meritorious and philanthropic some correct and accurate legislation upon this subject be undoubtedly necessary steamship that bring large body of emigrant must be subject to strict legal enactment so as to prevent the passenger from be expose to hardship and suffering and such legislation should be make as will give they abundance of space and air and light protect their health by afford all reasonable comfort and convenience and by provide for the quantity and quality of the food to be furnish and all of the other essential of roomy safe and healthful accommodation in their passage across the sea
 a statute provide for all this be absolutely need and in the spirit of humane legislation must be enact the present act by most of its provision will obtain and secure this protection for such passenger and be it not for some serious error contain in it it would be most willingly approve by i
 my objection be these in the first section in line from 13 to 24 inclusive it be provide that the compartment or space etc shall be of sufficient dimension to allow for each and any passenger etc 100 cubic foot if the compartment or space be locate on the first deck next below the uppermost deck of the vessel etc or 120 cubic foot for each passenger etc if the compartment or space be locate on the second deck below the uppermost deck of the vessel etc it shall not be lawful to carry or bring passenger on any deck other than the two deck mention etc
 nearly all of the new and most of the improved ocean steamer have a spar deck which be above the main deck the main deck be in the old style of steamer the only uppermost deck the spar deck be a comparatively new feature of the large and costly steamship and be now practically the uppermost deck below this spar deck be the main deck because of the misuse of the word uppermost deck instead of the use of the word main deck by this act the result will be to exclude nearly all of the large steamship from carry passenger anywhere but on the main deck and on the deck below which be the steerage deck and to leave the orlop or low deck heretofore use for passenger useless and unoccupied by passenger this objection which be now present in connection with other that will be presently explain will if this act be enforce as it be now phrase render useless for passenger traffic and expose to heavy loss all of the great ocean steam line and it will also hinder emigration as there will not be ship enough that could accept these condition to carry all who may now wish to come
 the use of the new and the hitherto unknown term uppermost deck create this difficulty and i can not consent to have an abuse of term like this to operate thus injuriously to these large fleet of ship the passenger will not be benefit by such a statute but emigration will be hinder if not for a while almost prevent for many
 again the act in the first section from line 31 to line 35 inclusive provide and such passenger shall not be carry or bring in any between deck nor in any compartment etc the clear height of which be less than 7 foot between the deck of all ship be the beam they be about a foot in width the legal method of ascertain tonnage for the purpose of taxation be to measure between the beam from the floor to the ceiling if this become a law the space require would be 8 foot from floor to ceiling and this be impracticable for in all ship the space between deck be adjust in proportion to the dimension of the ship and if these space between deck be change so as not to correspond in their proportion with the dimension of the vessel the ship will not work well in the sea her sailing quality will be injure and she will be render unfit for service
 it be only in great ship of vast tonnage that the height between deck can be increase all the ordinary sized ship be necessarily construct with 7 foot space in the interval between the beam from the floor to the ceiling to adopt this act with this provision would be to drive out of the service of transport passenger most all of the steamship now in such trade and no practical good obtain by it for really with the exception of the narrow beam the space between the deck be now 7 foot the purpose of the space command by the act be to obtain sufficient air and ventilation and that be actually now give to the passenger by the 7 foot that exist in all of these vessel between floor and ceiling
 there be also another objection that i must suggest in section 12 from line 14 to line 24 it be provide before such vessel shall be clear or may lawfully depart etc the master of say vessel shall furnish etc,"a correct list of all passenger who have be or be intend to be take on board the vessel and shall specify etc this provision would prevent the clearing of the vessel steam vessel start at an appoint hour and with punctuality down almost to the very hour of their departure new passenger other than those who have engage their passage constantly come on board if this provision be to be the law they must be reject for the ship can not without incur heavy penalty take passenger whose name be not set forth on the list require before such vessel shall be clear they should be allow to take such new passenger upon condition that they would furnish an additional list contain such persons&#39 name there be other point of objection of a minor character that might be present for consideration if the bill could be reconsider and amend but the three that i have recite be conspicuous defect in a bill that ought to be a code for such a purpose dear and explicit free from all such objection the practical result of this law would be to subject all of the compete line of large ocean steamer to great loss by restrict their carrying accommodation it would also stay the current of emigration that it be our policy to encourage as well as to protect a good bill correctly phrase and express and name in plain well know technical term the proper and usual place and deck where passenger be and ought to be place and carry will receive my prompt and immediate assent as a public necessity and blessing

to the house of representatives
 having watch with much interest the progress of house bill no 6242 entitle an act make appropriation for the construction repair and preservation of certain work on river and harbor and for other purpose and having since it be receive carefully examine it after mature consideration i be constrain to return it herewith to the house of representatives in which it originate without my signature and with my objection to its passage
 many of the appropriation in the bill be clearly for the general welfare and most beneficent in their character two of the object for which provision be make be by i consider so important that i feel it my duty to direct to they the attention of congress in my annual message in december last i urge the vital importance of legislation for the reclamation of the marsh and for the establishment of the harbor line along the potomac front in april last by special message i recommend an appropriation for the improvement of the mississippi river it be not necessary that i say that when my signature would make the bill appropriate for these and other valuable national object a law it be with great reluctance and only under a sense of duty that i withhold it
 my principal objection to the bill be that it contain appropriation for purpose not for the common defense or general welfare and which do not promote commerce among the states these provision on the contrary be entirely for the benefit of the particular locality in which it be propose to make the improvement i regard such appropriation of the public money as beyond the power give by the constitution to congress and the president
 i feel the more bound to withhold my signature from the bill because of the peculiar evil which manifestly result from this infraction of the constitution appropriation of this nature to be devote purely to local object tend to an increase in number and in amount as the citizen of one state find that money to raise which they in common with the whole country be tax be to be expend for local improvement in another state they demand similar benefit for themselves and it be not unnatural that they should seek to indemnify themselves for such use of the public fund by secure appropriation for similar improvement in their own neighborhood thus as the bill become more objectionable it secure more support this result be invariable and necessarily follow a neglect to observe the constitutional limitation impose upon the lawmaking power
 the appropriation for river and harbor improvement have under the influence to which i have allude increase year by year out of proportion to the progress of the country great as that have be in 1870 the aggregate appropriation be $ 3,975,900 in 1875 $ 6,648,517.50 in 1880 $ 8,976,500 and in 1881 $ 11,451,000 while by the present act there be appropriate $ 18,743,875
