 while feel every disposition to leave to the legislature the responsibility of determine what amount should be appropriate for the purpose of the bill so long as the appropriation be confine to object indicate by the grant of power i can not escape the conclusion that as a part of the lawmaking power of the government the duty devolve upon i to withhold my signature from a bill contain appropriation which in my opinion greatly exceed in amount the need of the country for the present fiscal year it be the usage to provide money for these purpose by annual appropriation bill the president be in effect direct to expend so large an amount of money within so brief a period that the expenditure can not be make economically and advantageously
 the extravagant expenditure of public money be an evil not to be measure by the value of that money to the people who be tax for it they sustain a great injury in the demoralize effect produce upon those who be intrust with official duty through all the ramification of government
 these objection could be remove and every constitutional purpose readily attain should congress enact that one half only of the aggregate amount provide for in the bill be appropriate for expenditure during the fiscal year and that the sum so appropriated be expend only for such object name in the bill as the secretary of war under the direction of the president shall determine provide that in no case shall the expenditure for any one purpose exceed the sum now designate by the bill for that purpose
 i feel authorized to make this suggestion because of the duty impose upon the president by the constitution to recommend to the consideration of congress such measure as he shall judge necessary and expedient and because it be my earnest desire that the public work which be in progress shall suffer no injury congress will also convene again in four month when this whole subject will be open for their consideration

revenue of the government it will be remember that i urge upon the attention of congress at its last session the importance of relieve the industry and enterprise of the country from the pressure of unnecessary taxation it be one of the trite maxim of political economy that all taxis be burdensome however wisely and prudently impose and though there have always be among our people wide difference of sentiment as to the good method of raise the national revenue and indeed as to the principle upon which taxation should be base there have be substantial accord in the doctrine that only such taxis ought to be levy as be necessary for a wise and economical administration of the government of late the public revenue have far exceed that limit and unless check by appropriate legislation such excess will continue to increase from year to year for the fiscal year end june 30 1881 the surplus revenue amount to $ 100,000,000 for the fiscal year end on the 30th of june last the surplus be more than one hundred and forty five million the report of the secretary show what disposition have be make of these money they have not only answer the requirement of the sink fund but have afford a large balance applicable to other reduction of the public debt but i renew the expression of my conviction that such rapid extinguishment of the national indebtedness as be now take place be by no mean a cause for congratulation it be a cause rather for serious apprehension if it continue it must speedily be follow by one of the evil result so clearly set forth in the report of the secretary either the surplus must lie idle in the treasury or the government will be force to buy at market rate its bond not then redeemable and which under such circumstance can not fail to command an enormous premium or the swollen revenue will be devote to extravagant expenditure which as experience have teach be ever the bane of an overflowing treasury it be make apparent in the course of the animate discussion which this question arouse at the last session of congress that the policy of diminish the revenue by reduce taxation command the general approval of the member of both houses i regret that because of conflict view as to the good method by which that policy should be make operative none of its benefit have as yet be reap in fulfillment of what i deem my constitutional duty but with little hope that i can make valuable contribution to this vex question i shall proceed to intimate briefly my own view in relation to it upon the showing of our financial condition at the close of the last fiscal year i feel justified in recommend to congress the abolition of all internal revenue taxis except those upon tobacco in its various form and upon distilled spirit and ferment liquor and except also the special tax upon the manufacturer of and dealer in such article i venture now to suggest that unless it shall be ascertain that the probable expenditure of the government for the come year have be underestimate all internal taxis save those which relate to distil spirit can be prudently abrogate such a course if accompany by a simplification of the machinery of collection which would then be easy of accomplishment might reasonably be expect to result in diminish the cost of such collection by at least $ 2,500,000 and in the retirement from office of from 1,500 to 2,000 person the system of excise duty have never commend itself to the favor of the american people and have never be resort to except for supply deficiency in the treasury when by reason of special exigency the duty on import have prove inadequate for the need of the government the sentiment of the country doubtless demand that the present excise tax shall be abolish as soon as such a course can be safely pursue it seem to i however that for various reason so sweep a measure as the total abolition of internal taxis would for the present be an unwise step two of these reason be deserve of special mention first it be by no mean clear that even if the exist system of duty on import be continue without modification those duty alone will yield sufficient revenue for all the need of the government it be estimate that $ 100,000,000 will be require for pension during the come year and it may well be doubt whether the maximum annual demand for that object have yet be reach uncertainty upon this question would alone justify in my judgment the retention for the present of that portion of the system of internal revenue which be least objectionable to the people second a total abolition of excise taxis would almost inevitably prove a serious if not an insurmountable obstacle to a thorough revision of the tariff and to any considerable reduction in import duty the present tariff system be in many respect unjust it make unequal distribution both of its burden and its benefit this fact be practically recognize by a majority of each house of congress in the passage of the act create the tariff commission the report of that commission will be place before you at the beginning of this session and will i trust afford you such information as to the condition and prospect of the various commercial agricultural manufacturing mining and other interest of the country and contain such suggestion for statutory revision as will practically aid your action upon this important already state $ 220,000,000.the income from this source for the fiscal year which will end on june 30 1883 will doubtless be considerably in excess of the sum last mention if the tax on domestic as to include within it the numerous article which yield inconsiderable revenue a simplification of the complex and inconsistent schedule of duty upon certain manufacture particularly those of cotton the regulation of interstate commerce have already be the subject of your deliberation one of the incident of the marvelous extension of the railway system of the country have be the adoption of such of the commissioner of agriculture present an account of the labor of that department during the past year and include information of much interest to the general public the condition of the forest of the country and the wasteful manner in which their destruction be take place give cause for serious apprehension their action in protect the earth 's surface in modify the extreme of climate and in regulate and sustain the flow of spring and stream be now well understand and their importance in relation to the growth and prosperity of the country can not be safely disregarded they be fast especially in the extreme western states and territories where the necessity for their preservation be great than in less mountainous region and where the prevail dryness of the climate render their restoration if they be once destroy well nigh impossible the communication which i make to congress at its first session in december last contain a somewhat full statement of my sentiment in relation to the principle and rule which ought to govern appointment to public service refer to the various plan which have theretofore be the subject of discussion in the national legislature plan which in the main be model upon the system which obtain in great britain but which lack certain of the prominent feature whereby that system be distinguish i feel bound to intimate my doubt whether they or any support of the executive since these suggestion be submit for your consideration there have be no legislation upon the subject to which they relate but there have meanwhile be an increase in the public interest in that subject and the people of the country apparently without distinction of party have in various way and upon frequent occasion give expression to their earnest wish for prompt and definite action in my judgment such action should no long be postpone i may add that my own sense of its press importance have be quicken by observation of a practical phase of the matter to which attention have more than once be call by my predecessor the civil list now comprise about 100,000 person far the large part of whom must under the term of the constitution he select by the president either directly or through his own appointee in the early year of the administration of the government the personal direction of appointment to the civil service may not have be an irksome task for the executive but now that the burden have increase fully a hundredfold it have become great thin he ought to bear and it necessarily divert his time and attention from the proper discharge of other duty no less delicate and responsible and which in the very nature of thing can not be delegate to other hand in the judgment of not a few who have give study and reflection to this matter the nation have outgrow the provision which the constitution have establish for fill the minor office in the public service but whatever may be think of the wisdom or expediency of change the fundamental law in this regard it be certain that much relief may be afford not only to the president and to the head of the departments but to senators and representatives in congress by discreet legislation they would be protect in a great measure by the bill now pende before the senate or by any other which should embody its important feature from the pressure of personal importunity and from the labor of examine conflict claim and pretension of candidate i trust that before the close of the present session some decisive action may be take for the correction of the evil which inhere in the present method of appointment and i assure you of my hearty cooperation in any measure which be likely to conduce to that end as to the most appropriate term and tenure of the official life of the subordinate employee of the government it seem to be generally agree that whatever their extent or character the one should be definite and the other stable and that neither should be regulate by zeal in the service of party or fidelity to the fortune of an individual it matter little to the people at large what competent person be at the head of this department or of that bureau if they feel assured that the removal of one and the accession of another will not involve the retirement of honest and faithful subordinate whose duty be purely administrative and have no legitimate connection with the triumph of any political principle or the success of any political party or faction it be to this latter class of officer that the senate bill to which i have already refer exclusively apply while neither that bill nor any other prominent scheme for improve the civil service concern the high grade of official who be appoint by the president and confirm by the senate i feel bound to correct a prevalent misapprehension as to the frequency with which the present executive have displace the incumbent of an office and appoint another in his stead it have be repeatedly allege that he have in this particular signally depart from the course which have be pursue under recent administration of the government the fact be as follow the whole number of executive appointment during the four year immediately precede mr. garfield 's accession to the presidency be 2,696 of this number 244 or 9 per cent involve the removal of previous incumbent the ratio of removal to the whole number of appointment be much the same during each of those four year in the first year with 790 appointment there be 74 removal or 9.3 per cent in the second with 917 appointment there be 85 removal or 8.5 per cent in the third with 480 appointment there be 48 removal or 10 per cent in the fourth with 429 appointment there be 37 removal or 8.6 per cent in the four month of president garfield 's administration there be 390 appointment and 89 removal or 22.7 per cent precisely the same number of removal 89 have take place in the fourteen month which have since elapse but they constitute only 7.8 per cent of the whole number of appointment 1,118 within that period and less than 2.6 of the entire list of official 3,459 exclusive of the army and navy which be fill by presidential appointment national election the closing year have be replete with blessing for which we owe to the giver of all good our reverent acknowledgment for the uninterrupted harmony of our foreign relation for the to the congress of the united states at the threshold of your deliberation i congratulate you upon the favorable aspect of the domestic and foreign affair of this government our relation with other country continue to be upon a friendly footing with the argentine republic austria belgium brazil denmark hayti italy santo domingo and sweden and norway no incident have occur which car for special extend the duration of the franco american claims commission have also be proclaim notice of the termination of the fishery article of the treaty of washington be duly give to the british government and the reciprocal privilege and exemption of the treaty will accordingly cease on july 1 1885 the fishery industry pursue by a numerous class of our citizen on the northern coast both of the atlantic and pacific ocean be worthy of the foster care of congress whenever bring into competition with the like industry of other country our fisherman as well as our manufacturer of fishing appliance and preparer of fish product have maintain a foremost place i suggest that congress create a commission to consider the general question of our right in the fishery and the mean of opening to our citizen under just and endure condition the richly stock fishing water and sealing ground of british north america question have arise touch the deportation to the united states from the british islands by governmental or municipal aid of person unable there to gain a living and equally a burden on the community here such of these person as fall under the pauper class as define by law have be send back in accordance with the provision of our statute her majesty 's government have insist that precaution have be take before shipment to prevent these objectionable visitor from come hither without guaranty of support by their relative in this country the action of the british authority in apply measure for relief have however in so many case prove ineffectual and especially so in certain recent instance of needy emigrant reach our territory through canada that a revision of our legislation upon this subject may be deem advisable correspondence relative to the clayton bulwer treaty have be continue and will be lay before congress the legislation of france against the importation of prepared swine product from the united states have be repeal that result be due no less to the friendly america i extend to the imperial government a friendly invitation to send expert to the united states to inquire whether the use of those product be dangerous to health this invitation be decline i have believe it of such importance however that the exact fact should be ascertain and promulgate that i have appoint a competent commission to make a thorough investigation of the subject its member provide at least for reimbursement of such expense as they may necessarily incur the coronation of the czar at moscow afford to this government an occasion for testify its continued friendship by send the government and be likely to be call in within less than four year unless meantime the surplus revenue shall be diminish the probable effect of such an extensive retirement of the security which be the basis of the national bank circulation would be such a contraction of the volume of the currency as to produce grave commercial embarrassment how can this danger be obviate the most effectual plan and one whose adoption at the early practicable opportunity i shall heartily approve have already be indicate if the revenue of the next four year shall be keep substantially commensurate with the expense the volume of circulation will not be likely to suffer any material disturbance but if on the other hand there shall be great delay in reduce taxation it will become necessary either to preferable i commend to your attention the very interesting and thoughtful suggestion upon this subject which appear in the secretary 's report the objection which he urge against the acceptance of any other security than the obligation of the government itself as a foundation for national bank circulation seem to i insuperable for avert the threaten contraction two course have be suggest either commend itself to my own judgment as the well be the enactment of a law repeal the tax on circulation and permit the bank to issue note for an amount equal to 90 per cent of the market value instead of as now the face value of their deposited bond i agree with the secretary in the belief that the adoption of this plan would afford the necessary relief the trade dollar be coin for the purpose of traffic in country where silver pass at its value as ascertain by its weight and fineness it never have a legal tender quality large number of these coin enter however into the volume of our currency by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas it be allege that certain person have within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states begin and set on foot preparation for an organized and forcible possession of and settlement upon the land of what be know as the oklahoma land in the indian territory which territory be designate recognize and describe by the treaty and law of the united states and by the executive authority as indian country and as such be subject to occupation by indian tribe only and whereas the law of the united states provide for the removal of all person reside or be find in say indian territory without express permission of the interior department
 now therefore for the purpose of properly protect the interest of the indian nation and tribe in say territory and that settler may not be induce to go into a country at great expense to themselves where they can not be allow to remain i chester a. arthur president of the united states do admonish and warn all such person so intend or prepare to remove upon say land or into said territory against any attempt to so remove or settle upon any of the land of said territory and i do far warn and notify any and all such person who do so offend that they will be speedily and immediately remove therefrom by the proper officer of the interior department and if necessary the aid and assistance of the military force of the united states will be involve to remove all such intruder from the say indian territory
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 1st day of july a. d. 1884 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and eighth
 chester a. arthur
 by the president

to the congress of the united states since the close of your last session the american people in the exercise of their high right of suffrage have choose their chief magistrate for the four year ensue when it be remember that at no period in the country 's history have the long political contest which customarily precede the day of the national election be wage with great fervor and intensity it be a subject of general congratulation that after the controversy at the poll be over and while the slight preponderance by which the issue have be determine be as yet unascertaine the public peace suffer no disturbance but the people everywhere patiently and quietly await the result nothing could more strikingly illustrate the temper of the american citizen his love of order and his loyalty to law nothing could more signally demonstrate the strength and wisdom of our political institution eight year have pass since a controversy concern the result of a national election sharply call the attention of the congress to the necessity of provide more precise and definite regulation for count the electoral vote it be of the grave importance that this question be solve before conflict claim to the presidency shall again distract the country and i be persuade that by the people at large any of the measure of relief thus far propose would be prefer to continue inaction our relation with all foreign power continue to be amicable with belgium a convention have be sign whereby the scope of present treaty have be so enlarge as to secure to citizen of either country within the jurisdiction of the other equal right and privilege in the acquisition and alienation of property a trade mark treaty have also be conclude the war between chile and peru be at an end for the arbitration of the claim of american citizen who during its continuance suffer through the act of the chilean authority a convention will soon be negotiate the state of hostility between france and china continue to be an embarrassing feature of our eastern relation the chinese government have promptly adjust and pay the claim of american citizen whose property be destroy in the recent riot at canton i renew the recommendation of my last annual message that the canton indemnity fund be return to china the true interpretation of the recent treaty with that country permit the restriction of chinese immigration be likely to be again the subject of your deliberation it may be seriously question whether the statute pass at the last session do not violate the treaty right of certain chinese who leave this country with return certificate valid under the old law and who now seem to be debar from relande for lack of the certificate require by the new the recent purchase by citizen of the united states of a large trading fleet heretofore under the chinese flag have considerably enhance our commercial importance in the east in view of the large number of vessel build or purchase by american citizen in other country and exclusively employ in legitimate traffic between foreign port under the recognize protection of our flag it might be well to provide a uniform rule for their registration and documentation so that the bona fide property right of our citizen therein shall be duly evidence and properly guard pursuant to the advice of the senate at the last session i recognize the flag of the international association of the kongo as that of a friendly government avoid in so do any prejudgment of conflict territorial claim in that region subsequently in execution of the express wish of the congress i appoint a commercial agent for the kongo basin the importance of the rich prospective trade of the kongo valley have lead to the general conviction that it should be open to all nation upon equal term at an international conference for the consideration of this subject call by the emperor of germany and now in session at berlin delegate be in attendance on behalf of the united states of the result of the conference you will be duly advise the government of korea have generously aid the effort of the united states minister to secure suitable premise for the use of the legation as the condition of diplomatic intercourse with eastern nation demand that the legation premise be own by the represent power i advise that an appropriation be make for the acquisition of this property by the government the united states already possess valuable premise at tangier as a gift from the sultan of morocco as be state hereafter they have lately receive a similar gift from the siamese government the government of japan stand ready to present to we extensive ground at tokyo whereon to erect a suitable building for the legation court house and jail and similar privilege can probably be secure in china and persia the owning of such premise would not only effect a large saving of the present rental but would permit of the due assertion of extraterritorial right in those country and would the well serve to maintain the dignity of the united states the failure of congress to make appropriation for our representation at the autonomous court of the khedive have prove a serious embarrassment in our intercourse with egypt and in view of the necessary intimacy of diplomatic relationship due to the participation of this government as one of the treaty power in all matter of administration there affect the right of foreigner i advise the restoration of the agency and consulate general at cairo on its former basis i do not conceive it to be the wish of congress that the united states should withdraw altogether from the honorable position they have hitherto hold with respect to the khedive or that citizen of this republic reside or sojourning in egypt should hereafter be without the aid and protection of a competent representative with france the traditional cordial relationship continue the colossal statue of liberty enlightening the world the generous gift of the people of france be expect to reach new york in may next i suggest that congressional action be take in recognition of the spirit which have prompt this gift and in aid of the timely completion of the pedestal upon which it be to be place our relation with germany a country which contribute to our own some of the good element of citizenship continue to be cordial the united states have extradition treaty with several of the german states but by reason of the confederation of those states under the imperial rule the application of such treaty be not as uniform and comprehensive as the interest of the two country require i propose therefore to open negotiation for a single convention of extradition to embrace all the territory of the empire it afford i pleasure to say that our intercourse with great britain continue to be of a most friendly character the government of hawaii have indicate its willingness to continue for seven year the provision of the exist reciprocity treaty such continuance in view of the relation of that country to the american system of states should in my judgment be favor the revolution in hayti against the established government have terminate while it be in progress it become necessary to enforce our neutrality law by institute proceeding against individual and vessel charge with their infringement these prosecution be in all case successful much anxiety have lately be display by various european governments and especially by the government of italy for the abolition of our import duty upon work of art it be well to consider whether the present discrimination in favor of the production of american artist abroad be not likely to result as they themselves seem very generally to believe it may in the practical exclusion of our painter and sculptor from the rich field for observation study and labor which they have hitherto enjoy there be prospect that the long pende revision of the foreign treaty of japan may be conclude at a new conference to be hold at tokyo while this government fully recognize the equal and independent station of japan in the community of nation it would not oppose the general adoption of such term of compromise as japan may be dispose to offer in furtherance of a uniform policy of intercourse with western nation during the past year the increase good will utah and provide for the appointment of commissioner with such governmental power as in its judgment may justly and wisely be put into their hand in the course of this communication reference have more than once be make to the policy of this government as regard the extension of our foreign trade it seem proper to declare the general principle that should in my opinion underlie our national effort in this direction the main condition of the problem may be thus state we be a people apt in mechanical pursuit and fertile in invention we cover a vast extent of territory rich in agricultural product and in nearly all the raw material necessary for successful manufacture we have a system of productive establishment more than sufficient to supply our own demand the wage of labor be nowhere else so great the scale of living of our artisan class be such as tend to secure their personal comfort and the development of those high moral and intellectual quality that go to the making of good citizen our system of tax and tariff legislation be yield a revenue which be in excess of the present need of the government these be the element from which it be seek to devise a scheme by which without unfavorably change the condition of the workingman our merchant marine shall be raise from its enfeeble condition and new market provide for the sale beyond our border of the manifold fruit of our industrial enterprise the problem be complex and can be solve by no single measure of innovation or reform the country of the american continent and the adjacent island be for the united states the natural mart of supply and demand it be from they that we should obtain what we do not produce or do not produce in sufficiency and it be to they that the surplus production of our field our mill and our workshop should flow under condition that will equalize or favor they in comparison with foreign competition four path of policy seem to point to this end first a series of reciprocal commercial treaty with the country of america which shall foster between we and they an unhampere movement of trade the condition of these treaty should be the free admission of such merchandise as this country do not produce in return for the admission free or under a favor scheme of duty of our own product the benefit of such exchange to apply only to good carry under the flag of the party to the contract the removal on both side from the vessel so privileged of all tonnage due and national impost so that those vessel may ply unhindered between our port and those of the other contracting party though without infringe on the reserved home coasting trade the removal or reduction of burden on the export product of those country come within the benefit of the treaty and the avoidance of the technical restriction and penalty by which our intercourse with those country be at present hamper secondly the establishment of the consular service of the united states on a salaried footing thus permit the relinquishment of consular fee not only as respect vessel under the national flag but also as respect vessel of the treaty nation carry good entitle to the benefit of the treaty thirdly the enactment of measure to favor the construction and maintenance of a steam carry marine under the flag of the united states fourthly the establishment of an uniform currency basis for the country of america so that the coin product of our mine may circulate on equal term throughout the whole system of commonwealth this would require a monetary union of america whereby the output of the bullion produce country and the circulation of those which yield neither gold nor silver could be adjust in conformity with the population wealth and commercial need of each as many of the country furnish no bullion to the common stock the surplus production of our mine and mint might thus be utilize and a step take toward the general remonetization of silver to the accomplishment of these end so far as they can be attain by separate treaty the negotiation already conclude and now in progress have be direct and the favor which this enlarge policy have thus far receive warrant the belief that its operation will ere long embrace all or nearly all the country of this hemisphere it be by no mean desirable however that the policy under consideration should be apply to these country alone the healthful enlargement of our trade with europe asia and africa should be seek by reduce tariff burden on such of their ware as neither we nor the other american states be fit to produce and thus enable ourselves to obtain in return a well market for our supply of food of raw material and of the manufacture in which we excel it seem to i that many of the embarrassing element in the great national conflict between protection and free trade may thus be turn to good account that the revenue may be reduce so as no long to overtax the people that protective duty may be retain without become burdensome that our shipping interest may be judiciously encourage the currency fix on firm basis and above all such an unity of interest establish among the states of the american system as will be of great and ever increase advantage to they all all treaty in the line of this policy which have be negotiate or be in process of negotiation contain a provision deem to be requisite under to the senate of the united states
 i transmit herewith to the senate for consideration with a view to ratification a treaty sign on the 1st of december with the republic of nicaragua provide for the construction of an interoceanic canal across the territory of that state
 the negotiation of this treaty be enter upon under a conviction that it be imperatively demand by the present and future political and material interest of the united states
 the establishment of water communication between the atlantic and pacific coast of the union be a necessity the accomplishment of which however within the territory of the united states be a physical impossibility while the enterprise of our citizen have respond to the duty of create mean of speedy transit by rail between the two ocean these great achievement be inadequate to supply a most important requisite of national union and prosperity
 for all maritime purpose the states upon the pacific be more distant from those upon the atlantic than if separate by either ocean alone europe and africa be near to new york and asia nearer to california than be these two great states to each other by sea week of steam voyage or month under sail be consume in the passage around the horn with the disadvantage of traverse tempestuous water or risk the navigation of the straits of magellan
 a nation like our can not rest satisfied with such a separation of its mutually dependent member we possess an ocean border of considerably over 10,000 mile on the atlantic and gulf of mexico and include alaska of some 10,000 mile on the pacific within a generation the western coast have develop into an empire with a large and rapidly grow population with vast but partially develop resource at the present rate of increase the end of the century will see we a commonwealth of perhaps nearly 100,000,000 inhabitant of which the west should have a considerably large and rich proportion than now form one nation in interest and aim the east and the west be more widely disjoin for all purpose of direct and economical intercourse by water and of national defense against maritime aggression than be most of the colony of other power from their mother country
 the problem of establish such water communication have long attract attention many project have be form and survey have be make of all possible available route as a knowledge of the true topical condition of the isthmus be gain insuperable difficulty in one case and another become evident until by a process of elimination only two route remain within range of profitable achievement one by way of panama and the other across nicaragua
 the treaty now lay before you provide for such a waterway through the friendly territory of nicaragua
 i invite your special attention to the provision of the convention itself as well evidence its scope
 from respect to the independent sovereignty of the republic through whose cooperation the project can alone be realize the stipulation of the treaty look to the full recognition and protection of nicaraguan right in the premise the united states have no motive or desire for territorial acquisition or political control beyond the present border and none such be contemplate by this treaty the two government unite in frame this scheme as the sole mean by which the work as indispensable to the one as to the other can be accomplish under such circumstance as to prevent alike the possibility of conflict between they and of interference from without
 the canal be primarily a domestic mean of water communication between the atlantic and pacific shore of the two country which unite for its construction the one contribute the territory and the other furnish the money therefor recognize the advantage which the world&#39;s commerce must derive from the work appreciate the benefit of enlarged use to the canal itself by contribute to its maintenance and by yield an interest return on the capital invest therein and inspire by the belief that any great enterprise which inure to the general benefit of the world be in some sort a trust for the common advancement of mankind the two government have by this treaty provide for its peaceable use by all nation on equal term while reserve to the coast trade of both country in which none but the contracting party be interested the privilege of favor toil
 the treaty provide for the construction of a railway and telegraph line if deem advisable as accessory to the canal as both may be necessary for the economical construction of the work and probably in its operation when complete
 the term of the treaty as to the protection of the canal while scrupulously confirm the sovereignty of nicaragua amply secure that state and the work itself from possible contingency of the future which it may not be within the sole power of nicaragua to meet
 from a purely commercial point of view the completion of such a waterway open a most favorable prospect for the future of our country the nation of the pacific coast of south america will by its mean be bring into close connection with our gulf states the relation of those american country to the united states be that of a natural market from which the want of direct communication have hitherto practically exclude we by pierce the isthmus the heretofore insuperable obstacle of time and sea distance disappear and our vessel and production will enter upon the world&#39;s competitive field with a decided advantage of which they will avail themselves
 when to this be join the large coasting trade between the atlantic and pacific states which must necessarily spring up it be evident that this canal afford even alone an efficient mean of restore our flag to its former place on the sea
 such a domestic coast trade would arise immediately for even the fishing vessel of both seaboard which now lie idle in the winter month could then profitably carry good between the eastern and the western states
 the political effect of the canal will be to knit close the states now depend upon railway corporation for all commercial and personal intercourse and it will not only cheapen the cost of transportation but will free individual from the possibility of unjust discrimination
 it will bring the european grain market of demand within easy distance of our pacific states and will give to the manufacturer on the atlantic seaboard economical access to the city of china thus break down the barrier which separate the principal manufacturing center of the united states from the market of the vast population of asia and place the eastern states of the union for all purpose of trade midway between europe and asia in point of time the gain for sailing vessel would be great amount from new york to san francisco to a saving of seventy five day to hongkong of twenty seven day to shanghai of thirty four day and to callao of fifty two day
 lake nicaragua be about 90 mile long and 40 mile in great width the water be fresh and afford abundant depth for vessel of the deep draft several island give facility for establish coaling station supply depot harbor and place for repair the advantage of this vast inland harbor be evident
 the lake be 110 foot above tide water six lock or five intermediate level be require for the pacific end of the canal on the atlantic side but five lock or four intermediate level be propose these lock would in practice no more limit the number of vessel pass through the canal than would the single tide lock on the pacific end which be necessary to any even or sea level route
 seventeen and a half mile of canal lie between the pacific and the lake the distance across the lake be 56 mile and a dam at the mouth of the san carlos a tributary of the san juan raise the water level 49 foot practically extend the lake 63 mile to that point by a channel from 600 to 1,200 foot wide with an abundant depth of water
 from the mouth of the san carlos where the canal will leave the san juan to the harbor of greytown the distance be 36 mile which it be hope may by new survey be shorten 10 mile
 the total canal excavation would thus be from 43 1/2 to 53 1/2 mile and the lake and river navigation amount to 119 mile by the present survey would be somewhat increase if the new survey be successful
 from new york to san francisco by this route for sailing vessel the time be ten day short than by the panama route
 the purely pecuniary prospect of the canal as an investment be subordinate to the great national benefit to accrue from it but it seem evident that the work great as its cost may appear will be a measure of prudent economy and foresight if undertake simply to afford our own vessel a free waterway for its far reach result will even within a few year in the life of a nation amply repay the expenditure by the increase of national prosperity far the canal would unquestionably be immediately remunerative it offer a short sea voyage with more continuously favor wind between the atlantic port of america and europe and the country of the east than any other practicable route and with low toll by reason of its less cost the nicaragua route must be the interoceanic highway for the bulk of the world&#39;s trade between the atlantic and the pacific
 so strong be this consideration that it offer an abundant guaranty for the investment to be make as well as for the speedy payment of the loan of four million which the treaty stipulate shall be make to nicaragua for the construction of internal improvement to serve as aid to the business of the canal
 i might suggest many other consideration in detail but it seem unnecessary to do so enough have be say to more than justify the practical utility of the measure i therefore commit it to the congress in the confident expectation that it will receive approval and that by appropriate legislation mean may be provide for inaugurate the work without delay after the treaty shall have be ratify
 in conclusion i urge the justice of recognize the aid which have recently be render in this matter by some of our citizen the effort of certain gentleman connect with the american company which receive the concession from nicaragua now terminate and replace by this international compact accomplish much of the preliminary labor lead to the conclusion of the treaty
 you may have occasion to examine the matter of their service when such further information as you may desire will be furnish you
 i may add that the canal can be construct by the able engineer corps of our army under their thorough system cheap and well than any work of such magnitude can in any other way be build

polygamy subscribe to the doctrine of polygamous marriage as a divine revelation and a law unto all high and more binding upon the conscience than any human law local or national thus be the strange spectacle present of a community protect by a republican form of government to which they owe allegiance sustain by their suffrage a principle and a belief which set at naught that obligation of absolute obedience to the law of the land which lie at the foundation of republican institution the strength the perpetuity and the destiny of the nation rest upon our home establish by the law of god guard by parental care regulate by parental authority and sanctify by parental love these be not the home of polygamy the mother of our land who rule the nation as they mold the character and guide the action of their son live accord to god s holy ordinance and each secure and happy in the exclusive love of the father of her child shed the warm light of true womanhood unperverted and unpollute upon all within her pure and wholesome family circle these be not the cheerless crush and unwomanly mother of polygamy the father of our family be the good citizen of the republic wife and child be the source of patriotism and conjugal and parental affection beget devotion to the country the man who undefile with plural marriage be surround in his single home with his wife and child have a stake in the country which inspire he with respect for its law and courage for its defense these be not the father of polygamous family there be no feature of this practice or the system which sanction it which be not oppose to all that be of value in our institution there should be no relaxation in the firm but just execution of the law now in operation and i should be glad to approve such further discreet legislation as will rid the country of this blot upon its fair fame since the people uphold polygamy in our territories be reenforce by immigration from other land i recommend that a law be pass to prevent the importation of mormon into the country the agricultural interest of the country demand just recognition and liberal encouragement it sustain with certainty and unfailing strength our nation 's prosperity by the product of its steady toil and bear its full share of the burden of taxation without complaint our agriculturist have but slight personal representation in the council of the nation and be generally content with the humbler duty of citizenship and willing to trust to the bounty of nature for a reward of their labor but the magnitude and value of this industry be appreciate when the statement be make that of our total annual export more than three fourth be the product of agriculture and of our total population nearly one half be exclusively engage in that occupation the department of agriculture be create for the purpose of acquire and diffusing among the people useful information respect the subject it have in charge and aid in the cause of intelligent and progressive farming by the collection of statistic by test the value and usefulness of new seed and plant and distribute such as be find desirable among agriculturist this and other power and duty with which this department be invest be of the utmost importance and if wisely exercise must be of great benefit to the country the aim of our beneficent government be the improvement of the people in every station and the amelioration of their condition surely our agriculturist should not be neglect the instrumentality establish in aid of the farmer of the land should not only be well equipped for the accomplishment of its purpose but those for whose benefit it have be adopt should be encourage to avail themselves fully of its advantage the prohibition of the importation into several country of certain of our animal and their product base upon the suspicion that health be endanger in their use and consumption suggest the importance of such precaution for the protection of our stock of all kind against disease as will disarm suspicion of danger and cause the removal of such an injurious prohibition if the law now in operation be insufficient to accomplish this protection i recommend their amendment to meet the necessity of the situation and i commend to the consideration of congress the suggestion contain in the report of the commissioner of agriculture calculate to increase the value and efficiency of this department the report of the civil service commission which will be submit contain an account of the manner in which the civil service law have be execute during the last year and much valuable information on this important subject i be inclined to think that there be no sentiment more general in the mind of the people of our country than a conviction of the correctness of the principle upon which the law enforce civil service reform be base in its present condition the law regulate only a part of the subordinate public position throughout the country it apply the test of fitness to applicant for these place by mean of a competitive examination and give large discretion to the commissioners as to the character of the examination and many other matter connect with its execution thus the rule and regulation adopt by the commission have much to do with the practical usefulness of the statute and with the result of its application the people may well trust the commission to execute the law with perfect fairness and with as little irritation as be possible but of course no relaxation of the principle which underlie it and no weakening of the safeguard which surround it can be expect experience in its administration will probably suggest amendment of the method of its execution but i venture to hope that we shall never again be remit to the system which distribute public position purely as reward for partisan service doubt may well be entertain whether our government could survive the strain of a continuance of this system which upon every change of administration inspire an immense army of claimant for office to lay siege to the patronage of government engross the time of public officer with their importunity spread abroad the contagion of their disappointment and fill the air with the tumult of their discontent the allurement of an immense number of office and place exhibit to the voter of the land and the promise of their bestowal in recognition of partisan activity debauch the suffrage and rob political action of its thoughtful and deliberative character the evil would increase with the multiplication of office consequent upon our extension and the mania for office holding grow from its indulgence would pervade our population so generally that patriotic purpose the support of principle the desire for the public good and solicitude for the nation 's welfare would be nearly banish from the activity of our party contest and cause they to degenerate into ignoble selfish and disgraceful struggle for the possession of office and public place civil service reform enforce by law come none too soon to check the progress of demoralization one of its effect not enough regard be the freedom it bring to the political action of those conservative and sober man who in fear of the confusion and risk attend an arbitrary and sudden change in all the public office with a change of party rule cast their ballot against such a chance party seem to be necessary and will long continue to exist nor can it be now deny that there be legitimate advantage not disconnect with office holding which follow party supremacy while partisanship continue bitter and pronounced and supply so much of motive to sentiment and action it be not fair to hold public official in charge of important trust responsible for the good result in the performance of their duty and yet insist that they shall rely in confidential and important place upon the work of those not only oppose to they in political affiliation but so steep in partisan prejudice and rancor that they have no loyalty to their chief and no desire for their success civil service reform do not exact this nor do it require that those in subordinate position who fail in yield their good service or who be incompetent should be retain simply because they be in place the whining of a clerk discharge for indolence or incompetency who though he gain his place by the bad possible operation of the spoils system suddenly discover that he be entitle to protection under the sanction of civil service reform represent an idea no less absurd than the clamor of the applicant who claim the vacant position as his compensation for the most questionable party work the civil service law do not prevent the discharge of the indolent or incompetent clerk but it do prevent supply his place with the unfit party worker thus in both these phase be see benefit to the public service and the people who desire good government having secure this statute will not relinquish its benefit without protest nor be they unmindful of the fact that its full advantage can only be gain through the complete good faith of those have its execution in charge and this they will insist upon i recommend that the salary of the civil service commissioners be increase to a sum more nearly commensurate to their important duty it be a source of considerable and not unnatural discontent that no adequate provision have yet be make for accommodate the principal library of the government of the vast collection of book and pamphlet gather at the capitol number some 700,000 exclusive of manuscript map and the product of the graphic art also of great volume and value only about 300,000 volume or less than half the collection be provide with shelf room the other which be increase at the rate of from twenty five to thirty thousand volume a year be not only inaccessible to the public but be subject to serious damage and deterioration from other cause in their present situation a consideration of the fact that the library of the capitol have twice be destroy or damage by fire its daily increase value and its importance as a place of deposit of book under the law relate to copyright make manifest the necessity of prompt action to insure its proper accommodation and protection my attention have be call to a controversy which have arise from the condition of the law relate to railroad facility in the city of washington which have involve the commissioners of the district in much annoyance and trouble i hope this difficulty will be promptly settle by appropriate legislation the commissioners represent that enough of the revenue of the district be now on deposit in the treasury of the united states to repay the sum advance by the government for sewer improvement under the act of june 30 1884 they desire now an advance of the share which ultimately should be bear by the district of the cost of extensive improvement to the street of the city the total expense of these contemplate improvement be estimate at $ 1,000,000 and they be of the opinion that a considerable sum could be save if they have all the money in hand so that contract for the whole work could be make at the same time they express confidence that if the advance ask for should be make the government would be reimburse the same within a reasonable time i have no doubt that these improvement could be make much cheap if undertake together and prosecute accord to a general plan the license law now in force within the district be deficient and uncertain in some of its provision and ought to be amend the commissioners urge with good reason the necessity of provide a building for the use of the district government which shall well secure the safety and preservation of its valuable book and record the present condition of the law relate to the succession to the presidency in the event of the death disability or removal of both the president and vice president be such as to require immediate amendment this subject have repeatedly be consider by congress but no result have be reach the recent lamentable death of the vice president and vacancy at the same time in all other office the incumbent of which might immediately exercise the function of the presidential office have cause public anxiety and a just demand that a recurrence of such a condition of affair should not be permit in conclusion i commend to the wise care and thoughtful attention of congress the need the welfare and the aspiration of an intelligent and generous nation to subordinate these to the narrow advantage of partisanship or the accomplishment of selfish aim be to violate the people 's trust and betray the people 's interest but an individual sense of
