to the senate and house of representatives
 it be make the constitutional duty of the president to recommend to the consideration of congress from time to time such measure as he shall judge necessary and expedient in no matter can the necessity of this be more evident than when the good faith of the united states under the solemn obligation of treaty with foreign power be concern
 the question of the treatment of the subject of china sojourn within the jurisdiction of the united states present such a matter for the urgent and earnest consideration of the executive and the congress
 in my first annual message upon the assembling of the present congress i advert to this question in the following word
 the harmony of our relation with china be fully sustain
 in the application of the act lately pass to execute the treaty of 1880 restrictive of the immigration of chinese laborer into the united states individual case of hardship have occur beyond the power of the executive to remedy and call for judicial determination
 the condition of the chinese question in the western states and territories be despite this restrictive legislation far from be satisfactory the recent outbreak in wyoming territory where number of unoffending chinamen indisputably within the protection of the treaty and the law be murder by a mob and the still more recent threatened outbreak of the same character in washington territory be fresh in the mind of all and there be apprehension lest the bitterness of feeling against the mongolian race on the pacific slope may find vent in similar lawless demonstration all the power of this government should be exert to maintain the ample good faith toward china in the treatment of these man and the inflexible sternness of the law in bring the wrongdoer to justice should be insist upon
 every effort have be make by this government to prevent these violent outbreak and to aid the representative of china in their investigation of these outrage and it be but just to say that they be traceable to the lawlessness of man not citizen of the united states engage in competition with chinese laborer
 race prejudice be the chief factor in originate these disturbance and it exist in a large part of our domain jeopardize our domestic peace and the good relationship we strive to maintain with china
 the admit right of a government to prevent the influx of element hostile to its internal peace and security may not be question even where there be no treaty stipulation on the subject that the exclusion of chinese labor be demand in other country where like condition prevail be strongly evidence in the dominion of canada where chinese immigration be now regulate by law more exclusive than our own if existing law be inadequate to compass the end in view i shall be prepare to give earnest consideration to any further remedial measure within the treaty limit which the wisdom of congress may devise
 at the time i write this the shocking occurrence at rock springs in wyoming territory be fresh in the mind of all and have be recently present anew to the attention of this government by the chinese minister in a note which while not unnaturally exhibit some misconception of our federal system of administration in the territories while they as yet be not in the exercise of the full measure of that sovereign self government pertaining to the states of the union present in truthful term the main feature of the cruel outrage there perpetrate upon inoffensive subject of china in the investigation of the rock springs outbreak and the ascertainment of the fact on which the chinese minister&#39; statement rest the chinese representative be aid by the agent of the united states and the report submit having be thus frame and recount the fact within the knowledge of witness on both side possess an impartial truthfulness which could not fail to give they great impressiveness
 the fact which so far be not controvert or affect by any exculpatory or mitigate testimony show the murder of a number of chinese subject in september last at rock springs the wounding of many other and the spoliation of the property of all when the unhappy survivor have be drive from their habitation there be no allegation that the victim by any lawless or disorderly act on their part contribute to bring about a collision on the contrary it appear that the law abide disposition of these people who be sojourner in our midst under the sanction of hospitality and express treaty obligation be make the pretext for an attack upon they this outrage upon law and treaty engagement be commit by a lawless mob none of the aggressor happily for the national good fame appear by the report to have be citizen of the united states they be alien engage in that remote district as mining laborer who become excited against the chinese laborer as it would seem because of their refusal to join they in a strike to secure high wage the oppression of chinese subject by their rival in the competition for labor do not differ in violence and illegality from that apply to other class of native or alien labor all be equally under the protection of law and equally entitle to enjoy the benefit of assure public order
 be there no treaty in existence refer to the right of chinese subject do they come hither as all other stranger who voluntarily resort to this land of freedom of self government and of law here peaceably to win their bread and to live their life there can be no question that they would be entitle still to the same measure of protection from violence and the same free forum for the redress of their grievance as any other alien
 so far as the treaty between the united states and china stipulate for the treatment of the chinese subject actually in the united states as the citizen or subject of the most favored nation be treat they create no new status for they they simply recognize and confirm a general and exist rule applicable to all alien alike for none be favor above other by domestic law and none by foreign treaty unless it be the chinese themselves in some respect for by the third article of the treaty of november 17 1880 between the united states and china it be provide that--
 art iii if chinese laborer or chinese of any other class now either permanently or temporarily reside in the territory of the united states meet with ill treatment at the hand of any other person the government of the united states will exert all its power to devise measure for their protection and to secure to they the same right privilege immunity and exemption as may be enjoy by the citizen or subject of the most favored nation and to which they be entitle by treaty
 this article may be hold to constitute a special privilege for chinese subject in the united states as compare with other alien not that it create any peculiar right which other do not share but because in case of ill treatment of the chinese in the united states this government be bind to exert all its power to devise measure for their protection by secure to they the right to which equally with any and all other foreigner they be entitle
 whether it be now incumbent upon the united states to amend their general law or devise new measure in this regard i do not consider in the present communication but confine myself to the particular point raise by the outrage and massacre at rock springs
 the note of the chinese minister and the document which accompany it give as i believe an unexaggerated statement of the lamentable incident and present impressively the regrettable circumstance that the proceeding in the name of justice for the ascertainment of the crime and fix the responsibility therefor be a ghastly mockery of justice so long as the chinese minister under his instruction make this the basis of an appeal to the principle and conviction of mankind no exception can be take but when he go far and take as his precedent the action of the chinese government in past instance where the life of american citizen and their property in china have be endanger argue a reciprocal obligation on the part of the united states to indemnify the chinese subject who suffer at rock springs it become necessary to meet his argument and to deny most emphatically the conclusion he seek to draw as to the existence of such a liability and the right of the chinese government to insist upon it
 i draw the attention of the congress to the latter part of the note of the secretary of state of february 18 1886 in reply to the chinese minister&#39; representation and invite special consideration of the cogent reason by which he reach the conclusion that whilst the united states government be under no obligation whether by the express term of its treaty with china or the principle of international law to indenmify these chinese subject for loss cause by such mean and under the admit circumstance yet that in view of the palpable and discreditable failure of the authority of wyoming territory to bring to justice the guilty party or to assure to the sufferer an impartial forum in which to seek and obtain compensation for the loss which those subject have incur by lack of police protection and consider far the entire absence of provocation or contribution on the part of the victim the executive may be induce to bring the matter to the benevolent consideration of the congress in order that that body in its high discretion may direct the bounty of the government in aid of innocent and peaceful stranger whose maltreatment have bring discredit upon the country with the distinct understanding that such action be in no wise to be hold as a precedent be wholly gratuitous and be resort to in a spirit of pure generosity toward those who be otherwise helpless
 the correspondence exchange be herewith submit for the information of the congress and accompany a like message to the house of representatives

to the senate and house of representatives
 the constitution impose upon the president the duty of recommend to the consideration of congress from time to time such measure as he shall judge necessary and expedient
 i be so deeply impressed with the importance of immediately and thoughtfully meet the problem which recent event and a present condition have thrust upon we involve the settlement of dispute arise between our labor man and their employer that i be constrain to recommend to congress legislation upon this serious and press subject
 under our form of government the value of labor as an element of national prosperity should be distinctly recognize and the welfare of the labor man should be regard as especially entitle to legislative care in a country which offer to all its citizen the high attainment of social and political distinction its workingmen can not justly or safely be consider as irrevocably consign to the limit of a class and entitle to no attention and allow no protest against neglect
 the labor man bear in his hand an indispensable contribution to our growth and progress may well insist with manly courage and as a right upon the same recognition from those who make our law as be accord to any other citizen have a valuable interest in charge and his reasonable demand should be meet in such a spirit of appreciation and fairness as to induce a contented and patriotic cooperation in the achievement of a grand national destiny
 while the real interest of labor be not promote by a resort to threat and violent manifestation and while those who under the pretext of an advocacy of the claim of labor wantonly attack the right of capital and for selfish purpose or the love of disorder sow seed of violence and discontent should neither be encourage nor conciliate all legislation on the subject should be calmly and deliberately undertake with no purpose of satisfy unreasonable demand or gain partisan advantage
 the present condition of the relation between labor and capital be far from satisfactory the discontent of the employ be due in a large degree to the grasping and heedless exaction of employer and the alleged discrimination in favor of capital as an object of governmental attention it must also be concede that the labor man be not always careful to avoid causeless and unjustifiable disturbance
 though the importance of a well accord between these interest be apparent it must be bear in mind that any effort in that direction by the federal government must be greatly limit by constitutional restriction there be many grievance which legislation by congress can not redress and many condition which can not by such mean be reform
 i be satisfied however that something may be do under federal authority to prevent the disturbance which so often arise from dispute between employer and the employ and which at time seriously threaten the business interest of the country and in my opinion the proper theory upon which to proceed be that of voluntary arbitration as the mean of settle these difficulty
 but i suggest that instead of arbitrator choose in the heat of conflict claim and after each dispute shall arise for the purpose of determine the same there be create a commission of labor consist of three member who shall be regular officer of the government charge among other duty with the consideration and settlement when possible of all controversy between labor and capital
 a commission thus organize would have the advantage of be a stable body and its member as they gain experience would constantly improve in their ability to deal intelligently and usefully with the question which might be submit to they if arbitrator be choose for temporary service as each case of dispute arise experience and familiarity with much that be involve in the question will be lacking extreme partisanship and bias will be the qualification seek on either side and frequent complaint of unfairness and partiality will be inevitable the imposition upon a federal court of a duty so foreign to the judicial function as the selection of an arbitrator in such case be at least of doubtful propriety
 the establishment by federal authority of such a bureau would be a just and sensible recognition of the value of labor and of its right to be represent in the department of the government so far as its conciliatory office shall have relation to disturbance which interfere with transit and commerce between the states its existence would be justify under the provision of the constitution which give to congress the power to regulate commerce with foreign nation and among the several state and in the frequent dispute between the labor man and their employer of less extent and the consequence of which be confine within state limit and threaten domestic violence the interposition of such a commission might be tender upon the application of the legislature or executive of a state under the constitutional provision which require the general government to protect each of the states against domestic violence
 if such a commission be fairly organize the risk of a loss of popular support and sympathy result from a refusal to submit to so peaceful an instrumentality would constrain both party to such dispute to invoke its interference and abide by its decision there would also be good reason to hope that the very existence of such an agency would invite application to it for advice and counsel frequently result in the avoidance of contention and misunderstanding
 if the usefulness of such a commission be doubted because it might lack power to enforce its decision much encouragement be derive from the concede good that have be accomplish by the railroad commission which have be organize in many of the states which have little more than advisory power have exert a most salutary influence in the settlement of dispute between conflict interest
 in july 1884 by a law of congress a bureau of labor be establish and place in charge of a commissioner of labor who be require to collect information upon the subject of labor its relation to capital the hour of labor and the earning of labor man and woman and the mean of promote their material social intellectual and moral prosperity
 the commission which i suggest could easily be ingraft upon the bureau thus already organize by the addition of two more commissioner and by supplement the duty now impose upon it by such other power and function as would permit the commissioner to act as arbitrator when necessary between labor and capital under such limitation and upon such occasion as should be deem proper and useful
 power should also be distinctly confer upon this bureau to investigate the cause of all dispute as they occur whether submit for arbitration or not so that information may always be at hand to aid legislation on the subject when necessary and desirable

to the house of representatives
 i return without my approval house bill no 1471 entitle an act increase the pension of andrew j. hill
 this bill double the pension which the person name therein have be receive for a number of year it appear from the report of the committee to which the bill be refer that a claim make by he for increase pension have be lately reject by the pension bureau on the ground that the claimant be now receive a pension commensurate with the degree of disability find to exist
 the policy of frequently reverse by special enactment the decision of the bureau invest by law with the examination of pension claim fully equip for such examination and which ought not to be suspect of any lack of liberality to our veteran soldier be exceedingly questionable it may well be doubted if a committee of congress have a well opportunity than such an agency to judge of the merit of these claim if however there be any lack of power in the pension bureau for a full investigation it should be supply if the system adopt be inadequate to do full justice to claimant it should be correct and if there be a want of sympathy and consideration for the defender of our government the bureau should be reorganize
 the disposition to concede the most generous treatment to the disabled aged and needy among our veteran ought not to be restrain and it must be admit that in some case justice and equity can not be do nor the charitable tendency of the government in favor of worthy object of its care indulge under fix rule these condition sometimes justify a resort to special legislation but i be convinced that the interposition by special enactment in the granting of pension should be rare and exceptional in the nature of thing if this be lightly do and upon slight occasion an invitation be offer for the presentation of claim to congress which upon their merit could not survive the test of an examination by the pension bureau and whose only hope of success depend upon sympathy often misdirect instead of right and justice the instrumentality organize by law for the determination of pension claim be thus often overrule and discredit and there be danger that in the end popular prejudice will be create against those who be worthily entitle to the bounty of the government
 there have lately be present to i on the same day for approval nearly 240 special bill grant and increase pension and restore to the pension list the name of party which for cause have be drop to aid executive duty they be refer to the pension bureau for examination and report after a delay absolutely necessary they have be return to i within a few hour of the limit constitutionally permit for executive action two hundred and thirty two of these bill be thus classify
 eighty one cover case in which favorable action by the pension bureau be deny by reason of the insufficiency of the testimony file to prove the fact allege
 these bill i have approve on the assumption that the claim be meritorious and that by the passage of the bill the government have waive full proof of the fact
 twenty six of the bill cover claim reject by the pension bureau because the evidence produce tend to prove that the alleged disability exist before the claimant&#39;s enlistment 21 cover claim which have be deny by such bureau because the evidence tend to show that the disability though contract in the service be not incur in the line of duty 33 cover claim which have be deny because the evidence tend to establish that the disability originate after the soldier&#39;s discharge from the army 47 cover claim which have be deny because the general pension law contain no provision under which they could be allow and 24 of the claim have never be present to the pension bureau
 i estimate the expenditure involve in these bill at more than $ 35,000 annually
 though my conception of public duty lead i to the conclusion upon the slight examination which i have be able to give such of these bill as be not comprise in the first class above mention that many of they should be disapprove i be utterly unable to submit within the time allow i for that purpose my objection to the same
 they will therefore become operative without my approval
 a sufficient reason for the return of the particular bill now under consideration be find in the fact that it provide that the name of andrew j. hill be place upon the pension roll while the record of the pension bureau as well as a medical certificate make a part of the committee&#39;s report disclose that the correct name of the intended beneficiary be alfred j. hill

to the senate and house of representatives
 by a joint resolution of congress approve march 3 1877 the president be authorize and direct to accept the colossal statue of liberty enlighten the world when present by the citizen of the french republic and to designate and set apart for the erection thereof a suitable site upon either governors or bedloes island in the harbor of new york and upon the completion thereof to cause the statue to be inaugurate with such ceremony as will serve to testify the gratitude of our people for this expressive and felicitous memorial of the sympathy of the citizen of our sister republic
 the president be far thereby authorize to cause suitable regulation to be make for its future maintenance as a beacon and for the permanent care and preservation thereof as a monument of art and the continue good will of the great nation which aid we in our struggle for freedom
 under the authority of this resolution on the 4th day of july 1884 the minister of the united states to the french republic by direction of the president of the united states accept the statue and receive a deed of presentation from the franco american union which be now preserve in the archive of the department of state
 i now transmit to congress a letter to the secretary of state from joseph w. drexel esq chairman of the executive committee of the american committee on the pedestal of the great statue of 39;liberty enlighten the world,&#39 date the 27th of april 1886 suggest the propriety of the further execution by the president of the joint resolution refer to by prescribe the ceremony of inauguration to be observe upon the complete erection of the statue upon its site on bedloes island in the harbor of new york
 thursday the 3d of september be the anniversary of the signing of the treaty of peace at paris by which the independence of these united states be recognize and secure have be suggest by this committee under whose auspex and agency the pedestal for the statue have be construct as an appropriate day for the ceremony of inauguration
 the international character which have be imprint upon this work by the joint resolution of 1877 make it incumbent upon congress to provide mean to carry their resolution into effect
 therefore i recommend the appropriation of such sum of money as in the judgment of congress shall be deem adequate and proper to defray the cost of the inauguration of this statue
 i have be inform by the committee that certain expense have be incur in the care and custody of the statue since it be deposit on bedloes island and the phraseology of the joint resolution provide for the permanent care and preservation thereof as a monument of art would seem to include the payment by the united states of the expense so incur since the reception of the statue in this country
 the action of the french government and people in relation to the presentation of this statue to the united states will i hope meet with hearty and responsive action upon the part of congress in which the executive will be most happy to cooperate


 to the heads of departments in the service of the general government
 i deem this a proper time to especially warn all subordinate in the several departments and all officeholder under the general government against the use of their official position in attempt to control political movement in their locality
 officeholder be the agent of the people not their master not only be their time and labor due to the government but they should scrupulously avoid in their political action as well as in the discharge of their official duty offend by a display of obtrusive partisanship their neighbor who have relation with they as public official
 they should also constantly remember that their party friend from whom they have receive preferment have not invest they with the power of arbitrarily manage their political affair they have no right as officeholder to dictate the political action of their party associate or to throttle freedom of action within party line by method and practice which pervert every useful and justifiable purpose of party organization
 the influence of federal officeholder should not be feel in the manipulation of political primary meeting and nominating convention the use by these official of their position to compass their selection as delegate to political convention be indecent and unfair and proper regard for the propriety and requirement of official place will also prevent their assume the active conduct of political campaign
 individual interest and activity in political affair be by no mean condemn officeholder be neither disfranchise nor forbid the exercise of political privilege but their privilege be not enlarge nor be their duty to party increase to pernicious activity by office holding
 a just discrimination in this regard between the thing a citizen may properly do and the purpose for which a public office should not be use be easy in the light of a correct appreciation of the relation between the people and those intrust with official place and a consideration of the necessity under our form of government of political action free from official coercion
 you be request to communicate the substance of these view to those for whose guidance they be intend

to the house of representatives
 i herewith return without my approval house bill no 10457 entitle an act for the relief of dependent parent and honorably discharge soldier and sailor who be now disabled and dependent upon their own labor for support
 this be the first general bill that have be sanction by the congress since the close of the late civil war permit a pension to the soldier and sailor who serve in that war upon the ground of service and present disability alone and in the entire absence of any injury receive by the casualty or incident of such service
 while by almost constant legislation since the close of this war there have be compensation award for every possible injury receive as a result of military service in the union army and while a great number of law pass for that purpose have be administer with great liberality and have be supplement by numerous private act to reach special case there have not until now be an avow departure from the principle thus far adhere to respect union soldier that the bounty of the government in the way of pension be generously bestow when grant to those who in this military service and in the line of military duty have to a great or less extent be disable
 but it be a mistake to suppose that service pension such as be permit by the second section of the bill under consideration be new to our legislation in 1818 thirty five year after the close of the revolutionary war they be grant to the soldier engage in that struggle conditional upon service until the end of the war or for a term not less than nine month and require every beneficiary under the act to be one who be or hereafter by reason of his reduce circumstance in life shall be in need of assistance from his country for support another law of a like character be pass in 1828 require service until the close of the revolutionary war and still another pass in 1832 provide for those person not include in the previous statute but who serve two year at some time during the war and give a proportionate sum to those who have serve not less than six month
 a service pension law be pass for the benefit of the soldier of 1812 in the year 1871 fifty six year after the close of that war which require only sixty days&#39 service and another be pass in 1878 sixty three year after the war require only fourteen days&#39 service
 the service pension bill pass at this session of congress thirty nine year after the close of the mexican war for the benefit of the soldier of that war require either some degree of disability or dependency or that the claimant under its provision should be 62 year of age and in either case that he should have serve sixty day or be actually engage in a battle
 it will be see that the bill of 1818 and the mexican pension bill be thus pass nearer the close of the war in which its beneficiary be engage than the other one thirty five year and the other thirty nine year after the termination of such war embrace person who be quite advanced in age assume to be comparatively few in number and whose circumstance dependence and disability be clearly define and could be quite easily fix
 the other law refer to appear to have be pass at a time so remote from the military service of the person which they embrace that their extreme age alone be deem to supply a presumption of dependency and need
 the number of enlistment in the revolutionary war be state to be 309,791 and in the war of 1812 576,622 but it be estimate that on account of repeat reenlistment the number of individual engage in these war do not exceed one half of the number represent by these figure in the war with mexico the number of enlistment be report to be 112,230 which represent a great proportion of individual engage than the report enlistment in the two previous war
 the number of pension grant under all law to soldier of the revolution be give at 62,069 to the soldier of the war of 1812 and their widow 60,178 and to soldier of the mexican war and their widow up to june 30 1885 7,619 the latter pension be grant to the soldier of a war involve much hardship for disability incur as a result of such service and it be not till within the last month that the few remain survivor be award a service pension
 the war of the rebellion terminate nearly twenty two year ago the number of man furnish for its prosecution be state to be 2,772,408 no corresponding number of statute have ever be pass to cover every kind of injury or disability incur in the military service of any war under these statute 561,571 pension have be grant from the year 1861 to june 30 1886 and more than 2,600 pensioner have be add to the roll by private act pass to meet case many of they of questionable merit which the general law do not cover
 on this 1st day of july 1886 365,763 pensioner of all class be upon the pension roll of whom 305,605 be survivor of the war of the rebellion and their widow and dependent for the year end june 30 1887 $ 75,000,000 have be appropriate for the payment of pension and the amount expend for that purpose from 1861 to july 1 1886 be $ 808,624,811.51
 while annually pay out such a vast sum for pension already grant it be now propose by the bill under consideration to award a service pension to the soldier of all war in which the united states have be engage include of course the war of the rebellion and to pay those entitle to the benefit of the act the sum of $ 12 per month
 so far as it relate to the soldier of the late civil war the bounty it afford they be give thirteen year early than it have be furnish the soldier of any other war and before a large majority of its beneficiary have advance in age beyond the strength and vigor of the prime of life
 it exact only a military or naval service of three month without any requirement of actual engagement with an enemy in battle and without a subjection to any of the actual danger of war
 the pension it award be allow to enlisted man who have not suffer the least injury disability loss or damage of any kind incur in or in any degree referable to their military service include those who never reach the front at all and those discharge from rendezvous at the close of the war if discharge three month after enlistment under the last call of the president for troop in december 1864 11,303 man be furnish who be thus discharge
 the section allow this pension do however require besides a service of three month and an honorable discharge that those seek the benefit of the act shall be such as be now or may hereafter be suffer from mental or physical disability not the result of their own vicious habit or gross carelessness which incapacitate they for the performance of labor in such a degree as to render they unable to earn a support and who be dependent upon their daily labor for support
 it provide far that such person shall upon make proof of the fact be place on the list of invalid pensioner of the united states and be entitle to receive for such total inability to procure their subsistence by daily labor $ 12 per month and such pension shall commence from the date of the filing of the application in the pension office upon proof that the disability then exist and continue during the existence of the same in the degree herein provide provide that person who be now receive pension under exist law or whose claim be pende in the pension office may by application to the commissioner of pensions in such form as he may prescribe receive the benefit of this act
 it be manifestly of the utmost importance that statute which like pension law should be liberally administer as measure of benevolence in behalf of worthy beneficiary should admit of no uncertainty as to their general object and consequence
 upon a careful consideration of the language of the section of this bill above give it seem to i to be so uncertain and liable to such conflict construction and to be subject to such unjust and mischievous application as to alone furnish sufficient ground for disapprove the propose legislation
 person seek to obtain the pension provide by this section must be now or hereafter--
 1 suffer from mental or physical disability
 2 such disability must not be the result of their own vicious habit or gross carelessness
 3 such disability must be such as incapacitate they for the performance of labor in such a degree as to render they unable to earn a support
 4 they must be dependent upon their daily labor for support
 5 upon proof of these condition they shall be place on the list of invalid pensioner of the united states and be entitle to receive for such total inability to procure their subsistence by daily labor $ 12 per month
 it be not probable that the word last quote such total inability to procure their subsistence by daily labor at all qualify the condition prescribe in the precede language of the section the total inability speak of must be such inability that is the inability already describe and constitute by the condition already detail in the previous part of the section
 it thus become important to consider the meaning and the scope of these last mention condition
 the mental and physical disability speak of have a distinct meaning in the practice of the pension bureau and include every impairment of bodily or mental strength and vigor for such disability there be now pay 131 different rate of pension range from $ 1 to $ 100 per month
 this disability must not be the result of the applicant&#39; vicious habit or gross carelessness practically this provision be not important the attempt of the government to escape the payment of a pension on such a plea would of course in a very large majority of instance and regardless of the merit of the case prove a failure there would be that strange but nearly universal willingness to help the individual as between he and the public treasury which go very far to insure a state of proof in favor of the claimant
 the disability of applicant must be such as to incapacitate they for the performance of labor in such a degree as to render they unable to earn a support
 it will be observe that there be no limitation or definition of the incapacitating injury or ailment itself it need only be such a degree of disability from any cause as render the claimant unable to earn a support by labor it seem to i that the support here mention as one which can not be earn be a complete and entire support with no diminution on account of the least impairment of physical or mental condition if it have be intend to embrace only those who by disease or injury be totally unable to labor it would have be very easy to express that idea instead of recognize as be do a degree of such inability
 what be a support who be to determine whether a man earn it or have it or have it not be the government to enter the home of claimant for pension and after an examination of their surrounding and circumstance settle those question shall the government say to one man that his manner of subsistence by his earning be a support and to another that the thing his earning furnish be not a support any attempt however honest to administer this law in such a manner would necessarily produce more unfairness and unjust discrimination and give more scope for partisan partiality and would result in more perversion of the government&#39;s benevolent intention than the execution of any statute ought to permit
 if in the effort to carry out the propose law the degree of disability as relate to earning be consider for the purpose of discover if in any way it curtail the support which the applicant if entirely sound would earn and to which he be entitle we enter the broad field long occupy by the pension bureau and we recognize as the only difference between the propose legislation and previous law pass for the benefit of the survive soldier of the civil war the incurrence in one case of disability in military service and in the other disability exist but in no way connect with or result from such service
 it must be bear in mind that in no case be there any grading of this propose pension under the operation of the rule first suggest if there be a lack in any degree great or small of the ability to earn such a support as the government determine the claimant should have and by the application of the rule secondly suggest if there be a reduction in any degree of the support which he might earn if sound he be entitle to a pension of $ 12
 in the latter case and under the proviso of the propose bill permit person now receive pension to be admit to the benefit of the act i do not see how those now on the pension roll for disability incur in the service and which diminish their earning capacity can be deny the pension provide in this bill
 of course none will apply who be now receive $ 12 or more per month but on the 30th day of june 1886 there be on the pension roll 202,621 person who be receive fifty eight different rate of pension from $ 1 to $ 11.75 per month of these 28,142 be receive $ 2 per month 63,116 $ 4 per month 37,254 $ 6 per month and 50,274 whose disability be rate as total $ 8 per month
 as to the meaning of the section of the bill under consideration there appear to have be quite a difference of opinion among its advocate in the congress the chairman of the committee on pensions in the house of representatives who report the bill declare that there be in it no provision for pension anyone who have a less disability than a total inability to labor and that it be a charity measure the chairman of the committee on pensions in the senate have charge of the bill in that body dissent from the construction of the bill announce in the house of representatives and declare that it not only embrace all soldier totally disable but in his judgment all who be disabled to any considerable extent and such a construction be substantially give to the bill by another distinguished senator who as a former secretary of the interior have impose upon he the duty of execute pension law and determine their intent and meaning
 another condition require of claimant under this act be that they shall be dependent upon their daily labor for support
 this language which may be say to assume that there exist within the reach of the person mention labor or the ability in some degree to work be more aptly use in a statute describe those not wholly deprived of this ability than in one which deal with those utterly unable to work
 i be of the opinion that it may fairly be contend that under the provision of this section any soldier whose faculty of mind or body have become impair by accident disease or age irrespective of his service in the army as a cause and who by his labor only be leave incapable of gain the fair support he might with unimpaired power have provide for himself and who be not so well endow with this world&#39;s good as to live without work may claim to participate in its bounty that it be not require that he should be without property but only that labor should be necessary to his support in some degree nor be it require that he should be now receive support from other
 believe this to be the proper interpretation of the bill i can not but remember that the soldier of our civil war in their pay and bounty receive such compensation for military service as have never be receive by soldier before since mankind first go to war that never before on behalf of any soldiery have so many and such generous law be pass to relieve against the incident of war that statute have be pass give they a preference in all public employment that the really needy and homeless union soldier of the rebellion have be to a large extent provide for at soldiers&#39 home institute and support by the government where they be maintain together free from the sense of degradation which attach to the usual support of charity and that never before in the history of the country have it be propose to render government aid toward the support of any of its soldier base alone upon a military service so recent and where age and circumstance appear so little to demand such aid
 hitherto such relief have be grant to survive soldier few in number venerable in age after a long lapse of time since their military service and as a parting benefaction tender by a grateful people
 i can not believe that the vast peaceful army of union soldier who having contentedly resume their place in the ordinary avocation of life cherish as sacred the memory of patriotic service or who having be disable by the casualty of war justly regard the present pension roll on which appear their name as a roll of honor desire at this time and in the present exigency to be confound with those who through such a bill as this be willing to be object of simple charity and to gain a place upon the pension roll through alleged dependence
 recent personal observation and experience constrain i to refer to another result which will inevitably follow the passage of this bill it be sad but nevertheless true that already in the matter of procure pension there exist a widespread disregard of truth and good faith stimulate by those who as agent undertake to establish claim for pension heedlessly enter upon by the expectant beneficiary and encourage or at least not condemn by those unwilling to obstruct a neighbor&#39;s plan
 in the execution of this propose law under any interpretation a wide field of inquiry would be open for the establishment of fact largely within the knowledge of the claimant alone and there can be no doubt that the race after the pension offer by this bill would not only stimulate weakness and pretend incapacity for labor but put a further premium on dishonesty and mendacity
 the effect of new invitation to apply for pension or of new advantage add to cause for pension already exist be sometimes startling
 thus in march 1879 large arrearage of pension be allow to be add to all claim file prior to july 1 1880 for the year from july 1 1879 to july 1 1880 there be file 110,673 claim though in the year immediately previous there be but 36,832 file and in the year follow but 18,455
 while cost should not be set against a patriotic duty or the recognition of a right still when a measure propose be base upon generosity or motive of charity it be not amiss to meditate somewhat upon the expense which it involve experience have demonstrate i believe that all estimate concern the probable future cost of a pension list be uncertain and unreliable and always fall far below actual realization
 the chairman of the house committee on pensions calculate that the number of pensioner under this bill would be 33,105 and the increase cost $ 4,767,120 this be upon the theory that only those who be entirely unable to work would be its beneficiary such be the principle of the revolutionary pension law of 1818 much more clearly state it seem to i than in this bill when the law of 1818 be upon its passage in congress the number of pensioner to be benefit thereby be think to be 374 but the number of applicant under the act be 22,297 and the number of pension actually allow 20,485 cost it be report for the first year $ 1,847,900 instead of $ 40,000 the estimate expense for that period
 a law be pass in 1853 for the benefit of the survive widow of revolutionary soldier who be marry after january 1 1800 it be estimate that they number 300 at the time of the passage of the act but the number of pension allow be 3,742 and the amount pay for such pension during the first year of the operation of the act be $ 180,000 instead of $ 24,000 as have be estimate
 i have make no search for other illustration and the above be at hand be give as tend to show that estimate can not be rely upon in such case
 if none should be pension under this bill except those utterly unable to work i be satisfied that the cost state in the estimate refer to would be many time multiply and with a constant increase from year to year and if those partially unable to earn their support should be admit to the privilege of this bill the probable increase of expense would be almost appalling
 i think it may be say that at the close of the war of the rebellion every northern state and a great majority of northern county and city be burden with taxation on account of the large bounty pay our soldier and the bond debt thereby create still constitute a large item in the account of the taxgatherer against the people federal taxation no less bear by the people than that directly levy upon their property be still maintain at the rate make necessary by the exigency of war if this bill should become a law with its tremendous addition to our pension obligation i be thoroughly convinced that further effort to reduce the federal revenue and restore some part of it to our people will and perhaps should be seriously question
 it have constantly be a cause of pride and congratulation to the american citizen that his country be not put to the charge of maintain a large stand army in time of peace yet we be now live under a war tax which have be tolerate in peaceful time to meet the obligation incur in war but for year past in all part of the country the demand for the reduction of the burden of taxation upon our labor and production have increase in volume and urgency
 i be not willing to approve a measure present the objection to which this bill be subject and which moreover will have the effect of disappoint the expectation of the people and their desire and hope for relief from war taxation in time of peace
 in my last annual message the follow language be use
 every patriotic heart respond to a tender consideration for those who having serve their country long and well be reduce to destitution and dependence not as an incident of their service but with advance age or through sickness or misfortune we be all tempt by the contemplation of such a condition to supply relief and be often impatient of the limitation of public duty yield to no one in the desire to indulge this feeling of consideration i can not rid myself of the conviction that if these ex soldier be to be relieve they and their cause be entitle to the benefit of an enactment under which relief may be claim as a right and that such relief should be grant under the sanction of law not in evasion of it nor should such worthy object of care all equally entitle be remit to the unequal operation of sympathy or the tender mercy of social and political influence with their unjust discrimination
 i do not think that the object the condition and the limitation thus suggest be contain in the bill under consideration
 i adhere to the sentiment thus heretofore express but the evil threaten by this bill be in my opinion such that charge with a great responsibility in behalf of the people i can not do otherwise than to bring to the consideration of this measure my good effort of thought and judgment and perform my constitutional duty in relation thereto regardless of all consequence except such as appear to i to be relate to the good and high interest of the country

to the house of representatives
 i return without my approval house bill no 10203 entitle an act to enable the commissioner of agriculture to make a special distribution of seed in the drought stricken county of texas and make an appropriation therefor
 it be represent that a long continue and extensive drought have exist in certain portion of the state of texas result in a failure of crop and consequent distress and destitution
 though there have be some difference in statement concern the extent of the people&#39; need in the locality thus affect there seem to be no doubt that there have exist a condition call for relief and i be willing to believe that notwithstanding the aid already furnish a donation of seed grain to the farmer locate in this region to enable they to put in new crop would serve to avert a continuance or return of an unfortunate blight
 and yet i feel obliged to withhold my approval of the plan as propose by this bill to indulge a benevolent and charitable sentiment through the appropriation of public fund for that purpose
 i can find no warrant for such an appropriation in the constitution and i do not believe that the power and duty of the general government ought to be extend to the relief of individual suffering which be in no manner properly relate to the public service or benefit a prevalent tendency to disregard the limited mission of this power and duty should i think be steadfastly resist to the end that the lesson should be constantly enforce that though the people support the government the government should not support the people
 the friendliness and charity of our countryman can always be rely upon to relieve their fellow citizen in misfortune this have be repeatedly and quite lately demonstrate federal aid in such case encourage the expectation of paternal care on the part of the government and weaken the sturdiness of our national character while it prevent the indulgence among our people of that kindly sentiment and conduct which strengthen the bond of a common brotherhood
 it be within my personal knowledge that individual aid have to some extent already be extend to the sufferer mention in this bill the failure of the propose appropriation of $ 10,000 additional to meet their remain want will not necessarily result in continue distress if the emergency be fully make known to the people of the country
 it be here suggest that the commissioner of agriculture be annually direct to expend a large sum of money for the purchase propagation and distribution of seed and other thing of this description two third of which be upon the request of senators representatives and delegates in congress supply to they for distribution among their constituent
 the appropriation of the current year for this purpose be $ 100,000 and it will probably be no less in the appropriation for the ensue year i understand that a large quantity of grain be furnish for such distribution and it be suppose that this free apportionment among their neighbor be a privilege which may be waive by our senators and representatives
 if sufficient of they should request the commissioner of agriculture to send their share of the grain thus allow they to the suffer farmer of texas they might be enable to sow their crop the constituent for whom in theory this grain be intend could well bear the temporary deprivation and the donor would experience the satisfaction attend deed of charity

to the congress of the united states you be confront at the threshold of your legislative duty with a condition of the national finance which imperatively demand immediate and careful consideration the amount of money annually exact through the operation of present law from the industry and necessity of the people largely exceed the sum necessary to meet the expense of the government when we consider that the theory of our institution guarantee to every citizen the full enjoyment of all the fruit of his industry and enterprise with only such deduction as may be his share toward the careful and economical maintenance of the government which protect he it be plain that the exaction of more than this be indefensible extortion and a culpable betrayal of american fairness and justice this wrong inflict upon those who bear the burden of national taxation like other wrong multiplie a brood of evil consequence the public treasury which should only exist as a conduit convey the people 's tribute to its legitimate object of expenditure become a hoarding place for money needlessly withdraw from trade and the people 's use thus cripple our national energy suspend our country 's development prevent investment in productive enterprise threaten financial disturbance and invite scheme of public plunder this condition of our treasury be not altogether new and it have more than once of late be submit to the people 's representative in the congress who alone can apply a remedy and yet the situation still continue with aggravate incident more than ever presage financial convulsion and widespread disaster it will not do to neglect this situation because its danger be not now palpably imminent and apparent they exist none the less certainly and await the unforeseen and unexpected occasion when suddenly they will be precipitate upon we on the 30th day of june 1885 the excess of revenue over public expenditure after comply with the annual requirement of the sink fund act be $ 17,859,735.84 during the year end june 30 1886 such excess amount to $ 49,405,545.20 and during the year end june 30 1887 it reach the sum of $ 55,567,849.54.the annual contribution to the sink fund during the three year above specify amount in the aggregate to $ 138,058,320.94 and deduct from the surplus as state be make by call in for that purpose outstanding 3 per cent bond of the government during the six month prior to june 30 1887 the surplus revenue have grow so large by repeat accumulation and it be fear the withdrawal of this great sum of money need by the people would so affect the business of the country that the sum of $ 79,864,100 of such surplus be apply to the payment of the principal and interest of the 3 per cent bond still outstanding and which be then payable at the option of the government the precarious condition of financial affair among the people still need relief immediately after the 30th day of june 1887 the remainder of the 3 per cent bond then outstanding amount with principal and interest to the sum of $ 18,877,500 be call in and apply to the sink fund contribution for the current fiscal year notwithstanding these operation of the treasury department representation of distress in business circle not only continue but increase and absolute peril seem at hand in these circumstance the contribution to the sink fund for the current fiscal year be at once complete by the expenditure of $ 27,684,283.55 in the purchase of government bond not yet due bear 4 and 41/2 per cent interest the premium pay thereon average about 24 per cent for the former and 8 per cent for the latter in addition to this the interest accrue during the current year upon the outstanding bond indebtedness of the government be to some extent anticipate and bank select as depository of public money be permit to somewhat increase their deposit while the expedient thus employ to release to the people the money lie idle in the treasury serve to avert immediate danger our surplus revenue have continue to accumulate the excess for the present year amount on the 1st day of december to $ 55,258,701.19 and estimate to reach the sum of $ 113,000,000 on the 30th of june next at which date it be expect that this sum add to prior accumulation will swell the surplus in the treasury to $ 140,000,000.there seem to be no assurance that with such a withdrawal from use of the people 's circulate medium our business community may not in the near future be subject to the same distress which be quite lately produce from the same cause and while the function of our national treasury should be few and simple and while its good condition would be reach i believe by its entire disconnection with private business interest yet when by a perversion of its purpose it idly hold money uselessly subtract from the channel of trade there seem to be reason for the claim that some legitimate mean should be devise by the government to restore in an emergency without waste or extravagance such money to its place among the people if such an emergency arise there now exist no clear and undoubted executive power of relief heretofore the redemption of 3 per cent bond which be payable at the option of the government have afford a mean for the disbursement of the excess of our revenue but these bond have all be retire and there be no bond outstanding the payment of which we have a right to insist upon the contribution to the sink fund which furnish the occasion for expenditure in the purchase of bond have be already make for the current year so that there be no outlet in that direction in the present state of legislation the only pretense of any exist executive power to restore at this time any part of our surplus revenue to the people by its expenditure consist in the supposition that the secretary of the treasury may enter the market and purchase the bond of the government not yet due at a rate of premium to be agree upon the only provision of law from which such a power could be derive be find in an appropriation bill pass a number of year ago and it be subject to the suspicion that it be intend as temporary and limited in its application instead of confer a continue discretion and authority no condition ought to exist which would justify the grant of power to a single official upon his judgment of its necessity to withhold from or release to the business of the people in an unusual manner money hold in the treasury and thus affect at his will the financial situation of the country and if it be deem wise to lodge in the secretary of the treasury the authority in the present juncture to purchase bond it should be plainly vest and provide as far as possible with such check and limitation as will define this official 's right and discretion and at the same time relieve he from undue responsibility in consider the question of purchase bond as a means of restore to circulation the surplus money accumulate in the treasury it should be bear in mind that premium must of course be pay upon such purchase that there may be a large part of these bond hold as investment which can not be purchase at any price and that combination among holder who be willing to sell may unreasonably enhance the cost of such bond to the government it have be suggest that the present bond debt might be refund at a less rate of interest and the difference between the old and new security pay in cash thus find use for the surplus in the treasury the success of this plan it be apparent must depend upon the volition of the holder of the present bond and it be not entirely certain that the inducement which must be offer they would result in more financial benefit to the government than the purchase of bond while the latter proposition would reduce the principal of the debt by actual payment instead of extend it the proposition to deposit the money hold by the government in bank throughout the country for use by the people be it seem to i exceedingly objectionable in principle as establish too close a relationship between the operation of the government treasury and the business of the country and too extensive a commingling of their money thus foster an unnatural reliance in private business upon public fund if this scheme should be adopt it should only be do as a temporary expedient to meet an urgent necessity legislative and executive effort should generally be in the opposite direction and should have a tendency to divorce as much and as fast as can be safely do the treasury department from private enterprise of course it be not expect that unnecessary and extravagant appropriation will be make for the purpose of avoid the accumulation of an excess of revenue such expenditure besides the demoralization of all just conception of public duty which it entail stimulate a habit of reckless improvidence not in the least consistent with the mission of our people or the high and beneficent purpose of our government i have deem it my duty to thus bring to the knowledge of my countryman as well as to the attention of their representative charge with the responsibility of legislative relief the gravity of our financial situation the failure of the congress heretofore to provide against the danger which it be quite evident the very nature of the difficulty must necessarily produce cause a condition of financial distress and apprehension since your last adjournment which tax to the utmost all the authority and expedient within executive control and these appear now to be exhaust if disaster result from the continued inaction of congress the responsibility must rest where it belong though the situation thus far consider be fraught with danger which should be fully realize and though it present feature of wrong to the people as well as peril to the country it be but a result grow out of a perfectly palpable and apparent cause constantly reproduce the same alarming circumstance a congested national treasury and a deplete monetary condition in the business of the country it need hardly be state that while the present situation demand a remedy we can only be save from a like predicament in the future by the removal of its cause our scheme of taxation by mean of which this needless surplus be take from the people and put into the public treasury consist of a tariff or duty levy upon importation from abroad and internal revenue taxis levy upon the consumption of tobacco and spirituous and malt liquor it must be concede that none of the thing subject to internal revenue taxation be strictly speak necessary there appear to be no just complaint of this taxation by the consumer of these article and there seem to be nothing so well able to bear the burden without hardship to any portion of the people but our present tariff law the vicious inequitable and illogical source of unnecessary taxation ought to be at once revise and amend these law as their primary and plain effect raise the price to consumer of all article import and subject to duty by precisely the sum pay for such duty thus the amount of the duty measure the tax pay by those who purchase for use these import article many of these thing however be raise or manufacture in our own country and the duty now levy upon foreign good and product be call protection to these home manufacture because they render it possible for those of our people who be manufacturer to make these tax article and sell they for a price equal to that demand for the import good that have pay custom duty so it happen that while comparatively a few use the import article million of our people who never use and never see any of the foreign product purchase and use thing of the same kind make in this country and pay therefor nearly or quite the same enhance price which the duty add to the import article those who buy import pay the duty charge thereon into the public treasury but the great majority of our citizen who buy domestic article of the same class pay a sum at least approximately equal to this duty to the home manufacturer this reference to the operation of our tariff law be not make by way of instruction but in order that we may be constantly remind of the manner in which they impose a burden upon those who consume domestic product as well as those who consume import article and thus create a tax upon all our people it be not propose to entirely relieve the country of this taxation it must be extensively continue as the source of the government 's income and in a readjustment of our tariff the interest of american labor engage in manufacture should be carefully consider as well as the preservation of our manufacturer it may be call protection or by any other name but relief from the hardship and danger of our present tariff law should be devise with especial precaution against imperil the existence of our manufacturing interest but this existence should not mean a condition which without regard to the public welfare or a national exigency must always insure the realization of immense profit instead of moderately profitable return as the volume and diversity of our national activity increase new recruit be add to those who desire a continuation of the advantage which they conceive the present system of tariff taxation directly afford they so stubbornly have all effort to reform the present condition be resist by those of our fellow citizen thus engage that they can hardly complain of the suspicion entertain to a certain extent that there exist an organize combination all along the line to maintain their advantage we be in the midst of centennial celebration and with become pride we rejoice in american skill and ingenuity in american energy and enterprise and in the wonderful natural advantage and resource develop by a century 's national growth yet when an attempt be make to justify a scheme which permit a tax to be lay upon every consumer in the land for the benefit of our manufacturer quite beyond a reasonable demand for governmental regard it suit the purpose of advocacy to call our manufacture infant industry still need the high and great degree of favor and foster care that can be wring from federal legislation it be also say that the increase in the price of domestic manufacture result from the present tariff be necessary in order that high wage may be pay to our workingman employ in manufactory than be pay for what be call the pauper labor of europe all will acknowledge the force of an argument which involve the welfare and liberal compensation of our labor people our labor be honorable in the eye of every american citizen and as it lie at the foundation of our development and progress it be entitle without affectation or hypocrisy to the utmost regard the standard of our laborer life should not be measure by that of any other country less favor and they be entitle to their full share of all our advantage by the last census it be make to appear that of the 17,392,099 of our population engage in all kind of industry 7,670,493 be employ in agriculture 4,074,238 in professional and personal service 2,934,876 of whom be domestic servant and laborer while 1,810,256 be employ in trade and transportation and 3,837,112 be class as employ in manufacturing and mining for present purpose however the last number give should be considerably reduce without attempt to enumerate all it will be concede that there should be deduct from those which it include 375,143 carpenter and joiner 285,401 milliner dressmaker and seamstress 172,726 blacksmith 133,756 tailor and tailoresse 102,473 mason 76,241 butcher 41,309 baker 22,083 plasterer and 4,891 engage in manufacture agricultural implement amount in the aggregate to 1,214,023 leave 2,623,089 person employ in such manufacturing industry as be claim to be benefit by a high tariff to these the appeal be make to save their employment and maintain their wage by resist a change there should be no disposition to answer such suggestion by the allegation that they be in a minority among those who labor and therefore should forego an advantage in the interest of low price for the majority their compensation as it may be affect by the operation of tariff law should at all time be scrupulously keep in view and yet with slight reflection they will not overlook the fact that they be consumer with the rest that they too have their own want and those of their family to supply from their earning and that the price of the necessary of life as well as the amount of their wage will regulate the measure of their welfare and comfort but the reduction of taxation demand should be so measure as not to necessitate or justify either the loss of employment by the workingman or the lessening of his wage and the profit still remain to the manufacturer after a necessary readjustment should furnish no excuse for the sacrifice of the interest of his employee either in their opportunity to work or in the diminution of their compensation nor can the worker in manufacture fail to understand that while a high tariff be claim to be necessary to allow the payment of remunerative wage it certainly result in a very large increase in the price of nearly all sort of manufacture which in almost countless form he need for the use of himself and his family he receive at the desk of his employer his wage and perhaps before he reach his home be oblige in a purchase for family use of an article which embrace his own labor to return in the payment of the increase in price which the tariff permit the hard earn compensation of many day of toil the farmer and the agriculturist who manufacture nothing but who pay the increase price which the tariff impose upon every agricultural implement upon all he wear and upon all he use and own except the increase of his flock and herd and such thing as his husbandry produce from the soil be invite to aid in maintain the present situation and he be tell that a high duty on import wool be necessary for the benefit of those who have sheep to shear in order that the price of their wool may be increase they of course be not remind that the farmer who have no sheep be by this scheme oblige in his purchase of clothing and woolen good to pay a tribute to his fellow farmer as well as to the manufacturer and merchant nor be any mention make of the fact that the sheep owner themselves and their household must wear clothing and use other article manufacture from the wool they sell at tariff price and thus as consumer must return their share of this increase price to the tradesman i think it may be fairly assume that a large proportion of the sheep own by the farmer throughout the country be find in small flock number from twenty five to fifty the duty on the grade of import wool which these sheep yield be 10 cent each pound if of the value of 30 cent or less and 12 cent if of the value of more than 30 cent if the liberal estimate of 6 pound be allow for each fleece the duty thereon would be 60 or 72 cent and this may be take as the utmost enhancement of its price to the farmer by reason of this duty eighteen dollar would thus represent the increase price of the wool from twenty five sheep and $ 36 that from the wool of fifty sheep and at present value this addition would amount to about one third of its price if upon its sale the farmer receive this or a less tariff profit the wool leave his hand charge with precisely that sum which in all its change will adhere to it until it reach the consumer when manufacture into cloth and other good and material for use its cost be not only increase to the extent of the farmer 's tariff profit but a further sum have be add for the benefit of the manufacturer under the operation of other tariff law in the meantime the day arrive when the farmer find it necessary to purchase woolen good and material to clothe himself and family for the winter when he face the tradesman for that purpose he discover that he be oblige not only to return in the way of increase price his tariff profit on the wool he sell and which then perhaps lie before he in manufactured form but that he must add a considerable sum thereto to meet a further increase in cost cause by a tariff duty on the manufacture thus in the end he be arouse to the fact that he have pay upon a moderate purchase as a result of the tariff scheme which when he sell his wool seem so profitable an increase in price more than sufficient to sweep away all the tariff profit he receive upon the wool he produce and sell when the number of farmer engage in wool raising be compare with all the farmer in the country and the small proportion they bear to our population be consider when it be make apparent that in the case of a large part of those who own sheep the benefit of the present tariff on wool be illusory and above all when it must be concede that the increase of the cost of living cause by such tariff become a burden upon those with moderate mean and the poor the employed and unemployed the sick and well and the young and old and that it constitute a tax which with relentless grasp be fasten upon the clothing of every man woman and child in the land reason be suggest why the removal or reduction of this duty should be include in a revision of our tariff law in speaking of the increase cost to the consumer of our home manufacture result from a duty lay upon import article of the same description the fact be not ever look that competition among our domestic producer sometimes have the effect of keep the price of their product below the high limit allow by such duty but it be notorious that this competition be too often strangle by combination quite prevalent at this time and frequently call trust which have for their object the regulation of the supply and price of commodity make and sell by member of the combination the people can hardly hope for any consideration in the operation of these selfish scheme if however in the absence of such combination a healthy and free competition reduce the price of any particular dutiable article of home production below the limit which it might otherwise reach under our tariff law and if with such reduce price its manufacture continue to thrive it be entirely evident that one thing have be discover which should be carefully scrutinize in an effort to reduce taxation the necessity of combination to maintain the price of any commodity to the tariff point furnish proof that someone be willing to accept low price for such commodity and that such price be remunerative and low price produce by competition prove the same thing thus where either of these condition exist a case would seem to be present for an easy reduction of taxation the consideration which have be present touch our tariff law be intend only to enforce an earnest recommendation that the surplus revenue of the government be prevent by the reduction of our custom duty and at the same time to emphasize a suggestion that in accomplish this purpose we may discharge a double duty to our people by grant to they a measure of relief from tariff taxation in quarter where it be most need and from source where it can be most fairly and justly accord nor can the presentation make of such consideration be with any degree of fairness regard as evidence of unfriendliness toward our manufacturing interest or of any lack of appreciation of their value and importance these interest constitute a lead and most substantial element of our national greatness and furnish the proud proof of our country 's progress but if in the emergency that press upon we our manufacturer be ask to surrender something for the public good and to avert disaster their patriotism as well as a grateful recognition of advantage already afford should lead they to willing cooperation no demand be make that they shall forego all the benefit of governmental regard but they can not fail to be admonish of their duty as well as their enlighten self interest and safety when they be remind of the fact that financial panic and collapse to which the present condition tend afford no great shelter or protection to our manufacture than to other important enterprise opportunity for safe careful and deliberate reform be now offer and none of we should be unmindful of a time when an abused and irritated people heedless of those who have resist timely and reasonable relief may insist upon a radical and sweeping rectification of their wrong the difficulty attend a wise and fair revision of our tariff law be not underestimate it will require on the part of the congress great labor and care and especially a broad and national contemplation of the subject and a patriotic disregard of such local and selfish claim as be unreasonable and reckless of the welfare of the entire country under our present law more than 4,000 article be subject to duty many of these do not in any way compete with our own manufacture and many be hardly worth attention as subject of revenue a considerable reduction can be make in the aggregate by add they to the free list the taxation of luxury present no feature of hardship but the necessary of life use and consume by all the people the duty upon which add to the cost of live in every home should be greatly cheapen the radical reduction of the duty impose upon raw material use in manufacture or its free importation be of course an important factor in any effort to reduce the price of these necessary it would not only relieve they from the increase cost cause by the tariff on such material but the manufactured product be thus cheapen that part of the tariff now lay upon such product as a compensation to our manufacturer for the present price of raw material could be accordingly modify such reduction or free importation would serve besides to largely reduce the revenue it be not apparent how such a change can have any injurious effect upon our manufacturer on the contrary it would appear to give they a well chance in foreign market with the manufacturer of other country who cheapen their ware by free material thus our people might have the opportunity of extend their sale beyond the limit of home consumption save they from the depression interruption in business and loss cause by a glut domestic market and afford their employee more certain and steady labor with its result quiet and contentment the question thus imperatively present for solution should be approach in a spirit high than partisanship and consider in the light of that regard for patriotic duty which should characterize the action of those intrust with the weal of a confide people but the obligation to declare
