effort to control legislation and improperly influence the suffrage of the people the grievance of those not include within the circle of these beneficiary when fully realize will surely arouse irritation and discontent our farmer long suffering and patient struggle in the race of life with the hard and most unremitting toil will not fail to see in spite of misrepresentation and mislead fallacy that they be oblige to accept such price for their product as be fix in foreign market where they compete with the farmer of the world that their land be decline in value while their debt increase and that without compensate favor they be force by the action of the government to pay for the benefit of other such enhanced price for the thing they need that the scanty return of their cheapen the cost of necessary for themselves and their family when to the selfishness of the beneficiary of unjust discrimination under our law there shall be add the discontent of those who suffer free institution be not less dangerous than the communism of oppressed poverty and toil which exasperate by injustice and discontent attack with wild disorder the citadel of rule he mock the people by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 a hundred year have pass since the government which our fore father found be formally organize at noon on the 30th day of april 1789 in the city of new york and in the presence of an assemblage of the heroic man whose patriotic devotion have lead the colony to victory and independence george washington take the oath of office as chief magistrate of the new bear republic this impressive act be precede at 9 o&#39;clock in the morning in all the church of the city by prayer for god&#39;s blessing on the government and its first president
 the centennial of this illustrious event in our history have be declare a general holiday by act of congress to the end that the people of the whole country may join in commemorative exercise appropriate to the day
 in order that the joy of the occasion may be associate with a deep thankfulness in the mind of the people for all our blessing in the past and a devout supplication to god for their gracious continuance in the future the representative of the religious creed both christian and hebrew have memorialize the government to designate an hour for prayer and thanksgive on that day
 now therefore i benjamin harrison president of the united states of america in response to this pious and reasonable request do recommend that on tuesday april 30 at the hour of 9 o&#39;clock in the morning the people of the entire country repair to their respective place of divine worship to implore the favor of god that the blessing of liberty prosperity and peace may abide with we as a people and that his hand may lead we in the path of righteousness and good deed
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states of america to be affix
 do in the city of washington this 4th day of april a. d. 1889 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and thirteenth
 benj harrison
 by the president
 james g. blaine
 secretary of state

my fellow citizens
 everyone here to day be distressingly conscious of the circumstance which have convene this meeting it would be wholly superfluous for i to attempt to set before you more impressively than the newspaper have already do the horror attend the calamity which have fall upon the city of johnstown and the neighbor hamlet in a large section of pennsylvania situate on the susquehanna river the grim pencil of dor&eacute would be inadequate to portray the distress and horror of this visitation in such meeting as we have to day here in the national capital and other like gathering that be take place in all the city of this land we have the only relief to the distress and darkness of the picture when such calamitous visitation fall upon any section of our country we can only put about the dark picture the golden border of love and charity it be in such fire as this that the brotherhood of man be weld and where more appropriately than here at the national capital can we give expression to that sympathy and brotherhood which be now so strongly appeal to by the distress of large body of our fellow citizen
 i be glad to say that early this morning from a city not long ago visit with pestilence and not long ago appeal to the charity of the philanthropic people of the whole land for relief the city of jacksonville f1a.-there come the reflex the ebb of that tide of charity which flow toward they in a telegram from the chairman of the relief association of that city authorize i to draw upon they for $ 2,000 for the relief of the sufferer at johnstown
 but this be no time for speech while i talk man and woman and child be suffer for the relief which we plan to give to day
 a word or two of practical suggestion and i will place this meeting in the hand of those who have assemble here to give effect to our love purpose i have to day have a dispatch from the governor of pennsylvania advise i that communication have just be open with williamsport on a branch of the susquehanna river and that the loss in that section have be appalling that thousand of people there be hungry and homeless and penniless and there be immediate urgency for food to relieve their necessity and he advise i that any supply of food that can be hastily gather here should be send direct to williamsport where they will be distribute i suggest therefore and the occasion be such that bell might be ring in your street to call the attention of the thoughtless to this great exigency that a committee should be appoint to speedily collect contribution of food in order that a train load with provision might be dispatch to night or in the early morning to these sufferer
 i suggest secondly that as many of these people have have the entire furniture of their house sweep away and have now only a temporary shelter that a committee be appoint to collect from your citizen such article of clothing especially bedclothe as can be spare and now that the summer season be on there can hardly be many household in washington that can not spare a blanket or a coverlid for the relief of the suffer one
 i suggest thirdly that of your substantial business people banker and other there be appoint a committee who shall collect money for after the first exigency have pass there will be find in those community very many who have lose their all who will need aid in the reconstruction of their demolish home and in furnish they in order that they may be again inhabit
 need i say in conclusion that as a temporary citizen of washington it would give i great satisfaction if the national capital should so generously respond to this call of our distressed fellow citizen as to be conspicuous among the city of the land for its ample and generous answer
 i feel as i be call for subscription that i should say that on saturday on be first apprise of the need at johnstown i telegraph to the mayor of that city my subscription i do not care now or at any time to speak of anything that be so personal as this but i feel it due to you as i be place here to day to solicit and urge other to give that i should say so much as that

 the question which have arise during the past few year between great britain and the united states be in abeyance or in course of amicable adjustment

 question affect american interest in connection with railway construct and operate by our citizen in peru have claim the attention of this government it be urge that other government in press peru to the payment of their claim have disregard the property right of american citizen the matter will be carefully investigate with a view to secure a proper and equitable adjustment

 within our own border a general condition of prosperity prevail the harvest of the last summer be exceptionally abundant and the trade condition now prevail seem to promise a successful season to the merchant and the manufacturer and general employment to our work people
 the report of the secretary of the treasury for the fiscal year end june 30 1889 have be prepare and will be present to congress it present with clearness the fiscal operation of the government and i avail myself of it to obtain some fact for use here
 the aggregate receipt from all source for the year be $ 387,050,058.84 derive as follow
 from custom $ 223 832 741.69
 from internal revenue 130,881,513.92
 from miscellaneous source 32,335,803.23
 the ordinary expenditure for the same period be $ 281,996,615.60 and the total expenditure include the sink fund be $ 329,579,929.25 the excess of receipt over expenditure be after provide for the sink fund $ 57,470,129.59
 for the current fiscal year the total revenue actual and estimated be $ 385,000,000 and the ordinary expenditure actual and estimate be $ 293,000,000 make with the sink fund a total expenditure of $ 341,321,116.99 leave an estimate surplus of $ 43,678,883.01
 during the fiscal year there be apply to the purchase of bond in addition to those for the sink fund $ 90,456,172.35 and during the first quarter of the current year the sum of $ 37,838,937.77 all of which be credit to the sink fund the revenue for the fiscal year end june 30 1891 be estimate by the treasury department at $ 385,000,000 and the expenditure for the same period include the sink fund at $ 341,430,477.70 this show an estimate surplus for that year of $ 43,569,522.30 which be more likely to be increase than reduce when the actual transaction be write up
 the existence of so large an actual and anticipated surplus should have the immediate attention of congress with a view to reduce the receipt of the treasury to the need of the government as closely as may be the collection of money not need for public use impose an unnecessary burden upon our people and the presence of so large a surplus in the public vault be a disturbing element in the conduct of private business it have call into use expedient for put it into circulation of very questionable propriety we should not collect revenue for the purpose of anticipate our bond beyond the requirement of the sink fund but any unappropriated surplus in the treasury should be so used as there be no other lawful way of return the money to circulation and the profit realize by the government offer a substantial advantage
 the loaning of public fund to the bank without interest upon the security of government bond i regard as an unauthorized and dangerous expedient it result in a temporary and unnatural increase of the banking capital of favor locality and compel a cautious and gradual recall of the deposit to avoid injury to the commercial interest it be not to be expect that the bank have these deposit will sell their bond to the treasury so long as the present highly beneficial arrangement be continue they now practically get interest both upon the bond and their proceed no further use should be make of this method of get the surplus into circulation and the deposit now outstanding should be gradually withdraw and apply to the purchase of bond it be fortunate that such a use can be make of the exist surplus and for some time to come of any casual surplus that may exist after congress have take the necessary step for a reduction of the revenue such legislation should be promptly but very considerately enact
 i recommend a revision of our tariff law both in its administrative feature and in the schedule the need of the former be generally concede and an agreement upon the evil and inconvenience to be remedie and the good method for their correction will probably not be difficult uniformity of valuation at all our port be essential and effective measure should be take to secure it it be equally desirable that question affect rate and classification should be promptly decide
 the preparation of a new schedule of custom duty be a matter of great delicacy because of its direct effect upon the business of the country and of great difficulty by reason of the wide divergence of opinion as to the object that may properly be promote by such legislation some disturbance of business may perhaps result from the consideration of this subject by congress but this temporary ill effect will be reduce to the minimum by prompt action and by the assurance which the country already enjoy that any necessary change will be so make as not to impair the just and reasonable protection of our home industry the inequality of the law should be adjust but the protective principle should be maintain and fairly apply to the product of our farm as well as of our shop these duty necessarily have relation to other thing besides the public revenue we can not limit their effect by fix our eye on the public treasury alone they have a direct relation to home production to work to wage and to the commercial independence of our country and the wise and patriotic legislator should enlarge the field of his vision to include all of these the necessary reduction in our public revenue can i be sure be make without make the small burden more onerous than the large by reason of the disability and limitation which the process of reduction put upon both capital and labor the free list can very safely be extend by place thereon article that do not offer injurious competition to such domestic product as our home labor can supply the removal of the internal tax upon tobacco would relieve an important agricultural product from a burden which be impose only because our revenue from custom duty be insufficient for the public need if safe provision against fraud can be devise the removal of the tax upon spirit use in the art and in manufacture would also offer an unobjectionable method of reduce the surplus
 a table present by the secretary of the treasury show the amount of money of all kind in circulation each year from 1878 to the present time be of interest it appear that the amount of national bank note in circulation have decrease during that period $ 114,109,729 of which $ 37,799,229 be chargeable to the last year the withdrawal of bank circulation will necessarily continue under exist condition it be probable that the adoption of the suggestion make by the comptroller of the currency namely that the minimum deposit of bond for the establishment of bank be reduce and that an issue of note to the par value of the bond be allow would help to maintain the bank circulation but while this withdrawal of bank note have be go on there have be a large increase in the amount of gold and silver coin in circulation and in the issue of gold and silver certificate
 the total amount of money of all kind in circulation on march 1 1878 be $ 805,793,807 while on october 1 1889 the total be $ 1,405,018,000 there be an increase of $ 293,417,552 in gold coin of $ 57,554,100 in standard silver dollar of $ 72,311,249 in gold certificate of $ 276,619,715 in silver certificate and of $ 14,073,787 in united states note make a total of $ 713,976,403 there be during the same period a decrease of $ 114,109,729 in bank circulation and of $ 642,481 in subsidiary silver the net increase be $ 599,224,193 the circulation per capita have increase about $ 5 during the time cover by the table refer to
 the total coinage of silver dollar be on november 1 1889 $ 343,638,001 of which $ 283,539,521 be in the treasury vault and $ 60,098,480 be in circulation of the amount in the vault $ 277,319,944 be represent by outstanding silver certificate leave $ 6,219,577 not in circulation and not represent by certificate
 the law require the purchase by the treasury of $ 2,000,000 worth of silver bullion each month to be coin into silver dollar of 412 1/2 grain have be observe by the department but neither the present secretary nor any of his predecessor have deem it safe to exercise the discretion give by law to increase the monthly purchase to $ 4,000,000 when the law be enact february 28 1878 the price of silver in the market be $ 1.204 per ounce make the bullion value of the dollar 93 cent since that time the price have fall as low as 91.2 cent per ounce reduce the bullion value of the dollar to 70.6 cent within the last few month the market price have somewhat advanced and on the 1st day of november last the bullion value of the silver dollar be 72 cent
 the evil anticipation which have accompany the coinage and use of the silver dollar have not be realize as a coin it have not have general use and the public treasury have be compel to store it but this be manifestly owe to the fact that its paper representative be more convenient the general acceptance and the use of the silver certificate show that silver have not be otherwise discredit some favorable condition have contribute to maintain this practical equality in their commercial use between the gold and silver dollar but some of these be trade condition that statutory enactment do not control and of the continuance of which we can not be certain
 i think it be clear that if we should make the coinage of silver at the present ratio free we must expect that the difference in the bullion value of the gold and silver dollar will be take account of in commercial transaction and i fear the same result would follow any considerable increase of the present rate of coinage such a result would be discreditable to our financial management and disastrous to all business interest we should not tread the dangerous edge of such a peril and indeed nothing more harmful could happen to the silver interest any safe legislation upon this subject must secure the equality of the two coin in their commercial use
 i have always be an advocate of the use of silver in our currency we be large producer of that metal and should not discredit it to the plan which will be present by the secretary of the treasury for the issuance of note or certificate upon the deposit of silver bullion at its market value i have be able to give only a hasty examination owe to the press of other matter and to the fact that it have be so recently formulate the detail of such a law require careful consideration but the general plan suggest by he seem to satisfy the purpose to continue the use of silver in connection with our currency and at the same time to obviate the danger of which i have speak at a late day i may communicate far with congress upon this subject
 the enforcement of the chinese exclusion act have be find to be very difficult on the northwestern frontier chinaman land at victoria find it easy to pass our border owe to the impossibility with the force at the command of the custom officer of guard so long an inland line the secretary of the treasury have authorize the employment of additional officer who will be assign to this duty and every effort will be make to enforce the law the dominion exact a head tax of $ 50 for each chinaman land and when these person in fraud of our law cross into our territory and be apprehend our officer do not know what to do with they as the dominion authority will not suffer they to be send back without a second payment of the tax an effort will be make to reach an understanding that will remove this difficulty
 the proclamation require by section 3 of the act of march 2 1889 relate to the killing of seal and other fur bear animal be issue by i on the 21st day of march and a revenue vessel be dispatch to enforce the law and protect the interest of the united states the establishment of a refuge station at point barrow as direct by congress be successfully accomplish
 judge by modern standard we be practically without coast defense many of the structure we have would enhance rather than diminish the peril of their garrison if subject to the fire of improved gun and very few be so locate as to give full effect to the great range of such gun as we be now make for coast defense use this general subject have have consideration in congress for some year and the appropriation for the construction of large rifle gun make one year ago be i be sure the expression of a purpose to provide suitable work in which these gun might be mount an appropriation now make for that purpose would not advance the completion of the work beyond our ability to supply they with fairly effective gun
 the security of our coast city against foreign attack should not rest altogether in the friendly disposition of other nation there should be a second line wholly in our own keeping i very urgently recommend an appropriation at this session for the construction of such work in our most expose harbor
 i approve the suggestion of the secretary of war that provision be make for encamp company of the national guard in our coast work for a specify time each year and for their training in the use of heavy gun his suggestion that an increase of the artillery force of the army be desirable be also in this connection commend to the consideration of congress
 the improvement of our important river and harbor should be promote by the necessary appropriation care should be take that the government be not commit to the prosecution of work not of public and general advantage and that the relative usefulness of work of that class be not overlook so far as this work can ever be say to be complete i do not doubt that the end would be soon and more economically reach if few separate work be undertake at the same time and those select for their great general interest be more rapidly push to completion a work once considerably begin should not be subject to the risk and deterioration which interrupt or insufficient appropriation necessarily occasion
 the assault make by david s. terry upon the person of justice field of the supreme court of the united states at lathtop cal in august last and the killing of the assailant by a deputy united states marshal who have be depute to accompany justice field and to protect he from anticipated violence at the hand of terry in connection with the legal proceeding which have follow suggest question which in my judgment be worthy of the attention of congress
 i recommend that more definite provision be make by law not only for the protection of federal officer but for a full trial of such case in the united states court in recommend such legislation i do not at all impeach either the general adequacy of the provision make by the state law for the protection of all citizen or the general good disposition of those charge with the execution of such law to give protection to the officer of the united states the duty of protect its officer as such and of punish those who assault they on account of their official act should not be devolve expressly or by acquiescence upon the local authority
 event which have be bring to my attention happen in other part of the country have also suggest the propriety of extend by legislation full protection to those who may be call as witness in the court of the united states the law compel those who be suppose to have knowledge of public offense to attend upon our court and grand jury and to give evidence there be a manifest result duty that these witness shall be protect from injury on account of their testimony the investigation of criminal offense be often render futile and the punishment of crime impossible by the intimidation of witness
 the necessity of provide some more speedy method for dispose of the case which now come for final adjudication to the supreme court become every year more apparent and urgent the plan of provide some intermediate court have final appellate jurisdiction of certain class of question and case have i think receive a more general approval from the bench and bar of the country than any other without attempt to discuss detail i recommend that provision be make for the establishment of such court
 the salary of the judge of the district court in many of the district be in my judgment inadequate i recommend that all such salary now below $ 5,000 per annum be increase to that amount it be quite true that the amount of labor perform by these judge be very unequal but as they can not properly engage in other pursuit to supplement their income the salary should be such in all case as to provide an independent and comfortable support
 earnest attention should be give by congress to a consideration of the question how far the restraint of those combination of capital commonly call trust be matter of federal jurisdiction when organize as they often be to crush out all healthy competition and to monopolize the production or sale of an article of commerce and general necessity they be dangerous conspiracy against the public good and should be make the subject of prohibitory and even penal legislation
 the subject of an international copyright have be frequently commend to the attention of congress by my predecessor the enactment of such a law would be eminently wise and just
 our naturalization law should be so revise as to make the inquiry into the moral character and good disposition toward our government of the person apply for citizenship more thorough this can only be do by take full control of the examination by fix the time for hear such application and by require the presence of some one who shall represent the government in the inquiry those who be the avow enemy of social order or who come to our shore to swell the injurious influence and to extend the evil practice of any association that defy our law should not only be deny citizenship but a domicile
 the enactment of a national bankrupt law of a character to be a permanent part of our general legislation be desirable it should be simple in its method and inexpensive in its administration
 the report of the postmaster general not only exhibit the operation of the department for the last fiscal year but contain many valuable suggestion for the improvement and extension of the service which be commend to your attention no other branch of the government have so close a contact with the daily life of the people almost everyone use the service it offer and every hour gain in the transmission of the great commercial mail have an actual and possible value that only those engage in trade can understand
 the saving of one day in the transmission of the mail between new york and san francisco which have recently be accomplish be an incident worthy of mention

 the report of the secretary of the navy show a reorganization of the bureaus of the department that will i do not doubt promote the efficiency of each
 in general satisfactory progress have be make in the construction of the new ship of war authorize by congress the first vessel of the new navy the dolphin be subject to very severe trial test and to very much adverse criticism but it be gratify to be able to state that a cruise around the world from which she have recently return have demonstrate that she be a first class vessel of her rate
 the report of the secretary show that while the effective force of the navy be rapidly increase by reason of the improve build and armament of the new ship the number of our ship fit for sea duty grow very slowly we have on the 4th of march last 37 serviceable ship and though 4 have since be add to the list the total have not be increase because in the meantime 4 have be lose or condemn twenty six additional vessel have be authorize and appropriate for but it be probable that when they be complete our list will only be increase to 42 -a gain of 5 the old wooden ship be disappear almost as fast as the new vessel be add these fact carry their own argument one of the new ship may in fighting strength be equal to two of the old but it can not do the cruise duty of two it be important therefore that we should have a more rapid increase in the number of serviceable ship i concur in the recommendation of the secretary that the construction of 8 armored ship 3 gunboat and 5 torpedo boat be authorize
 an appalling calamity befell three of our naval vessel on duty at the samoan islands in the harbor of apia in march last involve the loss of 4 officer and 47 seaman of two vessel the trenton and the vandalia and the disabling of a third the nipsic three vessel of the german navy also in the harbor share with our ship the force of the hurricane and suffer even more heavily while mourn the brave officer and man who died face with high resolve peril great than those of battle it be most gratifying to state that the credit of the american navy for seamanship courage and generosity be magnificently sustain in the storm beat harbor of apia
 the report of the secretary of the interior exhibit the transaction of the government with the indian tribe substantial progress have be make in the education of the child of school age and in the allotment of land to adult indians it be to be regret that the policy of break up the tribal relation and of deal with the indian as an individual do not appear early in our legislation large reservation hold in common and the maintenance of the authority of the chief and headman have deprive the individual of every incentive to the exercise of thrift and the annuity have contribute an affirmative impulse toward a state of confirm pauperism
 our treaty stipulation should be observe with fidelity and our legislation should be highly considerate of the good interest of an ignorant and helpless people the reservation be now generally surround by white settlement we can no long push the indian back into the wilderness and it remain only by every suitable agency to push he upward into the estate of a self support and responsible citizen for the adult the first step be to locate he upon a farm and for the child to place he in a school
 school attendance should be promote by every moral agency and those fail should be compel the national school for indians have be very successful and should be multiply and as far as possible should be so organized and conduct as to facilitate the transfer of the school to the states or territories in which they be locate when the indians in a neighborhood have accept citizenship and have become otherwise fit for such a transfer this condition of thing will be attain slowly but it will be hasten by keep it in mind and in the meantime that cooperation between the government and the mission school which have work much good should be cordially and impartially maintain
 the last congress enact two distinct law relate to negotiation with the sioux indians of dakota for a relinquishment of a portion of their land to the united states and for divide the remainder into separate reservation both be approve on the same day march 2 the one submit to the indians a specific proposition the other section 3 of the indian appropriation act authorize the president to appoint three commissioner to negotiate with these indians for the accomplishment of the same general purpose and require that any agreement make should be submit to congress for ratification
 on the 16th day of april last i appoint hon charles foster of ohio hon william warner of missouri and major general george crook of the united states army commissioner under the last name law they be however authorize and direct first to submit to the indians the definite proposition make to they by the act first mention and only in the event of a failure to secure the assent of the requisite number to that proposition to open negotiation for modify term under the other act the work of the commission be prolonged and arduous but the assent of the requisite number be it be understand finally obtain to the proposition make by congress though the report of the commission have not yet be submit in view of these fact i shall not as at present advise deem it necessary to submit the agreement to congress for ratification but it will in due course be submit for information this agreement release to the united states about 9,000,000 acre of land
 the commission provide for by section 14 of the indian appropriation bill to negotiate with the cherokee indians and all other indians own or claim land lie west of the ninety sixth degree of longitude for the cession to the united states of all such land be constitute by the appointment of hon lucius fairchild of wisconsin hon john f. hartranft of pennsylvania and hon alfred m. wilson of arkansas and organize on june 29 last their first conference with the representative of the cherokees be hold at tahlequah july 29 with no definite result general john f. hartranft of pennsylvania be prevent by ill health from take part in the conference his death which occur recently be justly and generally lament by a people he have serve with conspicuous gallantry in war and with great fidelity in peace the vacancy thus create be fill by the appointment of hon warren g. sayre of indiana
 a second conference between the commission and the cherokees be begin november 6 but no result have yet be obtain nor be it believe that a conclusion can be immediately expect the cattle syndicate now occupy the land for graze purpose be clearly one of the agency responsible for the obstruction of our negotiation with the cherokees the large body of agricultural land constitute what be know as the cherokee outlet ought not to be and indeed can not long be hold for graze and for the advantage of a few against the public interest and the good advantage of the indians themselves the united states have now under the treaty certain right in these land these will not be use oppressively but it can not be allow that those who by sufferance occupy these land shall interpose to defeat the wise and beneficent purpose of the government i can not but believe that the advantageous character of the offer make by the united states to the cherokee nation for a full release of these land as compare with other suggestion now make to they will yet obtain for it a favorable consideration
 under the agreement make between the united states and the muscogee or creek nation of indians on the 19th day of january 1889 an absolute title be secure by the united states to about 3,500,000 acre of land section 12 of the general indian appropriation act approve march 2 1889 make provision for the purchase by the united states from the seminole tribe of a certain portion of their land the delegate of the seminole nation having first duly evidence to i their power to act in that behalf deliver a proper release or conveyance to the united states of all the land mention in the act which be accept by i and certify to be in compliance with the statute
 by the term of both the act refer to all the land so purchase be declare to be a part of the public domain and open to settlement under the homestead law but of the land embrace in these purchase be in the aggregate about 5,500,000 acre 3,500,000 acre have already under the term of the treaty of 1866 be acquire by the united states for the purpose of settle other indian tribe thereon and have be appropriate to that purpose the land remain and available for settlement consist of 1,887,796 acre surround on all side by land in the occupancy of indian tribe congress have provide no civil government for the people who be to be invite by my proclamation to settle upon these land except as the new court which have be establish at muscogee or the united states court in some of the adjoining states have power to enforce the general law of the united states
 in this condition of thing i be quite reluctant to open the land to settlement but in view of the fact that several thousand person many of they with their family have gather upon the border of the indian territory with a view to secure homestead on the ceded land and that delay would involve they in much loss and suffering i do on the 23d day of march last issue a proclamation declare that the land therein describe would be open to settlement under the provision of the law on the 22d day of april follow at 12 o&#39;clock noon two land district have be establish and the office be open for the transaction of business when the appoint time arrive
 it be much to the credit of the settler that they very generally observe the limitation as to the time when they might enter the territory care will be take that those who enter in violation of the law do not secure the advantage they unfairly seek there be a good deal of apprehension that the strife for location would result in much violence and bloodshed but happily these anticipation be not realize it be estimate that there be now in the territory about 60,000 people and several considerable town have spring up for which temporary municipal government have be organize guthrie be say to have now a population of almost 8,000 eleven school and nine church have be establish and three daily and five weekly newspaper be publish in this city whose charter and ordinance have only the sanction of the voluntary acquiescence of the people from day to day
 oklahoma city have a population of about 5,000 and be proportionately as well provide as guthrie with church school and newspaper other town and village have population of from 100 to 1,000 be scatter over the territory
 in order to secure the peace of this new community in the absence of civil government i direct general merritt command the department of the missouri to act in conjunction with the marshal of the united states to preserve the peace and upon their requisition to use the troop to aid they in execute warrant and in quiet any riot or breach of the peace that might occur he be far direct to use his influence to promote good order and to avoid any conflict between or with the settler believe that the introduction and sale of liquor where no legal restraint or regulation exist would endanger the public peace and in view of the fact that such liquor must first be introduce into the indian reservation before reach the white settlement i far direct the general commanding to enforce the law relate to the introduction of ardent spirit into the indian country
 the presence of the troop have give a sense of security to the well dispose citizen and have tend to restrain the lawless in one instance the officer in immediate command of the troop go far than i deem justifiable in support the de facto municipal government of guthrie and he be so informed and direct to limit the interference of the military to the support of the marshal on the line indicate in the original order i very urgently recommend that congress at once provide a territorial government for these people serious question which may at any time lead to violent outbreak be await the institution of court for their peaceful adjustment the american genius for self government have be well illustrate in oklahoma but it be neither safe nor wise to leave these people long to the expedient which have temporarily serve they
 provision should be make for the acquisition of title to town lot in the town now establish in alaska for locate town site and for the establishment of municipal government only the mining law have be extend to that territory and no other form of title to land can now be obtain the general land law be frame with reference to the disposition of agricultural land and it be doubtful if their operation in alaska would be beneficial
 we have fortunately not extend to alaska the mistaken policy of establish reservation for the indian tribe and can deal with they from the beginning as individual with i be sure well result but any disposition of the public land and any regulation relate to timber and to the fishery should have a kindly regard to their interest have no power to levy taxis the people of alaska be wholly dependent upon the general government to whose revenue the seal fishery make a large annual contribution an appropriation for education should neither be overlook nor stint
 the smallness of the population and the great distance between the settlement offer serious obstacle to the establishment of the usual territorial form of government perhaps the organization of several sub district with a small municipal council of limited power for each would be safe and useful
 attention be call in this connection to the suggestion of the secretary of the treasury relate to the establishment of another port of entry in alaska and of other need custom facility and regulation
 in the administration of the land law the policy of facilitate in every proper way the adjustment of the honest claim of individual settler upon the public land have be pursue the number of pende case have during the precede administration be greatly increase under the operation of order for a time suspend final action in a large part of the case originate in the west and northwest and by the subsequent use of unusual method of examination only those who be familiar with the condition under which our agricultural land have be settle can appreciate the serious and often fatal consequence to the settler of a policy that put his title under suspicion or delay the issuance of his patent while care be take to prevent and to expose fraud it should not be impute without reason
 the manifest purpose of the homestead and preemption law be to promote the settlement of the public domain by person have a bona fide intent to make a home upon the select land where this intent be well establish and the requirement of the law have be substantially comply with the claimant be entitle to a prompt and friendly consideration of his case but where there be reason to believe that the claimant be the mere agent of another who be seek to evade a law intend to promote small holding and to secure by fraudulent method large tract of timber and other land both principal and agent should not only be thwart in their fraudulent purpose but should be make to feel the full penalty of our criminal statute the law should be so administer as not to confound these two class and to visit penalty only upon the latter
 the unsettled state of the title to large body of land in the territories of new mexico and arizona have greatly retard the development of those territories provision should be make by law for the prompt trial and final adjustment before a judicial tribunal or commission of all claim base upon mexican grant it be not just to an intelligent and enterprise people that their peace should be disturb and their prosperity retard by these old contention i express the hope that difference of opinion as to method may yield to the urgency of the case
 the law now provide a pension for every soldier and sailor who be muster into the service of the united states during the civil war and be now suffer from wound or disease have an origin in the service and in the line of duty two of the three necessary fact viz muster and disability be usually susceptible of easy proof but the third origin in the service be often difficult and in many deserving case impossible to establish that very many of those who endure the hardship of our most bloody and arduous campaign be now disabled from disease that have a real but not traceable origin in the service i do not doubt besides these there be another class compose of man many of whom serve an enlistment of three full year and of reenliste veteran who add a fourth year of service who escape the casualty of battle and the assault of disease who be always ready for any detail who be in every battle line of their command and be muster out in sound health and have since the close of the war while fight with the same indomitable and independent spirit the contest of civil life be overcome by disease or casualty
 i be not unaware that the pension roll already involve a very large annual expenditure neither be i deter by that fact from recommend that congress grant a pension to such honorably discharge soldier and sailor of the civil war as having render substantial service during the war be now dependent upon their own labor for a maintenance and by disease or casualty be incapacitate from earn it many of the man who would be include in this form of relief be now dependent upon public aid and it do not in my judgment consist with the national honor that they shall continue to subsist upon the local relief give indiscriminately to pauper instead of upon the special and generous provision of the nation they serve so gallantly and unselfishly our people will i be sure very generally approve such legislation and i be equally sure that the survivor of the union army and navy will feel a grateful sense of relief when this worthy and suffer class of their comrade be fairly care for
 there be some manifest inequality in the exist law that should be remedie to some of these the secretary of the interior have call attention
 it be gratify to be able to state that by the adoption of new and well method in the war department the call of the pension office for information as to the military and hospital record of pension claimant be now promptly answer and the injurious and vexatious delay that have heretofore occur be entirely avoid this will greatly facilitate the adjustment of all pende claim
 the advent of four new states south dakota north dakota montana and washington into the union under the constitution in the same month and the admission of their duly choose representative to our national congress at the same session be an event as unexampled as it be interesting
 the certification of the vote cast and of the constitution adopt in each of the states be file with i as require by the eighth section of the act of february 22 1889 by the governor of say territories respectively have after a careful examination find that the several constitution and government be republican in form and not repugnant to the constitution of the united states that all the provision of the act of congress have be comply with and that a majority of the vote cast in each of say propose states be in favor of the adoption of the constitution submit therein i do so declare by a separate proclamation as to each as to north dakota and south dakota on saturday november 2 as to montana on friday november 8 and as to washington on monday november 11
 each of these states have within it resource the development of which will employ the energy of and yield a comfortable subsistence to a great population the small of these new states washington stand twelfth and the large montana third among the forty two in area the people of these states be already well train intelligent and patriotic american citizen have common interest and sympathy with those of the old states and a common purpose to defend the integrity and uphold the honor of the nation
 the attention of the interstate commerce commission have be call to the urgent need of congressional legislation for the well protection of the life and limb of those engage in operate the great interstate freight line of the country and especially of the yardman and brakeman a petition sign by nearly 10,000 railway brakeman be present to the commission ask that step might be take to bring about the use of automatic brake and coupler on freight car
 at a meeting of state railroad commissioner and their accredited representative hold at washington in march last upon the invitation of the interstate commerce commission a resolution be unanimously adopt urge the commission to consider what can be do to prevent the loss of life and limb in couple and uncouple freight car and in handle the brake of such car during the year end june 30 1888 over 2,000 railroad employee be kill in service and more than 20,000 injure it be competent i think for congress to require uniformity in the construction of car use in interstate commerce and the use of improved safety appliance upon such train time will be necessary to make the need change but an earnest and intelligent beginning should be make at once it be a reproach to our civilization that any class of american workman should in the pursuit of a necessary and useful vocation be subject to a peril of life and limb as great as that of a soldier in time of war
 the creation of an executive department to be know as the department of agriculture by the act of february 9 last be a wise and timely response to a request which have long be respectfully urge by the farmer of the country but much remain to be do to perfect the organization of the department so that it may fairly realize the expectation which its creation excite in this connection attention be call to the suggestion contain in the report of the secretary which be herewith submit the need of a law officer for the department such as be provide for the other executive departments be manif the failure of the last congress to make the usual provision for the publication of the annual report should be promptly remedie the public interest in the report and its value to the farming community i be sure will not be diminish under the new organization of the department
 i recommend that the weather service be separate from the war department and establish as a bureau in the department of agriculture this will involve an entire reorganization both of the weather bureau and of the signal corps make of the first a purely civil organization and of the other a purely military staff corps the report of the chief signal officer show that the work of the corps on its military side have be deteriorate
 the interest of the people of the district of columbia should not be lose sight of in the pressure for consideration of measure affect the whole country have no legislature of its own either municipal or general its people must look to congress for the regulation of all those concern that in the states be the subject of local control our whole people have an interest that the national capital should be make attractive and beautiful and above all that its repute for social order should be well maintain the law regulate the sale of intoxicate drink in the district should be revise with a view to bring the traffic under stringent limitation and control
 in execution of the power confer upon i by the act make appropriation for the expense of the district of columbia for the year end june 30 1890 i do on the 17th day of august last appoint rudolph hering of new york samuel m. gray of rhode island and frederick p. stearns of massachusetts three eminent sanitary engineer to examine and report upon the system of sewerage exist in the district of columbia their report which be not yet complete will be in due course submit to congress
 the report of the commissioners of the district be herewith transmit and the attention of congress be call to the suggestion contain therein
 the proposition to observe the four hundredth anniversary of the discovery of america by the opening of a world&#39;s fair or exposition in some one of our great city will be present for the consideration of congress the value and interest of such an exposition may well claim the promotion of the general government
 on the 4th of march last the civil service commission have but a single member the vacancy be fill on the 7th day of may and since then the commissioners have be industriously though with an inadequate force engage in execute the law they be assure by i that a cordial support would be give they in the faithful and impartial enforcement of the statute and of the rule and regulation adopt in aid of it
 heretofore the book of eligible have be close to everyone except as certification be make upon the requisition of the appoint officer this secrecy be the source of much suspicion and of many charge of favoritism in the administration of the law what be secret be always suspect what be open can be judge the commission with the full approval of all its member have now open the list of eligible to the public the eligible list for the classified post office and custom house be now publicly post in the respective office as be also the certification for appointment the purpose of the civil service law be absolutely to exclude any other consideration in connection with appointment under it than that of merit as test by the examination the business proceed upon the theory that both the examine board and the appoint officer be absolutely ignorant as to the political view and association of all person on the civil service list it be not too much to say however that some recent congressional investigation have somewhat shake public confidence in the impartiality of the selection for appointment
 the reform of the civil service will make no safe or satisfactory advance until the present law and its equal administration be well establish in the confidence of the people it will be my pleasure as it be my duty to see that the law be execute with firmness and impartiality if some of its provision have be fraudulently evade by appoint officer our resentment should not suggest the repeal of the law but reform in its administration we should have one view of the matter and hold it with a sincerity that be not affect by the consideration that the party to which we belong be for the time in power
 my predecessor on the 4th day of january 1889 by an executive order to take effect march 15 bring the railway mail service under the operation of the civil service law provision be make that the order should take effect soon in any state where an eligible list be soon obtain on the 11th day of march mr. lyman then the only member of the commission report to i in write that it would not be possible to have the list of eligible ready before may 1 and request that the take effect of the order be postpone until that time which be do subject to the same provision contain in the original order as to states in which an eligible list be soon obtain
 as a result of the revision of the rule of the new classification and of the inclusion of the railway mail service the work of the commission have be greatly increase and the present clerical force be find to be inadequate i recommend that the additional clerk ask by the commission be appropriate for
 the duty of appointment be devolve by the constitution or by the law and the appoint officer be properly hold to a high responsibility in its exercise the growth of the country and the consequent increase of the civil list have magnify this function of the executive disproportionally it can not be deny however that the labor connect with this necessary work be increase often to the point of actual distress by the sudden and excessive demand that be make upon an incoming administration for removal and appointment but on the other hand it be not true that incumbency be a conclusive argument for continuance in office impartiality moderation fidelity to public duty and a good attainment in the discharge of it must be add before the argument be complete when those hold administrative office so conduct themselves as to convince just political opponent that no party consideration or bias affect in any way the discharge of their public duty we can more easily stay the demand for removal
 i be satisfied that both in and out of the classified service great benefit would accrue from the adoption of some system by which the officer would receive the distinction and benefit that in all private employment come from exceptional faithfulness and efficiency in the performance of duty
 i have suggest to the head of the executive departments that they consider whether a record might not be keep in each bureau of all those element that be cover by the term faithfulness and efficiency and a rating make show the relative merit of the clerk of each class this rating to be regard as a test of merit in make promotion
 i have also suggest to the postmaster general that he adopt some plan by which he can upon the basis of the report to the department and of frequent inspection indicate the relative merit of postmaster of each class they will be appropriately indicate in the official register and in the report of the department that a great stimulus would thus be give to the whole service i do not doubt and such a record would be the good defense against inconsiderate removal from office
 the interest of the general government in the education of the people find an early expression not only in the thoughtful and sometimes warn utterance of our able statesman but in liberal appropriation from the common resource for the support of education in the new states no one will deny that it be of the grave national concern that those who hold the ultimate control of all public affair should have the necessary intelligence wisely to direct and determine they national aid to education have heretofore take the form of land grant and in that form the constitutional power of congress to promote the education of the people be not seriously question i do not think it can be successfully question when the form be change to that of a direct grant of money from the public treasury
 such aid should be as it always have be suggest by some exceptional condition the sudden emancipation of the slave of the south the bestowal of the suffrage which soon follow and the impairment of the ability of the states where these new citizen be chiefly find to adequately provide educational facility present not only exceptional but unexampled condition that the situation have be much ameliorate there be no doubt the ability and interest of the states have happily increase
 but a great work remain to be do and i think the general government should lend its aid as the suggestion of a national grant in aid of education grow chiefly out of the condition and need of the emancipate slave and his descendant the relief should as far as possible while necessarily proceed upon some general line be apply to the need that suggest it it be essential if much good be to be accomplish that the sympathy and active interest of the people of the states should be enlist and that the method adopt should be such as to stimulate and not to supplant local taxation for school purpose
 as one congress can not bind a succeed one in such a case and as the effort must in some degree be experimental i recommend that any appropriation make for this purpose be so limited in annual amount and as to the time over which it be to extend as will on the one hand give the local school authority opportunity to make the good use of the first year&#39;s allowance and on the other deliver they from the temptation to unduly postpone the assumption of the whole burden themselves
 the colored people do not intrude themselves upon we they be bring here in chain and hold in the community where they be now chiefly find by a cruel slave code happily for both race they be now free they have from a standpoint of ignorance and poverty which be our shame not theirs make remarkable advance in education and in the acquisition of property they have as a people show themselves to be friendly and faithful toward the white race under temptation of tremendous strength they have their representative in the national cemetery where a grateful government have gather the ashe of those who die in its defense they have furnish to our regular army regiment that have win high praise from their command officer for courage and soldierly quality and for fidelity to the enlistment oath in civil life they be now the toiler of their community make their full contribution to the widen stream of prosperity which these community be receive their sudden withdrawal would stop production and bring disorder into the household as well as the shop generally they do not desire to quit their home and their employer resent the interference of the emigration agent who seek to stimulate such a desire
 but notwithstanding all this in many part of our country where the colored population be large the people of that race be by various device deprive of any effective exercise of their political right and of many of their civil right the wrong do not expend itself upon those whose vote be suppress every constituency in the union be wrong
 it have be the hope of every patriot that a sense of justice and of respect for the law would work a gradual cure of these flagrant evil surely no one suppose that the present can be accept as a permanent condition if it be say that these community must work out this problem for themselves we have a right to ask whether they be at work upon it do they suggest any solution when and under what condition be the black man to have a free ballot when be he in fact to have those full civil right which have so long be his in law when be that equality of influence which our form of government be intend to secure to the elector to be restore this generation should courageously face these grave question and not leave they as a heritage of woe to the next the consultation should proceed with candor calmness and great patience upon the line of justice and humanity not of prejudice and cruelty no question in our country can be at rest except upon the firm base of justice and of the law
 i earnestly invoke the attention of congress to the consideration of such measure within its well define constitutional power as will secure to all our people a free exercise of the right of suffrage and every other civil right under the constitution and law of the united states no evil however deplorable can justify the assumption either on the part of the executive or of congress of power not grant but both will be highly blamable if all the power grant be not wisely but firmly use to correct these evil the power to take the whole direction and control of the election of member of the house of representatives be clearly give to the general government a partial and qualified supervision of these election be now provide for by law and in my opinion this law may be so strengthen and extend as to secure on the whole well result than can be attain by a law take all the process of such election into federal control the colored man should be protect in all of his relation to the federal government whether as litigant juror or witness in our court as an elector for member of congress or as a peaceful traveler upon our interstate railway
 there be nothing more justly humiliating to the national pride and nothing more hurtful to the national prosperity than the inferiority of our merchant marine compare with that of other nation whose general resource wealth and seacoast line do not suggest any reason for their supremacy on the sea it be not always so and our people be agree i think that it shall not continue to be so it be not possible in this communication to discuss the cause of the decay of our shipping interest or the differ method by which it be propose to restore they the statement of a few well authenticate fact and some general suggestion as to legislation be all that be practicable that the great steamship line sail under the flag of england france germany spain and italy and engage in foreign commerce be .promote and have since be and now be liberally aid by grant of public money in one form or another be generally know that the american line of steamship have be abandon by we to an unequal contest with the aid line of other nation until they have be withdraw or in the few case where they be still maintain be subject to serious disadvantage be matter of common knowledge
 the present situation be such that traveler and merchandise find liverpool often a necessary intermediate port between new york and some of the south american capital the fact that some of the delegate from south american states to the conference of american nation now in session at washington reach our shore by reverse that line of travel be very conclusive of the need of such a conference and very suggestive as to the first and most necessary step in the direction of full and more beneficial intercourse with nation that be now our neighbor upon the line of latitude but not upon the line of establish commercial intercourse
 i recommend that such appropriation be make for ocean mail service in american steamship between our port and those of central and south america china japan and the important island in both of the great ocean as will be liberally remunerative for the service render and as will encourage the establishment and in some fair degree equalize the chance of american steamship line in the competition which they must meet that the american states lie south of we will cordially cooperate in establish and maintain such line of steamship to their principal port i do not doubt
 we should also make provision for a naval reserve to consist of such merchant ship of american construction and of a specified tonnage and speed as the owner will consent to place at the use of the government in case of need as armed cruiser england have adopt this policy and as a result can now upon necessity at once place upon her naval list some of the fast steamship in the world a proper supervision of the construction of such vessel would make their conversion into effective ship of war very easy
 i be an advocate of economy in our national expenditure but it be a misuse of term to make this word describe a policy that withhold an expenditure for the purpose of extend our foreign commerce the enlargement and improvement of our merchant marine the development of a sufficient body of train american seaman the promotion of rapid and regular mail communication between the port of other country and our own and the adaptation of large and swift american merchant steamship to naval use in time of war be public purpose of the high concern the enlarged participation of our people in the carrying trade the new and increase market that will be open for the product of our farm and factory and the full and well employment of our mechanic which will result from a liberal promotion of our foreign commerce insure the wide possible diffusion of benefit to all the states and to all our people everything be most propitious for the present inauguration of a liberal and progressive policy upon this subject and we should enter upon it with promptness and decision
 the legislation which i have suggest it be sincerely believe will promote the peace and honor of our country and the prosperity and security of the people i invoke the diligent and serious attention of congress to the consideration of these and such other measure as may be present have the same great end in view

gentleman
 i find in this parting call of the delegate of the conference of american states both pain and pleasure i participate in the regret which the delegate from the united states feel who be to part with those from other country i take pleasure in the knowledge of the fact that your labor have be bring to a happy conclusion the difference of opinion have be happily reconcile i remark with pleasure the proposition which will be productive of peace among the american states represent in the conference it will be without excuse if one of they shall lift a hostile hand against the other we give you the other day a review of the small detachment of the american army not to show you that we have an army but that we have none that our security be lodge with our people and that they be safe
 we rejoice that you have find in the organization of our country something which commend itself to your own we shall be glad to receive new lesson in return in conclusion i find much to approve in the friendly purpose of the conference toward this government and i bid each and every one of you a heartfelt good bye

mr. chairman and fellow citizen
 i thank you most sincerely for this cordial greeting but i shall not be betray by it into a lengthy speech the selection of this day for these exercise a day consecrate to the memory of those who die that there might be one flag of honor and authority in this republic be most fitting that one flag encircle we with its fold to day the unrivaled object of our loyal love
 this monument so impose and tasteful fittingly typify the grand and symmetrical character of he in whose honor it have be build his be the arduous greatness of thing do no friendly hand construct and place for his ambition a ladder upon which he might climb his own brave hand frame and nail the cleat upon which he climb to the height of public usefulness and fame he never cease to be student and instructor turn from peaceful pursuit to army service he quickly master tactic and strategy and in a brief army career teach some valuable lesson in military science turn again from the field to the council of the state he stand among the great debater that have make our national congress illustrious what he might have be or do as president of the united states be chiefly leave to friendly augury base upon a career that have no incident of failure or inadequacy the cruel circumstance attend his death have but one amelioration that space of life be give he to teach from his die bed a great lesson of patience and forbearance his mortal part will find honorable rest here but the lesson of his life and death will continue to be instructive and inspiring incident in american history

to the senate and house of representatives
 i transmit herewith for your information a letter from the secretary of state inclose a report of the international american conference which recommend that reciprocal commercial treaty be enter into between the united states and the several other republics of this hemisphere
 it have be so often and so persistently state that our tariff law offer an insurmountable barrier to a large exchange of product with the latin american nation that i deem it proper to call especial attention to the fact that more than 87 per cent of the product of those nation send to our port be now admit free if sugar be place upon the free list practically every important article export from those states will be give untaxe access to our market except wool the real difficulty in the way of negotiate profitable reciprocity treaty be that we have give freely so much that would have have value in the mutual concession which such treaty imply i can not doubt however that the present advantage which the product of these near and friendly states enjoy in our market though they be not by law exclusive will with other consideration favorably dispose they to adopt such measure by treaty or otherwise as will tend to equalize and greatly enlarge our mutual exchange
 it will certainly be time enough for we to consider whether we must cheapen the cost of production by cheapen labor in order to gain access to the south american market when we have fairly try the effect of established and reliable steam communication and of convenient method of money exchange there can be no doubt i think that with these facility well establish and with a rebate of duty upon import raw material use in the manufacture of good for export our merchant will be able to compete in the port of the latin american nation with those of any other country
 if after the congress shall have act upon pende tariff legislation it shall appear that under the general treaty make power or under any special power give by law our trade with the states represent in the conference can be enlarge upon a basis of mutual advantage it will be promptly do


by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas it be provide in the act of congress entitle an act to extend the northern boundary of the state of nebraska approve march 28 1882
 that the northern boundary of the state of nebraska shall be and hereby be subject to the provision hereinafter contain extend so as to include all that portion of the territory of dakota lie south of the forty third parallel of north latitude and east of the keya paha river and west of the main channel of the missouri river and when the indian title to the land thus describe shall be extinguish the jurisdiction over say land shall be and hereby be cede to the state of nebraska and subject to all the condition and limitation provide in the act of congress admit nebraska into the union and the northern boundary of the state shall be extend to say forty third parallel as fully and effectually as if say land have be include in the boundary of say state at the time of its admission to the union reserve to the united states the original right of soil in say land and of dispose of the same provide that this act so far as jurisdiction be concern shall not take effect until the president shall by proclamation declare that the indian title to say land have be extinguish nor shall it take effect until the state of nebraska shall have assent to the provision of this act and if the state of nebraska shall not by an act of its legislature consent to the provision of this act within two year next after the passage hereof this act shall cease and be of no effect
 and whereas by section 13 of the act entitle an act to divide a portion of the reservation of the sioux nation of indians in dakota into separate reservation and to secure the relinquishment of the indian title to the remainder and for other purpose approve march 2 1889 it be provided--
 that when the allotment to the ponca tribe of indians and to such other indians as allotment be provide for by this act shall have be make upon that portion of say reservation which be describe in the act entitle an act to extend the northern boundary of the state of nebraska approve march 28 1882 the president shall in pursuance of say act declare that the indian title be extinguish to all land describe in say act not so allotted hereunder and thereupon all of say land not so allotted and include in say act of march 28 1882 shall be open to settlement as provide in this act provide that the allotment to ponca and other indians authorize by this act to be make upon the land describe in the said act entitle an act to extend the northern boundary of the state of nebraska shall be make within six month from the time this act shall take effect
 and whereas the state of nebraska by an act of its legislature approve may 23 1882 entitle an act declare the assent of the state of nebraska to an act of congress of the united states entitle 39;an act to extend the northern boundary of the state of nebraska,&#39 approve march 28 1882 assent to and accept the provision of say act of congress approve march 28 1882 and
 whereas allotment have be make to the ponca tribe of indians under and in accordance with the provision of say section 13 of the act of march 2 1889 and no other indians having select or apply for allotment upon that portion of the reservation of the sioux nation of indians describe in the act of march 28 1882 aforesaid and the six months&#39 limit of time within which say allotment be authorize to be make having expire on the 10th day of august 1890
 now therefore i benjamin harrison president of the united states by virtue of the power in i vest by the act section 13 of march 2 1889 aforesaid and in pursuance of the act of march 28 1882 aforesaid do hereby declare that the indian title be extinguish to all land describe in say act of march 28 1882 not allot to the ponca tribe of indians as aforesaid and show upon a schedule in duplicate of allotment make and certify jointly by george p. litchfield united states special agent and james e. helms united states indian agent july 31 1890 and approve by the acting commissioner of indian affairs october 14 1890 and by the acting secretary of the interior october 22 1890 one copy of which schedule of allotment be now on file in the office of the commissioner of indian affairs and the other in the office of the commissioner of the general land office department of the interior
 be it know however that there be hereby reserve from entry or settlement that tract of land now occupy by the agency and school building of the old ponca agency to wit the south half of the southeast quarter of section 26 and the south half of the southwest quarter of section 25 all in township 32 north range 7 west of the sixth principal meridian
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 23d day of october a.d. 1890 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and fifteenth
 benj harrison
 by the president
 alvey a. adee acting secretary of state

to the senate and house of representatives the report of the several executive departments which will be lay before congress in the usual course will exhibit in detail the operation of the government for the last fiscal year only the more important incident and result and chiefly such as may be the foundation of the recommendation i shall submit will be refer to in this annual message the vast and increase business of the government have be transact by the several departments during the year with faithfulness energy and success the revenue amount to above $ 450,000,000 have be collect and disburse without reveal so far as i can ascertain a single case of defalcation or embezzlement an earnest effort have be make to stimulate a sense of responsibility and public duty in all officer and employee of every grade and the work do by they have almost wholly escape unfavorable criticism i speak of these matter with freedom because the credit of this good work be not mine but be share by the head of the several departments with the great body of faithful officer and employee who serve under they the close scrutiny of congress be invite to all the method of administration and to every item of expenditure the friendly relation of our country with the nation of europe and of the east have be undisturbed while the tie of good will and common interest that bind we to the states of the western hemisphere have be notably strengthen by the conference hold in this capital to consider measure for the general welfare pursuant to the invitation authorize by congress the representative of every independent state of the american continent and of hayti meet in conference in this capital in october 1889 and continue in session until the 19th of last april this important convocation mark a most interesting and influential epoch in the history of the western hemisphere it be noteworthy that brazil invite while under an imperial form of government share as a republic in the deliberation and result of the conference the recommendation of this conference be all transmit to congress at the last session the international marine conference which sit at washington last winter reach a very gratifying result the regulation suggest have be bring to the attention of all the government represent and their general adoption be confidently expect the legislation of congress at the last session be in conformity with the proposition of the conference and the proclamation therein provide for will be issue when the other power have give notice of their adhesion the conference of brussels to devise mean for suppress the slave trade in africa afford an opportunity for a new expression of the interest the american people feel in that great work it soon become evident that the measure propose would tax the resource of the kongo basin beyond the revenue available under the general act of berlin of 1884 the united states not be a party to that act could not share in its revision but the bill that have come to we from foreign source may well be reject for repugnancy if these critic really believe that the adoption by we of a free trade policy or of tariff rate have reference
