hurt it be noticeably strange that they should lead the outcry against the author of a policy so helpful to their countryman and crown with their favor those who would snatch from they a substantial share of a trade with other land already inadequate to their necessity there be no disposition among any of our people to promote prohibitory or retaliatory legislation our policy be adopt not to the  the general trade and industrial condition throughout the country during the year have show a marked improvement for many year prior to 1888 the merchandise balance of foreign trade have be largely in our favor but during that year and the year follow they turn against we it be very gratifying to know that the last fiscal year again show a balance in our favor of over $ 68,000,000 the bank clearing which furnish a good test of the volume of business transact for the first ten month of the year 1890 show as compare with the same month of 1889 an increase for the whole country of about 8.4 per cent while the increase outside of the city of new york be over 13 per cent during the month of october the clearing of the whole country show an increase of 3.1 per cent over october 1889 while outside of new york the increase be 11.5 per cent these figure show that the increase in the volume of business be very general throughout the country that this large business be be conduct upon a safe and profitable basis be show by the fact that there be 300 less failure report in october 1890 than in the same month of the precede year with liability diminish by about $ 5,000,000

 the criticism of the bill that have come to we from foreign source may well be reject for repugnancy if these critic really believe that the adoption by we of a free trade policy or of tariff rate have reference solely to revenue would diminish the participation of their own country in the commerce of the world their advocacy and promotion by speech and other form of organized effort of this movement among our people be a rare exhibition of unselfishness in trade and on the other hand if they sincerely believe that the adoption of a protective tariff policy by this country inure to their profit and our hurt it be noticeably strange that they should lead the outcry against the author of a policy so helpful to their countryman and crown with their favor those who would snatch from they a substantial share of a trade with other land already inadequate to their necessity
 there be no disposition among any of our people to promote prohibitory or retaliatory legislation our policy be adopt not to the hurt of other but to secure for ourselves those advantage that fairly grow out of our favor position as a nation our form of government with its incident of universal suffrage make it imperative that we shall save our work people from the agitation and distress which scant work and wage that have no margin for comfort always beget but after all this be do it will be find that our market be open to friendly commercial exchange of enormous value to the other great power

 in many of the product of wood and iron and in meat and breadstuff we have advantage that only need well facility of intercourse and transportation to secure for they large foreign market the reciprocity clause of the tariff act wisely and effectively open the way to secure a large reciprocal trade in exchange for the free admission to our port of certain product the right of independent nation to make special reciprocal trade concession be well establish and do not impair either the comity due to other power or what be know as the favor nation clause so generally find in commercial treaty what be give to one for an adequate agree consideration can not be claim by another freely the state of the revenue be such that we could dispense with any import duty upon coffee tea hide and the low grade of sugar and molasse that the large advantage result to the country produce and export these article by place they on the free list entitle we to expect a fair return in the way of custom concession upon article export by we to they be so obvious that to have gratuitously abandon this opportunity to enlarge our trade would have be an unpardonable error
 there be but two method of maintain control of this question open to congress to place all of these article upon the dutiable list subject to such treaty agreement as could be secure or to place they all presently upon the free list but subject to the reimposition of specified duty if the country from which we receive they should refuse to give to we suitable reciprocal benefit this latter method i think possess great advantage it express in advance the consent of congress to reciprocity arrangement affect these product which must otherwise have be delay and unascertaine until each treaty be ratify by the senate and the necessary legislation enact by congress experience have show that some treaty look to reciprocal trade have fail to secure a two third vote in the senate for ratification and other having pass that stage have for year await the concurrence of the house and senate in such modification of our revenue law as be necessary to give effect to their provision we now have the concurrence of both houses in advance in a distinct and definite offer of free entry to our port of specific article the executive be not require to deal in conjecture as to what congress will accept indeed this reciprocity provision be more than an offer our part of the bargain be complete delivery have be make and when the country from which we receive sugar coffee tea and hide have place on their free list such of our product as shall be agree upon as an equivalent for our concession a proclamation of that fact complete the transaction and in the meantime our own people have free sugar tea coffee and hide

 it may still be possible for this congress to inaugurate by suitable legislation a movement look to uniformity and increase safety in the use of coupler and brake upon freight train engage in interstate commerce the chief difficulty in the way be to secure agreement as to the good appliance simplicity effectiveness and cost be consider this difficulty will only yield to legislation which should be base upon full inquiry and impartial test the purpose should be to secure the cooperation of all well dispose manager and owner but the fearful fact that every year&#39;s delay involve the sacrifice of 2,000 life and the maiming of 20,000 young man should plead both with congress and the manager against any needless delay
 the subject of the conservation and equal distribution of the water supply of the arid region have have much attention from congress but have not as yet be put upon a permanent and satisfactory basis the urgency of the subject do not grow out of any large present demand for the use of these land for agriculture but out of the danger that the water supply and the site for the necessary catch basin may fall into the hand of individual or private corporation and be use to render subservient the large area dependent upon such supply the owner of the water be the owner of the land however the title may run all unappropriated natural water source and all necessary reservoir site should be hold by the government for the equal use at fair rate of the homestead settler who will eventually take up these land the united states should not in my opinion undertake the construction of dam or canal but should limit its work to such survey and observation as will determine the water supply both surface and subterranean the area capable of irrigation and the location and storage capacity of reservoir this do the use of the water and of the reservoir site might be grant to the respective states or territories or to individual or association upon the condition that the necessary work should be construct and the water furnish at fair rate without discrimination the rate to be subject to supervision by the legislature or by board of water commissioner duly constitute the essential thing to be secure be the common and equal use at fair rate of the accumulate water supply it be almost well that these land should remain arid than that those who occupy they should become the slave of unrestrained monopoly control the one essential element of land value and crop result
 the use of the telegraph by the post office department as a means for the rapid transmission of write communication be i believe upon proper term quite desirable the government do not own or operate the railroad and it should not i think own or operate the telegraph line it do however seem to be quite practicable for the government to contract with the telegraph company as it do with railroad company to carry at specify rate such communication as the sender may designate for this method of transmission i recommend that such legislation be enact as will enable the post office department fairly to test by experiment the advantage of such a use of the telegraph
 if any intelligent and loyal company of american citizen be require to catalogue the essential human condition of national life i do not doubt that with absolute unanimity they would begin with free and honest election and it be gratify to know that generally there be a grow and nonpartisan demand for well election law but against this sign of hope and progress must be set the depressing and undeniable fact that election law and method be sometimes cunningly contrive to secure minority control while violence complete the shortcoming of fraud
 in my last annual message i suggest that the development of the exist law provide a federal supervision of congressional election offer an effective method of reform these abuse the need of such a law have manifest itself in many part of the country and its wholesome restraint and penalty will be useful in all the constitutionality of such legislation have be affirm by the supreme court its probable effectiveness be evidence by the character of the opposition that be make to it it have be denounce as if it be a new exercise of federal power and an invasion of the right of states nothing could be far from the truth congress have already fix the time for the election of member of congress it have declare that vote for member of congress must be by write or print ballot it have provide for the appointment by the circuit court in certain case and upon the petition of a certain number of citizen of election supervisor and make it their duty to supervise the registration of voter conduct by the state officer to challenge person offer to register to personally inspect and scrutinize the registry list and to affix their name to the list for the purpose of identification and the prevention of fraud to attend at election and remain with the box till they be all cast and count to attach to the registry list and election return any statement touch the accuracy and fairness of the registry and election and to take and transmit to the clerk of the house of representatives any evidence of fraudulent practice which may be present to they the same law provide for the appointment of deputy united states marshal to attend at the poll support the supervisor in the discharge of their duty and to arrest person violate the election law the provision of this familiar title of the revised statutes have be put into exercise by both the great political party and in the north as well as in the south by the filing with the court of the petition require by the law
 it be not therefore a question whether we shall have a federal election law for we now have one and have have for nearly twenty year but whether we shall have an effective law the present law stop just short of effectiveness for it surrender to the local authority all control over the certification which establish the prima facie right to a seat in the house of representatives this defect should be cure equality of representation and the parity of the elector must be maintain or everything that be valuable in our system of government be lose the qualification of an elector must be seek in the law net in the opinion prejudice or fear of any class however powerful the path of the elector to the ballot box must be free from the ambush of fear and the enticement of fraud the count so true and open that none shall gainsay it such a law should be absolutely nonpartisan and impartial it should give the advantage to honesty and the control to majority surely there be nothing sectional about this creed and if it shall happen that the penalty of law intend to enforce these right fall here and not there it be not because the law be sectional but because happily crime be local and not universal nor should it be forget that every law whether relate to election or to any other subject whether enact by the state or by the nation have force behind it the court the marshal or constable the posse comitatus the prison be all and always behind the law
 one can not be justly charge with unfriendliness to any section or class who seek only to restrain violation of law and of personal right no community will find lawlessness profitable no community can afford to have it know that the officer who be charge with the preservation of the public peace and the restraint of the criminal class be themselves the product of fraud or violence the magistrate be then without respect and the law without sanction the flood of lawlessness can not be leveed and make to run in one channel the killing of a united states marshal carry a writ of arrest for an election offense be full of prompt and suggestion to man who be pursue by a city marshal for a crime against life or property
 but it be say that this legislation will revive race animosity and some have even suggest that when the peaceful method of fraud be make impossible they may be supplant by intimidation and violence if the propose law give to any qualified elector by a hair&#39; weight more than his equal influence or detract by so much from any other qualified elector it be fatally impeach but if the law be equal and the animosity it be to evoke grow out of the fact that some elector have be accustom to exercise the franchise for other as well as for themselves then these animosity ought not to be confess without shame and can not be give any weight in the discussion without dishonor no choice be leave to i but to enforce with vigor all law intend to secure to the citizen his constitutional right and to recommend that the inadequacy of such law be promptly remedie if to promote with zeal and ready interest every project for the development of its material interest its river harbor mine and factory and the intelligence peace and security under the law of its community and its home be not accept as sufficient evidence of friendliness to any state or section i can not add connivance at election practice that not only disturb local result but rob the elector of other state and section of their most priceless political right
 the preparation of the general appropriation bill should be conduct with the great care and the close scrutiny of expenditure appropriation should be adequate to the need of the public service but they should be absolutely free from prodigality
 i venture again to remind you that the brief time remain for the consideration of the important legislation now await your attention offer no margin for waste if the present duty be discharge with diligence fidelity and courage the work of the fifty first congress may be confidently submit to the considerate judgment of the people
 benj harrison

to the senate and house of representatives
 the sudden death of the hon william windore secretary of the treasury in new york on the evening of the 29th instant have direct my attention to the present state of the law as to the filling of a vacancy occasion by the death of the head of a department
 i transmit herewith an opinion of the attorney general from which it will be see that under the statute in force no officer in the treasury department or other person designate by i can exercise the duty of secretary of the treasury for a long period than ten day this limitation be i be sure unwise and necessarily involve in such a case as that now present undue haste and even indelicacy the president should not be require to take up the question of the selection of a successor before the last office of affection and respect have be pay to the dead if the propriety of an occasion as sad as that which now overshadow we be observe possibly one half of the brief time allow be go before with due regard to the decency of life the president and those with whom he should advise can take up the consideration of the grave duty of select a head for one of the great departments of the government
 hasty action by the senate be also necessarily involve and geographical limitation be practically impose by the necessity of select someone who can reach the capital and take the necessary oath of office before the expiration of the ten day
 it may be a very proper restriction of the power of the president in this connection that he shall not designate for any great length of time a person to discharge these important duty who have not be confirm by the senate but there would seem to be no reason why one of the assistant secretary of the department wherein the vacancy exist might not discharge the duty of secretary until a successor be select confirm and qualify the inconvenience of this limitation be make apparent at the time of the death of secretary folger president arthur in that case allow one of the assistant secretary who have be designate to act in the absence of the secretary to continue in the discharge of such duty for ten day then designate the same person to discharge the duty for a further term of ten day and then make a temporary appointment as secretary in order to secure the consideration that he need in fill this important place
 i recommend such a modification of the exist law as will permit the first or sole assistant or in the case of the treasury department where the assistant be not grade that one who may be designate by the president to discharge the duty of the head of the department until a successor be appoint and qualified

to the senate and house of representatives
 the report of the head of the several executive departments require by law to be submit to i which be herewith transmit and the report of the secretary of the treasury and the attorney general make directly to congress furnish a comprehensive view of the administrative work of the last fiscal year relate to internal affair it would be of great advantage if these report could have an alternative perusal by every member of congress and by all who take an interest in public affair such a perusal could not fail to excite a high appreciation of the vast labor and conscientious effort which be give to the conduct of our civil administration
 the report will i believe show that every question have be approach consider and decide from the standpoint of public duty upon consideration affect the public interest alone again i invite to every branch of the service the attention and scrutiny of congress

 in view of the report which have be receive as to the diminution of the seal herd in the bering sea i deem it wise to propose to her majesty&#39;s government in february last that an agreement for a closed season should be make pende the negotiation for arbitration which then seem to be approach a favorable conclusion after much correspondence and delay for which this government be not responsible an agreement be reach and sign on the 15th of june by which great britain undertake from that date and until may 1 1892 to prohibit the killing by her subject of seal in the bering sea and the government of the united states during the same period to enforce its exist prohibition against pelagic sealing and to limit the catch by the fur seal company upon the island to 7,500 skin if this agreement could have be reach early in response to the strenuous endeavor of this government it would have be more effective but come even as late as it do it unquestionably result in greatly diminish the destruction of the seal by the canadian sealer
 in my last annual message i state that the basis of arbitration propose by her majesty&#39;s government for the adjustment of the long pende controversy as to the seal fishery be not acceptable i be glad now to be able to announce that term satisfactory to this government have be agree upon and that an agreement as to the arbitrator be all that be necessary to the completion of the convention in view of the advanced position which this government have take upon the subject of international arbitration this renew expression of our adherence to this method for the settlement of dispute such as have arise in the bering sea will i doubt not meet with the concurrence of congress
 provision should be make for a joint demarcation of the frontier line between canada and the united states wherever require by the increase border settlement and especially for the exact location of the water boundary in the strait and river

 the law of the last congress provide a system of inspection for our meat intend for export and clothe the president with power to exclude foreign product from our market in case the country send they should perpetuate unjust discrimination against any product of the united states place this government in a position to effectively urge the removal of such discrimination against our meat it be gratify to be able to state that germany denmark italy austria and france in the order name have open their port to inspect american pork product the removal of these restriction in every instance be ask for and give solely upon the ground that we have now provide a meat inspection that should be accept as adequate to the complete removal of the danger real or fancy which have be previously urge the state department our minister abroad and the secretary of agriculture have cooperate with unflagge and intelligent zeal for the accomplishment of this great result the outline of an agreement have be reach with germany look to equitable trade concession in consideration of the continue free importation of her sugar but the time have not yet arrive when this correspondence can be submit to congress
 the recent political disturbance in the republic of brazil have excite regret and solicitude the information we possess be too meager to enable we to form a satisfactory judgment of the cause lead to the temporary assumption of supreme power by president fonseca but this government do not fail to express to he its anxious solicitude for the peace of brazil and for the maintenance of the free political institution which have recently be establish there nor to offer our advice that great moderation should be observe in the clash of party and the contest for leadership these counsel be receive in the most friendly spirit and the late information be that constitutional government have be reestablish without bloodshed
 the lynching at new orleans in march last of eleven man of italian nativity by a mob of citizen be a most deplorable and discreditable incident it do not however have its origin in any general animosity to the italian people nor in any disrespect to the government of italy with which our relation be of the most friendly character the fury of the mob be direct against these man as the suppose participant or accessory in the murder of a city officer i do not allude to this as mitigate in any degree this offense against law and humanity but only as affect the international question which grow out of it it be at once represent by the italian minister that several of those whose life have be take by the mob be italian subject and a demand be make for the punishment of the participant and for an indemnity to the family of those who be kill it be to be regret that the manner in which these claim be present be not such as to promote a calm discussion of the question involve but this may well be attribute to the excitement and indignation which the crime naturally evoke the view of this government as to its obligation to foreigner domicile here be fully state in the correspondence as well as its purpose to make an investigation of the affair with a view to determine whether there be present any circumstance that could under such rule of duty as we have indicate create an obligation upon the united states the temporary absence of a minister plenipotentiary of italy at this capital have retard the further correspondence but it be not doubt that a friendly conclusion be attainable

 the civil war in chile which begin in january last be continue but fortunately with infrequent and not important armed collision until august 28 when the congressional force land near valparaiso and after a bloody engagement capture that city president balmaceda at once recognize that his cause be lose and a provisional government be speedily establish by the victorious party our minister be promptly direct to recognize and put himself in communication with this government so soon as it should have establish its de facto character which be do during the pendency of this civil contest frequent indirect appeal be make to this government to extend belligerent right to the insurgent and to give audience to their representative this be decline and that policy be pursue throughout which this government when wrench by civil war so strenuously insist upon on the part of european nation the itata an armed vessel command by a naval officer of the insurgent fleet man by its sailor and with soldier on board be seize under process of the united states court at san diego cal for a violation of our neutrality law while in the custody of an officer of the court the vessel be forcibly wrest from his control and put to sea it would have be inconsistent with the dignity and self respect of this government not to have insist that the itala should be return to san diego to abide the judgment of the court this be so clear to the junta of the congressional party establish at iquique that before the arrival of the itata at that port the secretary of foreign relation of the provisional government address to rear admiral brown command the united states naval force a communication from which the following be an extract

 a trial in the district court of the united states for the southern district of california have recently result in a decision holding among other thing that inasmuch as the congressional party have not be recognize as a belligerent the act do in its interest could not be a violation of our neutrality law from this judgment the united states have appeal not that the condemnation of the vessel be a matter of importance but that we may know what the present state of our law be for if this construction of the statute be correct there be obvious necessity for revision and amendment

 on the 16th of october an event occur in valparaiso so serious and tragic in its circumstance and result as to very justly excite the indignation of our people and to call for prompt and decide action on the part of this government a considerable number of the sailor of the united states steamship baltimore then in the harbor at valparaiso be upon shore leave and unarmed be assault by armed man nearly simultaneously in different locality in the city one petty officer be kill outright and seven or eight seaman be seriously wound one of whom have since die so savage and brutal be the assault that several of our sailor receive more than two and one as many as eighteen stab wound an investigation of the affair be promptly make by a board of officer of the baltimore and their report show that these assault be unprovoked that our man be conduct themselves in a peaceable and orderly manner and that some of the police of the city take part in the assault and use their weapon with fatal effect while a few other with some well dispose citizen endeavor to protect our man thirty six of our sailor be arrest and some of they while be take to prison be cruelly beat and maltreat the fact that they be all discharge no criminal charge be lodge against any one of they show very clearly that they be innocent of any breach of the peace

 i deem it to be a matter of the high concern to the united states that this canal connect the water of the atlantic and pacific ocean and give to we a short water communication between our port upon those two great sea should be speedily construct and at the small practicable limit of cost the gain in freight to the people and the direct saving to the government of the united states in the use of its naval vessel would pay the entire cost of this work within a short series of year the report of the secretary of the navy show the saving in our naval expenditure which would result
 the senator from alabama mr. morgan in his argument upon this subject before the senate at the last session do not overestimate the importance of this work when he say that the canal be the most important subject now connect with the commercial growth and progress of the united states
 if this work be to be promote by the usual financial method and without the aid of this government the expenditure in its interest bear security and stock will probably be twice the actual cost this will necessitate high toll and constitute a heavy and altogether needless burden upon our commerce and that of the world every dollar of the bond and stock of the company should represent a dollar expend in the legitimate and economical prosecution of the work this be only possible by give to the bond the guaranty of the united states government such a guaranty would secure the ready sale at par of a 3 per cent bond from time to time as the money be need i do not doubt that build upon these business method the canal would when fully inaugurate earn its fix charge and operating expense but if its bond be to be market at heavy discount and every bond sell be to be accompany by a gift of stock as have come to be expect by investor in such enterprise the traffic will be seriously burden to pay interest and dividend i be quite willing to recommend government promotion in the prosecution of a work which if no other mean offer for secure its completion be of such transcendent interest that the government should in my opinion secure it by direct appropriation from its treasury
 a guaranty of the bond of the canal company to an amount necessary to the completion of the canal could i think be so give as not to involve any serious risk of ultimate loss the thing to be carefully guard be the completion of the work within the limit of the guaranty the subrogation of the united states to the right of the first mortgage bondholder for any amount it may have to pay and in the meantime a control of the stock of the company as a security against mismanagement and loss i most sincerely hope that neither party nor sectional line will be draw upon this great american project so full of interest to the people of all our states and so influential in its effect upon the prestige and prosperity of our common country

 during the twelve month from october 1 1890 to september 30 1891 the total value of our foreign commerce import and export combine be $ 1,747,806,406 which be the large of any year in the history of the united states the large in any previous year be in 1890 when our commerce amount to $ 1,647,139,093 and the last year exceed this enormous aggregate by over one hundred million it be interesting and to some will be surprising to know that during the year end september 30 1891 our import of merchandise amount to $ 824,715,270 which be an increase of more than $ 11,000,000 over the value of the import of the corresponding month of the precede year when the import of merchandise be unusually large in anticipation of the tariff legislation then pende the average annual value of the import of merchandise for the ten year from 1881 to 1890 be $ 692,186,522 and during the year end september 30 1891 this annual average be exceed by $ 132,528,469

 there be certainly nothing in the condition of trade foreign or domestic there be certainly nothing in the condition of our people of any class to suggest that the exist tariff and revenue legislation bear oppressively upon the people or retard the commercial development of the nation it may be argue that our condition would be well if tariff legislation be upon a free trade basis but it can not be deny that all the condition of prosperity and of general contentment be present in a large degree than ever before in our history and that too just when it be prophesy they would be in the bad state agitation for radical change in tariff and financial legislation can not help but may seriously impede business to the prosperity of which some degree of stability in legislation be essential

 under the law of july 14 1890 the secretary of the treasury have purchase since august 13 during the fiscal year 48,393,113 ounce of silver bullion at an average cost of $ 1.045 per ounce the high price pay during the year be $ 1.2025 and the low $ 0.9636 in exchange for this silver bullion there have be issue $ 50,577,498 of the treasury note authorize by the act the low price of silver reach during the fiscal year be $ 0.9636 on april 22 1891 but on november 1 the market price be only $ 0.96 which would give to the silver dollar a bullion value of 74 1/4 cent
 before the influence of the prospective silver legislation be feel in the market silver be worth in new york about $ 0.955 per ounce the able advocate of free coinage in the last congress be most confident in their prediction that the purchase by the government require by the law would at once bring the price of silver to $ 1.2929 per ounce which would make the bullion value of a dollar 100 cent and hold it there the prophecy of the antisilver man of disaster to result from the coinage of $ 2,000,000 per month be not wide of the mark the friend of free silver be not agree i think as to the cause that bring their hopeful prediction to naught some fact be know the export of silver from london to india during the first nine month of this calendar year fall off over 50 per cent or $ 17,202,730 compare with the same month of the precede year the export of domestic silver bullion from this country which have average for the last ten year over $ 17,000,000 fall in the last fiscal year to $ 13,797,391 while for the first time in recent year the import of silver into this country exceed the export by the sum of $ 2,745,365 in the previous year the net export of silver from the united states amount to $ 8,545,455 the production of the united states increase from 50,000,000 ounce in 1889 to 54,500,000 in 1890 the government be now buy and put aside annually 54,000,000 ounce which allow for 7,140,000 ounce of new bullion use in the art be 6,640,000 more than our domestic product available for coinage
 i hope the depression in the price of silver be temporary and that a further trial of this legislation will more favorably affect it that the increase volume of currency thus supply for the use of the people be need and that beneficial result upon trade and price have follow this legislation i think must be very clear to everyone nor should it be forget that for every dollar of these note issue a full dollar&#39; worth of silver bullion be at the time deposit in the treasury as a security for its redemption upon this subject as upon the tariff my recommendation be that the exist law be give a full trial and that our business interest be spare the distressing influence which threat of radical change always impart under exist legislation it be in the power of the treasury department to maintain that essential condition of national finance as well as of commercial prosperity the parity in use of the coin dollar and their paper representative the assurance that these power would be freely and unhesitatingly use have do much to produce and sustain the present favorable business condition
 i be still of the opinion that the free coinage of silver under exist condition would disastrously affect our business interest at home and abroad we could not hope to maintain an equality in the purchasing power of the gold and silver dollar in our own market and in foreign trade the stamp give no add value to the bullion contain in coin the producer of the country its farmer and laborer have the high interest that every dollar paper or coin issue by the government shall be as good as any other if there be one less valuable than another its sure and constant errand will be to pay they for their toil and for their crop the money lender will protect himself by stipulate for payment in gold but the laborer have never be able to do that to place business upon a silver basis would mean a sudden and severe contraction of the currency by the withdrawal of gold and gold note and such an unsettling of all value as would produce a commercial panic i can not believe that a people so strong and prosperous as ours will promote such a policy
 the producer of silver be entitle to just consideration but they should not forget that the government be now buy and put out of the market what be the equivalent of the entire product of our silver mine this be more than they themselves think of ask two year ago i believe it be the earnest desire of a great majority of the people as it be mine that a full coin use shall be make of silver just as soon as the cooperation of other nation can be secure and a ratio fix that will give circulation equally to gold and silver the business of the world require the use of both metal but i do not see any prospect of gain but much of loss by give up the present system in which a full use be make of gold and a large use of silver for one in which silver alone will circulate such an event would be at once fatal to the further progress of the silver movement bimetallism be the desire end and the true friend of silver will be careful not to overrun the goal and bring in silver monometallism with its necessary attendant the loss of our gold to europe and the relief of the pressure there for a large currency i have endeavor by the use of official and unofficial agency to keep a close observation of the state of public sentiment in europe upon this question and have not find it to be such as to justify i in propose an international conference there be however i be sure a grow sentiment in europe in favor of a large use of silver and i know of no more effectual way of promote this sentiment than by accumulate gold here a scarcity of gold in the european reserve will be the most persuasive argument for the use of silver

 the outbreak among the sioux which occur in december last be as to its cause and incident fully report upon by the war department and the department of the interior that these indians have some just complaint especially in the matter of the reduction of the appropriation for ration and in the delay attend the enactment of law to enable the department to perform the engagement enter into with they be probably true but the sioux tribe be naturally warlike and turbulent and their warrior be excite by their medicine man and chief who preach the coming of an indian messiah who be to give they power to destroy their enemy in view of the alarm that prevail among the white settler near the reservation and of the fatal consequence that would have result from an indian incursion i place at the disposal of general miles command the division of the missouri all such force as be think by he to be require he be entitle to the credit of having give thorough protection to the settler and of bring the hostile into subjection with the least possible loss of life

 the relation of the five civilized tribes now occupy the indian territory to the united states be not i believe that well calculate to promote the high advancement of these indians that there should be within our border five independent state have no relation except those grow out of treaty with the government of the united states no representation in the national legislature its people not citizen be a startling anomaly

 the good work of reduce the large indian reservation by allotment in severalty to the indians and the cession of the remain land to the united states for disposition under the homestead law have be prosecute during the year with energy and success in september last i be enable to open to settlement in the territory of oklahoma 900,000 acre of land all of which be take up by settler in a single day the rush for these land be accompany by a great deal of excitement but be happily free from incident of violence

 the method of appointment by the states of elector of president and vice president have recently attract renew interest by reason of a departure by the state of michigan from the method which have become uniform in all the states prior to 1832 various method have be use by the different states and even by the same state in some the choice be make by the legislature in other elector be choose by district but more generally by the voter of the whole state upon a general ticket the movement toward the adoption of the last name method have an early beginning and go steadily forward among the states until in 1832 there remain but a single state south carolina that have not adopt it that state until the civil war continue to choose its elector by a vote of the legislature but after the war change its method and conform to the practice of the other states for nearly sixty year all the states save one have appoint their elector by a popular vote upon a general ticket and for nearly thirty year this method be universal
 after a full test of other method without important division or dissent in any state and without any purpose of party advantage as we must believe but solely upon the consideration that uniformity be desirable and that a general election in territorial division not subject to change be most consistent with the popular character of our institution well preserve the equality of the voter and perfectly remove the choice of president from the baneful influence of the gerrymander the practice of all the states be bring into harmony that this concurrence should now be break be i think an unfortunate and even a threatening episode and one that may well suggest whether the states that still give their approval to the old and prevailing method ought not to secure by a constitutional amendment a practice which have have the approval of all the recent michigan legislation provide for choose what be popularly know as the congressional elector for president by congressional district and the two senatorial elector by district create for that purpose this legislation be of course accompany by a new congressional apportionment and the two statute bring the electoral vote of the state under the influence of the gerrymander
 these gerrymander for congressional purpose be in most case buttress by a gerrymander of the legislative district thus make it impossible for a majority of the legal voter of the state to correct the apportionment and equalize the congressional district a minority rule be establish that only a political convulsion can overthrow i have recently be advise that in one county of a certain state three district for the election of member of the legislature be constitute as follow one have 65,000 population one 15,000 and one 10,000 while in another county detach noncontiguous section have be unite to make a legislative district these method have already find effective application to the choice of senator and representatives in congress and now an evil start have be make in the direction of apply they to the choice by the states of elector of president and vice president if this be accomplish we shall then have the three great department of the government in the grasp of the gerrymander the legislative and executive directly and the judiciary indirectly through the power of appointment
 an election imply a body of elector have prescribe qualification each one of whom have an equal value and influence in determine the result so when the constitution provide that each state shall appoint elect in such manner as the legislature thereof may direct a number of elector etc an unrestricted power be not give to the legislature in the selection of the method to be use a republican form of government be guarantee by the constitution to each state and the power give by the same instrument to the legislature of the states to prescribe method for the choice by the state of elector must be exercise under that limitation the essential feature of such a government be the right of the people to choose their own officer and the near practicable equality of value in the suffrage give in determine that choice
 it will not be claim that the power give to the legislature would support a law provide that the person receive the small vote should be the elector or a law that all the elector should be choose by the voter of a single congressional district the state be to choose and finder the pretense of regulating method the legislature can neither vest the right of choice elsewhere nor adopt method not conformable to republican institution it be not my purpose here to discuss the question whether a choice by the legislature or by the voter of equal single district be a choice by the state but only to recommend such regulation of this matter by constitutional amendment as will secure uniformity and prevent that disgraceful partisan jugglery to which such a liberty of choice if it exist offer a temptation
 nothing just now be more important than to provide every guaranty for the absolutely fair and free choice by an equal suffrage within the respective states of all the officer of the national government whether that suffrage be apply directly as in the choice of member of the house of representatives or indirectly as in the choice of senator and elector of president respect for public officer and obedience to law will not cease to be the characteristic of our people until our election cease to declare the will of majority fairly ascertain without fraud suppression or gerrymander if i be call upon to declare wherein our chief national danger lie i should say without hesitation in the overthrow of majority control by the suppression or perversion of the popular suffrage that there be a real danger here all must agree but the energy of those who see it have be chiefly expend in try to fix responsibility upon the opposite party rather than in effort to make such practice impossible by either party
 be it not possible now to adjourn that interminable and inconclusive debate while we take by consent one step in the direction of reform by eliminate the gerrymander which have be denounce by all party as an influence in the selection of elector of president and member of congress all the states have act freely and separately determine that the choice of elector by a general ticket be the wise and safe method and it would seem there could be no objection to a constitutional amendment make that method permanent if a legislature choose in one year upon purely local question should pende a presidential contest meet rescind the law for a choice upon a general ticket and provide for the choice of elector by the legislature and this trick should determine the result it be not too much to say that the public peace might be seriously and widely endanger
 i have allude to the gerrymander as affect the method of select elector of president by congressional district but the primary intent and effect of this form of political robbery have relation to the selection of member of the house of representatives the power of congress be ample to deal with this threatening and intolerable abuse the unfailing test of sincerity in election reform will be find in a willingness to confer as to remedy and to put into force such measure as will most effectually preserve the right of the people to free and equal representation
 an attempt be make in the last congress to bring to bear the constitutional power of the general government for the correction of fraud against the suffrage it be important to know whether the opposition to such measure be really rest in particular feature suppose to be objectionable or include any proposition to give to the election law of the united states adequacy to the correction of grave and acknowledge evil i must yet entertain the hope that it be possible to secure a calm patriotic consideration of such constitutional or statutory change as may be necessary to secure the choice of the officer of the government to the people by fair apportionment and free election
 i believe it would be possible to constitute a commission nonpartisan in its membership and compose of patriotic wise and impartial man to whom a consideration of the question of the evil connect with our election system and method might be commit with a good prospect of secure unanimity in some plan for remove or mitigate those evil the constitution would permit the selection of the commission to be vest in the supreme court if that method would give the good guaranty of impartiality this commission should be charge with the duty of inquire into the whole subject of the law of election as relate to the choice of officer of the national government with a view to secure to every elector a free and unmolested exercise of the suffrage and as near an approach to an equality of value in each ballot cast as be attainable
 while the policy of the general government upon the tariff upon the restoration of our merchant marine upon river and harbor improvement and other such matter of grave and general concern be liable to be turn this way or that by the result of congressional election and administrative policy sometimes involve issue that tend to peace or war to be turn this way or that by the result of a presidential election there be a rightful interest in all the states and in every congressional district that will not be deceive or silence by the audacious pretense that the question of the right of any body of legal voter in any state or in any congressional district to give their suffrage freely upon these general question be a matter only of local concern or control the demand that the limitation of suffrage shall be find in the law and only there be a just demand and no just man should resent or resist it my appeal be and must continue to be for a consultation that shall proceed with candor calmness and patience upon the line of justice and humanity not of prejudice and cruelty

rate among railroad employee the method of appointment by the states of elector of president and vice president have recently attract renew interest by reason of a departure by the state of michigan from the method which have become uniform in all the states prior to 1832 various method have be use by the different states and even by the same state in some the choice be make by the legislature in other elector be choose by district but more generally by the voter of the whole state upon a general ticket the movement toward the adoption of the last name method have an early beginning and go steadily forward among the states until in 1832 there remain but a single state south carolina that have not adopt it that state until the civil war continue to choose its elector by a vote of the legislature but after the war change its method and conform to the practice of the other states for nearly sixty year all the states save one have appoint their elector by a popular vote upon a general ticket and for nearly thirty year this method be universal after a full test of other method without important division or dissent in any state and without any purpose of party advantage as we must believe but solely upon the consideration that uniformity be desirable and that a general election in territorial division not subject to change be most consistent with the popular character of our institution well preserve the equality of the voter and perfectly remove the choice of president from the baneful influence of the gerrymander the practice of all the states be bring into harmony that this concurrence should now be break be i think an unfortunate and even a threatening episode and one that may well suggest whether the states that still give their approval to the old and prevailing method ought not to secure by a constitutional amendment a practice which have have the approval of all the recent michigan legislation provide for choose what be popularly know as the the legislative district thus make it impossible for a majority of the legal voter of the state to correct the apportionment and equalize the congressional district a minority rule be establish that only a political convulsion can overthrow i have recently be advise that in one county of a certain state three district for the election of member of the legislature be constitute as follow one have 65,000 population one 15,000 and one 10,000 while in another county detach noncontiguous section have be unite to make a legislative district these method have already find effective application to the choice of senator and representatives in congress and now an evil start have be make in the direction of apply they to the choice by the states of elector of president and vice president if this appointment an election imply a body of elector have prescribe qualification each one of whom have an equal value and influence in determine the result so when the constitution provide that each state republican form of government be guarantee by the constitution to each state and the power give by the same instrument to the legislature of the states to prescribe method for the choice by the state of elector must be exercise under that limitation the essential feature of such a government be the right of the people to choose their own officer and the near practicable equality of value in the suffrage give in determine that choice it will not be claim that the power give to the legislature would support a law provide that the person receive the small vote should be the elector or a law district be a choice by the state but only to recommend such regulation of this matter by constitutional amendment as will secure uniformity and prevent that disgraceful partisan jugglery to which such a liberty of choice if it exist offer a temptation nothing just now be more important than to provide every guaranty for the absolutely fair and free choice by an equal suffrage within the respective states of all the officer of the national government whether that suffrage be apply directly as in the choice of member of the house of representatives or indirectly as in the choice of senator and elector of president respect for public officer and obedience to law will not cease to be the characteristic of our people until our election cease to declare the will of majority fairly ascertain without fraud suppression or gerrymander if i be call upon to declare wherein our chief national danger lie i should say without hesitation in the overthrow of majority control by the suppression or perversion of the popular suffrage that there be a real danger here all must agree but the energy of those who see it have be chiefly expend in try to fix responsibility upon the opposite party rather than in effort to make such practice impossible by either party be it not possible now to adjourn that interminable and inconclusive debate while we take by consent one step in the direction of reform by eliminate the gerrymander which have be denounce by all party as an influence in the selection of elector of president and member of congress all the states have act freely and separately determine that the choice of elector by a general ticket be the wise and safe method and it would seem there could be no objection to a constitutional amendment make that method permanent if a legislature choose in one year upon purely local question should pende a presidential contest meet rescind the law for a choice upon a general ticket and provide for the choice of elector by the legislature and this trick should determine the result it be not too much to say that the public peace might be seriously and widely endanger i have allude to the gerrymander as affect the method of select elector of president by congressional district but the primary intent and effect of this form of political robbery have relation to the selection of member of the house of representatives the power of congress be ample to deal with this threatening and intolerable abuse the unfailing test of sincerity in election reform will be find in a willingness to confer as to remedy and to put into force such measure as will most effectually preserve the right of the people to free and equal representation an attempt be make in the last congress to bring to bear the to the senate and house of representatives
 in my annual message deliver to congress at the beginning of the present session after a brief statement of the fact then in the possession of this government touch the assault in the street of valparaiso chile upon the sailor of the united states steamship baltimore on the evening of the 16th of october last i say
 this government be now await the result of an investigation which have be conduct by the criminal court at valparaiso it be report unofficially that the investigation be about complete and it be expect that the result will soon be communicate to this government together with some adequate and satisfactory response to the note by which the attention of chile be call to this incident if these just expectation should be disappoint or further needless delay intervene i will by a special message bring this matter again to the attention of congress for such action as may be necessary
 in my opinion the time have now come when i should lay before the congress and the country the correspondence between this government and the government of chile from the time of the breaking out of the revolution against balmaceda together with all other fact in the possession of the executive department relate to this matter the diplomatic correspondence be herewith transmit together with some correspondence between the naval officer for the time in command in chilean water and the secretary of the navy and also the evidence take at the mare island navy yard since the arrival of the baltimore at san francisco i do not deem it necessary in this communication to attempt any full analysis of the correspondence or of the evidence a brief restatement of the international question involve and of the reason why the response of the chilean government be unsatisfactory be all that i deem necessary
 it may be well at the outset to say that whatever may have be say in this country or in chile in criticism of mr. egan our minister at santiago the true history of this exciting period in chilean affair from the outbreak of the revolution until this time disclose no act on the part of mr. egan unworthy of his position or that could justly be the occasion of serious animadversion or criticism he have i think on the whole bear himself in very try circumstance with dignity discretion and courage and have conduct the correspondence with ability courtesy and fairness
 it be worth while also at the beginning to say that the right of mr. egan to give shelter in the legation to certain adherent of the balmaceda government who apply to he for asylum have not be deny by the chilean authority nor have any demand be make for the surrender of these refugee that there be urgent need of asylum be show by mr. egan&#39;s note of august 24 1891 describe the disorder that prevail in santiago and by the evidence of captain schley as to the pillage and violence that prevail at valparaiso the correspondence disclose however that the request of mr. egan for a safe conduct from the country in behalf of these refugee be deny the precedent cite by he in the correspondence particularly the case of the revolution in peru in 1865 do not leave the chilean government in a position to deny the right of asylum to political refugee and seem very clearly to support mr. egan&#39;s contention that a safe conduct to neutral territory be a necessary and acknowledge incident of the asylum these refugee have very recently without formal safe conduct but by the acquiescence of the chilean authority be place on board the yorktown and be now be convey to callao peru this incident might be consider wholly closed but for the disrespect manifest toward this government by the close and offensive police surveillance of the legation premise which be maintain during most of the period of the stay of the refugee therein after the date of my annual message and up to the time of the transfer of the refugee to the yorktown the legation premise seem to have be surround by police in uniform and police agent or detective in citizen&#39;s dress who offensively scrutinize person enter or leave the legation and on one or more occasion arrest member of the minister&#39;s family commander evans who by my direction recently visit mr. egan at santiago in his telegram to the navy department describe the legation as a veritable prison and state that the police agent or detective be after his arrival withdraw during his stay it appear far from the note of mr. egan of november 20 1891 that on one occasion at least these police agent whom he declare to be know to he invade the legation premise pound upon its window and use insulting and threaten language toward person therein this breach of the right of a minister to freedom from police espionage and restraint seem to have be so flagrant that the argentine minister who be dean of the diplomatic corps having observe it felt call upon to protest against it to the chilean minister of foreign affair the chilean authority have as will be observe from the correspondence charge the refugee and the inmate of the legation with insult the police but it seem to i incredible that man whose life be in jeopardy and whose safety could only be secure by retirement and quietness should have seek to provoke a collision which could only end in their destruction or to aggravate their condition by intensify a popular feeling that at one time so threaten the legation as to require mr. egan to appeal to the minister of foreign affair
 but the most serious incident disclose by the correspondence be that of the attack upon the sailor of the baltimore in the street of valparaiso on the 16th of october last in my annual message speak upon the information then in my possession i say
 so far as i have yet be able to learn no other explanation of this bloody work have be suggest than that it have its origin in hostility to those man as sailor of the united states wear the uniform of their government and not in any individual act or personal animosity
 we have now receive from the chilean government an abstract of the conclusion of the fiscal general upon the testimony take by the judge of crime in an investigation which be make to extend over nearly three month i very much regret to be compel to say that this report do not enable i to modify the conclusion announce in my annual message i be still of the opinion that our sailor be assault beat stab and kill not for anything they or any one of they have do but for what the government of the united states have do or be charge with having do by its civil officer and naval commander if that be the true aspect of the case the injury be to the government of the united states not to these poor sailor who be assault in a manner so brutal and so cowardly
 before attempt to give an outline of the fact upon which this conclusion rest i think it right to say a word or two upon the legal aspect of the case the baltimore be in the harbor of valparaiso by virtue of that general invitation which nation be hold to extend to the war vessel of other power with which they have friendly relation this invitation i think must be hold ordinarily to embrace the privilege of such communication with the shore as be reasonable necessary and proper for the comfort and convenience of the officer and man of such vessel captain schley testify that when his vessel return to valparaiso on september 14 the city officer as be customary extend the hospitality of the city to his officer and crew it be not claim that every personal collision or injury in which a sailor or officer of such naval vessel visit the shore may be involve raise an international question but i be clearly of the opinion that where such sailor or officer be assault by a resident populace animate by hostility to the government whose uniform these sailor and officer wear and in resentment of act do by their government not by they their nation must take notice of the event as one involve an infraction of its right and dignity not in a secondary way as where a citizen be injure and present his claim through his own government but in a primary way precisely as if its minister or consul or the flag itself have be the object of the same character of assault
 the officer and sailor of the baltimore be in the harbor of valparaiso under the order of their government not by their own choice they be upon the shore by the imply invitation of the government of chile and with the approval of their commanding officer and it do not distinguish their case from that of a consul that his stay be more permanent or that he hold the express invitation of the local government to justify his long residence nor do it affect the question that the injury be the act of a mob if there have be no participation by the police or military in this cruel work and no neglect on their part to extend protection the case would still be one in my opinion when its extent and character be consider involve international right the incident of the affair be briefly as follow
 on the 16th of october last captain schley command the united states steamship baltimore give shore leave to 117 petty officer and sailor of his ship these man leave the ship about 1.30 p.m. no incident of violence occur none of our man be arrest no complaint be lodge against they nor do any collision or outbreak occur until about 6 o&#39;clock p.m. captain schley state that he be himself on shore and about the street of the city until 5.30 p.m. that he meet very many of his man who be upon leave that they be sober and be conduct themselves with propriety salute chilean and other officer as they meet they other officer of the ship and captain jenkins of the merchant ship keweenaw corroborate captain schley as to the general sobriety and good behavior of our man the sisters of charity at the hospital to which our wounded man be take when inquire of state that they be sober when receive if the situation have be otherwise we must believe that the chilean police authority would have make arrest about 6 p.m. the assault begin and it be remarkable that the investigation by the judge of crime though so protract do not enable he to give any more satisfactory account of its origin than be find in the statement that it begin between drunken sailor repeatedly in the correspondence it be assert that it be impossible to learn the precise cause of the riot the minister of foreign affair matta in his telegram to mr. montt under date december 31 state that the quarrel begin between two sailor in a tavern and be continue in the street person who be pass join in it
 the testimony of talbot an apprentice who be with riggin be that the outbreak in which they be involve begin by a chilean sailor&#39;s spit in the face of talbot which be resent by a knockdown it appear that riggin and talbot be at the time unaccompanie by other of their shipmate these two man be immediately beset by a crowd of chilean citizen and sailor through which they break their way to a street car and enter it for safety they be pursue drive from the car and riggin be so seriously beat that he fall in the street apparently dead there be nothing in the report of the chilean investigation make to we that seriously impeach this testimony it appear from chilean source that almost instantly with a suddenness that strongly imply meditation and preparation a mob state by the police authority at one time to number 2,000 and at another 1,000 be engage in the assault upon our sailor who be represent as resist with stone club and bright arm the report of the intendente of october 30 state that the fight begin at 6 p.m. in three street which be name that information be receive at the intendencia at 6.15 and that the police arrive on the scene at 6.30 a full half hour after the assault begin at that time he say that a mob of 2,000 man have collect and that for several square there be the appearance of a real battlefield
 the scene at this point be very graphically set before we by the chilean testimony the american sailor who after so long an examination have not be find guilty of any breach of the peace so far as the chilean authority be able to discover unarmed and defenseless be flee for their life pursue by overwhelming number and fight only to aid their own escape from death or to succor some mate whose life be in great peril eighteen of they be brutally stab and beat while one chilean seem from the report to have suffer some injury but how serious or with what character of weapon or whether by a missile throw by our man or by some of his fellow rioter be unascertaine
 the pretense that our man be fight with stone club and bright arm be in view of these fact incredible it be far refute by the fact that our prisoner when search be absolutely without arm only seven penknife be find in the possession of the man arrest while there be receive by our man more than thirty stab wound every one of which be inflict in the back and almost every confused wound be in the back or back of the head the evidence of the ship&#39;s officer of the day be that even the jackknife of the man be take from they before leave the ship
 as to the brutal nature of the treatment receive by our man the following extract from the account give of the affair by the la patria newspaper of valparaiso of october 17 can not be regard as too friendly
 the yankees as soon as their pursuer give chase go by way of the calle del arsenal toward the city car station in the presence of an ordinary number of citizen among whom be some sailor the north americans take seat in the street car to escape from the stone which the chileans throw at they it be believe for an instant that the north americans have save themselves from popular fury but such be not the case scarcely have the car begin to move when a crowd gather around and stop its progress under these circumstance and without any cessation of the howling and throwing of stone at the north americans the conductor enter the car and see the risk of the situation to the vehicle order they to get out at the instant the sailor leave the car in the midst of a hail of stone the say conductor receive a stone blow on the head one of the yankee sailor manage to escape in the direction of the plaza wheelright but the other be fell to the ground by a stone manage to raise himself from the ground where he lay he stagger in an opposite direction from the station in front of the house of senor mazzini he be again wound fall then senseless and breathless
 no amount of evasion or subterfuge be able to cloud our clear vision of this brutal work it should be notice in this connection that the american sailor arrest after an examination be during the four day follow the arrest every one discharge no charge of any breach of the peace or other criminal conduct having be sustain against a single one of they the judge of crime foster in a note to the intendente under date of october 22 before the dispatch from this government of the following day which arouse the authority of chile to a well sense of the gravity of the affair say
 having preside temporarily over this court in regard to the seaman of the united states cruiser baltimore who have be try on account of the deplorable conduct which take place etc
 the noticeable point here be that our sailor have be try before the 22d of october and that the trial result in their acquittal and return to their vessel it be quite remarkable and quite characteristic of the management of this affair by the chilean police authority that we should now be advise that seaman davidson of the baltimore have be include in the indictment his offense be so far as i have be able to ascertain that he attempt to defend a shipmate against an assailant who be strike at he with a knife the perfect vindication of our man be furnish by this report one only be find to have be guilty of criminal fault and that for an act clearly justifiable
 as to the part take by the police in the affair the case make by chile be also far from satisfactory the point where riggin be kill be only three minutes&#39 walk from the police station and not more than twice that distance from the intendencia and yet accord to their official report a full half hour elapse after the assault begin before the police be upon the ground it have be state that all but two of our man have say that the police do their duty the evidence take at mare island show that if such a statement be procure from our man it be accomplish by require they to sign a writing in a language they do not understand and by the representation that it be a mere declaration that they have take no part in the disturbance lieutenant mccrea who act as interpreter say in his evidence that when our sailor be examine before the court the subject of the conduct of the police be so carefully avoid that he report the fact to captain schley on his return to the vessel
 the evidence of the existence of animosity toward our sailor in the mind of the sailor of the chilean navy and of the populace of valparaiso be so abundant and various as to leave no doubt in the mind of anyone who will examine the paper submit it manifest itself in threaten and insult gesture toward our man as they pass the chilean man of war in their boat and in the derisive and abusive epithet with which they greet every appearance of an american sailor on the evening of the riot captain schley report that boat from the chilean war ship several time go out of their course to cross the bow of his boat compel they to back water he complain of the discourtesy and it be correct that this feeling be share by man of high rank be show by an incident relate by surgeon stitt of the baltimore after the battle of placilla he with other medical officer of the war vessel in the harbor be give voluntary assistance to the wound in the hospital the son of a chilean army officer of high rank be under his care and when the father discover it he fly into a passion and say he would rather have his son die than have americans touch he and at once have he remove from the ward this feeling be not well conceal in the dispatch of the foreign office and have quite open expression in the disrespectful treatment of the american legation the chilean boatman in the bay refuse even for large offer of money to return our sailor who crowd the mole to their ship when they be endeavor to escape from the city on the night of the assault the market boat of the baltimore be threaten and even quite recently the gig of commander evans of the yorktown be stone while wait for he at the mole
 the evidence of our sailor clearly show that the attack be expect by the chilean people that threat have be make against our man and that in one case somewhat early in the afternoon the keeper of one house into which some of our man have go close his establishment in anticipation of the attack which he advise they would be make upon they as darkness come on
 in a report of captain schley to the navy department he say
 in the only interview that i have with judge foster who be investigate the case relative to the disturbance before he be aware of the entire gravity of the matter he inform i that the assault upon my man be the outcome of hatred for our people among the low class because they think we have sympathize with the balmaceda government on account of the itata matter whether with reason or without he could of course not admit but such he think be the explanation of the assault at that time
 several of our man seek security from the mob by such complete or partial change in their dress as would conceal the fact of their be seaman of the baltimore and find it then possible to walk the street without molestation these incident conclusively establish that the attack be upon the uniform the nationality and not upon the man
 the origin of this feeling be probably find in the refusal of this government to give recognition to the congressional party before it have establish itself in the seizure of the itala for an alleged violation of the neutrality law in the cable incident and in the charge that admiral brown convey information to valparaiso of the landing at quinteros it be not my purpose to enter here any defense of the action of this government in these matter it be enough for the present purpose to say that if there be any breach of international comity or duty on our part it should have be make the subject of official complaint through diplomatic channel or for reprisal for which a full responsibility be assume we can not consent that these incident and these perversion of the truth shall be use to excite a murderous attack upon our unoffending sailor and the government of chile go acquit of responsibility in fact the conduct of this government during the war in chile pursue those line of international duty which we have so strongly insist upon on the part of other nation when this country be in the throe of a civil conflict we continue the establish diplomatic relation with the government in power until it be overthrow and promptly and cordially recognize the new government when it be establish the good office of this government be offer to bring about a peaceful adjustment and the interposition of mr. egan to mitigate severity and to shelter adherent of the congressional party be effective and frequent the charge against admiral brown be too base to gain credence with anyone who know his high personal and professional character
 recur to the evidence of our sailor i think it be show that there be several distinct assault and so nearly simultaneous as to show that they do not spread from one point a press summary of the report of the fiscal show that the evidence of the chilean official and other be in conflict as to the place of origin several place be name by different witness as the locality where the first outbreak occur this if correctly report show that there be several distinct outbreak and so nearly at the same time as to cause this confusion the la patria in the same issue from which i have already quote after describe the killing of riggin and the fight which from that point extend to the mole say
 at the same time in other street of the port the yankee sailor fight fiercely with the people of the town who believe to see in they incarnate enemy of the chilean navy
