 the testimony of captain jenkins of the american merchant ship keweenaw which have go to valparaiso for repair and who be a witness of some part of the assault upon the crew of the baltimore be strongly corroborative of the testimony of our own sailor when he say that he see chilean sentry drive back a seaman seek shelter upon a mob that be pursue he the officer and man of captain jenkins&#39;s ship furnish the most conclusive testimony as to the indignity which be practice toward americans in valparaiso when american sailor even of merchant ship can only secure their safety by deny their nationality it must be time to readjust our relation with a government that permit such demonstration
 as to the participation of the police the evidence of our sailor show that our man be strike and beat by police officer before and after arrest and that one at least be drag with a lasso about his neck by a mount policeman that the death of riggin be the result of a rifle shot fire by a policeman or soldier on duty be show directly by the testimony of johnson in whose arm he be at the time and by the evidence of charles langen an american sailor not then a member of the baltimore&#39;s crew who stand close by and see the transaction the chilean authority do not pretend to fix the responsibility of this shot upon any particular person but avow their inability to ascertain who fire it far than that it be fire from a crowd the character of the wound as describe by one of the surgeon of the baltimore clearly support his opinion that it be make by a rifle ball the orifice of exit be as much as an inch or an inch and a quarter in width when shoot the poor fellow be unconscious and in the arm of a comrade who be endeavor to carry he to a neighboring drug store for treatment the story of the police that in come up the street they pass these man and leave they behind they be inconsistent with their own statement as to the direction of their approach and with their duty to protect they and be clearly disprove in fact riggin be not behind but in front of the advance force and be not stand in the crowd but be unconscious and support in the arm of johnson when he be shoot
 the communication of the chilean government in relation to this cruel and disastrous attack upon our man as will appear from the correspondence have not in any degree take the form of a manly and satisfactory expression of regret much less of apology the event be of so serious a character that if the injury suffer by our man have be wholly the result of an accident in a chilean port the incident be grave enough to have call for some public expression of sympathy and regret from the local authority it be not enough to say that the affair be lamentable for humanity would require that expression even if the beating and killing of our man have be justifiable it be not enough to say that the incident be regret couple with the statement that the affair be not of an unusual character in port where foreign sailor be accustom to meet it be not for a generous and sincere government to seek for word of small or equivocal meaning in which to convey to a friendly power an apology for an offense so atrocious as this in the case of the assault by a mob in new orleans upon the spanish consulate in 1851 mr. webster write to the spanish minister mr. calderon that the act complain of be a disgraceful and flagrant breach of duty and propriety and that his government regret they as deeply as minister calderon or his government could possibly do that these act have cause the president great pain and he think a proper acknowledgment be due to her majesty&#39;s government he invite the spanish consul to return to his post guarantee protection and offer to salute the spanish flag if the consul should come in a spanish vessel such a treatment by the government of chile of this assault would have be more creditable to the chilean authority and much less can hardly be satisfactory to a government that value its dignity and honor
 in our note of october 23 last which appear in the correspondence after receive the report of the board of officer appoint by captain schley to investigate the affair the chilean government be advise of the aspect which it then assume and call upon for any fact in its possession that might tend to modify the unfavorable impression which our report have create it be very clear from the correspondence that before the receipt of this note the examination be regard by the police authority as practically closed it be however reopen and protract through a period of nearly three month we might justly have complain of this unreasonable delay but in view of the fact that the government of chile be still provisional and with a disposition to be forbear and hopeful of a friendly termination i have await the report which have but recently be make
 on the 21st instant i cause to be communicate to the government of chile by the american minister at santiago the conclusion of this government after a full consideration of all the evidence and of every suggestion affect this matter and to these conclusion i adhere they be state as follow
 first that the assault be not relieve of the aspect which the early information of the event give to it viz that of an attack upon the uniform of the united states navy have its origin and motive in a feeling of hostility to this government and not in any act of the sailor or of any of they
 second that the public authority of valparaiso flagrantly fail in their duty to protect our man and that some of the police and of the chilean soldier and sailor be themselves guilty of unprovoked assault upon our sailor before and after arrest he the president think the preponderance of the evidence and the inherent probability lead to the conclusion that riggin be kill by the police or soldier
 third that he the president be therefore compel to bring the case back to the position take by this government in the note of mr. wharton of october 23 last and to ask for a suitable apology and for some adequate reparation for the injury do to this government
 in the same note the attention of the chilean government be call to the offensive character of a note address by mr. matta its minister of foreign affair to mr. montt its minister at this capital on the 11th ultimo this dispatch be not officially communicate to this government but as mr. montt be direct to translate it and to give it to the press of the country it seem to i that it could not pass without official notice it be not only undiplomatic but grossly insult to our naval officer and to the executive department as it directly impute untruth and insincerity to the report of the naval officer and to the official communication make by the executive department to congress it will be observe that i have notify the chilean government that unless this note be at once withdraw and an apology as public as the offense make i will terminate diplomatic relation
 the request for the recall of mr. egan upon the ground that he be not persona grata be unaccompanie by any suggestion that could properly be use in support of it and i infer that the request be base upon official act of mr. egan which have receive the approval of this government but however that may be i could not consent to consider such a question until it have first be settle whether our correspondence with chile could be conduct upon a basis of mutual respect
 in submit these paper to congress for that grave and patriotic consideration which the question involve demand i desire to say that i be of the opinion that the demand make of chile by this government should be adhere to and enforce if the dignity as well as the prestige and influence of the united states be not to be wholly sacrifice we must protect those who in foreign port display the flag or wear the color of this government against insult brutality and death inflict in resentment of the act of their government and not for any fault of their own it have be my desire in every way to cultivate friendly and intimate relation with all the government of this hemisphere we do not covet their territory we desire their peace and prosperity we look for no advantage in our relation with they except the increase exchange of commerce upon a basis of mutual benefit we regret every civil contest that disturb their peace and paralyze their development and be always ready to give our good office for the restoration of peace it must however be understand that this government while exercise the utmost forbearance toward weak power will extend its strong and adequate protection to its citizen to its officer and to its humblest sailor when make the victim of wantonness and cruelty in resentment not of their personal misconduct but of the official act of their government
 upon information receive that patrick shields an irishman and probably a british subject but at the time a fireman of the american steamer keweenaw in the harbor of valparaiso for repair have be subject to personal injury in that city largely by the police i direct the attorney general to cause the evidence of the officer and crew of that vessel to be take upon its arrival in san francisco and that testimony be also herewith transmit the brutality and even savagery of the treatment of this poor man by the chilean police would be incredible if the evidence of shields be not support by other direct testimony and by the distressing condition of the man himself when he be finally able to reach his vessel the captain of the vessel say
 he come back a wreck black from his neck to his hip from beat weak and stupid and be still in a kind of paralyzed condition and have never be able to do duty since
 a claim for reparation have be make in behalf of this man for while he be not a citizen of the united states the doctrine long hold by we as express in the consular regulation be
 the principle which be maintain by this government in regard to the protection as distinguish from the relief of seaman be well settle it be hold that the circumstance that the vessel be american be evidence that the seaman on board be such and in every regularly document merchant vessel the crew will find their protection in the flag that cover they
 i have as yet receive no reply to our note of the 21st instant but in my opinion i ought not to delay long to bring these matter to the attention of congress for such action as may be deem appropriate

to the senate and house of representatives
 i transmit herewith additional correspondence between this government and the government of chile consist of a note of mr. montt the chilean minister at this capital to mr. blaine date january 23 a reply of mr. blaine thereto of date january 27 and a dispatch from mr. egan our minister at santiago transmit the response of mr. peteira the chilean minister of foreign affair to the note of mr. blaine of january 21 which be receive by i on the 26th instant the note of mr. montt to mr. blaine though date january 23 be not deliver at the state department until after 12 o&#39;clock m. of the 25th and be not translate and its receipt notify to i until late in the afternoon of that day
 the response of mr. pereira to our note of the 21st withdraw with acceptable expression of regret the offensive note of mr. matta of the 11th ultimo and also the request for the recall of mr. egan the treatment of the incident of the assault upon the sailor of the baltimore be so conciliatory and friendly that i be of the opinion that there be a good prospect that the difference grow out of that serious affair can now be adjust upon term satisfactory to this government by the usual method and without special power from congress this turn in the affair be very gratifying to i as i be sure it will be to the congress and to our people the general support of the effort of the executive to enforce the just right of the nation in this matter have give an instructive and useful illustration of the unity and patriotism of our people
 should it be necessary i will again communicate with congress upon the subject

hon william mckinley jr. and other
 committee etc
 gentlemen
 i now avail myself of the first period of relief from public duty to respond to the notification which you bring to i on june 20 of my nomination for the office of president of the united states by the republican national convention recently hold at minneapolis i accept the nomination and be grateful for the approval express by the convention of the act of the administration
 i have endeavor without waver or weariness so far as the direction of public affair be commit to i to carry out the pledge make to the people in 1888 if the policy of the administration have not be distinctively and progressively american and republican policy the fault have not be in the purpose but in the execution i shall speak frankly of the legislation of congress and of the work of the executive department for the credit of any success that have be attain be in such measure due to other mdash senators and representatives and to the efficient head of the several executive department mdash that i may do so without impropriety
 a vote of want of confidence be ask by our adversary and this challenge to a review of what have be do we promptly and gladly accept
 the great work of the fifty first congress have be subject to the revision of a democratic house of representatives and the act of the executive department to its scrutiny and investigation a democratic national administration be succeed by a republican administration and the freshness of the event give unusual facility for fair comparison and judgment there have seldom be a time i think when a change from the declare policy of the republican party to the declare policy of the democratic party involve such serious result to the business interest of the country a brief review of what have be do and of what the democratic party propose to undo will justify this opinion
 the republican party during the civil war devise a national currency consist of united states note issue and redeemable by the government and of national bank note base upon the security of united states bond a tax be levy upon the issue of state bank and the intend result that all such issue should be withdraw be realize there be man among we now who never see a state bank note
 the note furnish directly or indirectly by the united states have be the only and the safe and acceptable paper currency of the people bank failure have bring no fright delay or loss to the bill holder the note of an insolvent bank be as good and as current as a treasury note for the credit of the united states be behind it our money be all national money mdash i might almost say international for these bill be not only equally and indiscriminately accept at par in all the states but in some foreign country
 the democratic party if intrust with the control of the government be now pledge to repeal the tax on state bank issue with a view to put into circulation again under such diverse legislation as the states may adopt a flood of local bank issue only those who in the year before the war experience the inconvenience and loss attendant upon the use of such money can appreciate what a return to that system involve
 the denomination of a bill be then often no indication of its value the bank detector of yesterday be not a safe guide to day as to credit or value merchant deposit several time during the day lest the hour of bank closing should show a depreciation of the money take in the morning the traveler could not use in a journey to the east the issue of the most solvent bank of the west and in consequence a money changer&#39;s office be the familiar neighbor of the ticket office and the lunch counter the farmer and the laborer find the money receive for their product or their labor depreciate when they come to make their purchase and the whole business of the country be hinder and burden
 change may become necessary but a national system of currency safe and acceptable throughout the whole country be the good fruit of bitter experience and i be sure our people will not consent to the reactionary proposal make by the democratic party
 few subject have elicit more discussion or excite more general interest than that of a recovery by the united states of its appropriate share of the ocean carry trade this subject touch not only our pocket but our national pride practically all the freight for transport to europe the enormous annual supply of provision furnish by this country and for the large return of manufacture product have for many year be pay to foreign owner
 thousand of immigrant annually seek home under our flag have be deny the sight of it until they enter sandy hook while increase thousand of american citizen bent on european travel have each year step into a foreign jurisdiction at the new york dock the merchandise balance of trade which the treasury book show be largely reduce by the annual tribute which we pay for freight and passage money
 the great ship mdash the fast upon the sea mdash which be now in peace profit by our trade be in a secondary sense warship of their respective government and in time of war would under exist contract with those government speedily take on the gun for which their deck be already prepared and enter with terrible efficiency upon the work of destroy our commerce the undisputed fact be that the great steamship line of europe be build up and be now in part sustain by direct or indirect government aid the latter take the form of liberal pay for carry the mail or of an annual bonus give in consideration of agreement to construct the ship so as to adapt they for carry an armament and to turn they over to the government on demand upon specific term
 it be plain to every intelligent american that if the united states would have such line a similar policy must be enter upon the fifty first congress enact such a law and under its beneficent influence sixteen american steamship of an aggregate tonnage of 57,400 ton and cost $ 7,400,000 have be build or contract to be build in american shipyard
 in addition to this it be now practically certain that we shall soon have under the american flag one of the fine steamship line sail out of new york for any european port this contract will result in the construction in american yard of four new passenger steamship of 10,000 ton each cost about $ 8,000,000 and will add to our naval reserve six steamship the fast upon the sea
 a special interest have be take by i in the establishment of line from our south atlantic and gulf port and though my expectation have not yet be realize attention have be call to the advantage possess by these port and when their people be more fully alive to their interest i do not doubt that they will be able to secure the capital need to enable they to profit by their great natural advantage
 the democratic party have find no place in its platform for any reference to this subject and have show its hostility to the general policy by refuse to expend an appropriation make during the last administration for ocean mail contract with american line
 the patriotic people the workman in our shop the capitalist seek new enterprise must decide whether the great ship own by americans which have seek american registry shall again humbly ask a place in the english naval reserve the great ship now on the designers&#39 table go to foreign shop for construction and the united states lose the now brighten opportunity of recover a place commensurate with its wealth the skill of its constructor and the courage of its sailor in the carry trade of all the sea
 another related measure as furnish an increase ocean traffic for our ship and of great and permanent benefit to the farmer and manufacturer as well be the reciprocity policy declare by section 3 of the tariff act of 1890 and now in practical operation with five of the nation of central and south america san domingo the spanish and british west india islands and with germany and austria under special trade arrangement with each
 the removal of the duty upon sugar and the continuance of coffee and tea upon the free list while give great relief to our people by cheapen article use increasingly in every household be also of such enormous advantage to the country export these article as to suggest that in consideration thereof reciprocal favor should be show in their tariff to article export by we to their market
 great credit be due to mr. elaine for the vigor with which he press this view upon the country we have only begin to realize the benefit of these trade arrangement the work of create new agency and of adapt our good to new market have necessarily take time but the result already attain be such i be sure as to establish in popular favor the policy of reciprocal trade base upon the free importation of such article as do not injuriously compete with the product of our own farm mine or factory in exchange for the free or favor introduction of our product into other country
 the obvious efficacy of this policy in increase the foreign trade of the united states at once attract the alarmed attention of european trade journal and board of trade the british board of trade have present to that government a memorial asking for the appointment of a commission to consider the good mean of counteract what be call the commercial crusade of the united states
 at a meeting hold in march last of the associated chambers of commerce of great britain the president report that the export from great britain to the latin american country during the last year have decrease $ 23,750,000 and that this be not due to temporary cause but directly to the reciprocity policy of the united states
 germany and france have also show their startled appreciation of the fact that a new and vigorous contestant have appear in the battle of the market and have already secure important advantage
 the most convincing evidence of the tremendous commercial strength of our position be find in the fact that great britain and spain have find it necessary to make reciprocal trade agreement with ns for their west india colony and that germany and austria have give we important concession in exchange for the continue free importation of their beet sugar
 a few detail only as to the increase of our trade can be give here take all the country with which such arrangement have be make our trade to june 30 1892 have increase 23.78 per cent with brazil the increase be nearly 11 per cent with cuba during the first ten month our export increase $ 5,702,193 or 54.86 per cent and with porto rico $ 590,959 or 34 per cent the liberal participation of our farmer in the benefit of this policy be show by the following report from our consul general at havana under date of july 26 last
 during the first half year of 1891 havana receive 140,056 bag of flour from spain and other port of the island about an equal amount or approximately 280,112 bag
 during the same period havana receive 13,9/6 bag of american flour and other port approximately an equal amount make about 28,000 bag
 but for the first half of this year spain have send less than 1,000 bag to the whole island and the united states have send to havana alone 168,487 bag and about an equal amount to other port of the island make approximately 337,000 for the first half of 1892
 partly by reason of the reciprocal trade agreement but more largely by reason of the removal of the sanitary restriction upon american pork our export of pork product to germany increase during the ten month end june 30 last $ 2,025,074 or about 32 per cent
 the british trade journal of london in a recent issue speak of the increase of american coal export and of the fall off of the english coal export to cuba say
 it be another case of american competition the united states now supply cuba with about 150,000 ton of coal annually and there be every prospect of this trade increase as the forest of the island become exhausted and the use of steam machinery on the sugar estate be develop alabama coal especially be secure a reputation in the spanish west indies and the river and rail improvement of the southern states will undoubtedly create an important gulf trade
 the new reciprocity policy by which the united states be enable to import cuban sugar will of course assist the american coal exporter even more effectively than the new line of railway
 the democratic platform promise a repeal of the tariff law contain this provision and especially denounce as a sham reciprocity that section of the law under which these trade arrangement have be make if no other issue be involve in the campaign this alone would give it momentous importance
 be the farmer of the great grain grow states willing to surrender these new large and increase market for their surplus be we to have nothing in exchange for the free importation of sugar and coffee and at the same time to destroy the sugar planter of the south and the beet sugar industry of the northwest and of the pacific coast or be we to have the tax sugar and coffee which a tariff for revenue only necessarily involve with the add loss of the new market which have be open
 as i have show our own commercial rival in europe do not regard this reciprocity policy as a sham but as a serious threat to a trade supremacy they have long enjoy they would rejoice mdash and if prudence do not restrain would illuminate their depressed manufacturing cities&mdash;over the news that the united states have abandon its system of protection and reciprocity they see very clearly that restriction of american production and trade and a corresponding increase of european production and trade would follow and i will not believe that what be so plain to they can be hide from our own people
 the declaration of the platform in favor of the american doctrine of protection meet my most hearty approval the convention do not adopt a schedule but a principle that be to control all tariff schedule there may be difference of opinion among protectionist as to the rate upon particular article necessary to effect an equalization between wage abroad and at home in some not remote national campaign the issue have be or more correctly have be make to appear to be between a high and a low protective tariff both party express some solicitous regard for the wage of our work people and for the prosperity of our domestic industry
 but under a more courageous leadership the democratic party have now practically declare that if give power it will enact a tariff law without any regard to its effect upon wage or upon the capital invest in our great industry the majority report of the committee on platform to the democratic national convention at chicago contain this clause
 that when custom house taxation be levy upon article of any kind produce in this country the difference between the cost of labor here and labor abroad when such a difference exist fully measure any possible benefit to labor and the enormous additional imposition of the exist tariff fall with crush force upon our farmer and work man
 here we have a distinct admission of the republican contention that american workman be advantage by a tariff rate equal to the difference between home and foreign wage and a declaration only against the alleged additional imposition of the exist tariff law again this majority report far declare but in make a reduction in taxis it be not propose to injure any domestic industry but rather to promote their healthy growth moreover many industry have come to rely upon legislation for successful continuance so that any change of law must be at every step regardful of the labor and the capital thus involve
 here we have an admission that many of our industry depend upon protective duty for their successful continuance and a declaration that tariff change should be regardful of the workman in such industry and of the invest capital
 the overwhelming rejection of these proposition which have before receive the sanction of democratic national convention be not more indicative of the new and more courageous leadership to which the party have now commit itself than the substitute which be adopt this substitute declare that protective duty be unconstitutional mdash high protection low protection&mdash;all unconstitutional
 a democratic congress hold this view can not enact nor a democratic president approve any tariff schedule the purpose or effect of which be to limit importation or to give any advantage to an american workman or producer a bounty might i judge be give to the importer under this view of the constitution in order to increase importation and so the revenue for revenue only be the limitation reciprocity of course fall under this denunciation for its object and effect be not revenue but the promotion of commercial exchange the profit of which go wholly to our producer
 this destructive un american doctrine be not hold or teach by the historic democratic statesman whose fame as american patriot have reach this generation mdash certainly not by jefferson or jackson this mad crusade against american shop the bitter epithet apply to american manufacturer the persistent disbelief of every report of the opening of a tin plate mill or of an increase of our foreign trade by reciprocity be as surprising as they be discreditable
 there be not a thoughtful business man in the country who do not know that the enactment into law of the declaration of the chicago convention upon the subject of the tariff would at once plunge the country into a business convulsion such as it have never see and there be not a thoughtful workingman who do not know that it would at once enormously reduce the amount of work to be do in this country by the increase of importation that would follow and necessitate a reduction of his wage to the european standard
 if any one suggest that this radical policy will not be execute if the democratic party attain power what shall be think of a party that be capable of thus trifle with great interest the threat of such legislation would be only less hurtful than the fact
 a distinguished democrat rightly describe this movement as a challenge to the protect industry to a fight of extermination and another such rightly express the logic of the situation when he interpret the chicago platform to be an invitation to all democrats hold even the most moderate protection view to go into the republican party
 and now a few word in regard to the exist tariff law we be fortunately able to judge of its influence upon production and price by the market report the day of the prophet of calamity have be succeed by that of the trade reporter
 an examination into the effect of the law upon the price of protect product and of the cost of such article as enter into the living of people of small mean have be make by a senate committee compose of lead senators of both party with the aid of the good statistician and the report sign by all the member of the committee have be give to the public no such wide and careful inquiry have ever before be make these fact appear from the report
 first the cost of article enter into the use of those earn less than $ 1,000 per annum have decrease up to may 1892 3.4 per cent while in farm product there have be an increase in price owe in part to an increase foreign demand and the opening of new market
 in england during the same period the cost of living increase 1 9 per cent test by their power to purchase article of necessity the earning of our work people have never be as great as they be now
 second there have be an average advance in the rate of wage of .75 of 1 per cent
 third there have be an advance in the price of all farm product of 18.67 per cent and of all cereal 33.59 per cent
 the ninth annual report of the chief of the bureau of labor statistic of the state of new york a democratic officer very recently issue strongly corroborate as to that state the fact find by the senate committee his extended inquiry show that in the year immediately follow the passage of the tariff act of 1890 the aggregate sum pay in wage in that state be $ 6,377,925 in excess and the aggregate production $ 31,315,130111 excess of the precede year
 in view of this showing of an increase in wage of a reduction in the cost of article of common necessity and of a marked advance in the price of agricultural product it be plain that this tariff law have not impose burden but have confer benefit upon the farmer and the workingman
 some special effect of the act should be notice it be a courageous attempt to rid our people of a long maintain foreign monopoly in the production of tin plate pearl button silk plush linen lace etc once or twice in our history the production of tin plate have be attempt and the price obtain by the welsh maker would have enable our maker to produce it at a profit but the welsh maker at once cut price to a point that drive the american beginner out of the business and when this be accomplish again make their own price
 a correspondent of the industrial world the official organ of the welsh tin plate worker publish at swansea in the issue of june 10 1892 advise a new trial of these method he say
 do not be deceive the victory of the republicans at the poll mean the retention of the mckinley bill and mean the rapidly accruing loss of the 80 per cent of the export american trade have there be no democratic victory in 1890 the spread of the tin plate manufacture in the united states would have be both rapid and bona fide it be not yet too late to do something to reduce the price of plate put they down to 11 shilling per box of 100,14 by 20 full weight basis let the workman lake half pay for a few month and turn out more then let the master forego profit for the same time
 and again that paper say
 it be clearly the interest of both employer and workman to produce tin plate tariff or no tariff at a price that will drive all competitor from the field
 but in spite of the doubt raise by the election of 1890 and of the machination of foreign producer to maintain their monopoly the tin plate industry have be establish in the united states and the alliance between the welsh producer and the democratic party for its destruction will not succeed
 the official return to the treasury department of the production of tin and terne plate in the united states during the last fiscal year show a total production of 13,240,830 pound and a comparison of the first quarter 826,922 pound with the last 8,000,000 pound show the rapid development of the industry over 5,000,000 pound during the last quarter be make from american black plate the remainder from foreign plate
 mr. ayer the treasury agent in charge estimate as the result of careful inquiry that the production of the current year will be 100,000,000 pound and that by the end of the year our production will be at the rate of 200,000,000 pound per annum
 another industry that have be practically create by the mckinley bill be the making of pearl button few article come to we from abroad be so distinctly the product of starvation wage
 but without unduly extend this letter i can not follow in detail the influence of the tariff law of 1890 it have transplant several important industry and establish they here and have revive or enlarge all other the act give to the miner protection against foreign silver bear lead ore the free introduction of which threaten the great mining industry of the rocky mountain states and to the wool grower protection for their fleece and flock which have save they from a further and disastrous decline the house of representatives at its last session pass bill place these ore and wool upon the free list the people of the west will know how destructive to their prosperity these measure would be
 this tariff law have give employment to many thousand of american man and woman and will each year give employment to increase thousand its repeal would throw thousand out of employment and give work to other only at reduce wage the appeal of the free trader to the workingman be largely address to his prejudice or to his passion and not infrequently be pronouncedly communistic the new democratic leadership rage at the employer and seek to communicate his rage to the employee i greatly regret that all employer of labor be not just and considerate and that capital sometimes take too large a share of the profit but i do not see that these evil will be ameliorate by a tariff policy the first necessary effect of which be a severe wage cut and the second a large diminution of the aggregate amount of work to be do in this country
 if the injustice of his employer tempt the workman to strike back he should be very sure that his blow do not fall upon his own head or upon his wife and child the workman in our great industry be as a body remarkably intelligent and be lover of home and country they may be rouse by injustice or what seem to they to be such or be lead for the moment by other into act of passion but they will settle the tariff contest in the calm light of their november fireside and with sole reference to the prosperity of the country of which they be citizen and of the home they have found for their wife and child
 no intelligent advocate of a protective tariff claim that it be able of itself to maintain a uniform rate of wage without regard to fluctuation in the supply of and demand for the product of labor but it be confidently claim that protective duty strongly tend to hold up wage and be the only barrier against a reduction to the european scale
 the southern states have have a liberal participation in the benefit of the tariff law and though their representative have generally oppose the protection policy i rejoice that their sugar rice coal ore iron fruit cotton cloth and other product have not be leave to the fate which the vote of their representative would have bring upon they
 in the construction of the nicaragua canal in the new trade with south and central america in the establishment of american steamship line these states have also special interest and all these interest will not always consent to be without representation at washington
 shrewdly but not quite fairly our adversary speak only of the increase duty impose upon tin pearl button and other article by the mckinley bill and omit altogether any reference to the great and beneficial enlargement of the free list during the last fiscal year $ 458,000,772 worth of merchandise or 55.35 per cent of our total importation come in free the large per centage in our history while in 1889 the per cent of free importation be only 34.42
 the placing of sugar upon the free list have save to the consumer in duty in fifteen month after pay the bounty provide for $ 87,000,000 this relief have be substantially feel in even&#39 household upon every saturday&#39;s purchase of the workingman per cent
 one of the favorite argument against a protective tariff be that it shut we out from a participation in what be call with swell emphasis the market of the world if this view be not a false one how do it happen that our commercial competitor be not able to bear with more serenity our suppose surrender to they of the market of the world and how do it happen that the partial loss of our market close foreign tin plate mill and plush factory that still have all other market
 our natural advantage our protective tariff and the reciprocity policy make it possible for we to have a large participation in the market of the world without open our own to a competition that would destroy the comfort and independence of our people
 the resolution of the convention in favor of bimetalism declare i think the true and necessary condition of a movement that have upon these line my cordial adherence and support i be thoroughly convinced that the free coinage of silver at such a ratio to gold as will maintain the equality in their commercial use of the two coin dollar would conduce to the prosperity of all the great producing and commercial nation of the world
 the one essential condition be that these dollar shall have and retain an equal acceptability and value in all commercial transaction they be not only a medium of exchange but a measure of value and when two unequal measure be call in law by the same name commerce be unsettled and confused and the unwary and ignorant be cheat dollar of unequal commercial value will not circulate together the well dollar be withdraw and become merchandise
 the true interest of all our people and especially of the farmer and work people who can not closely observe the money market be that every dollar paper or coin issue or authorize by the government shall at all time and in all its use be the exact equivalent not only in debt pay but in purchase power of any other dollar
 i be quite sure that if we should now act upon this subject independently of other nation we would greatly promote their interest and injure our own the monetary condition in europe within the last two year have i think tend very much to develop a sentiment in favor of a large use of silver and i be much pleased and encourage by the cordiality promptness and unanimity with which the invitation of this government for an international conference upon this subject be accept by all the power we may not only hope for but expect highly beneficial result from this conference which will now soon assemble when the result of the conference be know we shall then be able intelligently to readjust our financial legislation to any new condition
 in my last annual message to congress i say
 i must yet entertain the hope that it be possible to secure a calm patriotic consideration of such constitutional or statutory change as may be necessary to secure the choice of the officer of the government to the people by fair apportionment and free election i believe it would be possible to constitute a commission nonpartisan in its membership and compose of patriotic wise and impartial man to whom a consideration of the question of the evil connect with our election system and method might be commit with a good prospect of secure unanimity in some plan for remove or mitigate those evil
 the constitution would permit the selection of the commission to be vest in the supreme court if that method would give the good guaranty of impartiality this commission should be charge with the duty of inquire into the whole subject of the law of election as relate to the choice of officer of the national government with a view to secure to every elector a free and unmolested exercise of the suffrage and as near an approach to an equality of value in each ballot cast as be attainable the demand that the limitation of suffrage shall be find in the law and only there be a just demand and no just man should resent or resist it
 it seem to i that an appeal to our people to consider the question of readjust our legislation upon absolutely fair non- partisan line might find some effective response many time i have have occasion to say that law and election method design to give unfair advantage to the party make they would some time be use to perpetuate in power a faction of a party against the will of a majority of the people
 of this we seem to have an illustration in the recent state election in alabama there be no republican ticket in the field the contest be between white democrats the kolb party say they be refuse the representation guarantee by law upon the election board and that when the court by mandamus attempt to right this wrong an appeal that could not be hear until after the election make the writ ineffectual ballot box be throw out for alleged irregularity or destroy and it be assert on behalf of one half at least of the white voter of alabama that the officer to whom certificate have be give be not honestly elect
 there be no security for the personal or political right of any man in a community where any other man be deprive of his personal or political right the power of the states over the question of the qualification of elector be ample to protect they against the danger of an ignorant or depraved suffrage and the demand that every man find to be qualified under the law shall be make secure in the right to cast a free ballot and to have that ballot honestly count can not be abate
 our old republican battle cry a free ballot and a fair count come back to we not only from alabama but from other states and from man who differ with we widely in opinion have come to see that party and political debate be but a mockery if when the debate be end the judgment of honest majority be to be reverse by ballot box fraud and tally sheet manipulation in the interest of the party or party faction in power
 these new political movement in the states and the recent decision of some of the state court against unfair apportionment law encourage the hope that the arbitrary and partisan election law and practice which have prevail may be correct by the states the law make equal and nonpartisan and the election free and honest the republican party would rejoice at such a solution as a healthy and patriotic local sentiment be the good assurance of free and honest election
 i shall again urge upon congress that provision be make for the appointment of a nonpartisan commission to consider the subject of apportionment and election in their relation to the choice of federal officer
 the civil service system have be extend and law enforce with vigor and impartiality there have be no partisan juggling with the law in any of the department or bureau as have before happen but appointment to the classified service have be make impartially from the eligible list the system now in force in all the department have for the first time place promotion strictly upon the basis of merit as ascertain by a daily record and the efficiency of the force thereby greatly increase
 the approval so heartily give by the convention to all those agency which contribute to the education of the child of the land be worthily bestow and meet my hearty approval as do also the declaration as to liberty of thought and conscience and the separation of church and state
 the safety of the republic be an intelligent citizenship and the increase interest manifest in the states in education the cheerfulness with which the necessary taxis be pay by all class and the renew interest manifest by the child in the national flag be hopeful indication that the come generation will direct public affair with increase prudence and patriotism
 our interest in free public school open to all child of suitable age be supreme and our care for they will be jealous and constant the public school system however be not intend to restrain the natural right of the parent after contribute to the public school fund to choose other educational agency for his child
 i favor aid by the general government to the public school with a special view to the necessity of some of the southern states but it be gratify to notice that many of these state be with commendable liberality develop their school system and increase their school revenue to the great advantage of the child of both race
 the considerate attention of the farmer of the whole country be invite to the work do through the state and agricultural departments in the interest of agriculture our pork product have for ten year be not only exclude by the great continental nation of europe but their value discredit by the reason give for this exclusion all previous effort to secure the removal of these restriction have fail but the wise legislation of the fifty first congress provide for the inspection and official certification of our meat and give to the president power to forbid the introduction into this country of select product of such country as should continue to refuse our inspect meat enable we to open all the market of europe to our pork product the result have be not only to sustain price by provide new market for our surplus but to add fifty cent per one hundred pound to the market value of the inspect meat
 under the reciprocity agreement special favor have be secure for agricultural product and our export of such product have be greatly increase with a sure prospect of a further and rapid increase the agricultural department have maintain in europe an agent whose special duty it be to introduce there the various preparation of corn as article of food and his work have be very successful
 the department have also send skilled veterinarian to liverpool to examine in connection with the british veterinarian the live cattle from the united states land at that port and the result in connection with the sanitary method adopt at home have be that we hear no more about our cattle be infect with pleuro pneumonia a judicious system of quarantine line have prevent the infection of northern cattle with the texas fever
 the tariff bill of 1890 give well protection to farm product subject to foreign competition than they ever have before and the home market for such product have be enlarge by the establishment of new industry and the development of other
 we may confidently submit to the intelligent and candid judgment of the american farmer whether in any corresponding period so much have be do to promote his interest and whether in a continuance and extension of these method there be not a well prospect offer to he than in the invitation of the democratic party to give our home market to foreign manufacturer and to abandon the reciprocity policy and well also than the radical and untried method of relief propose by other party which be solicit his support
 i have often express my strong conviction of the value of the nicaragua ship canal to our commerce and to our navy the project be not one of convenience but of necessity it be quite possible i believe if the united states will support the enterprise to secure the speedy completion of the canal without tax the treasury for any direct contribution and at the same time to secure to the united states that influence in its management which be imperative
 it have be the purpose of the administration to make its foreign policy not a matter of partisan politic but of patriotism and national honor and i have very great gratification in be able to state that the democratic member of the committees of foreign affairs respond in a true american spirit i have not hesitate to consult freely with they about the most confidential and delicate affair and here frankly confess my obligation for needed cooperation they do not regard a patient but firm insistence upon american right and upon immunity from insult and injury for our citizen and sailor in foreign port as a policy of irritation and bluster they do not believe as some other seem to believe that to be a democrat one must take the foreign side of every international question if a republican administration be conduct the american side i do not believe that a tame submission to insult and outrage by any nation at the hand of another can ever form the basis of a last friendship the necessary element of mutual respect will be want
 the chilean incident now so happily and honorably adjust will i do not doubt place our relation with that brave people upon a more friendly basis than ever before this already appear in the agreement since negotiate by mr. egan for the settlement by a commission of the long unsettled claim between the two government the work of mr. egan have be highly advantageous to the united states the confidence which i refuse to withdraw from he have be abundantly justify
 in our relation with the great european power the right of the united states and of our citizen have be insist upon with firmness the strength of our cause and not the strength of our adversary have give tone to our correspondence
 the samoan question and the bering sea question which come over from the precede administration have be the one settle and the other submit to arbitration upon a fair basis
 never before i think in a like period have so many important treaty and commercial agreement be conclude and never before i be sure have the honor and influence national and commercial of the united states be hold in high estimation in both hemisphere
 the union soldier and sailor be now veteran of time as well as of war the parallel of age have approach close to the citadel of life and the end for each of a brave and honorable struggle be not remote increase infirmity and year give the minor tone of sadness and pathos to the mighty appeal of service and suffering the ear that do not listen with sympathy and the heart that do not respond with generosity be the ear and heart of an alien and not of an american now soon again the survive veteran be to parade upon the great avenue of the national capital and every tribute of honor and love should attend the march a comrade in the column of the victors&#39 parade in 1865 i be not less a comrade now
 i have use every suitable occasion to urge upon the people of all section the consideration that no good cause can 1&gt;e promote upon the line of lawlessness mob do not discriminate and the punishment inflict by they have no repressive or salutary influence on the contrary they beget revenge and perpetuate feud it be especially the duty of the educate and influential to see that the weak and ignorant when accuse of crime be fairly try before lawful tribunal the moral sentiment of the country should be arouse and bring to bear for the suppression of these offense against the law and social order
 the necessity for a careful discrimination among the emigrant seek our shore become every day more apparent we do not want and should not receive those who by reason of bad character or habit be not want at home the industrious and self respecting the lover of law and liberty should be discriminate from the pauper the criminal and the anarchist who come only to burden and disturb our community every effort have be make to enforce the law and some conviction have be secure under the contract labor law
 the general condition of our country be one of great prosperity the blessing of god have rest upon our field and upon our people the annual value of our foreign commerce have increase more than $ 400,000,000 over the average for the precede ten year and more than $ 210,000,000 over 1890 the last year unaffected by the new tariff our export in 1892 exceed those of 1890 by more than $ 172,000,000 and the annual average for ten year by $ 265,000,000 our export of breadstuff increase over those of 1890 more than $ 144,000,000 of provision over $ 4,000,000 and of manufacture over $ 8,000,000 the merchandise balance of trade in our favor in 1892 be $ 202,944,342
 no other nation can match the commercial progress which these figure disclose our compassion may well go out to those whose party necessity and habit still compel they to declare that our people be oppress and our trade restrict by a protective tariff
 it be not possible for i to refer even in the brief way to many of the topic present in the resolution adopt by the convention upon all that have not be discuss i have before publicly express my view
 a change in the personnel of a national administration be of comparatively little moment if those exercise public function be able honest diligent and faithful other possess all these quality may be find to take their place but change in the law and administrative policy be of great moment when public affair have be give a direction and business have adjust itself to these line any sudden change involve a stoppage and new business adjustment if the change of direction be so radical as to bring the commercial turn table into use the business change involve be not readjustment but reconstruction
 the democratic party offer a programme of demolition the protective policy mdash to which all business even that of the importer be now adjust mdash the reciprocity policy the new merchant marine be all to be demolish not gradually not take down but blow up to this programme of destruction it have add one constructive feature the reestablishment of state bank of issue
 the policy of the republican party be on the other hand distinctively a policy of safe progression and development&mdash;of new factory new market and new ship it will subject business to no perilous change but offer attractive opportunity for expansion upon familiar line
 very respectfully your
 bej harrison
 washington d.c.
 september 3 1892

to the senate and house of representatives in submit my annual message to congress i have great satisfaction in be able to say that the general condition affect the commercial and industrial interest of the united states be in the high degree favorable a comparison of the exist condition with those of the most favor period in the history of the country will i believe show that so high a degree of prosperity and so general a diffusion of the comfort of life be never before enjoy by our people the total wealth of the country in 1860 be $ 16,159,616,068 in 1890 it amount to $ 62,610,000,000 an increase of 287 per cent the total mileage of railway in the united states in 1860 be 30,626 in 1890 it be 167,741 an increase of 448 per cent and it be estimate that there will be about 4,000 mile of track add by the close of the year 1892.the official return of the eleventh census and those of the tenth census for seventy five lead city furnish the basis for the following comparison in 1880 the 2,251,134.in 1880 the wage earn be $ 501,965,778.in 1890 the wage earn be $ 1,221,170,454.in 1880 the value of the product be $ 2,711,579,899.in 1890 the value of the product be $ 4,860,286,837.i am inform by the superintendent of the census that the omission of certain industry in 1880 which be include in 1890 account in part for the remarkable increase thus show but after make full allowance for difference of method and deduct the return for all industry not include in the census of 1880 there remain in the report from these seventy five city an increase in the capital employ of $ 1,522,745,604 in the value of the product of $ 2,024,236,166 in wage earn of $ 677,943,929 and in the number of wage earner employ of 856,029 the wage earning not only show an increase aggregate but to the senate and house of representatives
 in submit my annual message to congress i have great satisfaction in be able to say that the general condition affect the commercial and industrial interest of the united states be in the high degree favorable a comparison of the exist condition with those of the most favor period in the history of the country will i believe show that so high a degree of prosperity and so general a diffusion of the comfort of life be never before enjoy by our people

 i believe that the protective system which have now for something more than thirty year continuously prevail in our legislation have be a mighty instrument for the development of our national wealth and a most powerful agency in protect the home of our workingman from the invasion of want i have feel a most solicitous interest to preserve to our work people rate of wage that would not only give daily bread but supply a comfortable margin for those home attraction and family comfort and enjoyment without which life be neither hopeful nor sweet they be american citizen a part of the great people for whom our constitution and government be frame and institute and it can not be a perversion of that constitution to so legislate as to preserve in their home the comfort independence loyalty and sense of interest in the government which be essential to good citizenship in peace and which will bring this stalwart throng as in 1861 to the defense of the flag when it be assail
 it be not my purpose to renew here the argument in favor of a protective tariff the result of the recent election must be accept as having introduce a new policy we must assume that the present tariff construct upon the line of protection be to be repeal and that there be to be substitute for it a tariff law construct solely with reference to revenue that no duty be to be high because the increase will keep open an american mill or keep up the wage of an american workman but that in every case such a rate of duty be to be impose as will bring to the treasury of the united states the large return of revenue the contention have not be between schedule but between principle and it would be offensive to suggest that the prevail party will not carry into legislation the principle advocate by it and the pledge give to the people the tariff bill pass by the house of representatives at the last session be as i suppose even in the opinion of their promoter inadequate and justify only by the fact that the senate and house of representatives be not in accord and that a general revision could not therefore be undertake

of europe in motion and crowd our warehouse with foreign make good and at the same time keep our own mill busy that will give we an increase participation in the market of the world of great value than the home market we surrender that will give increase work to foreign workman upon product to be consume by our people without diminish the amount of work to be do here that will enable the american manufacturer to pay to his workman from 50 to 100 per cent more in wage than be pay in the foreign mill and yet to compete in our market and in foreign market with the foreign producer that will far reduce the cost of article of wear and food without reduce the wage of those who produce they that can be celebrate after its effect have be realize as its expectation have be in european as well as in american city the author and promoter of it will be entitle to the high praise we have have in our history several experience of the contrast effect of a revenue and of a protective tariff but this generation have not feel they and the experience of one generation be not highly instructive to the next the friend of the protective system with undiminished confidence in the principle they have advocate will await the result of the new experiment

 the report of the secretary of agriculture contain not only a most interesting statement of the progressive and valuable work do under the administration of secretary rusk but many suggestion for the enlarged usefulness of this important department in the successful effort to break down the restriction to the free introduction of our meat product in the country of europe the secretary have be untire from the first stimulate and aid all other government officer at home and abroad whose official duty enable they to participate in the work the total trade in hog product with europe in may 1892 amount to 82,000,000 pound against 46,900,000 in the same month of 1891 in june 1892 the export aggregate 85,700,000 pound against 46,500,000 pound in the same month of the previous year in july there be an increase of 41 per cent and in august of 55 per cent over the corresponding month of 1891 over 40,000,000 pound of inspect pork have be export since the law be put into operation and a comparison of the four month of may june july and august 1892 with the same month of 1891 show an increase in the number of pound of our export of pork product of 62 per cent and an increase in value of 66 1/2 per cent the export of dress beef increase from 137,900,000 pound in 1889 to 220,500,000 pound in 1892 or about 60 per cent during the past year there have be export 394,607 head of live cattle as against 205,786 export in 1889 this increase exportation have be largely promote by the inspection authorize by law and the faithful effort of the secretary and his efficient subordinate to make that inspection thorough and to carefully exclude from all cargo disease or suspect cattle the requirement of the english regulation that live cattle arrive from the united states must be slaughter at the dock have its origin in the claim that pleuro pneumonia exist among american cattle and that the existence of the disease could only certainly be determine by a post mortem inspection
 the department of agriculture have labor with great energy and faithfulness to extirpate this disease and on the 26th day of september last a public announcement be make by the secretary that the disease no long exist anywhere within the united states he be entirely satisfied after the most search inquiry that this statement be justify and that by a continuance of the inspection and quarantine now require of cattle bring into this country the disease can be prevent from again get any foothold the value to the cattle industry of the united states of this achievement can hardly be estimate we can not perhaps at once insist that this evidence shall be accept as satisfactory by other country but if the present exemption from the disease be maintain and the inspection of our cattle arrive at foreign port in which our own veterinarian participate confirm it we may justly expect that the requirement that our cattle shall be slaughter at the dock will be revoke as the sanitary restriction upon our pork product have be if our cattle can be take alive to the interior the trade will be enormously increase

 the subject of quarantine regulation inspection and control be bring suddenly to my attention by the arrival at our port in august last of vessel infect with cholera quarantine regulation should be uniform at all our port under the constitution they be plainly within the exclusive federal jurisdiction when and so far as congress shall legislate in my opinion the whole subject should be take into national control and adequate power give to the executive to protect our people against plague invasion on the 1st of september last i approve regulation establish a twenty day quarantine for all vessel bring immigrant from foreign port this order will be continue in force some loss and suffering have result to passenger but a due care for the home of our people justifie in such case the utmost precaution there be danger that with the coming of spring cholera will again appear and a liberal appropriation should be make at this session to enable our quarantine and port officer to exclude the deadly plague
 but the most careful and stringent quarantine regulation may not be sufficient absolutely to exclude the disease the progress of medical and sanitary science have be such however that if approve precaution be take at once to put all of our city and town in the good sanitary condition and provision be make for isolate any sporadic case and for a thorough disinfection an epidemic can i be sure be avoid this work appertain to the local authority and the responsibility and the penalty will be appal if it be neglect or unduly delay
 we be peculiarly subject in our great port to the spread of infectious disease by reason of the fact that unrestricted immigration bring to we out of european city in the overcrowded steerage of great steamship a large number of person whose surrounding make they the easy victim of the plague this consideration as well as those affect the political moral and industrial interest of our country lead i to renew the suggestion that admission to our country and to the high privilege of its citizenship should be more restricted and more careful we have i think a right and owe a duty to our own people and especially to our work people not only to keep out the vicious the ignorant the civil disturber the pauper and the contract laborer but to check the too great flow of immigration now come by further limitation

 the district of columbia be leave by a decision of the supreme court of the district without any law regulate the liquor traffic an old statute of the legislature of the district relate to the licensing of various vocation have hitherto be treat by the commissioners as give they power to grant or refuse license to sell intoxicate liquor and as subject those who sell without license to penalty but in may last the supreme court of the district hold against this view of the power of the commissioners it be of urgent importance therefore that congress should supply either by direct enactment or by confer discretionary power upon the commissioners proper limitation and restraint upon the liquor traffic in the district the district have suffer in its reputation by many crime of violence a large per cent of they result from drunkenness and the liquor traffic the capital of the nation should be free from this reproach by the enactment of stringent restriction and limitation upon the traffic

 i have in each of the three annual message which it have be my duty to submit to congress call attention to the evil and danger connect with our election method and practice as they be relate to the choice of officer of the national government in my last annual message i endeavor to invoke serious attention to the evil of unfair apportionment for congress i can not close this message without again call attention to these grave and threatening evil i have hope that it be possible to secure a nonpartisan inquiry by mean of a commission into evil the existence of which be know to all and that out of this might grow legislation from which all thought of partisan advantage should be eliminate and only the high thought appear of maintain the freedom and purity of the ballot and the equality of the elector without the guaranty of which the government could never have be form and without the continuance of which it can not continue to exist in peace and prosperity

 lawlessness be not less such but more where it usurp the function of the peace officer and of the court the frequent lynching of colored people accuse of crime be without the excuse which have sometimes be urge by mob for a failure to pursue the appoint method for the punishment of crime that the accuse have an undue influence over court and jury such act be a reproach to the community where they occur and so far as they can be make the subject of federal jurisdiction the strong repressive legislation be demand a public sentiment that will sustain the officer of the law in resist mob and in protect accuse person in their custody should be promote by every possible mean the officer who give his life in the brave discharge of this duty be worthy of special honor no lesson need to be so urgently impress upon our people as this that no worthy end or cause can be promote by lawlessness
 this exhibit of the work of the executive departments be submit to congress and to the public in the hope that there will be find in it a due sense of responsibility and an earnest purpose to maintain the national honor and to promote the happiness and prosperity of all our people and this brief exhibit of the growth and prosperity of the country will give we a level from which to note the increase or decadence that new legislative policy may bring to we there be no reason why the national influence power and prosperity should not observe the same rate of increase that have characterize the past thirty year we carry the great impulse and increase of these year into the future there be no reason why in many line of production we should not surpass all other nation as we have already do in some there be no near frontier to our possible development retrogression would be a crime

to the senate
 i transmit herewith with a view to its ratification a treaty of annexation conclude on the 14th day of february 1893 between john w. foster secretary of state who be duly empower to act in that behalf on the part of the united states and lorin a. thurston w. r. castle w. c. wilder c. l. carlet and joseph marsden the commissioner on the part of the government of the hawaiian islands the provisional treaty it will be observe do not attempt to deal in detail with the question that grow out of the annexation of the hawaiian islands to the united states the commissioner represent the hawaiian government have consent to leave to the future and to the just and benevolent purpose of the united states the adjustment of all such question
 i do not deem it necessary to discuss at any length the condition which have result in this decisive action it have be the policy of the administration not only to respect but to encourage the continuance of an independent government in the hawaiian islands so long as it afford suitable guaranty for the protection of life and property and maintain a stability and strength that give adequate security against the domination of any other power the moral support of this government have continually manifest itself in the most friendly diplomatic relation and in many act of courtesy to the hawaiian ruler
 the overthrow of the monarchy be not in any way promote by this government but have its origin in what seem to have be a reactionary and revolutionary policy on the part of queen liliuokalani which put in serious peril not only the large and preponderate interest of the united states in the island but all foreign interest and indeed the decent administration of civil affair and the peace of the island it be quite evident that the monarchy have become effete and the queen&#39;s government so weak and inadequate as to be the prey of design and unscrupulous person the restoration of queen liliuokalani to her throne be undesirable if not impossible and unless actively support by the united states would be accompany by serious disaster and the disorganization of all business interest the influence and interest of the united states in the island must be increase and not diminish
 only two course be now open one the establishment of a protectorate by the united states and the other annexation full and complete i think the latter course which have be adopt in the treaty will be highly promotive of the good interest of the hawaiian people and be the only one that will adequately secure the interest of the united states these interest be not wholly selfish it be essential that none of the other great power shall secure these island such a possession would not consist with our safety and with the peace of the world this view of the situation be so apparent and conclusive that no protest have be hear from any government against proceeding look to annexation every foreign representative at honolulu promptly acknowledge the provisional government and i think there be a general concurrence in the opinion that the deposed queen ought not to be restore
 prompt action upon this treaty be very desirable if it meet the approval of the senate peace and good order will be secure in the island under exist law until such time as congress can provide by legislation a permanent from of government for the island this legislation should be and i do not doubt will be not only just to the native and all other resident and citizen of the island but should be characterize by great liberality and a high regard to the right of all people and of all foreigner domicile there the correspondence which accompany the treaty will put the senate in possession of all the fact know to the executive
