common sense principle not only suit to this mundane sphere but whose application our people be more and more recognize to be absolutely essential to the most successful operation of their government if not to its perpetuity it seem to i to be entirely inconsistent with the character of this reform as well as with its good enforcement to oblige the commission to rely for clerical assistance upon clerk detail from other department there ought not to be such a condition in any department that clerk hire to do work there can be spare to habitually work at another place and it do not accord with a sensible view of civil service reform that person should be employ on the theory that their labor be necessary in one department when in point of fact their service be devoted to entirely different work in another department i earnestly urge that the clerk necessary to carry on the work of the commission be regularly put upon its roster and that the system of oblige the commissioners to rely upon the service of clerk belong to other departments be discontinue this ought not to increase the expense to the government while it would certainly be more consistent and add greatly to the efficiency of the commission economy in public expenditure be a duty that can not innocently be neglect by those intrust with the control of money draw from the people for public use it must be confess that our apparently endless resource the familiarity of our people with immense accumulation of wealth the grow sentiment among they that the expenditure of public money should in some manner be to their immediate and personal advantage the indirect and almost stealthy manner in which a large part of our taxis be exact and a degenerated sense of official accountability have lead to grow extravagance in governmental appropriation at this time when a deplete public treasury confront we when many of our people be engage in a hard struggle for the necessary of life and when enforce economy be press upon the great mass of our countryman i desire to urge with all the earnestness at my command that congressional legislation be so limited by strict economy as to exhibit an appreciation of the condition of the treasury and a sympathy with the straiten circumstance of our fellow citizen the duty of public economy be also of immense importance in its intimate and necessary relation to the task now in hand of provide revenue to meet government expenditure and yet reduce the people 's burden of federal taxation after a hard struggle tariff reform be directly before we nothing so important claim our attention and nothing so clearly present itself as both an opportunity and a duty an opportunity to deserve the gratitude of our fellow citizen and a duty impose upon we by our oft repeat profession and by the emphatic mandate of the people after full discussion our countryman have speak in favor of this reform and they have confide the work of its accomplishment to the hand of those who be solemnly pledge to it if there be anything in the theory of a representation in public place of the people and their desire if public officer be really the servant of the people and if political promise and profession have any bind force our failure to give the relief so long await will be sheer recreancy nothing should intervene to distract our attention or disturb our effort until this reform be accomplish by wise and careful legislation while we should stanchly adhere to the principle that only the necessity of revenue justify the imposition of tariff duty and other federal taxation and that they should be limit by strict economy we can not close our eye to the fact that condition have grow up among we which in justice and fairness call for discriminating care in the distribution of such duty and taxation as the emergency of our government actually demand manifestly if we be to aid the people directly through tariff reform one of its most obvious feature should be a reduction in present tariff charge upon the necessary of life the benefit of such a reduction would be palpable and substantial see and feel by thousand who would be well feed and well clothe and well shelter these gift should be the willing benefaction of a government whose high function be the promotion of the welfare of the people not less closely related to our people 's prosperity and well being be the removal of restriction upon the importation of the raw material necessary to our manufacture the world should be open to our national ingenuity and enterprise this can not be while federal legislation through the imposition of high tariff forbid to american manufacturer as cheap material as those use by their competitor it be quite obvious that the .enhancement of the price of our manufacture product result from this policy not only confine the market for these product within our own border to the direct disadvantage of our manufacturer but also increase their cost to our citizen the interest of labor be certainly though indirectly involve in this feature of our tariff system the sharp competition and active struggle among our manufacturer to supply the limited demand for their good soon fill the narrow market to which they be confine then follow a suspension of work in mill and factory a discharge of employee and distress in the home of our workingman even if the often disprove assertion could be make good that a low rate of wage would result from free raw material and low tariff duty the intelligence of our workman lead they quickly to discover that their steady employment permit by free raw material be the most important factor in their relation to tariff legislation a measure have be prepare by the appropriate congressional committee embody tariff reform on the line herein suggest which will be promptly submit for legislative action it be the result of much patriotic and unselfish work and i believe it deal with its subject consistently and as thoroughly as existing condition permit i be satisfied that the reduced tariff duty provide for in the propose legislation add to exist internal revenue taxation will in the near future though perhaps not immediately produce sufficient revenue to meet the need of the government the committee after full consideration and to provide against a temporary deficiency which may exist before the business of the country adjust itself to the new tariff schedule have wisely embrace in their plan a few additional internal revenue taxis include a small tax upon income derive from certain corporate investment these new adjustment be not only absolutely just and easily bear but they have the further merit of be such as can be remit without unfavorable business disturbance whenever the necessity of their imposition no long exist in my great desire for the success of this measure i can not restrain the suggestion that its success can only be attain by mean of unselfish counsel on the part of the friend of tariff reform and as a result of their willingness to subordinate personal desire and ambition to the general good the local interest affect by the propose reform be so numerous and so varied that if all be insist upon the legislation embody the reform must inevitably fail in conclusion my intense feeling of responsibility impel i to invoke for the manifold interest of a generous and confide people the most scrupulous care and to pledge my willing support to every legislative effort for the advancement of the greatness and prosperity of our beloved country
to the senate and house of representatives
 in my recent annual message to the congress i briefly refer to our relation with hawaii and express the intention of transmit further information on the subject when additional advice permit
 though i be not able now to report a definite change in the actual situation i be convinced that the difficulty lately create both here and in hawaii and now stand in the way of a solution through executive action of the problem present render it proper and expedient that the matter should be refer to the broad authority and discretion of congress with a full explanation of the endeavor thus far make to deal with the emergency and a statement of the consideration which have govern my action i suppose that right and justice should determine the path to be follow in treat this subject if national honesty be to be disregard and a desire for territorial extension or dissatisfaction with a form of government not our own ought to regulate our conduct i have entirely misapprehend the mission and character of our government and the behavior which the conscience of our people demand of their public servant
 when the present administration enter upon its duty the senate have under consideration a treaty provide for the annexation of the hawaiian islands to the territory of the united states surely under our constitution and law the enlargement of our limit be a manifestation of the high attribute of sovereignty and if enter upon as an executive act all thing relate to the transaction should be clear and free from suspicion additional importance attach to this particular treaty of annexation because it contemplate a departure from unbroken american tradition in provide for the addition to our territory of island of the sea more than 2,000 mile remove from our near coast
 these consideration might not of themselves call for interference with the completion of a treaty enter upon by a previous administration but it appear from the document accompany the treaty when submit to the senate that the ownership of hawaii be tender to we by a provisional government set up to succeed the constitutional ruler of the island who have be dethrone and it do not appear that such provisional government have the sanction of either popular revolution or suffrage two other remarkable feature of the transaction naturally attract attention one be the extraordinary haste not to say precipitancy characterize all the transaction connect with the treaty it appear that a so call committee of safety ostensibly the source of the revolt against the constitutional government of hawaii be organize on saturday the 14th day of january that on monday the 16th the united states force be land at honolulu from a naval vessel lie in its harbor that on the 17th the scheme of a provisional government be perfect and a proclamation name its officer be on the same day prepare and read at the government building that immediately thereupon the united states minister recognize the provisional government thus create that two day afterwards on the 19th day of january commissioner represent such government sail for this country in a steamer especially charter for the occasion arrive in san francisco on the 28th day of january and in washington on the 3d day of february that on the next day they have their first interview with the secretary of state and another on the 11th when the treaty of annexation be practically agree upon and that on the 14th it be formally conclude and on the 15th transmit to the senate thus between the initiation of the scheme for a provisional government in hawaii on the 14th day of january and the submission to the senate of the treaty of annexation conclude with such government the entire interval be thirty two day fifteen of which be spend by the hawaiian commissioner in their journey to washington
 in the next place upon the face of the paper submit with the treaty it clearly appear that there be open and undetermine an issue of fact of the most vital importance the message of the president accompany the treaty declare that the overthrow of the monarchy be not in any way promote by this government and in a letter to the president from the secretary of state also submit to the senate with the treaty the follow passage occur
 at the time the provisional government take possession of the government building no troop or officer of the united states be present or take any part whatever in the proceeding no public recognition be accord to the provisional government by the united states minister until after the queen&#39;s abdication and when they be in effective possession of the government building the archive the treasury the barrack the police station and all the potential machinery of the government
 but a protest also accompany say treaty sign by the queen and her minister at the time she make way for the provisional government which explicitly state that she yield to the superior force of the united states whose minister have cause united states troop to be land at honolulu and declare that he would support such provisional government
 the truth or falsity of this protest be surely of the first importance if true nothing but the concealment of its truth could induce our government to negotiate with the semblance of a government thus create nor could a treaty result from the act state in the protest have be knowingly deem worthy of consideration by the senate yet the truth or falsity of the protest have not be investigate
 i conceive it to be my duty therefore to withdraw the treaty from the senate for examination and meanwhile to cause an accurate full and impartial investigation to be make of the fact attend the subversion of the constitutional government of hawaii and the installment in its place of the provisional government i select for the work of investigation the hon james h. blount of georgia whose service of eighteen year as a member of the house of representatives and whose experience as chairman of the committee of foreign affairs in that body and his consequent familiarity with international topic join with his high character and honorable reputation seem to render he peculiarly fit for the duty intrust to he his report detail his action under the instruction give to he and the conclusion derive from his investigation accompany this message
 these conclusion do not rest for their acceptance entirely upon mr. blount&#39;s honesty and ability as a man nor upon his acuman and impartiality as an investigator they be accompany by the evidence upon which they be base which evidence be also herewith transmit and from which it seem to i no other deduction could possibly be reach than those arrive at by the commissioner
 the report with its accompany proof and such other evidence as be now before the congress or be herewith submit justifie in my opinion the statement that when the president be lead to submit the treaty to the senate with the declaration that the overthrow of the monarchy be not in any way promote by this government and when the senate be induce to receive and discuss it on that basis both president and senate be mislead
 the attempt will not be make in this communication to touch upon all the fact which throw light upon the progress and consummation of this scheme of annexation a very brief and imperfect reference to the fact and evidence at hand will exhibit its character and the incident in which it have its birth
 it be unnecessary to set forth the reason which in january 1893 lead a considerable proportion of american and other foreign merchant and trader reside at honolulu to favor the annexation of hawaii to the united states it be sufficient to note the fact and to observe that the project be one which be zealously promote by the minister represent the united states in that country he evidently have an ardent desire that it should become a fact accomplish by his agency and during his ministry and be not inconveniently scrupulous as to the mean employ to that end on the 19th day of november 1892 nearly two month before the first overt act tend toward the subversion of the hawaiian government and the attempt transfer of hawaiian territory to the united states he address a long letter to the secretary of state in which the case for annexation be elaborately argue on moral political and economical ground he refer to the loss to the hawaiian sugar interest from the operation of the mckinley bill and the tendency to still further depreciation of sugar property unless some positive measure of relief be grant he strongly inveigh against the exist hawaiian government and emphatically declare for annexation he say
 in truth the monarchy here be an absurd anachronism it have nothing on which it logically or legitimately stand the feudal basis on which it once stand no long exist the monarchy now be only an impediment to good government an obstruction to the prosperity and progress of the island
 he far say
 as a crown colony of great britain or a territory of the united states the government modification could be make readily and good administration of the law secure destiny and the vast future interest of the united states in the pacific clearly indicate who at no distant day must be responsible for the government of these island under a territorial government they could be as easily govern as any of the exist territory of the united states hawaii have reach the parting of the way she must now take the road which lead to asia or the other which outlet she in america give she an american civilization and bind she to the care of american destiny
 he also declare
 one of two course seem to i absolutely necessary to be follow either bold and vigorous measure for annexation or a custom union an ocean cable from the californian coast to honolulu pearl harbor perpetually cede to the united states with an imply but not expressly stipulate american protectorate over the island i believe the former to be the well that which will prove much the more advantageous to the island and the cheap and least embarrassing in the end to the united states if it be wise for the united states through secretary marcy thirty eight year ago to offer to expend $ 100,000 to secure a treaty of annexation it certainly can not be chimerical or unwise to expend $ 100,000 to secure annexation in the near future to day the united states have five time the wealth she possess in 1854 and the reason now exist for annexation be much strong than they be then i can not refrain from express the opinion with emphasis that the golden hour be near at hand
 these declaration certainly show a disposition and condition of mind which may be usefully recall when interpret the significance of the minister&#39; concede act or when consider the probability of such conduct on his part as may not be admit
 in this view it seem proper to also quote from a letter write by the minister to the secretary of state on the 8th day of march 1892 nearly a year prior to the first step take toward annexation after state the possibility that the exist government of hawaii might be overturn by an orderly and peaceful revolution minister stevens write as follow
 ordinarily in like circumstance the rule seem to be to limit the landing and movement of united states force in foreign water and dominion exclusively to the protection of the united states legation and of the life and property of american citizen but as the relation of the united states to hawaii be exceptional and in former year the united states official here take somewhat exceptional action in circumstance of disorder i desire to know how far the present minister and naval commander may deviate from established international rule and precedent in the contingency indicate in the first part of this dispatch
 to a minister of this temper full of zeal for annexation there seem to arise in january 1893 the precise opportunity for which he be watchfully wait an opportunity which by timely deviation from established international rule and precedent might be improve to successfully accomplish the great object in view and we be quite prepared for the exultant enthusiasm with which in a letter to the state department date february 1 1893 he declare
 the hawaiian pear be now fully ripe and this be the golden hour for the united states to pluck it
 as a further illustration of the activity of this diplomatic representative attention be call to the fact that on the day the above letter be write apparently unable long to restrain his ardor he issue a proclamation whereby in the name of the united states he assume the protection of the hawaiian islands and declare that say action be take pende and subject to negotiation at washington of course this assumption of a protectorate be promptly disavow by our government but the american flag remain over the government building at honolulu and the force remain on guard until april and after mr. blount&#39;s arrival on the scene when both be remove
 a brief statement of the occurrence that lead to the subversion of the constitutional government of hawaii in the interest of annexation to the united states will exhibit the true complexion of that transaction
 on saturday january 14 1893 the queen of hawaii who have be contemplate the proclamation of a new constitution have in deference to the wish and remonstrance of her cabinet renounce the project for the present at least take this relinquished purpose as a basis of action citizen of honolulu number from fifty to one hundred mostly resident alien meet in a private office and select a so call committee of safety compose of thirteen person seven of whom be foreign subject and consist of five americans one englishman and one german this committee though its design be not reveal have in view nothing less than annexation to the united states and between saturday the 14th and the follow monday the 16th of january though exactly what action be take may not be clearly disclose they be certainly in communication with the united states minister on monday morning the queen and her cabinet make public proclamation with a notice which be specially serve upon the representative of all foreign government that any change in the constitution would be seek only in the method provide by that instrument nevertheless at the call and under the auspex of the committee of safety a mass meeting of citizen be hold on that day to protest against the queen&#39;s allege illegal and unlawful proceeding and purpose even at this meeting the committee of safety continue to disguise their real purpose and content themselves with procure the passage of a resolution denounce the queen and empower the committee to devise way and mean to secure the permanent maintenance of law and order and the protection of life liberty and property in hawaii this meeting adjourn between 3 and 4 o&#39;clock in the afternoon on the same day and immediately after such adjournment the committee unwilling to take further step without the cooperation of the united states minister address he a note represent that the public safety be menace and that life and property be in danger and conclude as follow
 we be unable to protect ourselves without aid and therefore pray for the protection of the united states force
 whatever may be think of the other content of this note the absolute truth of this latter statement be incontestable when the note be write and deliver the committee so far as it appear have neither a man nor a gun at their command and after its delivery they become so panic stricken at their position that they send some of their number to interview the minister and request he not to land the united states force till the next morning but he reply that the troop have be order and whether the committee be ready or not the landing should take place and so it happen that on the 16th day of january 1893 between 4 and 5 o&#39;clock in the afternoon a detachment of marine from the united states steamer boston with two piece of artillery land at honolulu the man upward of 160 in all be supply with double cartridge belt fill with ammunition and with haversack and canteen and be accompany by a hospital corps with stretcher and medical supply
 this military demonstration upon the soil of honolulu be of itself an act of war unless make either with the consent of the government of hawaii or for the bona fide purpose of protect the imperil life and property of citizen of the united states but there be no pretense of any such consent on the part of the government of the queen which at that time be undisputed and be both the de facto and the de jure government in point of fact the exist government instead of request the presence of an armed force protest against it there be as little basis for the pretense that such force be land for the security of american life and property if so they would have be station in the vicinity of such property and so as to protect it instead of at a distance and so as to command the hawaiian government building and palace admiral skerrett the officer in command of our naval force on the pacific station have frankly state that in his opinion the location of the troop be inadvisable if they be land for the protection of american citizen whose residence and place of business as well as the legation and consulate be in a distant part of the city but the location select be a wise one if the force be land for the purpose of support the provisional government if any peril to life and property call for any such martial array have exist great britain and other foreign power interested would not have be behind the united states in activity to protect their citizen but they make no sign in that direction when these armed man be land the city of honolulu be in its customary orderly and peaceful condition there be no symptom of riot or disturbance in any quarter man woman and child be about the street as usual and nothing vary the ordinary routine or disturb the ordinary tranquillity except the landing of the boston&#39;s marines and their march through the town to the quarter assign they indeed the fact that after having call for the landing of the united states force on the plea of danger to life and property the committee of safety themselves request the minister to postpone action expose the untruthfulness of their representation of present peril to life and property the peril they see be an anticipation grow out of guilty intention on their part and something which though not then exist they know would certainly follow their attempt to overthrow the government of the queen without the aid of the united states force
 thus it appear that hawaii be take possession of by the united states force without the consent or wish of the government of the island or of anybody else so far as show except the united states minister therefore the military occupation of honolulu by the united states on the day mention be wholly without justification either as an occupation by consent or as an occupation necessitate by danger threaten american life and property it must be account for in some other way and on some other ground and its real motive and purpose be neither obscure nor far to seek
 the united states force be now on the scene and favorably station the committee proceed to carry out their original scheme they meet the next morning tuesday the 17th perfect the plan of temporary government and fix upon its principal officer ten of whom be draw from the thirteen member of the committee of safety between 1 and 2 o&#39;clock by squad and by different route to avoid notice and having first take the precaution of ascertain whether there be anyone there to oppose they they proceed to the government building to proclaim the new government no sign of opposition be manifest and thereupon an american citizen begin to read the proclamation from the step of the government building almost entirely without auditor it be say that before the reading be finish quite a concourse of person variously estimate at from 50 to 100 some armed and some unarmed gather about the committee to give they aid and confidence this statement be not important since the one control factor in the whole affair be unquestionably the united states marine who draw up under arm and with artillery in readiness only 76 yard distant dominate the situation
 the provisional government thus proclaim be by the term of the proclamation to exist until term of union with the united states have be negotiate and agree upon the united states minister pursuant to prior agreement recognize this government within an hour after the reading of the proclamation and before 5 o&#39;clock in answer to an inquiry on behalf of the queen and her cabinet announce that he have do so
 when our minister recognize the provisional government the only basis upon which it rest be the fact that the committee of safety have in the manner above state declare it to exist it be neither a government de fato nor de jure that it be not in such possession of the government property and agency as entitle it to recognition be conclusively prove by a note find in the file of the legation at honolulu address by the declare head of the provisional government to minister stevens date january 17 1893 in which he acknowledge with expression of appreciation the minister&#39; recognition of the provisional government and state that it be not yet in the possession of the station house the place where a large number of the queen&#39;s troop be quarter though the same have be demand of the queen&#39;s officer in charge nevertheless this wrongful recognition by our minister place the government of the queen in a position of most perilous perplexity on the one hand she have possession of the palace of the barrack and of the police station and have at her command at least 500 fully armed man and several piece of artillery indeed the whole military force of her kingdom be on her side and at her disposal while the committee of safety by actual search have discover that there be but very few arm in honolulu that be not in the service of the government
 in this state of thing if the queen could have deal with the insurgent alone her course would have be plain and the result unmistakable but the united states have ally itself with her enemy have recognize they as the true government of hawaii and have put she and her adherent in the position of opposition against lawful authority she know that she could not withstand the power of the united states but she believe that she might safely trust to its justice accordingly some hour after the recognition of the provisional government by the united states minister the palace the barrack and the police station with all the military resource of the country be deliver up by the queen upon the representation make to she that her cause would thereafter be review at washington and while protest that she surrender to the superior force of the united states whose minister have cause united states troop to be land at honolulu and declare that he would support the provisional government and that she yield her authority to prevent collision of armed force and loss of life and only until such time as the united states upon the fact be present to it should undo the action of its representative and reinstate she in the authority she claim as the constitutional sovereign of the hawaiian islands
 this protest be deliver to the chief of the provisional government who indorse thereon his acknowledgment of its receipt the term of the protest be read without dissent by those assume to constitute the provisional government who be certainly charge with the knowledge that the queen instead of finally abandon her power have appeal to the justice of the united states for reinstatement in her authority and yet the provisional government with this unanswered protest in its hand hasten to negotiate with the united states for the permanent banishment of the queen from power and for a sale of her kingdom
 our country be in danger of occupy the position of having actually set up a temporary government on foreign soil for the purpose of acquire through that agency territory which we have wrongfully put in its possession the control of both side of a bargain acquire in such a manner be call by a familiar and unpleasant name when find in private transaction we be not without a precedent show how scrupulously we avoid such accusation in former day after the people of texas have declare their independence of mexico they resolve that on the acknowledgment of their independence by the united states they would seek admission into the union several month after the battle of san jacinto by which texan independence be practically assure and establish president jackson decline to recognize it allege as one of his reason that in the circumstance it become we to beware of a too early movement as it might subject we however unjustly to the imputation of seek to establish the claim of our neighbor to a territory with a view to its subsequent acquisition by ourselves this be in marked contrast with the hasty recognition of a government openly and concededly set up for the purpose of tender to us territorial annexation
 i believe that a candid and thorough examination of the fact will force the conviction that the provisional government owe its existence to an armed invasion by the united states fair minded people with the evidence before they will hardly claim that the hawaiian government be overthrow by the people of the island or that the provisional government have ever exist with their consent i do not understand that any member of this government claim that the people would uphold it by their suffrage if they be allow to vote on the question
 while naturally sympathize with every effort to establish a republican form of government it have be the settle policy of the united states to concede to people of foreign country the same freedom and independence in the management of their domestic affair that we have always claim for ourselves and it have be our practice to recognize revolutionary government as soon as it become apparent that they be support by the people for illustration of this rule i need only to refer to the revolution in brazil in 1889 when our minister be instruct to recognize the republic so soon as a majority of the people of brazil should have signify their assent to its establishment and maintenance to the revolution in chile in 1891 when our minister be direct to recognize the new government if it be accept by the people and to the revolution in venezuela in 1892 when our recognition be accord on condition that the new government be fully establish in possession of the power of the nation and accept by the people
 as i apprehend the situation we be bring face to face with the following condition
 the lawful government of hawaii be overthrow without the drawing of a sword or the firing of a shot by a process every step of which it may safely be assert be directly traceable to and dependent for its success upon the agency of the united states act through its diplomatic and naval representative
 but for the notorious predilection of the united states minister for annexation the committee of safety which should be call the committee of annexation would never have exist
 but for the landing of the united states force upon false pretext respect the danger to life and property the committee would never have expose themselves to the pain and penalty of treason by undertake the subversion of the queen&#39;s government
 but for the presence of the united states force in the immediate vicinity and in position to afford all need protection and support the committee would not have proclaim the provisional government from the step of the government building
 and finally but for the lawless occupation of honolulu under false pretext by the united states force and but for minister stevens&#39;s recognition of the provisional government when the united states force be its sole support and constitute its only military strength the queen and her government would never have yield to the provisional government even for a time and for the sole purpose of submit her case to the enlightened justice of the united states
 believe therefore that the united states could not under the circumstance disclose annex the island without justly incur the imputation of acquire they by unjustifiable method i shall not again submit the treaty of annexation to the senate for its consideration and in the instruction to minister willis a copy of which accompany this message i have direct he to so inform the provisional government
 but in the present instance our duty do not in my opinion end with refuse to consummate this questionable transaction it have be the boast of our government that it seek to do justice in all thing without regard to the strength or weakness of those with whom it deal i mistake the american people if they favor the odious doctrine that there be no such thing as international morality that there be one law for a strong nation and another for a weak one and that even by indirection a strong power may with impunity despoil a weak one of its territory
 by an act of war commit with the participation of a diplomatic representative of the united states and without authority of congress the government of a feeble but friendly and confide people have be overthrow a substantial wrong have thus be do which a due regard for our national character as well as the right of the injured people require we should endeavor to repair the provisional government have not assume a republican or other constitutional form but have remain a mere executive council or oligarchy set up without the assent of the people it have not seek to find a permanent basis of popular support and have give no evidence of an intention to do so indeed the representative of that government assert that the people of hawaii be unfit for popular government and frankly avow that they can be well rule by arbitrary or despotic power
 the law of nation be round upon reason and justice and the rule of conduct govern individual relation between citizen or subject of a civilized state be equally applicable as between enlightened nation the consideration that international law be without a court for its enforcement and that obedience to its command practically depend upon good faith instead of upon the mandate of a superior tribunal only give additional sanction to the law itself and brand any deliberate infraction of it not merely as a wrong but as a disgrace a man of true honor protect the unwritten word which bind his conscience more scrupulously if possible than he do the bond a breach of which subject he to legal liability and the united states in aim to maintain itself as one of the most enlightened nation would do its citizen gross injustice if it apply to its international relation any other than a high standard of honor and morality on that ground the united states can not properly be put in the position of countenance a wrong after its commission any more than in that of consent to it in advance on that ground it can not allow itself to refuse to redress an injury inflict through an abuse of power by officer clothe with its authority and wear its uniform and on the same ground if a feeble but friendly state be in danger of be rob of its independence and its sovereignty by a misuse of the name and power of the united states the united states can not fail to vindicate its honor and its sense of justice by an earnest effort to make all possible reparation
 these principle apply to the present case with irresistible force when the special condition of the queen&#39;s surrender of her sovereignty be recall she surrender not to the provisional government but to the united states she surrender not absolutely and permanently but temporarily and conditionally until such time as the fact could be consider by the united states furthermore the provisional government acquiesce in her surrender in that manner and on those term not only by tacit consent but through the positive act of some member of that government who urge her peaceable submission not merely to avoid bloodshed but because she could place implicit reliance upon the justice of the united states and that the whole subject would be finally consider at washington
 i have not however overlook an incident of this unfortunate affair which remain to be mention the member of the provisional government and their supporter though not entitle to extreme sympathy have be lead to their present predicament of revolt against the government of the queen by the indefensible encouragement and assistance of our diplomatic representative this fact may entitle they to claim that in our effort to rectify the wrong commit some regard should be have for their safety this sentiment be strongly second by my anxiety to do nothing which would invite either harsh retaliation on the part of the queen or violence and bloodshed in any quarter in the belief that the queen as well as her enemy would be willing to adopt such a course as would meet these condition and in view of the fact that both the queen and the provisional government have at one time apparently acquiesce in a reference of the entire case to the united states government and consider the further fact that in any event the provisional government by its own declare limitation be only to exist until term of union with the united states of america have be negotiate and agree upon i hope that after the assurance to the member of that government that such union could not be consummate i might compass a peaceful adjustment of the difficulty
 actuate by these desire and purpose and not unmindful of the inherent perplexity of the situation nor of the limitation upon my power i instruct minister willis to advise the queen and her supporter of my desire to aid in the restoration of the status exist before the lawless landing of the united states force at honolulu on the 16th of january last if such restoration could be effect upon term provide for clemency as well as justice to all party concern the condition suggest as the instruction show contemplate a general amnesty to those concern in set up the provisional government and a recognition of all its bona fide act and obligation in short they require that the past should be bury and that the restore government should reassume its authority as if its continuity have not be interrupt these condition have not prove acceptable to the queen and though she have be inform that they will be insist upon and that unless accede to the effort of the president to aid in the restoration of her government will cease i have not thus far learn that she be willing to yield they her acquiescence the check which my plan have thus encounter have prevent their presentation to the member of the provisional government while unfortunate public misrepresentation of the situation and exaggerated statement of the sentiment of our people have obviously injure the prospect of successful executive mediation
 i therefore submit this communication with its accompany exhibit embrace mr. blount&#39;s report the evidence and statement take by he at honolulu the instruction give to both mr. blount and minister willis and correspondence connect with the affair in hand
 in commend this subject to the extended power and wide discretion of the congress i desire to add the assurance that i shall be much gratified to cooperate in any legislative plan which may be devise for the solution of the problem before we which be consistent with american honor integrity and morality

house of representatives
 i return without my approval house bill no 4956 entitle an act direct the coinage of the silver bullion hold in the treasury and for other purposes.&#39;&#39
 my strong desire to avoid disagreement with those in both houses of congress who have support this bill would lead i to approve it if i could believe that the public good would not be thereby endanger and that such action on my part would be a proper discharge of official duty inasmuch however as i be unable to satisfy myself that the propose legislation be either wise or opportune my conception of the obligation and responsibility attach to the great office i hold forbid the indulgence of my personal desire and inexorably confine i to that course which be dictate by my reason and judgment and point out by a sincere purpose to protect and promote the general interest of our people
 the financial disturbance which sweep over the country during the last year be unparalleled in its severity and disastrous consequence there seem to be almost an entire displacement of faith in our financial ability and a loss of confidence in our fiscal policy among those who attempt to assign cause for our distress it be very generally concede that the operation of a provision of law then in force which require the government to purchase monthly a large amount of silver bullion and issue its note in payment therefor be either entirely or to a large extent responsible for our condition this lead to the repeal on the 1st day of november 1893 of this statutory provision
 we have however fall so low in the depth of depression and timidity and apprehension have so completely gain control in financial circle that our rapid recuperation could not be reasonably expect our recovery have nevertheless steadily progress and though less than five month have elapse since the repeal of the mischievous silver purchase requirement a wholesome improvement be unmistakably apparent confidence in our absolute solvency be to such an extent reinstate and faith in our disposition to adhere to sound financial method be so far restore as to produce the most encouraging result both at home and abroad the wheel of domestic industry have be slowly set in motion and the tide of foreign investment have again start in our direction
 our recovery be so well under way nothing should be do to check our convalescence nor should we forget that a relapse at this time would almost surely reduce we to a low stage of financial distress than that from which we be just emerge
 i believe that if the bill under consideration should become a law it would be regard as a retrogression from the financial intention indicate by our recent repeal of the provision force silver bullion purchase that it would weaken if it do not destroy return faith and confidence in our sound financial tendency and that as a consequence our progress to renew business health would be unfortunately check and a return to our recent distressing plight seriously threaten
 this propose legislation be so related to the currency condition grow out of the law compel the purchase of silver by the government that a glance at such condition and a partial review of the law refer to may not be unprofitable
 between the 14th day of august 1890 when the law become operative and the 1st day of november 1893 when the clause it contain direct the purchase of silver be repeal there be purchase by the secretary of the treasury more than 168,000,000 ounce of silver bullion in payment for this bullion the government issue its treasury note of various denomination amount to nearly $ 156,000,000 which note be immediately add to the currency in circulation among our people such note be by the law make legal tender in payment of all debt public and private except when otherwise expressly stipulate and be make receivable for custom taxis and all public due and when so received might be reissue they be also permit to be hold by banking association as a part of their lawful reserve
 on the demand of the holder these treasury note be to be redeem in gold or silver coin in the discretion of the secretary of the treasury but it be declare as a part of this redemption provision that it be the establish policy of the united states to maintain the two metal on a parity with each other upon the present legal ratio or such ratio as may be provide by law the money coin from such bullion be to be standard silver dollar and after direct the immediate coinage of a little less than 28,000,000 ounce the law provide that as much of the remain bullion should be thereafter coin as might be necessary to provide for the redemption of the treasury note issue on its purchase and that any gain or seigniorage arise from such coinage shall be account for and pay into the treasury
 this gain or seigniorage evidently indicate so much of the bullion own by the government as should remain after use a sufficient amount to coin as many standard silver dollar as should equal in number the dollar represent by the treasury note issue in payment of the entire quantity of bullion these treasury note now outstanding and in circulation amount to $ 152,951,280 and although there have be thus far but a comparatively small amount of this bullion coin yet the so call gain or seigniorage as above define which would arise from the coinage of the entire mass have be easily ascertain to be a quantity of bullion sufficient to make when coin 55,156,681 standard silver dollar
 consider the present intrinsic relation between gold and silver the maintenance of the parity between the two metal as mention in this law can mean nothing less than the maintenance of such a parity in the estimation and confidence of the people who use our money in their daily transaction manifestly the maintenance of this parity can only be accomplish so far as it be affect by these treasury note and in the estimation of the holder of the same by give to such holder on their redemption the coin whether it be gold or silver which they prefer it follow that while in term the law leave the choice of coin to be pay on such redemption to the discretion of the secretary of the treasury the exercise of this discretion if oppose to the demand of the holder be entirely inconsistent with the effective and beneficial maintenance of the parity between the two metal
 if both gold and silver be to serve we as money and if they together be to supply to our people a safe and stable currency the necessity of preserve this parity be obvious such necessity have be repeatedly concede in the platform of both political party and in our federal statute it be nowhere more emphatically recognize than in the recent law which repeal the provision under which the bullion now on hand be purchase this law insist upon the maintenance of the parity in value of the coin of the two metal and the equal power of every dollar at all time in the market and in the payment of debt
 the secretary of the treasury have therefore for the good of reason not only promptly comply with every demand for the redemption of these treasury note in gold but the present situation as well as the letter and spirit of the law appear plainly to justify if they do not enjoin upon he a continuation of such redemption
 the condition i have endeavor to present may be thus summarize first the government have purchase and now have on hand sufficient silver bullion to permit the coinage of all the silver dollar necessary to redeem in such dollar the treasury note issue for the purchase of say silver bullion and enough besides to coin as gain or seigniorage 55,156,681 additional standard silver dollar
 second there be outstanding and now in circulation treasury note issue in payment of the bullion purchase amounting to $ 152,951,280 these note be legal tender in payment of all debt public and private except when otherwise expressly stipulate they be receivable for custom taxis and all public due when hold by banking association they may be count as part of their lawful reserve and they be redeem by the government in gold at the option of the holder these advantageous attribute be deliberately attach to these note at the time of their issue they be fully understand by our people to whom such note have be distribute as currency and have inspire confidence in their safety and value and have undoubtedly thus induce their continue and content use as money instead of anxiety for their redemption
 having refer to some incident which i deem relevant to the subject it remain for i to submit a specific statement of my objection to the bill now under consideration
 this bill consist of two section exclude one which merely appropriate a sum sufficient to carry the act into effect the first section provide for the immediate coinage of the silver bullion in the treasury which represent the so call gain or seigniorage or which would arise from the coinage of all the bullion on hand which gain or seigniorage this section declare to be $ 55,156,681 it direct that the money so coin or the certificate issue thereon shall be use in the payment of public expenditure and provide that if the need of the treasury demand it the secretary of the treasury may in his discretion issue silver certificate in excess of such coinage not exceed the amount of seigniorage in say section authorize to be coin
 the second section direct that as soon as possible after the coinage of this seigniorage the remainder of the bullion hold by the government shall be coin into legal tender standard silver dollar and that they shall be hold in the treasury for the redemption of the treasury note issue in the purchase of said bullion it provide that as fast as the bullion shall be coin for the redemption of say note they shall not be reissue but shall be cancel and destroy in amount equal to the coin hold at any time in the treasury derive from the coinage provide for and that silver certificate shall be issue on such coin in the manner now provide by law it be however especially declare in say section that the act shall not be construe to change exist law relate to the legal tender character or mode of redemption of the treasury note issue for the purchase of the silver bullion to be coin
 the entire bill be most unfortunately construct nearly every sentence present uncertainty and invite controversy as to its meaning and intent the first section be especially faulty in this respect and it be extremely doubtful whether its language will permit the consummation of its suppose purpose i be lead to believe that the promoter of the bill intend in this section to provide for the coinage of the bullion constitute the gain or seigniorage as it be call into standard silver dollar and yet there be positively nothing in the section to prevent its coinage into any description of silver coin now authorize under any exist law
 i suppose this section be also intend in case the need of the treasury call for money fast than the seigniorage bullion could actually be coin to permit the issue of silver certificate in advance of such coinage but its language would seem to permit the issuance of such certificate to double the amount of seigniorage as state one half of which would not represent an ounce of silver in the treasury the debate upon this section in the congress develop an earnest and positive difference of opinion as to its object and meaning in any event i be clear that the present perplexity and embarrassment of the secretary of the treasury ought not to be augment by devolve upon he the execution of a law so uncertain and confused
 i be not willing however to rest my objection to this section solely on these ground in my judgment sound finance do not commend a further infusion of silver into our currency at this time unaccompanie by further adequate provision for the maintenance in our treasury of a safe gold reserve
 doubt also arise as to the meaning and construction of the second section of the bill if the silver dollar therein direct to be coin be as the section provide to be hold in the treasury for the redemption of treasury note it be suggest that strictly speak certificate can not be issue on such coin in the manner now provide by law because these dollar be money hold in the treasury for the express purpose of redeem treasury note on demand which would ordinarily mean that they be set apart for the purpose of substitute they for these treasury note they be not therefore hold in such a way as to furnish a basis for certificate accord to any provision of exist law
 if however silver certificate can properly be issue upon these dollar there be nothing in the section to indicate the characteristic and function of these certificate if they be to be of the same character as silver certificate in circulation under exist law they would at well be receivable only for custom taxis and all public due and under the language of this section it be to say the least extremely doubtful whether the certificate it contemplate would be lawfully receive even for such purpose
 whatever else may be say of the uncertainty of expression in this bill they certainly ought not to be find in legislation affect subject so important and far reach as our finance and currency in state other and more important reason for my disapproval of this section i shall however assume that under its provision the treasury note issue in payment for silver bullion will continue to be redeem as heretofore in silver or gold at the option of the holder and that if when they be present for redemption or reach the treasury in any other manner there be in the treasury coin silver dollar equal in nominal value to such treasury note then and in that case the note will be destroy and silver certificate to an equal amount be substitute
 i be convinced that this scheme be ill advised and dangerous as an ultimate result of its operation treasury note which be legal tender for all debt public and private and which be redeemable in gold or silver at the option of the holder will be replace by silver certificate which whatever may be their character and description will have none of these quality in anticipation of this result and as an immediate effect the treasury note will naturally appreciate in value and desirability the fact that gold can be realize upon they and the further fact that their destruction have be decree when they reach the treasury must tend to their withdrawal from general circulation to be immediately present for gold redemption or to be hoard for presentation at a more convenient season the sequel of both operation will be a large addition to the silver currency in our circulation and a corresponding reduction of gold in the treasury the argument have be make that these thing will not occur at once because a long time must elapse before the coinage of anything but the seigniorage can be enter upon if the physical effect of the execution of the second section of this bill be not to be realize until far in the future this may furnish a strong reason why it should not be pass so much in advance but the postponement of its actual operation can not prevent the fear and loss of confidence and nervous precaution which would immediately follow its passage and bring about its bad consequence i regard this section of the bill as embody a plan by which the government will be oblige to pay out its scanty store of gold for no other purpose than to force an unnatural addition of silver money into the hand of our people this be an exact reversal of the policy which safe finance dictate if we be to preserve parity between gold and silver and maintain sensible bimetallism
 we have now outstanding more than $ 338,000,000 in silver certificate issue under exist law they be serve the purpose of money usefully and without question our gold reserve amount to only a little more than $ 100,000,000 be directly charge with the redemption of $ 346,000,000 of united states note when it be propose to inflate our silver currency it be a time for strengthen our gold reserve instead of deplete it i can not conceive of a long step toward silver monometallism than we take when we spend our gold to buy silver certificate for circulation especially in view of the practical difficulty surround the replenishment of our gold
 this lead i to earnestly present the desirability of grant to the secretary of the treasury a well power than now exist to issue bond to protect our gold reserve when for any reason it should be necessary our currency be in such a confused condition and our financial affair be apt to assume at any time so critical a position that it seem to i such a course be dictate by ordinary prudence
 i be not insensible to the argument in favor of coin the bullion seigniorage now in the treasury and i believe it could be do safely and with advantage if the secretary of the treasury have the power to issue bond at a low rate of interest under authority in substitution of that now exist and well suit to the protection of the treasury
 i hope a way will present itself in the near future for the adjustment of our monetary affair in such a comprehensive and conservative manner as will accord to silver its proper place in our currency but in the meantime i be extremely solicitous that whatever action we take on this subject may be such as to prevent loss and discouragement to our people at home and the destruction of confidence in our financial management abroad

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas by reason of unlawful obstruction combination and assemblage of person it have become impracticable in the judgment of the president to enforce by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding the law of the united states within the state of illinois and especially in the city of chicago within said state and
 whereas for the purpose of enforce the faithful execution of the law of the united states and protect its property and remove obstruction to the united states mail in the state and city aforesaid the president have employ a part of the military force of the united states
 now therefore i grover cleveland president of the united states do hereby admonish all good citizen and all person who may be or may come within the city and state aforesaid against aiding countenancing encouraging or take any part in such unlawful obstruction combination and assemblage and i hereby warn all person engage in or in any way connect with such unlawful obstruction combination and assemblage to disperse and retire peaceably to their respective abode on or before 12 o&#39;clock noon on the 9th day of july instant
 those who disregard this warning and persist in take part with a riotous mob in forcibly resist and obstruct the execution of the law of the united states or interfere with the function of the government or destroy or attempt to destroy the property belong to the united states or under its protection can not be regard otherwise than as public enemy
 troop employ against such a riotous mob will act with all the moderation and forbearance consistent with the accomplishment of the desire end but the stern necessity that confront they will not with certainty permit discrimination between guilty participant and those who be mingle with they from curiosity and without criminal intent the only safe course therefore for those not actually unlawfully participate be to abide at their home or at least not to be find in the neighborhood of riotous assemblage
 while there will be no hesitation or vacillation in the decisive treatment of the guilty this warning be especially intend to protect and save the innocent
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be hereto affix
 do at the city of washington this 8th day of july a. d. 1894 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and nineteenth
 grover cleveland
 by the president
 w. q. gresham
 secretary of state
