their work have be well do and their standing and intelligence give assurance that the report and suggestion they make be worthy of careful consideration the tariff act pass at the last session of the congress need important amendment if it be to be execute effectively and with certainty in addition to such necessary amendment as will not change rate of duty i be still very decidedly in favor of put coal and iron upon the free list so far as the sugar schedule be concern i would be glad under exist aggravation to see every particle of differential duty in favor of refined sugar stricken out of our tariff law if with all the favor now accord the sugar refining interest in our tariff law it still languish to the extent of closed refinery and thousand of discharged workman it would seem to present a hopeless case for reasonable legislative aid whatever else be do or omit i earnestly repeat here the recommendation i have make in another portion of this communication that the additional duty of one tenth of a cent per pound lay upon sugar import from country pay a bounty on its export be abrogate it seem to i that exceedingly important consideration point to the propriety of this amendment with the advent of a new tariff policy not only calculate to relieve the consumer of our land in the cost of their daily life but to invite a well development of american thrift and create for we close and more profitable commercial relation with the rest of the world it follow as a logical and imperative necessity that we should at once remove the chief if not the only obstacle which have so long prevent our participation in the foreign carrying trade of the sea a tariff build upon the theory that it be well to check import and that a home market should bind the industry and effort of american producer be fitly supplement by a refusal to allow american registry to vessel build abroad though own and navigate by our people thus exhibit a willingness to abandon all contest for the advantage of american transoceanic carriage our new tariff policy build upon the theory that it be well to encourage such importation as our people need and that our product and manufacture should find market in every part of the habitable globe be consistently supplement by the great possible liberty to our citizen in the ownership and navigation of ship in which our product and manufacture may be transport the million now pay to foreigner for carry american passenger and product across the sea should be turn into american hand shipbuilding which have be protect to strangulation should be revive by the prospect of profitable employment for ship when build and the american sailor should be resurrect and again take his place a sturdy and industrious citizen in time of peace and a patriotic and safe defender of american interest in the day of conflict the ancient provision of our law deny american registry to ship build abroad and own by americans appear in the light of present condition not only to be a failure for good at every point but to be near a relic of barbarism than anything that exist under the permission of a statute of the united states i earnestly recommend its prompt repeal during the last month the gold reserve in the treasury for the purpose of redeem the note of the government circulate as money in the hand of the people become so reduced and its further depletion in the near future seem so certain that in the exercise of proper care for the public welfare it become necessary to replenish this reserve and thus maintain popular faith in the ability and determination of the government to meet as agree its pecuniary obligation it would have be well if in this emergency authority have exist to issue the bond of the government bear a low rate of interest and mature within a short period but the congress having fail to confer such authority resort be necessarily have to the resumption act of 1875 and pursuant to its provision bond be issue draw interest at the rate of 5 per cent per annum and mature ten year after their issue that be the short time authorize by the act i be glad to say however that on the sale of these bond the premium receive operate to reduce the rate of interest to be pay by the government to less than 3 per cent nothing could be bad or far remove from sensible finance than the relation exist between the currency the government have issue the gold hold for its redemption and the mean which must be resort to for the purpose of replenish such redemption fund when impair even if the claim upon this fund be confine to the obligation originally intend and if the redemption of these obligation mean their cancellation the fund would be very small but these obligation when receive and redeem in gold be not cancel but be reissue and may do duty many time by way of draw gold from the treasury thus we have an endless chain in operation constantly deplete the treasury 's gold and never near a final rest as if this be not bad enough we have by a statutory declaration that it be the policy of the government to maintain the parity between gold and silver aid the force and momentum of this exhausting process and add largely to the currency obligation claim this peculiar gold redemption our small gold reserve be thus subject to drain from every side the demand that increase our danger also increase the necessity of protect this reserve against depletion and it be most unsatisfactory to know that the protection afford be only a temporary palliation it be perfectly and palpably plain that the only way under present condition by which this reserve when dangerously deplete can be replenish be through the issue and sale of the bond of the government for gold and yet congress have not only thus far decline to authorize the issue of bond well suit to such a purpose but there seem a disposition in some quarter to deny both the necessity and power for the issue of bond at all i can not for a moment believe that any of our citizen be deliberately willing that their government should default in its pecuniary obligation or that its financial operation should be reduce to a silver basis at any rate i should not feel that my duty be do if i omit any effort i could make to avert such a calamity as long therefore as no provision be make for the final redemption or the putting aside of the currency obligation now use to repeatedly and constantly draw from the government its gold and as long as no well authority for bond issue be allow than at present exist such authority will be utilize whenever and as often as it become necessary to maintain a sufficient gold reserve and in abundant time to save the credit of our country and make good the financial declaration of our government question relate to our bank and currency be closely connect with the subject just refer to and they also present some unsatisfactory feature prominent among they be the lack of elasticity in our currency circulation and its frequent concentration in financial center when it be most need in other part of the country the absolute divorcement of the government from the business of banking be the ideal relationship of the government to the circulation of the currency of the country this condition can not be immediately reach but as a step in that direction and as a means of secure a more elastic currency and obviate other objection to the present arrangement of bank circulation the secretary of the treasury present in his report a scheme modifying present banking law and provide for the issue of circulate note by state bank free from taxation under certain limitation the secretary explain his plan so plainly and its advantage be develop by he with such remarkable clearness that any effort on my part to present argument in its support would be superfluous i shall therefore content myself with an unqualified indorsement of the secretary 's propose change in the law and a brief and imperfect statement of their prominent feature it be propose to repeal all law provide for the deposit of united states bond as security for circulation to permit national bank to issue circulate note not exceed in amount 75 per cent of their pay up and unimpaired capital provide they deposit with the government as a guaranty fund in united states legal tender note include treasury note of 1890 a sum equal in amount to 30 per cent of the note they desire to issue this deposit to be maintain at all time but whenever any bank retire any part of its circulation a proportional part of its guaranty fund shall be return to it to permit the secretary of the treasury to prepare and keep on hand ready for issue in case an increase in circulation be desire blank national bank note for each bank have circulation and to repeal the provision of the present law impose limitation and restriction upon bank desire to reduce or increase their circulation thus permit such increase or reduction within the limit of 75 per cent of capital to be quickly make as emergency arise in addition to the guaranty fund require it be propose to provide a safety fund for the immediate redemption of the circulate note of fail bank by impose a small annual tax say one half of 1 per cent upon the average circulation of each bank until the fund amount to 5 per cent of the total circulation outstanding when a bank fail its guaranty fund be to be pay into this safety fund and its note be to be redeem in the first instance from such safety fund thus augment any impairment of such fund cause thereby to be make good from the immediately available cash asset of say bank and if these should be insufficient such impairment to be make good by pro rata assessment among the other bank their contribution constitute a first lien upon the asset of the fail bank in favor of the contribute bank as a further security it be contemplate that the exist provision fix the individual liability of stockholder be to be retain and the bank 's indebtedness on account of its circulate note be to be make a first lien on all its asset for the purpose of meet the expense of printing note official supervision cancellation and other like charge there shall be impose a tax of say one half of 1 per cent per annum upon the average amount of note in circulation it be far provide that there shall be no national bank note issue of a less denomination than $ 10 that each national bank except in case of a fail bank shall redeem or retire its note in the first instance at its own office or at agency to be designate by it and that no fixed reserve need be maintain on account of deposit another very important feature of this plan be the exemption of state bank from taxation by the united states in case where it be show to the satisfaction of the secretary of the treasury and comptroller of the currency by bank claim such exemption that they have not have outstanding their circulate note exceed 75 per cent of their pay up and unimpaired capital that their stockholder be individually liable for the redemption of their circulate note to the full extent of their ownership of stock that the liability of say bank upon their circulate note constitute under their state law a first lien upon their asset that such bank have keep and maintain a guaranty fund in united states legal tender note include treasury note of 1890 equal to 30 per cent of their outstanding circulating note and that such bank have promptly redeem their circulate note when present at their principal or branch office it be quite likely that this scheme may be usefully amend in some of its detail but i be satisfied it furnish a basis for a very great improvement in our present banking and currency system i conclude this communication fully appreciate that the responsibility for all legislation affect the people of the united states rest upon their representative in the congress and assure they that whether in accordance with recommendation i have make or not i shall be glad to cooperate in perfect any legislation that tend to the prosperity and welfare of our country
to the senate and house of representatives



 in my last annual message i commend to the serious consideration of the congress the condition of our national finance and in connection with the subject indorse a plan of currency legislation which at that time seem to furnish protection against impend danger this plan have not be approve by the congress in the meantime the situation have so change and the emergency now appear so threaten that i deem it my duty to ask at the hand of the legislative branch of the government such prompt and effective action as will restore confidence in our financial soundness and avert business disaster and universal distress among our people
 whatever may be the merit of the plan outline in my annual message as a remedy for ill then exist and as a safeguard against the depletion of the gold reserve then in the treasury i be now convinced that its reception by the congress and our present advanced stage of financial perplexity necessitate additional or different legislation
 with natural resource unlimited in variety and productive strength and with a people whose activity and enterprise seek only a fair opportunity to achieve national success and greatness our progress should not be check by a false financial policy and a heedless disregard of sound monetary law nor should the timidity and fear which they engender stand in the way of our prosperity
 it be hardly dispute that this predicament confront we to day therefore no one in any degree responsible for the making and execution of our law should fail to see a patriotic duty in honestly and sincerely attempt to relieve the situation manifestly this effort will not succeed unless it be make untrammele by the prejudice of partisanship and with a steadfast determination to resist the temptation to accomplish party advantage we may well remember that if we be threaten with financial difficulty all our people in every station of life be concern and surely those who suffer will not receive the promotion of party interest as an excuse for permit our present trouble to advance to a disastrous conclusion it be also of the utmost importance that we approach the study of the problem present as free as possible from the tyranny of preconceived opinion to the end that in a common danger we may be able to seek with unclouded vision a safe and reasonable protection
 the real trouble which confront we consist in a lack of confidence widespread and constantly increase in the continue ability or disposition of the government to pay its obligation in gold this lack of confidence grow to some extent out of the palpable and apparent embarrassment attend the effort of the government under exist law to procure gold and to a great extent out of the impossibility of either keep it in the treasury or cancel obligation by its expenditure after it be obtain
 the only way leave open to the government for procure gold be by the issue and sale of its bond the only bond that can be so issue be authorize nearly twenty five year ago and be not well calculate to meet our present need among other disadvantage they be make payable in coin instead of specifically in gold which in exist condition detract largely and in an increase ratio from their desirability as investment it be by no mean certain that bond of this description can much long be dispose of at a price creditable to the financial character of our government
 the most dangerous and irritate feature of the situation however remain to be mention it be find in the mean by which the treasury be despoiled of the gold thus obtain without cancel a single government obligation and solely for the benefit of those who find profit in ship it abroad or whose fear induce they to hoard it at home we have outstanding about five hundred million of currency note of the government for which gold may be demand and curiously enough the law require that when present and in fact redeem and pay in gold they shall be reissue thus the same note may do duty many time in draw gold from the treasury nor can the process be arrest as long as private party for profit or otherwise see an advantage in repeat the operation more than $ 300,000,000 in these note have already be redeem in gold and notwithstanding such redemption they be all still outstanding
 since the 17th day of january 1894 our bond interest bear debt have be increase $ 100,000,000 for the purpose of obtain gold to replenish our coin reserve two issue be make amounting to fifty million each one in january and the other in november as a result of the first issue there be realize something more than $ 58,000,000 in gold between that issue and the succeed one in november comprise a period of about ten month nearly $ 103,000,000 in gold be draw from the treasury this make the second issue necessary and upon that more than fifty eight million in gold be again realize between the date of this second issue and the present time cover a period of only about two month more than $ 69,000,000 in gold have be draw from the treasury these large sum of gold be expend without any cancellation of government obligation or in any permanent way benefit our people or improve our pecuniary situation
 the financial event of the past year suggest fact and condition which should certainly arrest attention
 more than $ 172,000,000 in gold have be draw out of the treasury during the year for the purpose of shipment abroad or hoard at home
 while nearly $ 103,000,000 of this amount be draw out during the first ten month of the year a sum aggregate more than two third of that amount be about $ 69,000,000 be draw out during the follow two month thus indicate a marked acceleration of the depleting process with the lapse of time
 the obligation upon which this gold have be draw from the treasury be still outstanding and be available for use in repeat the exhausting operation with short interval as our perplexity accumulate
 condition be certainly supervene tend to make the bond which may be issue to replenish our gold less useful for that purpose
 an adequate gold reserve be in all circumstance absolutely essential to the upholding of our public credit and to the maintenance of our high national character
 our gold reserve have again reach such a stage of diminution as to require its speedy reenforcement
 the aggravation that must inevitably follow present condition and method will certainly lead to misfortune and loss not only to our national credit and prosperity and to financial enterprise but to those of our people who seek employment as a means of livelihood and to those whose only capital be their daily labor
 it will hardly do to say that a simple increase of revenue will cure our trouble the apprehension now exist and constantly increase as to our financial ability do not rest upon a calculation of our revenue the time have pass when the eye of investor abroad and our people at home be fix upon the revenue of the government change condition have attract their attention to the gold of the government there need be no fear that we can not pay our current expense with such money as we have there be now in the treasury a comfortable surplus of more than $ 63,000,000 but it be not in gold and therefore do not meet our difficulty
 i can not see that difference of opinion concern the extent to which silver ought to be coin or use in our currency should interfere with the counsel of those whose duty it be to rectify evil now apparent in our financial situation they have to consider the question of national credit and the consequence that will follow from its collapse whatever idea may be insist upon as to silver or bimetallism a proper solution of the question now press upon we only require a recognition of gold as well as silver and a concession of its importance rightfully or wrongfully acquire as a basis of national credit a necessity in the honorable discharge of our obligation payable in gold and a badge of solvency i do not understand that the real fiend of silver desire a condition that might follow inaction or neglect to appreciate the meaning of the present exigency if it should result in the entire banishment of gold from our financial and currency arrangement
 besides the treasury note which certainly should be pay in gold amount to nearly $ 500,000,000 there will fall due in 1904 one hundred million of bond issue during the last year for which we have receive gold and in 1907 nearly six hundred million of 4 per cent bond issue in 1877 shall the payment of these obligation in gold be repudiate if they be to be pay in such a manner as the preservation of our national honor and national solvency demand we should not destroy or even imperil our ability to supply ourselves with gold for that purpose
 while i be not unfriendly to silver and while i desire to see it recognize to such an extent as be consistent with financial safety and the preservation of national honor and credit i be not willing to see gold entirely banish from our currency and finance to avert such a consequence i believe thorough and radical remedial legislation should be promptly pass i therefore beg the congress to give the subject immediate attention
 in my opinion the secretary of the treasury should be authorize to issue bond of the government for the purpose of procure and maintain a sufficient gold reserve and the redemption and cancellation of the united states legal tender note and the treasury note issue for the purchase of silver under the law of july 14 1890 we should be relieve from the humiliating process of issue bond to procure gold to be immediately and repeatedly draw out on these obligation for purpose not relate to the benefit of our government or our people the principal and interest of these bond should be payable on their face in gold because they should be sell only for gold or its representative and because there would now probably be difficulty in favorably dispose of bond not contain this stipulation i suggest that the bond be issue in denomination of twenty and fifty dollar and their multiple and that they bear interest at a rate not exceed 3 per cent per annum i do not see why they should not be payable fifty year from their date we of the present generation have large amount to pay if we meet our obligation and long bond be most salable the secretary of the treasury might well be permit at his discretion to receive on the sale of bond the legal tender and treasury note to be retire and of course when they be thus retire or redeem in gold they should be cancel
 these bond under exist law could be deposit by national bank as security for circulation and such bank should be allow to issue circulation up to the face value of these or any other bond so deposit except bond outstanding bear only 2 per cent interest and which sell in the market at less than par national bank should not be allow to take out circulate note of a less denomination than $ 10 and when such as be now outstanding reach the treasury except for redemption and retirement they should be cancel and note of the denomination of $ 10 and upward issue in their stead silver certificate of the denomination of $ 10 and upward should be replace by certificate of the denomination under $ 10
 as a constant mean for the maintenance of a reasonable supply of gold in the treasury our duty on import should be pay in gold allow all other due to the government to be pay in any other form of money
 i believe all the provision i have suggest should be embody in our law if we be to enjoy a complete reinstatement of a sound financial condition they need not interfere with any currency scheme provide for the increase of the circulate medium through the agency of national or state bank that may commend itself to the congress since they can easily be adjust to such a scheme objection have be make to the issuance of interest bear obligation for the purpose of retire the noninterest bear legal tender note in point of fact however these note have burden we with a large load of interest and it be still accumulate the aggregate interest on the original issue of bond the proceed of which in gold constitute the reserve for the payment of these note amount to $ 70,326,250 on january 1 1895 and the annual charge for interest on these bond and those issue for the same purpose during the last year will be $ 9,145,000 date from january 1 1895
 while the cancellation of these note would not relieve we from the obligation already incur on their account these figure be give by way of suggest that their existence have not be free from interest charge and that the long they be outstanding judge from the experience of the last year the more expensive they will become
 in conclusion i desire to frankly confess my reluctance to issue more bond in present circumstance and with no well result than have lately follow that course i can not however refrain from add to an assurance of my anxiety to cooperate with the present congress in any reasonable measure of relief an expression of my determination to leave nothing undo which furnish a hope for improve the situation or check a suspicion of our disinclination or disability to meet with the strict honor every national obligation

to the congress of the united states
 since my recent communication to the congress call attention to our financial condition and suggest legislation which i deem essential to our national welfare and credit the anxiety and apprehension then exist in business circle have continue
 as a precaution therefore against the failure of timely legislative aid through congressional action cautious preparation have be pende to employ to the good possible advantage in default of well mean such executive authority as may without additional legislation be exercise for the purpose of reenforce and maintain in our treasury an adequate and safe gold reserve
 in the judgment of those especially charge with this responsibility the business situation be so critical and the legislative situation be so unpromising with the omission thus far on the part of congress to beneficially enlarge the power of the secretary of the treasury in the premise as to enjoin immediate executive action with the facility now at hand
 therefore in pursuance of section 3700 of the revised statutes the detail of an arrangement have this day be conclude with party abundantly able to fulfill their undertaking whereby bond of the united states authorize under the act of july 14 1875 payable in coin thirty year after their date with interest at the rate of 4 per cent per annum to the amount of a little less than $ 62,400,000 be to be issue for the purchase of gold coin amount to a sum slightly in excess of $ 65,000,000 to be deliver to the treasury of the united states which sum add to the gold now hold in our reserve will so restore such reserve as to make it amount to something more than $ 100,000,000 such a premium be to be allow to the government upon the bond as to fix the rate of interest upon the amount of gold realize at 3 3/4 per cent per annum at least one half of the gold to be obtain be to be supply from abroad which be a very important and favorable feature of the transaction
 the privilege be especially reserve to the government to substitute at par within ten day from this date in lieu of the 4 per cent coin bond other bond in term payable in gold and bear only 3 per cent interest if the issue of the same should in the meantime be authorize by the congress
 the arrangement thus complete which after careful inquiry appear in present circumstance and consider all the object desire to be the well attainable develop such a difference in the estimation of investor between bond make payable in coin and those specifically make payable in gold in favor of the latter as be represent by three fourth of a cent in annual interest in the agreement just conclude the annual saving in interest to the government if 3 per cent gold bond should be substitute for 4 per cent coin bond under the privilege reserve would be $ 539,159 amount in thirty year or at the maturity of the coin bond to $ 16,174,770
 of course there never should be a doubt in any quarter as to the redemption in gold of the bond of the government which be make payable in coin therefore the discrimination in the judgment of investor between our bond obligation payable in coin and those specifically make payable in gold be very significant it be hardly necessary to suggest that whatever may be our view on the subject the sentiment or preference of those with whom we must negotiate in dispose of our bond for gold be not subject to our dictation
 i have only to add that in my opinion the transaction herein detail for the information of the congress promise well result than the effort previously make in the direction of effectively add to our gold reserve through the sale of bond and i believe it will tend as far as such action can in present circumstance to meet the determination express in the law repeal the silver purchase clause of the act of july 14 1890 and that in the language of such repeal act the arrangement make will aid our effort to insure the maintenance of the parity in value of the coin of the two metal and the equal power of every dollar at all time in the market and in the payment of debt

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas the island of cuba be now the seat of serious civil disturbance accompany by armed resistance to the authority of the established government of spain a power with which the united states be and desire to remain on term of peace and amity and
 whereas the law of the united states prohibit their citizen as well as all other be within and subject to their jurisdiction from take part in such disturbance adversely to such establish government by accept or exercise commission for warlike service against it by enlistment or procure other to enlist for such service by fit out or arm or procure to be fit out and armed ship of war for such service by augment the force of any ship of war engage in such service and arrive in a port of the united states and by set on foot or provide or prepare the mean for military enterprise to be carry on from the united states against the territory of such government
 now therefore in recognition of the law aforesaid and in discharge of the obligation of the united states toward a friendly power and as a measure of precaution and to the end that citizen of the united states and all other within their jurisdiction may be deter from subject themselves to legal forfeiture and penalty i grover cleveland president of the united states of america do hereby admonish all such citizen and other person to abstain from every violation of the law hereinbefore refer to and do hereby warn they that all violation of such law will be rigorously prosecute and i do hereby enjoin upon all officer of the united states charge with the execution of say law the utmost diligence in prevent violation thereof and in bring to trial and punishment any offender against the same
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 12th day of june a. d. 1895 and of the independence of the united states of america the one hundred and nineteenth
 grover cleveland
 by the president
 richard olney
 secretary of state

to the congress of the united states the present assemblage of the legislative branch of our government occur at a time when the interest of our people and the need of the country give especial prominence to the condition of our foreign relation and the exigency of our national finance the report of the head of the several administrative departments of the government fully and plainly exhibit what have be accomplish within the scope of their respective duty and present such recommendation for the betterment of our country 's condition as patriotic and intelligent labor and observation suggest i therefore deem my executive duty adequately perform at this time by present to the congress the important phase of our situation as relate to our intercourse with foreign nation and a statement of the financial problem which confront we omitting except as they be relate to these topic any reference to departmental operation i earnestly invite however not only the careful consideration but the severely critical scrutiny of the congress and my fellow countryman to the report concern these departmental operation if justly and fairly examine they will furnish proof of assiduous and painstaking care for the public welfare i press the recommendation they contain upon the respectful attention of those charge with the duty of legislation because i believe their adoption would promote the people 's good by amendatory tariff legislation in january last the argentine republic recognize the value of the large market open to the free importation of its wool under our last tariff act have admit certain product of the united states to entry at reduce duty it be pleasing to note that the effort we have make to enlarge the exchange of trade on a sound basis of mutual benefit be in this instance appreciate by the country from which our woolen factory draw their needful supply of raw material the missions boundary dispute between the argentine republic and brazil refer to the president of the united states as arbitrator during the term of my predecessor and which be submit to i for determination result in an award in favor of brazil upon the historical and documentary evidence present thus end a long protract controversy and again demonstrate the wisdom and desirability of settle international boundary dispute by recourse to friendly arbitration negotiation be progress for a revival of the united states and chilean claims commission whose work be abruptly terminate last year by the expiration of the stipulate time within which award could be make the resumption of specie payment by chile be a step of great interest and importance both in its direct consequence upon her own welfare and as evince the ascendency of sound financial principle in one of the most influential of the south american republics the close of the momentous struggle between china and japan while relieve the diplomatic agent of this government from the delicate duty they undertake at the request of both country of render such service to the subject of either belligerent within the territorial limit of the other as our neutral position permit develop a domestic condition in the chinese empire which have cause much anxiety and call for prompt and careful attention either as a result of a weak control by the central government over the provincial administration follow a diminution of traditional governmental authority under the stress of an overwhelming national disaster or as a manifestation upon good opportunity of the aversion of the chinese population to all foreign way and undertaking there have occur in widely separate province of china serious outbreak of the old fanatical spirit against foreigner which unchecke by the local authority if not actually connive at by they have culminate in mob attack on foreign missionary station cause much destruction of property and attend with personal injury as well as loss of life although but one american citizen be report to have be actually wound and although the destruction of property may have fall more heavily upon the missionary of other nationality than our own it plainly behoove this government to take the most prompt and decide action to guard against similar or perhaps more dreadful calamity befall the hundred of american mission station which have grow up throughout the interior of china under the temperate rule of toleration custom and imperial edict the demand of the united states and other power for the degradation and punishment of the responsible official of the respective city and province who by neglect or otherwise have permit uprising and for the adoption of stern measure by the emperor 's government for the protection of the life and property of foreigner be follow by the disgrace and dismissal of certain provincial official find derelict in duty and the punishment by death of a number of those adjudge guilty of actual participation in the outrage this government also insist that a special american commission should visit the province where the first disturbance occur for the purpose of investigation the latter commission form after much opposition have go overland from tientsin accompany by a suitable chinese escort and by its demonstration of the readiness and ability of our government to protect its citizen will act it be believe as a most influential deterrent of any similar outbreak the energetic step we have thus take be all the more likely to result in future safety to our citizen in china because the imperial government be i be persuade entirely convinced that we desire only the liberty and protection of our own citizen and redress for any wrong they may have suffer and that we have no ulterior design or object political or otherwise china will not forget either our kindly service to her citizen during her late war nor the further fact that while furnish all the facility at our command to further the negotiation of a peace between she and japan we seek no advantage and interpose no counsel the government of both china and japan have in special dispatch transmit through their respective diplomatic representative express in a most pleasing manner their grateful appreciation of our assistance to their citizen during the unhappy struggle and of the value of our aid in pave the way to their resumption of peaceful relation the customary cordial relation between this country and france have be undisturbed with the exception that a full explanation of the treatment of john l. waller by the expeditionary military authority of france still remain to be give mr. waller formerly united states consul at tamatav remain in madagascar after his term of office expire and be apparently successful in procure business concession from the hovas of great or less value after the occupation of tamatav and the declaration of martial law by the french he be arrest upon various charge among they that of communicate military information to the enemy of france be try and convict by a military tribunal and sentence to twenty year imprisonment follow the course justify by abundant precedent this government request from that of france the record of the proceeding of the french tribunal which result in mr. waller 's condemnation this request have be comply with to the extent of supply a copy of the official record from which appear the constitution and organization of the court the charge as formulate and the general course and result of the trial and by which it be show that the accuse be try in open court and be defend by counsel but the evidence adduce in support of the charge which be not receive by the french minister for foreign affair till the first week in october have thus far be withhold the french government take the ground that its production in response to our demand would establish a bad precedent the effort of our ambassador to procure it however though impede by recent change in the french ministry have not be relax and it be confidently expect that some satisfactory solution of the matter will shortly be reach meanwhile it appear that mr. waller 's confinement have every alleviation which the state of his health and all the other circumstance of the case demand or permit in agreeable contrast to the difference above note respect a matter of common concern where nothing be seek except such a mutually satisfactory outcome as the true merit of the case require be the recent resolution of the french chambers favor the conclusion of a permanent treaty of arbitration between the two country an invitation have be extend by france to the government and people of the united states to participate in a great international exposition at paris in 1900 as a suitable commemoration of the close of this the world 's marvelous century of progress i heartily recommend its acceptance together with such legislation as will adequately provide for a due representation of this government and its people on the occasion our relation with the states of the german empire be in some aspect typical of a condition of thing elsewhere find in country whose production and trade be similar to our own the close rivalry of compete industry the influence of the delusive doctrine that the internal development of a nation be promote and its wealth increase by a policy which in undertaking to reserve its home market for the exclusive use of its own producer necessarily obstruct their sale in foreign market and prevent free access to the product of the world the desire to retain trade in time wear rut regardless of the inexorable law of new need and change condition of demand and supply and our own halting tardiness in invite a free exchange of commodity and by this mean imperil our footing in the external market naturally open to we have create a situation somewhat injurious to american export interest not only in germany where they be perhaps most noticeable but in adjacent country the export affect be largely american cattle and other food product the reason assign for unfavorable discrimination be that their consumption be deleterious to the public health this be all the more irritate in view of the fact that no european state be as jealous of the excellence and wholesomeness of its export food supply as the united states nor so easily able on account of inherent soundness to guarantee those quality nor be these difficulty confine to our food product design for exportation our great insurance company for example having build up a vast business abroad and invest a large share of their gain in foreign country in compliance with the local law and regulation then exist now find themselves within a narrowing circle of onerous and unforeseen condition and be confront by the necessity of retirement from a field thus make unprofitable if indeed they be not summarily expel as some of they have lately be from prussia it be not to be forget that international trade can not be one side its current be alternate and its movement should be honestly reciprocal without this it almost necessarily degenerate into a device to gain advantage or a contrivance to secure benefit with only the semblance of a return in our dealing with other nation we ought to be open handed and scrupulously fair this should be our policy as a produce nation and it plainly become we as a people who love generosity and the moral aspect of national good faith and reciprocal forbearance these consideration should not however constrain we to submit to unfair discrimination nor to silently acquiesce in vexatious hindrance to the enjoyment of our share of the legitimate advantage of proper trade relation if an examination of the situation suggest such measure on our part as would involve restriction similar to those from which we suffer the way to such a course be easy it should however by no mean be lightly enter upon since the necessity for the inauguration of such a policy would be regret by the good sentiment of our people and because it naturally and logically might lead to consequence of the grave character i take pleasure in call to your attention the encomium bestow on those vessel of our new navy which take part in the notable ceremony of the opening of the kiel canal it be fitting that this extraordinary achievement of the new german nationality should be celebrate in the presence of america 's exposition of the late development of the world s naval energy our relation with great britain always intimate and important have demand during the past year even a great share of consideration than be usual several vexatious question be leave undetermined by the decision of the bering sea arbitration tribunal the application of the principle lay down by that august body have not be follow by the result they be intend to accomplish either because the principle themselves lack should be make it be apparent that the boundary dispute between great britain and the republic of venezuela concern the limit of british guiana be approach an acute stage a definite statement of the may be find in the single and simple remedy of the free coinage of silver they contend that our mint shall be at once throw open to the free unlimited and independent coinage of both gold and silver the gold dollar at the present standard and only 50 cent in intrinsic worth of silver in the silver dollar be there infinitely strong reason than can be adduce for hope that such action would secure for we a bimetallic currency move on line of parity an experiment so novel and hazardous as that propose might well stagger those who believe that stability be an imperative condition of sound money no government no human contrivance or act of legislation have ever be able to hold the two metal together in free coinage at a ratio appreciably different from that which be establish in the market of the world those who believe that our independent free coinage of silver at an artificial ratio with gold of 16 to 1 would restore the parity between the metal and consequently between the coin oppose an unsupported and improbable theory to the general belief and practice of other nation and to the teaching of the wise statesman and economist of the world both in the past and present and what be far more conclusive they run counter to our own actual experience twice in our early history our lawmaker in attempt to establish a bimetallic currency undertake free coinage upon a ratio which accidentally vary from the actual relative value of the two metal not more than 3 per cent in both case notwithstanding great difficulty and cost of transportation than now exist the coin whose intrinsic worth be undervalue in the ratio gradually and surely disappear from our circulation and go to other country where their real value be well recognize act of congress be impotent to create equality where natural cause decreed even a slight inequality twice in our recent history we have signally fail to raise by legislation the value of silver under an act of congress pass in 1878 the government be require for more than twelve year to expend annually at least $ 24,000,000 in the purchase of silver bullion for coinage the act of july 14 1890 in a still bold effort increase the amount of silver the government be compel to purchase and force it to become the buyer annually of 54,000,000 ounce or practically the entire product of our mine under both law silver rapidly and steadily decline in value the prophecy and the express hope and expectation of those in the congress who lead in the passage of the last mention act that it would reestablish and maintain the former parity between the two metal be still fresh in our memory in the light of these experience which accord with the experience of other nation there be certainly no secure ground for the belief that an act of congress could now bridge an inequality of 50 per cent between gold and silver at our present ratio nor be there the least possibility that our country which have less than one seventh of the silver money in the world could by its action alone raise not only our own but all silver to its lose ratio with gold our attempt to accomplish this by the free coinage of silver at a ratio differ widely from actual relative value would be the signal for the complete departure of gold from our circulation the immediate and large contraction of our circulate medium and a shrinkage in the real value and monetary efficiency of all other form of currency as they settle to the level of silver monometallism everyone who receive a fix salary and every worker for wage would find the dollar in his hand ruthlessly scale down to the point of bitter disappointment if not to pinch privation a change in our standard to silver monometallism would also bring on a collapse of the entire system of credit which when base on a standard which be recognize and adopt by the world of business be many time more potent and useful than the entire volume of currency and be safely capable of almost indefinite expansion to meet the growth of trade and enterprise in a self invite struggle through darkness and uncertainty our humiliation would be increase by the consciousness that we have part company with all the enlightened and progressive nation of the world and be desperately and hopelessly strive to meet the stress of modern commerce and competition with a debased and unsuitable currency and in association with the few weak and laggard nation which have silver alone as their standard of value all history warn we against rash experiment which threaten violent change in our monetary standard and the degradation of our currency the past be full of lesson teach not only the economic danger but the national immorality that follow in the train of such experiment i will not believe that the american people can be persuade after sober deliberation to jeopardize their nation 's prestige and proud standing by encourage financial nostrum nor that they will yield to the false allurement of cheap money when they realize that it must result in the weakening of that financial integrity and rectitude which thus far in our history have be so devotedly cherish as one of the trait of true americanism our country 's indebtedness whether owe by the government or exist between individual have be contract with reference to our present standard to decree by act of congress that these debt shall be payable in less valuable dollar than those within the contemplation and intention of the party when contract would operate to transfer by the fiat of law and without compensation an amount of property and a volume of right and interest almost incalculable those who advocate a blind and headlong plunge to free coinage in the name of bimetallism and profess the belief contrary to all experience that we could thus establish a double standard and a concurrent circulation of both metal in our coinage be certainly reckon from a cloudy standpoint our present standard of value be the standard of the civilized world and permit the only bimetallism now possible or at least that be within the independent reach of any single nation however powerful that nation may be while the value of gold as a standard be steady by almost universal commercial and business use it do not despise silver nor seek its banishment wherever this standard be maintain there be at its side in free and unquestioned circulation a volume of silver currency sometimes equal and sometimes even exceed it in amount both maintain at a parity notwithstanding a depreciation or fluctuation in the intrinsic value of silver there be a vast difference between a standard of value and a currency for monetary use the standard must necessarily be fix and certain the currency may be in diver form and of various kind no silver standard country have a gold currency in circulation but an enlightened and wise system of finance secure the benefit of both gold and silver as currency and circulate medium by keep the standard stable and all other currency at par with it such a system and such a standard also give free scope for the use and expansion of safe and conservative credit so indispensable to broad and grow commercial transaction and so well substitute for the actual use of money if a fixed and stable standard be maintain such as the magnitude and safety of our commercial transaction and business require the use of money itself be conveniently minimize every dollar of fixed and stable value have through the agency of confident credit an astonishing capacity of multiply itself in financial work every unstable and fluctuating dollar fail as a basis of credit and in its use beget gambling speculation and undermine the foundation of honest enterprise i have venture to express myself on this subject with earnestness and plainness of speech because i can not rid myself of the belief that there lurk in the proposition for the free coinage of silver so strongly approve and so enthusiastically advocate by a multitude of my countryman a serious menace to our prosperity and an insidious temptation of our people to wander from the allegiance they owe to public and private integrity it be because i do not distrust the good faith and sincerity of those who press this scheme that i have imperfectly but with zeal submit my thought upon this momentous subject i can not refrain from beg they to reexamine their view and belief in the light of patriotic reason and familiar experience and to weigh again and again the consequence of such legislation as their effort have invite even the continue agitation of the subject add greatly to the difficulty of a dangerous financial situation already force upon we in conclusion i especially entreat the people 's representative in the congress who be charge with the responsibility of inaugurate measure for the safety and prosperity of our common country to promptly and effectively consider the ill of our critical financial plight i have suggest a remedy which my judgment approve i desire however to assure the congress that i be prepared to cooperate with they in perfect any other measure promise thorough and practical relief and that i will gladly labor with they in every patriotic endeavor to further the interest and guard the welfare of our countryman whom in our respective place of duty we have undertake to serve
to the congress
 in my annual message address to the congress on the 3d instant i call attention to the pende boundary controversy between great britain and the republic of venezuela and recite the substance of a representation make by this government to her britannic majesty&#39 s government suggest reason why such dispute should be submit to arbitration for settlement and inquire whether it would be so submit
 the answer of the british government which be then await have since be receive and together with the dispatch to which it be a reply be hereto append
 such reply be embody in two communication address by the british prime minister to sir julian pauncefote the british ambassador at this capital it will be see that one of these communication be devote exclusively to observation upon the monroe doctrine and claim that in the present instance a new and strange extension and development of this doctrine be insist on by the united states that the reason justify an appeal to the doctrine enunciate by president monroe be generally inapplicable to the state of thing in which we live at the present day and especially inapplicable to a controversy involve the boundary line between great britain and venezuela
 without attempt extended argument in reply to these position it may not be amiss to suggest that the doctrine upon which we stand be strong and sound because its enforcement be important to our peace and safety as a nation and be essential to the integrity of our free institution and the tranquil maintenance of our distinctive form of government it be intend to apply to every stage of our national life and can not become obsolete while our republic endure if the balance of power be justly a cause for jealous anxiety among the government of the old world and a subject for our absolute noninterference none the less be an observance of the monroe doctrine of vital concern to our people and their government
 assuming therefore that we may properly insist upon this doctrine without regard to the state of thing in which we live or any change condition here or elsewhere it be not apparent why its application may not be invoke in the present controversy
 if a european power by an extension of its boundary take possession of the territory of one of our neighbor republic against its will and in derogation of its right it be difficult to see why to that extent such european power do not thereby attempt to extend its system of government to that portion of this continent which be thus take this be the precise action which president monroe declare to be dangerous to our peace and safety and it can make no difference whether the european system be extend by an advance of frontier or otherwise
 it be also suggest in the british reply that we should not seek to apply the monroe doctrine to the pende dispute because it do not embody any principle of international law which be round on the general consent of nation and that no statesman however eminent and no nation however powerful be competent to insert into the code of international law a novel principle which be never recognize before and which have not since be accept by the government of any other country
 practically the principle for which we contend have peculiar if not exclusive relation to the united states it may not have be admit in so many word to the code of international law but since in international council every nation be entitle to the right belong to it if the enforcement of the monroe doctrine be something we may justly claim it have its place in the code of international law as certainly and as securely as if it be specifically mention and when the united states be a suitor before the high tribunal that administer international law the question to be determine be whether or not we present claim which the justice of that code of law can find to be right and valid
 the monroe doctrine find its recognition in those principle of international law which be base upon the theory that every nation shall have its right protect and its just claim enforce
 of course this government be entirely confident that under the sanction of this doctrine we have clear right and undoubted claim nor be this ignore in the british reply the prime minister while not admit that the monroe doctrine be applicable to present condition state
 in declare that the united states would resist any such enterprise if it be contemplate president monroe adopt a policy which receive the entire sympathy of the english government of that date
 he far declare
 though the language of president monroe be direct to the attainment of object which most englishman would agree to be salutary it be impossible to admit that they have be inscribe by any adequate authority in the code of international law
 again he say
 they her majesty&#39;s government fully concur with the view which president monroe apparently entertain that any disturbance of the exist territorial distribution in that hemisphere by any fresh acquisition on the part of any european state would be a highly inexpedient change
 in the belief that the doctrine for which we contend be clear and definite that it be round upon substantial consideration and involve our safety and welfare that it be fully applicable to our present condition and to the state of the world&#39;s progress and that it be directly relate to the pende controversy and without any conviction as to the final merit of the dispute but anxious to learn in a satisfactory and conclusive manner whether great britain seek under a claim of boundary to extend her possession on this continent without right or whether she merely seek possession of territory fairly include within her line of ownership this government propose to the government of great britain a resort to arbitration as the proper mean of settle the question to the end that a vexatious boundary dispute between the two contestant might be determine and our exact standing and relation in respect to the controversy might be make clear
 it will be see from the correspondence herewith submit that this proposition have be decline by the british government upon ground which in the circumstance seem to i to be far from satisfactory it be deeply disappointing that such an appeal actuate by the most friendly feeling toward both nation directly concern address to the sense of justice and to the magnanimity of one of the great power of the world and touch its relation to one comparatively weak and small should have produce no well result
 the course to be pursue by this government in view of the present condition do not appear to admit of serious doubt having labor faithfully for many year to induce great britain to submit this dispute to impartial arbitration and having be now finally apprise of her refusal to do so nothing remain but to accept the situation to recognize its plain requirement and deal with it accordingly great britain&#39;s present proposition have never thus far be regard as admissible by venezuela though any adjustment of the boundary which that country may deem for her advantage and may enter into of her own free will can not of course be object to by the united states
 assuming however that the attitude of venezuela will remain unchanged the dispute have reach such a stage as to make it now incumbent upon the united states to take measure to determine with sufficient certainty for its justification what be the true divisional line between the republic of venezuela and british guiana the inquiry to that end should of course be conduct carefully and judicially and due weight should be give to all available evidence record and fact in support of the claim of both party
 in order that such an examination should be prosecute in a thorough and satisfactory manner i suggest that the congress make an adequate appropriation for the expense of a commission to be appoint by the executive who shall make the necessary investigation and report upon the matter with the least possible delay when such report be make and accept it will in my opinion be the duty of the united states to resist by every mean in its power as a willful aggression upon its right and interest the appropriation by great britain of any land or the exercise of governmental jurisdiction over any territory which after investigation we have determine of right belong to venezuela
 in make these recommendation i be fully alive to the responsibility incur and keenly realize all the consequence that may follow
 i be nevertheless firm in my conviction that while it be a grievous thing to contemplate the two great english speak people of the world as be otherwise than friendly competitor in the onward march of civilization and strenuous and worthy rival in all the art of peace there be no calamity which a great nation can invite which equal that which follow a supine submission to wrong and injustice and the consequent loss of national self respect and honor beneath which be shield and defend a people&#39; safety and greatness

to the congress
 in my last annual message the evil of our present financial system be plainly point out and the cause and mean of the depletion of government gold be explain it be therein state that after all the effort that have be make by the executive branch of the government to protect our gold reserve by the issuance of bond amount to more than $ 162,000,000 such reserve then amount to but little more than $ 79,000,000 that about $ 16,000,000 have be withdraw from such reserve during the month next previous to the date of that message and that quite large withdrawal for shipment in the immediate future be predict
 the contingency then fear have reach we and the withdrawal of gold since the communication refer to and other that appear inevitable threaten such a depletion in our government gold reserve as bring we face to face to the necessity of further action for its protection this condition be intensify by the prevalence in certain quarter of sudden and unusual apprehension and timidity in business circle
 we be in the midst of another season of perplexity cause by our dangerous and fatuous financial operation these may be expect to recur with certainty as long as there be no amendment in our financial system if in this particular instance our predicament be at all influence by a recent insistence upon the position we should occupy in our relation to certain question concern our foreign policy this furnish a signal and impressive warning that even the patriotic sentiment of our people be not an adequate substitute for a sound financial policy
 of course there can be no doubt in any thoughtful mind as to the complete solvency of our nation nor can there be any just apprehension that the american people will be satisfied with less than an honest payment of our public obligation in the recognize money of the world we should not overlook the fact however that arouse fear be unreasone and must be take into account in all effort to avert possible loss and the sacrifice of our people&#39; interest
 the real and sensible cure for our recur trouble can only be effect by a complete change in our financial scheme pende that the executive branch of the government will not relax its effort nor abandon its determination to use every mean within its reach to maintain before the world american credit nor will there be any hesitation in exhibit its confidence in the resource of our country and the constant patriotism of our people
 in view however of the peculiar situation now confront we i have venture to herein express the earnest hope that the congress in default of the inauguration of a well system of finance will not take a recess from its labor before it have by legislative enactment or declaration do something not only to remind those apprehensive among our own people that the resource of their government and a scrupulous regard for honest dealing afford a sure guaranty of unquestioned safety and soundness but to reassure the world that with these factor and the patriotism of our citizen the ability and determination of our nation to meet in any circumstance every obligation it incur do not admit of question
 i ask at the hand of the congress such prompt aid as it alone have the power to give to prevent in a time of fear and apprehension any sacrifice of the people&#39; interest and the public fund or the impairment of our public credit in an effort by executive action to relieve the danger of the present emergency

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas by a proclamation date the 12th day of june a.d. 1895 attention be call to the serious civil disturbance accompany by armed resistance to the established government of spain then prevail in the island of cuba and citizen of the united states and all other person be admonish to abstain from take part in such disturbance in contravention of the neutrality law of the united states and
 whereas say civil disturbance and armed resistance to the authority of spain a power with which the united states be on term of peace and amity continue to prevail in say island of cuba and
 whereas since the date of say proclamation say neutrality law of the united states have be the subject of authoritative exposition by the judicial tribunal of last resort and it have thus be declare that any combination of person organize in the united states for the purpose of proceed to and make war upon a foreign country with which the united states be at peace and provide with arm to be use for such purpose constitute a military expedition or enterprise within the meaning of say neutrality law and that the providing or prepare of the mean for such military expedition or enterprise which be expressly prohibit by say law include furnish or aid in transportation for such military expedition or enterprise and
 whereas by express enactment if two or more person conspire to commit an offense against the united states any act of one conspirator to effect the object of such conspiracy render all the conspirator liable to fine and imprisonment and
 whereas there be reason to believe that citizen of the united states and other within their jurisdiction fail to apprehend the meaning and operation of the neutrality law of the united states as authoritatively interpret as aforesaid and may be mislead into participation in transaction which be violation of say law and will render they liable to the severe penalty provide for such violation
 now therefore that the law above refer to as judicially construe may be duly execute that the international obligation of the united states may be fully satisfied and that their citizen and all other within their jurisdiction be seasonably apprised of their legal duty in the premise may abstain from disobedience to the law of the united states and thereby escape the forfeiture and penalty legally consequent thereon i grover cleveland president of the united states do hereby solemnly warn all citizen of the united states and all other within their jurisdiction against violation of the say law interpret as hereinbefore explain and give notice that all such violation will be vigorously prosecute and i do hereby invoke the cooperation of all good citizen in the enforcement of say law and in the detection and apprehension of any offender against the same and do hereby enjoin upon all the executive officer of the united states the utmost diligence in prevent prosecute and punish any infraction thereof
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 27th day of july a. d. 1896 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and twenty first
 grover cleveland
 by the president
