 secretary of state

to the congress of the united states as representative of the people in the legislative branch of their government you have assemble at a time when the strength and excellence of our free institution and the fitness of our citizen to enjoy popular rule have be again make manifest a political contest involve momentous consequence fraught with feverish apprehension and create aggressiveness so intense as to approach bitterness and passion have be wage throughout our land and determine by the decree of free and independent suffrage without disturbance of our tranquillity or the least sign of weakness in our national structure when we consider these incident and contemplate the peaceful obedience and manly submission which have succeed a heated clash of political opinion we discover abundant evidence of a determination on the part of our countryman to abide by every verdict of the popular will and to be control at all time by an abide faith in the agency establish for the direction of the affair of their government thus our people exhibit a patriotic disposition which entitle they to demand of those who undertake to make and execute their law such faithful and unselfish service in their behalf as can only be prompt by a serious appreciation of the trust and confidence which the acceptance of public duty invite in obedience to a constitutional requirement i herein submit to the congress certain information concern national affair with the suggestion of such legislation as in my judgment be necessary and expedient to secure brevity and avoid tiresome narration i shall omit many detail concern matter within federal control which though by no mean unimportant be more profitably discuss in departmental report i shall also far curtail this communication by omit a minute recital of many minor incident connect with our foreign relation which have heretofore find a place in executive message but be now contain in a report of the secretary of state which be herewith submit at the outset of a reference to the more important matter affect our relation with foreign power it would afford i satisfaction if i could assure the congress that the disturbed condition in asiatic turkey have during the past year assume a less hideous and bloody aspect and that either as a consequence of the awakening of the turkish government to the demand of humane civilization or as the result of decisive action on the part of the great nation have the right by treaty to interfere for the protection of those expose to the rage of mad bigotry and cruel fanaticism the shocking feature of the situation have be mitigate instead however of welcome a soften disposition or protective intervention we have be afflict by continue and not unfrequent report of the wanton destruction of home and the bloody butchery of man woman and child make martyr to their profession of christian faith while none of our citizen in turkey have thus far be kill or wound though often in the midst of dreadful scene of danger their safety in the future be by no mean assure our government at home and our minister at constantinople have leave nothing undo to protect our missionary in ottoman territory who constitute nearly all the individual reside there who have a right to claim our protection on the score of american citizenship our effort in this direction will not be relax but the deep feeling and sympathy that have be arouse among our people ought not to so far blind their reason and judgment as to lead they to demand impossible thing the outbreak of the blind fury which lead to murder and pillage in turkey occur suddenly and without notice and an attempt on our part to force such a hostile presence there as might be effective for prevention or protection would not only be resist by the ottoman government but would be regard as an interruption of their plan by the great nation who assert their exclusive right to intervene in their own time and method for the security of life and property in turkey several naval vessel be station in the mediterranean as a measure of caution and to furnish all possible relief and refuge in case of emergency we have make claim against the turkish government for the pillage and destruction of missionary property at harpoot and marash during uprising at those place thus far the validity of these demand have not be admit though our minister prior to such outrage and in anticipation of danger demand protection for the person and property of our missionary citizen in the locality mention and notwithstanding that strong evidence exist of actual complicity of turkish soldier in the work of destruction and robbery the fact as they now appear do not permit we to doubt the justice of these claim and nothing will be omit to bring about their prompt settlement a number of armenian refugee having arrive at our port an order have lately be obtain from the turkish government permit the wife and child of such refugee to join they here it be hope that hereafter no obstacle will be interpose to prevent the escape of all those who seek to avoid the peril which threaten they in turkish dominion our recently appoint consul to erzerum be at his post and discharge the duty of his office though for some unaccountable reason his formal exequatur from the sultan have not be issue i do not believe that the present somber prospect in turkey will be long permit to offend the sight of christendom it so mar the humane and enlightened civilization that belong to the close of the nineteenth century that it seem hardly possible that the earnest demand of good people throughout the christian world for its corrective treatment will remain unanswered the insurrection in cuba still continue with all its perplexity it be difficult to perceive that any progress have thus far be make toward the pacification of the island or that the situation of affair as depict in my last annual message have in the least improve if spain still hold havana and the seaport and all the considerable town the insurgent still roam at will over at least two third of the inland country if the determination of spain to put down the insurrection seem but to strengthen with the lapse of time and be evince by she unhesitate devotion of largely increase military and naval force to the task there be much reason to believe that the insurgent have gain in point of number and character and resource and be none the less inflexible in their resolve not to succumb without practically secure the great object for which they take up arm if spain have not yet reestablish her authority neither have the insurgent yet make good their title to be regard as an independent state indeed as the contest have go on the pretense that civil government exist on the island except so far as spain be able to maintain it have be practically abandon spain do keep on foot such a government more or less imperfectly in the large town and their immediate suburb but that exception be make the entire country be either give over to anarchy or be subject to the military occupation of one or the other party it be report indeed on reliable authority that at the demand of the commander in chief of the insurgent army the putative cuban government have now give up all attempt to exercise its function leave that government confessedly what there be the good reason for suppose it always to have be in fact a government merely on paper be the spanish army able to meet their antagonist in the open or in pitch battle prompt and decisive result might be look for and the immense superiority of the spanish force in number discipline and equipment could hardly fail to tell greatly to their advantage but they be call upon to face a foe that shun general engagement that can choose and do choose its own ground that from the nature of the country be visible or invisible at pleasure and that fight only from ambuscade and when all the advantage of position and number be on its side in a country where all that be indispensable to life in the way of food clothing and shelter be so easily obtainable especially by those bear and breed on the soil it be obvious that there be hardly a limit to the time during which hostility of this sort may be prolong meanwhile as in all case of protract civil strife the passion of the combatant grow more and more inflame and excess on both side become more frequent and more deplorable they be also participate in by band of marauder who now in the name of one party and now in the name of the other as may well suit the occasion harry the country at will and plunder its wretched inhabitant for their own advantage such a condition of thing would inevitably entail immense destruction of property even if it be the policy of both party to prevent it as far as practicable but while such seem to be the original policy of the spanish government it have now apparently abandon it and be act upon the same theory as the insurgent namely that the exigency of the contest require the wholesale annihilation of property that it may not prove of use and advantage to the enemy it be to the same end that in pursuance of general order spanish garrison be now be withdraw from plantation and the rural population require to concentrate itself in the town the sure result would seem to be that the industrial value of the island be fast diminishing and that unless there be a speedy and radical change in exist condition it will soon disappear altogether that value consist very largely of course in its capacity to produce sugar a capacity already much reduce by the interruption to tillage which have take place during the last two year it be reliably assert that should these interruption continue during the current year and practically extend as be now threaten to the entire sugar produce territory of the island so much time and so much money will be require to restore the land to its normal productiveness that it be extremely doubtful if capital can be induce to even make the attempt the spectacle of the utter ruin of an adjoining country by nature one of the most fertile and charming on the globe would engage the serious attention of the government and people of the united states in any circumstance in point of fact they have a concern with it which be by no mean of a wholly sentimental or philanthropic character it lie so near to we as to be hardly separate from our territory our actual pecuniary interest in it be second only to that of the people and government of spain it be reasonably estimate that at least from $ 30,000,000 to $ 50,000,000 of american capital be invest in plantation and in railroad mining and other business enterprise on the island the volume of trade between the united states and cuba which in 1889 amount to about $ 64,000,000 rise in 1893 to about $ 103,000,000 and in 1894 the year before the present insurrection break out amount to nearly $ 96,000,000 besides this large pecuniary stake in the fortune of cuba the united states find itself inextricably involve in the present contest in other way both vexatious and costly many cubans reside in this country and indirectly promote the insurrection through the press by public meeting by the purchase and shipment of arm by the raising of fund and by other mean which the spirit of our institution and the tenor of our law do not permit to be make the subject of criminal prosecution some of they though cubans at heart and in all their feeling and interest have take out paper as naturalized citizen of the united states a proceeding resort to with a view to possible protection by this government and not unnaturally regard with much indignation by the country of their origin the insurgent be undoubtedly encourage and support by the widespread sympathy the people of this country always and instinctively feel for every struggle for well and free government and which in the case of the more adventurous and restless element of our population lead in only too many instance to active and personal participation in the contest the result be that this government be constantly call upon to protect american citizen to claim damage for injury to person and property now estimate at many million of dollar and to ask explanation and apology for the act of spanish official whose zeal for the repression of rebellion sometimes blind they to the immunity belong to the unoffending citizen of a friendly power it follow from the same cause that the united states be compel to actively police a long line of seacoast against unlawful expedition the escape of which the utmost vigilance will not always suffice to prevent these inevitable entanglement of the united states with the rebellion in cuba the large american property interest affect and consideration of philanthropy and humanity in general have lead to a vehement demand in various quarter for some sort of positive intervention on the part of the united states it be at first propose that belligerent right should be accord to the insurgent a proposition no long urge because untimely and in practical operation dearly perilous and injurious to our own interest it have since be and be now sometimes contend that the independence of the insurgent should be recognize but imperfect and restrict as the spanish government of the island may be no other exist there unless the will of the military officer in temporary command of a particular district can be dignified as a species of government it be now also suggest that the united states should buy the island a suggestion possibly worthy of consideration if there be any evidence of a desire or willingness on the part of spain to entertain such a proposal it be urge finally that all other method fail the exist internecine strife in cuba should be terminate by our intervention even at the cost of a war between the united states and spain a war which its advocate confidently prophesy could neither be large in its proportion nor doubtful in its issue the correctness of this forecast need be neither affirm nor deny the united states have nevertheless a character to maintain as a nation which plainly dictate that right and not might should be the rule of its conduct far though the united states be not a nation to which peace be a necessity it be in truth the most pacific of power and desire nothing so much as to live in amity with all the world its own ample and diversified domain satisfy all possible longing for territory preclude all dream of conquest and prevent any casting of covetous eye upon neighboring region however attractive that our conduct toward spain and her dominion have constitute no exception to this national disposition be make manifest by the course of our government not only thus far during the present insurrection but during the ten year that follow the rise at yara in 1868 no other great power it may safely be say under circumstance of similar perplexity would have manifest the same restraint and the same patient endurance it may also be say that this persistent attitude of the united states toward spain in connection with cuba unquestionably evince no slight respect and regard for spain on the part of the american people they in truth do not forget her connection with the discovery of the western hemisphere nor do they underestimate the great quality of the spanish people nor fail to fully recognize their splendid patriotism and their chivalrous devotion to the national honor they view with wonder and admiration the cheerful resolution with which vast body of man be send across thousand of mile of ocean and an enormous debt accumulate that the costly possession of the gem of the antilles may still hold its place in the spanish crown and yet neither the government nor the people of the united states have shut their eye to the course of event in cuba or have fail to realize the existence of concede grievance which have lead to the present revolt from the authority of spain grievance recognize by the queen regent and by the cortes voice by the most patriotic and enlighten of spanish statesman without regard to party and demonstrate by reform propose by the executive and approve by the legislative branch of the have hope to discover the most promising and effective mean of compose the present strife with honor and advantage to spain and with the achievement of all the reasonable object of the insurrection it would seem that if spain should offer to cuba genuine autonomy a measure of home rule which while preserve the sovereignty of spain would satisfy all rational requirement of her spanish subject there should be no just reason why the pacification of the island might not be effect on that basis such a result would appear to be in the true interest of all concern it would at once stop the conflict which be now consume the resource of the island and make it worthless for whichever party may ultimately prevail it would keep intact the possession of spain without touch her honor which will be consult rather than impugn by the adequate redress of admitted grievance it would put the prosperity of the island and the fortune of its inhabitant within their own control without sever the natural and ancient tie which bind they to the mother country and would yet enable they to test their capacity for self government under the most favorable condition it have be object on the one side that spain should not promise autonomy until her insurgent subject lie down their arm on the other side that promise autonomy however liberal be insufficient because without assurance of the promise be fulfil but the reasonableness of a requirement by spain of unconditional surrender on the part of the insurgent cubans before their autonomy be concede be not altogether apparent it ignore important feature of the situation the stability two year duration have give to the insurrection the feasibility of its indefinite prolongation in the nature of thing and as show by past experience the utter and imminent ruin of the island unless the present strife be speedily compose above all the rank abuse which all party in spain all branch of her government and all her lead public man concede to exist and profess a desire to remove face such circumstance to withhold the proffer of need reform until the party demand they put themselves at mercy by throw down their arm have the appearance of neglect the gravest of peril and invite suspicion as to the sincerity of any profess willingness to grant reform the objection on behalf of the insurgent that promise reform can not be rely upon must of course be consider though we have no right to assume and no reason for assume that anything spain undertake to do for the relief of cuba will not be do accord to both the spirit and the letter of measure of home rule be tender the cuban insurgent and would be accept by they upon a guaranty of its execution the united states would endeavor to find a way not objectionable to spain of furnish such graranty while no definite response to this intimation have yet be receive from the spanish government it be believe to be not altogether unwelcome while as already suggest no reason be perceive add enormously to the time and labor and expenditure necessary to bring about the industrial recuperation of the island it be therefore fervently hope on all ground that earnest effort for heal the breach between spain and the insurgent cubans upon the line above indicate may be at once inaugurate and push to an immediate and successful issue the friendly office of the united states either in the manner above outline or in any other way consistent with our constitution and law will always be at the disposal of either party whatever circumstance may arise our policy and our interest would constrain we to object to the acquisition of the island or an interference with its control by any other power it should be add that it can not be reasonably assume that the hitherto expectant attitude of the united states will be indefinitely maintain while we be anxious to accord all due respect to the sovereignty of spain we can not view the pende conflict in all its feature and properly apprehend our inevitably close relation to it and its possible result without consider that by the course of event we may be draw into such an unusual and unprecedented condition as will fix a limit to our patient wait for spain to end the contest either alone and in her own way or with our friendly cooperation when the inability of spain to deal successfully with the insurrection have become manifest and it be demonstrate that her sovereignty be extinct in cuba for all purpose of its rightful existence and when a hopeless struggle for its reestablishment have degenerate into a strife which mean nothing more than the useless sacrifice of human life and the utter destruction of the very subject matter of the conflict a situation will be present in which our obligation to the sovereignty of spain will be supersede by high obligation which we can hardly hesitate to recognize and discharge defer the choice of way and method until the time for action arrive we should make they depend upon the precise condition then exist and they should not be determine upon without give careful heed to every consideration involve our honor and interest or the international duty we owe to spain until we face the contingency suggest or the situation be by other incident imperatively change we should continue in the line of conduct heretofore pursue thus in all circumstance exhibit our obedience to the requirement of public law and our regard for the duty enjoin upon we by the position we occupy in the family of nation a contemplation of emergency that may arise should plainly lead we to avoid their creation either through a careless disregard of present duty or even an undue stimulation and ill timed expression of feeling but i have deem it not amiss to remind the congress be nearly $ 70,000,000 more than during the precede year those who insist that the cost to our people of article come to they from abroad for their needful use should only be increase through tariff believe our present tariff law if allow a fair opportunity will in the near future yield a revenue which with reasonably economical expenditure will overcome all deficiency in the meantime no deficit that have occur or may occur need excite or disturb we to meet any such deficit we have in the treasury in addition to a gold reserve of one hundred million a surplus of more than $ 128,000,000 applicable to the payment of the expense of the government and which must unless expend for that purpose remain a useless hoard or if not extravagantly waste must in any event be pervert from the purpose of its exaction from our people the payment therefore of any deficiency in the revenue from this fund be nothing more than its proper and legitimate use the government thus apply a surplus fortunately in its treasury to the payment of expense not meet by its current revenue be not at all to be liken to a man live beyond his income and thus incur debt or encroach on his principal it be not one of the function of our government to accumulate and make addition to a fund not need for immediate expenditure with individual it be the chief object of struggle and effort the application of an accumulate fund by the government to the payment of its running expense be a duty an individual live beyond his income and embarrass himself with debt or draw upon his accumulate fund of principal be either unfortunate or improvident the distinction be between a government charge with the duty of expend for the benefit of the people and for proper purpose all the money it receive from any source and the individual who be expect to manifest a natural desire to avoid debt or to accumulate as much as possible and to live within the income derive from such accumulation to the end that they may be increase or at least remain unimpaired for the future use and enjoyment of himself or the object of his love and affection who may survive he it be immeasurably well to appropriate our surplus to the payment of justifiable expense than to allow it to become an invitation to reckless appropriation and extravagant expenditure i suppose it will not be deny that under the present law our people obtain the necessary of a comfortable existence at a cheap rate than formerly this be a matter of supreme importance since it be the palpable duty of every just government to make the burden of taxation as light as possible the people should not be require to relinquish this privilege of cheap living except under the stress of their government 's necessity make plainly manifest this reference to the condition and prospect of our revenue naturally suggest an allusion to the weakness and vice of our financial method they have be frequently press upon the attention of congress in previous executive communication and the inevitable danger of their continue toleration point out without now repeat these detail i can not refrain from again earnestly present the necessity of the prompt reform of a system oppose to every rule of sound finance and show by experience to be fraught with the grave peril and perplexity the terrible civil war which shake the foundation of our government more than thirty year ago bring in its train the destruction of property the wasting of our country 's substance and the estrangement of brother these be now past and forget even the distressing loss of life the conflict entail be but a sacred memory which foster patriotic sentiment and keep alive a tender regard for those who nobly die and yet there remain with we to day in full strength and activity as an incident of that tremendous struggle a feature of its financial necessity not only unsuited to our present circumstance but manifestly a disturbing menace to business security and an ever present agent of monetary distress because we may be enjoy a temporary relief from its depressing influence this should not lull we into a false security nor lead we to forget the suddenness of past visitation i be more convinced than ever that we can have no assure financial peace and safety until the government currency obligation upon which gold may be demand from the treasury be withdraw from circulation and cancel this might be do as have be heretofore recommend by their exchange for long term bond bear a low rate of interest or by their redemption with the proceed of such bond even if only the united states note know as greenback be thus retire it be probable that the treasury note issue in payment of silver purchase under the act of july 14 1890 now pay in gold when demand would not create much disturbance as they might from time to time when receive in the treasury by redemption in gold or otherwise be gradually and prudently replace by silver coin this plan of issue bond for the purpose of redemption certainly appear to be the most effective and direct path to the need reform in default of this however it would be a step in the right direction if currency obligation redeemable in gold whenever so redeemed should be cancel instead of be reissue this operation would be a slow remedy but it would improve present condition national bank should redeem their own note they should be allow to issue circulation to the par value of bond deposit as security for its redemption and the tax on their circulation should be reduce to one fourth of 1 per cent in consider project for the retirement of united states note and treasury note issue under the law of 1890 i be of the opinion that we have place too much stress upon the danger of contract the currency and have calculate too little upon the gold that would be add to our circulation if invite to we by well and safe financial method it be not so much a contraction of our currency that should be avoid as its unequal distribution this might be obviate and any fear of harmful contraction at the same time remove by allow the organization of small bank and in less populous community than be now permit and also authorize exist bank to establish branch in small community under proper restriction the entire case may be present by the statement that the day of sensible and sound financial method will not dawn upon we until our government abandon the banking business and the accumulation of fund and confine its monetary operation to the receipt of the money contribute by the people for its support and to the expenditure of such money for the people 's benefit our business interest and all good citizen long for rest from feverish agitation and the inauguration by the government of a reform financial policy which will encourage enterprise and make certain the reward of labor and industry another topic in which our people rightfully take a deep interest may be here briefly consider i refer to the existence of trust and other huge aggregation of capital the object of which be to secure the monopoly of some particular branch of trade industry or commerce and to stifle wholesome competition when these be defend it be usually on the ground that though they increase profit they also reduce price and thus may benefit the public it must be remember however that a reduction of price to the people be not one of the real object of these organization nor be their tendency necessarily in that direction if it occur in a particular case it be only because it accord with the purpose or interest of those manage the scheme such occasional result fall far short of compensate the palpable evil charge to the account of trust and monopoly their tendency be to crush out individual independence and to hinder or prevent the free use of human faculty and the full development of human character through they the farmer the artisan and the small trader be in danger of dislodgment from the proud position of be his own master watchful of all that touch his country 's prosperity in which he have an individual lot and interested in all that affect the advantage of business of which he be a factor to be relegate to the level of a mere appurtenance to a great machine with little free will with no duty but that of passive obedience and with little hope or opportunity of rise in the scale of responsible and helpful citizenship to the instinctive belief that such be the inevitable trend of trust and monopoly be due the widespread and deep seat popular aversion in which they be hold and the not unreasonable insistence that whatever may be their incidental economic advantage their general effect upon personal character prospect and usefulness can not be otherwise than injurious though congress have attempt to deal with this matter by legislation the law pass for that purpose thus far have prove ineffective not because of any lack of disposition or attempt to enforce they but simply because the law themselves as interpret by the court do not reach the difficulty if the insufficiency of exist law can be remedie by further legislation it should be do the fact must be recognize however that all federal legislation on this subject may fall short of its purpose because of inherent obstacle and also because of the complex character of our governmental system which while make the federal authority supreme within its sphere have carefully limit that sphere by mete and bound that can not be transgress the decision of our high court on this precise question render it quite doubtful whether the evil of trust and monopoly can be adequately treat through federal action unless they seek directly and purposely to include in their object transportation or intercourse between states or between the united states and foreign country it do not follow however that this be the limit of the remedy that may be apply even though it may be find that federal authority be not broad enough to fully reach the case there can be no doubt of the power of the several states to act effectively in the premise and there should be no reason to doubt their willingness to judiciously exercise such power in conclude this communication its last word shall be an appeal to the congress for the most rigid economy in the expenditure of the money it hold in trust for the people the way to perplex extravagance be easy but a return to frugality be difficult when however it be consider that those who bear the burden of taxation have no guaranty of honest care save in the fidelity of their public servant the duty of all possible retrenchment be plainly manifest when our difference be forget and our contest of political opinion be no long remember nothing in the retrospect of our public service will be as fortunate and comforting as the recollection of official duty well perform and the memory of a constant devotion to the interest of our confide fellow countryman
to the senate
 i transmit herewith a treaty for the arbitration of all matter in difference between the united states and great britain
 the provision of the treaty be the result of long and patient deliberation and represent concession make by each party for the sake of agreement upon the general scheme
 though the result reach may not meet the view of the advocate of immediate unlimited and irrevocable arbitration of all international controversy it be nevertheless confidently believe that the treaty can not fail to be everywhere recognize as make a long step in the right direction and as embody a practical working plan by which dispute between the two country will reach a peaceful adjustment as matter of course and in ordinary routine
 in the initiation of such an important movement it must be expect that some of its feature will assume a tentative character look to a further advance and yet it be apparent that the treaty which have be formulate not only make war between the party to it a remote possibility but preclude those fear and rumor of war which of themselves too often assume the proportion of national disaster
 it be eminently fitting as well as fortunate that the attempt to accomplish result so beneficent should be initiate by kindre people speak the same tongue and join together by all the tie of common tradition common institution and common aspiration the experiment of substitute civilized method for brute force as the mean of settle inter national question of right will thus be try under the happy auspex its success ought not to be doubtful and the fact that its ultimate ensue benefit be not likely to be limit to the two country immediately concern should cause it to be promote all the more eagerly the example set and the lesson furnish by the successful operation of this treaty be sure to be feel and take to heart soon or later by other nation and will thus mark the beginning of a new epoch in civilization
 profoundly impressed as i be therefore by the promise of transcendent good which this treaty afford i do not hesitate to accompany its transmission with an expression of my earnest hope that it may commend itself to the favorable consideration of the senate

to the house of representatives
 i herewith return without approval house bill no 7864 entitle an act to amend the immigration law of the united states
 by the first section of this bill it be propose to amend section 1 of the act of march 3 1891 relate to immigration by add to the class of alien thereby exclude from admission to the united states the follow
 all person physically capable and over 16 year of age who can not read and write the english language or some other language but a person not so able to read and write who be over 50 year of age and be the parent or grandparent of a qualified immigrant over 21 year of age and capable of support such parent or grandparent may accompany such immigrant or such a parent or grandparent may be send for and come to join the family of a child or grandchild over 21 year of age similarly qualified and capable and a wife or minor child not so able to read and write may accompany or be send for and come and join the husband or parent similarly qualified and capable
 a radical departure from our national policy relate to immigration be here present heretofore we have welcome all who come to we from other land except those whose moral or physical condition or history threaten danger to our national welfare and safety rely upon the zealous watchfulness of our people to prevent injury to our political and social fabric we have encourage those come from foreign country to cast their lot with we and join in the development of our vast domain secure in return a share in the blessing of american citizenship
 a century&#39;s stupendous growth largely due to the assimilation and thrift of million of sturdy and patriotic adopt citizen attest the success of this generous and free handed policy which while guard the people&#39; interest exact from our immigrant only physical and moral soundness and a willingness and ability to work
 a contemplation of the grand result of this policy can not fail to arouse a sentiment in its defense for however it might have be regard as an original proposition and view as an experiment its accomplishment be such that if it be to be uproot at this late day its disadvantage should be plainly apparent and the substitute adopt should be just and adequate free from uncertainty and guard against difficult or oppressive administration
 it be not claim i believe that the time have come for the further restriction of immigration on the ground that an excess of population overcrowd our land
 it be say however that the quality of recent immigration be undesirable the time be quite within recent memory when the same thing be say of immigrant who with their descendant be now number among our good citizen
 it be say that too many immigrant settle in our city thus dangerously increase their idle and vicious population this be certainly a disadvantage it can not be show however that it affect all our city nor that it be permanent nor do it appear that this condition where it exist demand as its remedy the reversal of our present immigration policy
 the claim be also make that the influx of foreign laborer deprive of the opportunity to work those who be well entitle than they to the privilege of earn their livelihood by daily toil an unfortunate condition be certainly present when any who be willing to labor be unemployed but so far as this condition now exist among our people it must be concede to be a result of phenomenal business depression and the stagnation of all enterprise in which labor be a factor with the advent of settled and wholesome financial and economic governmental policy and consequent encouragement to the activity of capital the misfortune of unemployed labor should to a great extent at least be remedie if it continue its natural consequence must be to check the further immigration to our city of foreign laborer and to deplete the rank of those already there in the meantime those most willing and well entitle ought to be able to secure the advantage of such work as there be to do
 it be propose by the bill under consideration to meet the allege difficulty of the situation by establish an educational test by which the right of a foreigner to make his home with we shall be determine its general scheme be to prohibit from admission to our country all immigrant physically capable and over 16 year of age who can not read and write the english language or some other language and it be provide that this test shall be apply by require immigrant seek admission to read and afterwards to write not less than twenty nor more than twenty five word of the constitution of the united states in some language and that any immigrant fail in this shall not be admit but shall be return to the country from whence he come at the expense of the steamship or railroad company which bring he
 the good reason that could be give for this radical restriction of immigration be the necessity of protect our population against degeneration and save our national peace and quiet from import turbulence and disorder
 i can not believe that we would be protect against these evil by limit immigration to those who can read and write in any language twenty five word of our constitution in my opinion it be infinitely more safe to admit a hundred thousand immigrant who though unable to read and write seek among we only a home and opportunity to work than to admit one of those unruly agitator and enemy of governmental control who can not only read and write but delight in arouse by inflammatory speech the illiterate and peacefully incline to discontent and tumult violence and disorder do not originate with illiterate laborer they be rather the victim of the educate agitator the ability to read and write as require in this bill in and of itself afford in my opinion a misleading test of contented industry and supply unsatisfactory evidence of desirable citizenship or a proper apprehension of the benefit of our institution if any particular element of our illiterate immigration be to be fear for other cause than illiteracy these cause should be deal with directly instead of make illiteracy the pretext for exclusion to the detriment of other illiterate immigrant against whom the real cause of complaint can not be allege
 the provision intend to rid that part of the propose legislation already refer to from obvious hardship appear to i to be indefinite and inadequate
 a parent grandparent wife or minor child of a qualified immigrant though unable to read and write may accompany the immigrant or be send for to join his family provide the immigrant be capable of support such relative these exception to the general rule of exclusion contain in the bill be make to prevent the separation of family and yet neither brother nor sister be provide for in order that relative who be provide for may be reunite those still in foreign land must be send for to join the immigrant here what formality be necessary to constitute this prerequisite and how be the fact of relationship and that the relative be send for to be establish be the illiterate relative of immigrant who have come here under prior law entitle to the advantage of these exception a husband who can read and write and who determine to abandon his illiterate wife abroad will find here under this law an absolutely safe retreat the illiterate relative mention must not only be send for but such immigrant must be capable of support they when they arrive this requirement proceed upon the assumption that the foreign relative come here be in every case by reason of poverty liable to become a public charge unless the immigrant be capable of their support the contrary be very often true and yet if unable to read and write though quite able and willing to support themselves and their relative here besides they could not be admit under the provision of this bill if the immigrant be impoverished though the aid of his fortunate but illiterate relative might be the mean of save he from pauperism
 the fourth section of this bill provides--
 that it shall be unlawful for any male alien who have not in good faith make his declaration before the proper court of his intention to become a citizen of the united states to be employ on any public work of the united states or to come regularly or habitually into the united states by land or water for the purpose of engage in any mechanical trade or manual labor for wage or salary return from time to time to a foreign country
 the fifth section provides--
 that it shall be unlawful for any person partnership company or corporation knowingly to employ any alien come into the united states in violation of the next precede section of this act
 the prohibition against the employment of alien upon any public work of the united states be in line with other legislation of a like character it be quite a different thing however to declare it a crime for an alien to come regularly and habitually into the united states for the purpose of obtain work from private party if such alien return from time to time to a foreign country and to constitute any employment of such alien a criminal offense
 when we consider these provision of the bill in connection with our long northern frontier and the boundary of our states and territories often but an imaginary line separate they from the british dominion and recall the friendly intercourse between the people who be neighbor on either side the provision of this bill affect they must be regard as illiberal narrow and un american
 the resident of these states and territories have separate and especial interest which in many case make an interchange of labor between their people and their alien neighbor most important frequently with the advantage largely in favor of our citizen this suggest the inexpediency of federal interference with these condition when not necessary to the correction of a substantial evil affect the general welfare such unfriendly legislation as be propose could hardly fail to provoke retaliatory measure to the injury of many of our citizen who now find employment on adjoining foreign soil
 the uncertainty of construction to which the language of these provision be subject be a serious objection to a statute which describe a crime an important element in the offense seek to be create by these section be the come regularly or habitually into the united states these word be impossible of definite and certain construction the same may be say of the equally important word return from time to time to a foreign country
 a careful examination of this bill have convince i that for the reason give and other not specifically state its provision be unnecessarily harsh and oppressive and that its defect in construction would cause vexation and its operation would result in harm to our citizen

to the congress of the united states
 regret the necessity which have require i to call you together i feel that your assembling in extraordinary session be indispensable because of the condition in which we find the revenue of the government it be concede that its current expenditure be great than its receipt and that such a condition have exist for now more than three year with unlimited mean at our command we be present the remarkable spectacle of increase our public debt by borrow money to meet the ordinary outlay incident upon even an economical and prudent administration of the government an examination of the subject disclose this fact in every detail and lead inevitably to the conclusion that the condition of the revenue which allow it be unjustifiable and should be correct
 we find by the report of the secretary of the treasury that the revenue for the fiscal year end june 30 1892 from all source be $ 425,868,260.22 and the expenditure for all purpose be $ 415,953,806.56 leave an excess of receipt over expenditure of $ 9,914,453.66 during that fiscal year $ 40,570,467.98 be pay upon the public debt which have be reduce since march 1 1889 $ 259,076,890 and the annual interest charge decrease $ 11,684,576.60 the receipt of the government from all source during the fiscal year end june 30 1893 amount to $ 461,716,561.94 and its expenditure to $ 459,374,887.65 show an excess of receipt over expenditure of $ 2,341,674.29
 since that time the receipt of no fiscal year and with but few exception of no month of any fiscal year have exceed the expenditure the receipt of the government from all source during the fiscal year end june 30 1894 be $ 372,802,498.29 and its expenditure $ 442,605,758.87 leave a deficit the first since the resumption of specie payment of $ 69,803,260.58 notwithstanding there be a decrease of $ 16,769,128.78 in the ordinary expense of the government as compare with the previous fiscal year its income be still not sufficient to provide for its daily necessity and the gold reserve in the treasury for the redemption of greenback be draw upon to meet they but this do not suffice and the government then resort to loan to replenish the reserve
 in february 1894 $ 50,000,000 in bond be issue and in november follow a second issue of $ 50,000,000 be deem necessary the sum of $ 117,171,795 be realize by the sale of these bond but the reserve be steadily decrease until on february 8 1895 a third sale of $ 62,315,400 in bond for $ 65,116,244 be announce to congress
 the receipt of the government for the fiscal year end june 30 1895 be $ 390,373,203.30 and the expenditure $ 433,178,426.48 show a deficit of $ 42,805,223.18 a further loan of $ 100,000,000 be negotiate by the government in february 1896 the sale net $ 1,166,246 and swell the aggregate of bond issue within three year to $ 262,315,400 for the fiscal year end june 30 1896 the revenue of the government from all source amount to $ 409,475,408.78 while its expenditure be $ 434,678,654.48 or an excess of expenditure over receipt of $ 25,203,245.70 in other word the total receipt for the three fiscal year end june 30 1896 be insufficient by $ 137,811,729.46 to meet the total expenditure
 nor have this condition since improve for the first half of the present fiscal year the receipt of the government exclusive of postal revenue be $ 157,507,603.76 and its expenditure exclusive of postal service $ 195,410,000.22 or an excess of expenditure over receipt of $ 37,902,396.46 in january of this year the receipt exclusive of postal revenue be $ 24,316,994.05 and the expenditure exclusive of postal service $ 30,269,389.29 a deficit of $ 5,952,395.24 for the month in february of this year the receipt exclusive of postal revenue be $ 24,400,997.38 and expenditure exclusive of postal service $ 28,796,056.66 a deficit of $ 4,395,059.28 or a total deficiency of $ 186,061,580.44 for the three year and eight month end march 1 1897 not only be we without a surplus in the treasury but with an increase in the public debt there have be a corresponding increase in the annual interest charge from $ 22,893,883.20 in 1892 the low of any year since 1862 to $ 34,387,297.60 in 1896 or an increase of $ 11,493,414.40
 it may be urge that even if the revenue of the government have be sufficient to meet all its ordinary expense during the past three year the gold reserve would still have be insufficient to meet the demand upon it and that bond would necessarily have be issue for its repletion be this as it may it be clearly manifest without deny or affirm the correctness of such a conclusion that the debt would have be decrease in at least the amount of the deficiency and business confidence immeasurably strengthen throughout the country
 congress should promptly correct the exist condition ample revenue must be supply not only for the ordinary expense of the government but for the prompt payment of liberal pension and the liquidation of the principal and interest of the public debt in raise revenue duty should be so levy upon foreign product as to preserve the home market so far as possible to our own producer to revive and increase manufacture to relieve and encourage agriculture to increase our domestic and foreign commerce to aid and develop mining and building and to render to labor in every field of useful occupation the liberal wage and adequate reward to which skill and industry be justly entitle the necessity of the passage of a tariff law which shall provide ample revenue need not be far urge the imperative demand of the hour be the prompt enactment of such a measure and to this object i earnestly recommend that congress shall make every endeavor before other business be transact let we first provide sufficient revenue to faithfully administer the government without the contracting of further debt or the continued disturbance of our finance


 to the senate and house of representatives of the united states
 official information from our consul in cuba establish the fact that a large number of american citizen in the island be in a state of destitution suffer for want of food and medicine this apply particularly to the rural district of the central and eastern part
 the agricultural class have be force from their farm into the near town where they be without work or money the local authority of the several town however kindly dispose be unable to relieve the need of their own people and be altogether powerless to help our citizen
 the late report of consul general lee estimate six to eight hundred americans be without mean of support i have assure he that provision would be make at once to relieve they to that end i recommend that congress make an appropriation of not less than $ 50,000 to be immediately available for use under the direction of the secretary of state
 it be desirable that a part of the sum which may be appropriate by congress should in the discretion of the secretary of state also be use for the transportation of american citizen who desire to return to the united states be without mean to do so



to the congress of the united states
 in my message convene the congress in extraordinary session i call attention to a single subject that of provide revenue adequate to meet the reasonable and proper expense of the government i believe that to be the most pressing subject for settlement then a bill to provide the necessary revenue for the government have already pass the house of representatives and the senate and await executive action
 another question of very great importance be that of the establishment of our currency and banking system on a well basis which i comment upon in my inaugural address in the follow word
 our financial system need some revision our money be all good now but its value must not far be threaten it should all be put upon an endure basis not subject to easy attack nor its stability to doubt or dispute the several form of our paper money offer in my judgment a constant embarrassment to the government and imperil a safe balance in the treasury
 nothing be settle more clearly at the late national election than the determination upon the part of the people to keep their currency stable in value and equal to that of the most advanced nation of the world
 the soundness of our currency be nowhere question no loss can occur to its holder it be the system which should be simplify and strengthen keep our money just as good as it be now with less expense to the government and the people
 the sentiment of the country be strongly in favor of early action by congress in this direction to revise our currency law and remove they from partisan contention a notable assembly of business man with delegate from twenty nine states and territories be hold at indianapolis in january of this year the financial situation command their earnest attention and after a two day session the convention recommend to congress the appointment of a monetary commission
 i recommend this report to the consideration of congress the author of the report recommend a commission to make a thorough investigation of the monetary affair and need of this country in all relation and aspect and to make proper suggestion as to any evil find to exist and the remedy therefor
 this subject should receive the attention of congress at its special session it ought not to be postpone until the regular session
 i therefore urgently recommend that a special commission be create non partisan in its character to be compose of well inform citizen of different party who will command the confidence of congress and the country because of their special fitness for the work whose duty it shall be to make recommendation of whatever change in our present banking and currency law may be find necessary and expedient and to report their conclusion on or before the 1st day of november next in order that the same may be transmit by i to congress for its consideration at its first regular session
 it be to be hope that the report thus make will be so comprehensive and sound as to receive the support of all party and the favorable action of congress at all event such a report can not fail to be of value to the executive branch of the government as well as to those charge with public legislation and to greatly assist in the establishment of an improved system of finance

to the senate and house of representatives it give i pleasure to extend greeting to the fifty fifth congress assemble in regular session at the seat of government with many of whose senator and representatives i have be associate in the legislative service their meeting occur under felicitous condition justify sincere congratulation and call for our grateful acknowledgment to a beneficent providence which have so signally bless and prosper we as a nation peace and good will with all the nation of the earth continue unbroken a matter of genuine satisfaction be the grow feeling of fraternal regard and unification of all section of our country the incompleteness of which have too long delay realization of the high blessing of the union the spirit of patriotism be universal and be ever increase in fervor the public question which now most engross we be lift far above either partisanship prejudice or former sectional difference they affect every part of our common country alike and permit of no division on ancient line question of foreign policy of revenue the soundness of the currency the inviolability of national obligation the improvement of the public service appeal to the individual conscience of every earnest citizen to whatever party he belong or in whatever section of the country he may reside the extra session of this congress which close during july last enact important legislation and while its full effect have not yet be realize what it have already accomplish assure we of its timeliness and wisdom to test its permanent value further time will be require and the people satisfied with its operation and result thus far be in no mind to withhold from it a fair trial tariff legislation having be settle by the extra session of congress the question next press for consideration be that of the currency the work of put our finance upon a sound basis difficult as it may seem will appear easy when we recall the financial operation of the government since 1866 on the 30th day of june of that year we have outstanding demand liability in the sum of $ 728,868,447.41 on the 1st of january 1879 these liability have be reduce to$443,889,495.88 of our interest bear obligation the figure be even more striking on july 1 1866 the principal of the interest bear debt of the government be $ 2,332,331,208 on the 1st day of july 1893 this sum have be reduce to $ 585,137,100 or an aggregate reduction of $ 1,747,294,108 the interest bear debt of the united states on the 1st day of december 1897 be $ 847,365,620 the government money now outstanding december 1 consist of $ 346,681,016 of united states note $ 107,793,280 of treasury note issue by authority of the law of 1890 $ 384,963,504 of silver certificate and $ 61,280,761 of standard silver dollar with the great resource of the government and with the honorable example of the past before we we ought not to hesitate to enter upon a currency revision which will make our demand obligation less onerous to the government and relieve our financial law from ambiguity and doubt the brief review of what be accomplish from the close of the war to 1893 make unreasonable and groundless any distrust either of our financial ability or soundness while the situation from 1893 to 1897 must admonish congress of the immediate necessity of so legislate as to make the return of the condition then prevail impossible there be many plan propose as a remedy for the evil before we can find the true remedy we must appreciate the real evil it be not that our currency of every kind be not good for every dollar of it be good good because the government 's pledge be out to keep it so and that pledge will not be break however the guaranty of our purpose to keep the pledge will be well show by advance toward its fulfillment the evil of the present system be find in the great cost to the government of maintain the parity of our different form of money that be keep all of they at par with gold we surely can not be long heedless of the burden this impose upon the people even under fairly prosperous condition while the past four year have demonstrate that it be not only an expensive charge upon the government but a dangerous menace to the national credit it be manifest that we must devise some plan to protect the government against bond issue for repeat redemption we must either curtail the opportunity for speculation make easy by the multiplied redemption of our demand obligation or increase the gold reserve for their redemption we have $ 900,000,000 of currency which the government by solemn enactment have undertake to keep at par with gold nobody be oblige to redeem in gold but the government the bank be not require to redeem in gold the government be oblige to keep equal with gold all its outstanding currency and coin obligation while its receipt be not require to be pay in gold they be pay in every kind of money but gold and the only mean by which the government can with certainty get gold be by borrow it can get it in no other way when it most need it the government without any fix gold revenue be pledge to maintain gold redemption which it have steadily and faithfully do and which under the authority now give it will continue to do the law which require the government after having redeem its united states note to pay they out again as current fund demand a constant replenishment of the gold reserve this be especially so in time of business panic and when the revenue be insufficient to meet the expense of the government at such time the government have no other way to supply its deficit and maintain redemption but through the increase of its bond debt as during the administration of my predecessor when $ 262,315,400 of four and a half per cent bond be issue and sell and the proceed use to pay the expense of the government in excess of the revenue and sustain the gold reserve while it be true that the great part of the proceed of these bond be use to supply deficient revenue a considerable portion be require to maintain the gold reserve with our revenue equal to our expense there would be no deficit require the issuance of bond but if the gold reserve fall below $ 100,000,000 how will it be replenish except by sell more bond be there any other way practicable under exist law the serious question then be shall we continue the policy that have be pursue in the past that be when the gold reserve reach the point of danger issue more bond and supply the need gold or shall we provide other mean to prevent these recur drain upon the gold reserve if no further legislation be have and the policy of sell bond be to be continue then congress should give the secretary of the treasury authority to sell bond at long or short period bear a less rate of interest than be now authorize by law i earnestly recommend as soon as the receipt of the government be quite sufficient to pay all the expense of the government that when any of the united states note be present for redemption in gold and be redeem in gold such note shall be keep and set apart and only pay out in exchange for gold this be an obvious duty if the holder of the united states note prefer the gold and get it from the government he should not receive back from the government a united states note without pay gold in exchange for it the reason for this be make all the more apparent when the government issue an interest bear debt to provide gold for the redemption of united states note a non interest bear debt surely it should not pay they out again except on demand and for gold if they be put out in any other way they may return again to be follow by another bond issue to redeem they another interest bear debt to redeem a non interest bear debt in my view it be of the utmost importance that the government should be relieve from the burden of provide all the gold require for exchange and export this responsibility be alone bear by the government without any of the usual and necessary banking power to help itself the bank do not feel the strain of gold redemption the whole strain rest upon the government and the size of the gold reserve in the treasury have come to be with or without reason the signal of danger or of security this ought to be stop if we be to have an era of prosperity in the country with sufficient receipt for the expense of the government we may feel no immediate embarrassment from our present currency but the danger still exist and will be ever present menace we so long as the exist system continue and besides it be in time of adequate revenue and business tranquillity that the government should prepare for the bad we can not avoid without serious consequence the wise consideration and prompt solution of this question the secretary of the treasury have outline a plan in great detail for the purpose of remove the threaten recurrence of a deplete gold reserve and save we from future embarrassment on that account to this plan i invite your careful consideration i concur with the secretary of the treasury in his recommendation that national bank be allow to issue note to the face value of the bond which they have deposit for circulation and that the tax on circulate note secure by deposit of such bond be reduce to one half of one per cent per annum i also join he in recommend that authority be give for the establishment of national bank with a minimum capital of $ 25,000 this will enable the small village and agricultural region of the country to be supply with currency to meet their need i recommend that the issue of national bank note be restrict to the denomination of ten dollar and upwards if the suggestion i have herein make shall have the approval of congress then i would recommend that national bank be require to redeem their note in gold the most important problem with which this government be now call upon to deal the recognize state the wise utterance of president grant in his memorable message of december 7 1875 be signally relevant to the present situation in cuba and it may be wholesome now to recall they contest in a former message to congress i have occasion to consider this question and reach the conclusion that the conflict in cuba dreadful and devastating as be its incident do not rise to the fearful dignity of war it be possible that the act of foreign power and even act of spain herself of this very nature might be point to in defense of such recognition but now as in its past history the united states should carefully avoid the false light which might lead it into the maze of doubtful law and of questionable propriety and adhere rigidly and sternly to the rule which have be its guide of do only that which be right and honest and of good report the question of accord or of withholding right of belligerency must be judge in every case in view of the particular attend fact unless justify by necessity it be always and justly regard as an unfriendly act and a gratuitous demonstration of moral support to the rebellion it be necessary and it be require when the interest and right of another government or of its people be so far affect by a pende civil conflict as to require a definition of its relation to the party thereto but this conflict must be one which will be recognize in the sense of international law as war belligerence too be a fact the mere existence of contend armed body and their occasional conflict do not constitute war in the sense refer to apply to the exist condition of affair in cuba the test recognize by publicist and writer on international law and which have be observe by nation of dignity honesty and power when free from sensitive or selfish and unworthy motive i fail to find in the insurrection the existence of such a substantial political organization real palpable and manifest to the world have the form and capable of the ordinary function of government toward its own people and to other state with court for the administration of justice with a local habitation possess such organization of force such material such occupation of territory as to take the contest out of the category of a mere rebellious insurrection or occasional skirmish and place it on the terrible footing of war to which a recognition of belligerency would aim to elevate it the contest moreover be solely on land the insurrection have not possess itself of a single seaport whence it may send forth its flag nor have it any mean of communication with foreign power except through the military line of its adversary no apprehension of any of those sudden and difficult complication which a war upon the ocean be apt to precipitate upon the vessel both commercial and national and upon the consular officer of other power call for the definition of their relation to the party to the contest consider as a question of expediency i regard the accordance of belligerent right still to be as unwise and premature as i regard it to be at present indefensible as a measure of right such recognition entail upon the country accord the right which flow from it difficult and complicated duty and require the exaction from the contend party of the strict observance of their right and obligation it confer the right of search upon the exercise the supervision recognize by our treaty of 1795 over our commerce on the high sea a very large part of which in its traffic between the atlantic and the gulf states and between all of they peaceful relation of the two states there can be little doubt to what result such supervision would before long draw this nation it would be unworthy of the united states to inaugurate the possibility of such result by measure of questionable right or expediency or by any indirection turn to the practical aspect of a recognition of belligerency and review its inconvenience and positive danger still far pertinent consideration appear in the code of nation there be no such thing as a naked recognition of belligerency unaccompanie by the assumption of international neutrality such recognition without more will not confer upon either party to a domestic conflict a status not theretofore actually possess or affect the relation of either party to other state the act of recognition usually take the form of a solemn proclamation of neutrality which recite the de facto condition of belligerency as its motive it announce a domestic law of neutrality in the declare state it assume the international obligation of a neutral in the presence of a public state of war it warn all citizen and other within the jurisdiction of the proclaimant that they violate those rigorous obligation at their own peril and can not expect to be shield from the consequence the right of visit and search on the sea and seizure of vessel and cargo and contraband of war and good prize under admiralty law military investment of the island but up to the margin of our own territorial water and a condition of thing would exist for which the cubans within their own domain could not hope to create a parallel while its creation through aid or sympathy from within our domain would be even more impossible than now with the additional obligation of international neutrality we would perforce assume the enforcement of this enlarge and onerous code of neutrality would only be influential within our own jurisdiction by land and sea and applicable by our own instrumentality it could impart to the united states no jurisdiction between spain and the insurgent it would give the united states no right of intervention to enforce the conduct of the strife within the paramount authority of spain accord to the international code of war for these reason i regard the recognition of the belligerency of the cuban insurgent as now unwise and therefore inadmissible should that step hereafter be deem
