to the congress of the united states
 obedient to that precept of the constitution which command the president to give from time to time to the congress information of the state of union and to recommend to their consideration such measure as shall be judge necessary and expedient it become my duty now to address your body with regard to the grave crisis that have arise in the relation of the united states to spain by reason of the warfare that for more than three year have rage in the neighbor island of cuba
 i do so because of the intimate connection of the cuban question with the state of our own union and the grave relation the course which it be now incumbent upon the nation to adopt must need bear to the traditional policy of our government if it be to accord with the precept lay down by the founder of the republic and religiously observe by succeed administration to the present day
 the present revolution be but the successor of other similar insurrection which have occur in cuba against the dominion of spain extend over a period of nearly half a century each of which during its progress have subject the united states to great effort and expense in enforce its neutrality law cause enormous loss to american trade and commerce cause irritation annoyance and disturbance among our citizen and by the exercise of cruel barbarous and uncivilized practice of warfare shock the sensibility and offend the humane sympathy of our people
 since the present revolution begin in february 1895 this country have see the fertile domain at our threshold ravage by fire and sword in the course of a struggle unequaled in the history of the island and rarely parallel as to the number of the combatant and the bitterness of the contest by any revolution of modern time where dependent people strive to be free have be oppose by the power of the sovereign state
 our people have behold a once prosperous community reduce to comparative want its lucrative commerce virtually paralyze its exceptional productiveness diminish its field lay waste its mill in ruin and its people perish by ten of thousand from hunger and destitution we have find ourselves constrain in the observance of that strict neutrality which our law enjoin and which the law of nation command to police our own water and watch our own seaport in prevention of any unlawful act in aid of the cubans
 our trade have suffer the capital invest by our citizen in cuba have be largely lose and the temper and forbearance of our people have be so sorely try as to beget a perilous unrest among our own citizen which have inevitably find its expression from time to time in the national legislature so that issue wholly external to our own body politic engross attention and stand in the way of the close devotion to domestic advancement that become a self contain commonwealth whose primal maxim have be the avoidance of all foreign entanglement all this must need awaken and have indeed arouse the utmost concern on the part of this government as well during my predecessor&rsquo;s term as in my own
 in april 1896 the evil from which our company suffer through the cuban war become so onerous that my predecessor make an effort to bring about a peace through the mediation of this government in any way that might tend to an honorable adjustment of the contest between spain and her revolted colony on the basis of some effective scheme of self government of cuba under the flag and sovereignty of spain it fail through the refusal of the spanish government then in power to consider any form of mediation or indeed any plan of settlement which do not begin with the actual submission of the insurgent to the mother
 country and the only on such term as spain herself might see fit to grant the war continue unabated the resistance of the insurgent be in no wise diminish
 the effort of spain be increase both by the dispatch of fresh levy to cuba and by the addition to the horror of the strife of a new and inhuman phase happily unprecedented in the modern history of civilized christian people the policy of devastation and concentration inaugurate by the captain general&rsquo;s bando of october 21 1896 in the province of pinar del rio be thence extend to embrace all of the island to which the power of the spanish arm be able to reach by occupation or by military operation the peasantry include all dwell in the open agricultural interior be drive into the garrison town or isolate place hold by the troop
 the raising and movement of provision of all kind be interdict the field ware lay waste dwelling unroofed and fire mill destroy and in short everything that could desolate the land and render it unfit for human habitation or support be command by one or the other of the contend party and execute by all the power at their disposal
 by the time the present administration take office a year ago reconcentration&mdash;so called&mdash;had be make effective over the well part of the four central and western province santa clara matanzas havana pinar del rio
 the agricultural population to the estimate number of 300,000 or more be herd within the town and their immediate vicinage deprive of the mean of support render destitute of shelter leave poorly clothe and expose to the most unsanitary condition as the scarcity of food increase with the devastation of the depopulated area of production destitution and want become misery and starvation month by month the death rate increase in an alarming ration by march 1897 accord to conservative estimate from official spanish source the mortality among the reconcentrado from starvation and the disease thereto incident exceed 50 per centum of their total number
 no practical relief be accord to the destitute the overburdened town already suffer from the general dearth could give no aid so call ldquo;zone of cultivation&rdquo establish within the immediate area of effective military control about the city and fortified camp prove illusory as a remedy for the suffering the unfortunate be for the most part woman and child with aged and helpless man enfeeble by disease and hunger could not have till the soil without tool seed or shelter for their own support or for the supply of the city reconcentration adopt avowedly as a ware measure in order to cut off the resource of the insurgent work its predestine result as i say in my message of last december it be not civilized warfare it be extermination the only peace it could beget be that of the wilderness and the grave
 meanwhile the military situation in the island have undergo a noticeable change the extraordinary activity that characterize the second year of the war when the insurgent invade even the thitherto unharmed field of pinar del rio and carry havoc and destruction up to the wall of the city of havana itself have relapse into a dogged struggle in the central and eastern province the spanish arm regain a measure of control in pinar del rio and part of havana but under the exist condition of the rural country without immediate improvement of their productive situation even thus partially restrict the revolutionist hold their own and their conquest and submission put forward by spain as the essential and sole basis of peace seem as far distant as at the outset
 in this state of affair my administration find itself confront with the grave problem of its duty my message of last december review the situation and narrate the step take with a view to relieve its acuteness and open the way to some from of honorable settlement the assassination of the prime minister canovas lead to a change of government in spain the former administration pledge to subjugation without concession give place to that of a ~~more liberal party commit long in advance to a policy of reform involve the wide principle of home rule for cuba and puerto rico
 the overture of this government make through its new envoy general woodford and look to an immediate and effective amelioration of the condition of the island although not accept to the extent of the condition of the island although not accept to the extent of admit mediation in any shape be meet by assurance that home rule in advanced phase would be forthwith offer to cuba without wait for the war to end and that more humane method should thenceforth prevail in the conduct of hostility coincidentally with these declaration the new government of spain continue and complete the policy already begin by its predecessor of testify friendly regard for this nation by release american citizen hold under one charge or another connect with the insurrection so that by the end of november not a single person entitle in any way to our national protection remain in a spanish prison
 while these negotiation be in progress the increase destitution of the unfortunate reconcentrado and alarming mortality among they claim earnest attention the success which have attend the limited measure of relief extend to the suffer american citizen among they by the judicious expenditure through the consular agency of the money appropriate expressly for their succor by the joint resolution approve may 24 1897 prompt the humane extension of a similar scheme of aid to the great body of sufferer a suggestion to this end be acquiesce in by the spanish authority on the 24th of december last i cause to be issue an appeal to the american people invite contribution in money or in kind for the succor of the starve sufferer in cuba follow this on the 8th of january by a similar public announcement of the formation of a central cuban relief committee with headquarters in new york city compose of three member represent the american national red cross and the religious and business element of the community
 the effort of that committee have be untiring and have accomplish much arrangement for free transportation to cuba have greatly aid the charitable work the president of the american red cross and representative of other contributory organization have generously visit cuba and cooperate with the consul general and the local authority to make effective distribution of the relief collect through the effort of the central committee nearly $ 200,000 in money and supply have already reach the sufferer and more be forthcoming the supply be admit duty free and transportation to the interior have be arrange so that the relief at first necessarily confine to havana and the large city be now extend through most if not all of the town where suffering exist
 thousand of life have already be save the necessity for change in the condition of the reconcentrados be recognize by the spanish government within a few day past the order of general weyler have be revoke the reconcentrado it be say be to be permit to return to their home and aid to resume the self support pursuit of peace public work have be order to give they employment and a sum of $ 600,000 have be appropriate for their relief
 the war in cuba be of such a nature that short of subjugation or extermination a final military victory for either side seem impracticable the alternative lie in the physical exhaustion of the one or the other party or perhaps of both&mdash;a condition which in effect end the ten year&rsquo;s war by the truce of zanjon the prospect of such a protraction and conclusion of the present strife be a contingency hardly to be contemplate with equanimity by the civilized world and least of all by the united states affect and injure as we be deeply and intimately by its very existence
 realize this it appear to be my duty in a spirit of true friendliness no less to spain than the cubans who have so much to lose by the prolongation of the struggle to seek to bring about on immediate termination of the war to this end i submit on the 27th ultimo as a result of much representation and correspondence through the united states minister at
 madrid proposition to the spanish government look to an armistice until october 1 for the negotiation of peace with the good office of the president
 in addition i ask the immediate revocation of the order of reconcentration so as to permit the people to return to their farm and the needy to be relieve with provision and supply from the united states cooperate with the spanish authority so as to afford full relief
 the reply of the spanish cabinet be receive on the night of the 31st ultimo it offer as the mean to bring about peace in cuba to confide the preparation thereof to the insular parliament inasmuch as the concurrence of that body would be necessary to reach a final result it be however understand that the power reserve by the constitution to the central government be not lessen or diminish as the cuban parliament do not meet until the 4th of may next the spanish government would not object for its part to accept at one a suspension of hostility if ask for by the insurgent from the general in chief to whom it would pertain in such case to determine the duration and condition of the armistice
 the proposition submit by general woodford and the reply of the spanish government be both in the form or brief memoranda the text of which be before i and be substantially in the language above give the function of the cuban parliament in the matter of ldquo;preparing&rdquo peace and the manner of its do so be not express in the spanish memorandum but from general woodford&rsquo;s explanatory report of preliminary discussion precede the final conference it be understand that the spanish government stand ready to give the insular congress full power to settle the term of peace with the insurgents&mdash;whether by direct negotiation or indirectly by mean of legislation do not appear
 with this last overture in the direction of immediate peace and its disappointing reception by spain the executive be bring to the end of his effort
 in my annual message of december last i say
 of the untried measure there remain only recognition of the insurgent as belligerent recognition of the independence of cuba neutral intervention to end the war by impose a national a rational compromise between the contestant and intervention in favor of one or the other party i speak not of forcible annexation for that can not be think of that by our code of morality would be criminal aggression
 thereupon i review these alternative in the light of president grant&rsquo;s measure word utter in 1875 when after seven year of sanguinary destructive and cruel hostility in cuba he reach the conclusion that the recognition of the independence of cuba be impracticable and indefensible and that the recognition of belligerence be not warrant by the fact accord to the test of public law i comment especially upon the latter aspect of the question point out the inconvenience and positive danger of a recognition of belligerence which while add to the already onerous burden of neutrality within our own jurisdiction could not in any way extend our influence or effective office in the territory of hostility
 nothing have since occur to change my view in this regard and i recognize as fully now as then that the issuance of a proclamation of neutrality by which process the so call recognition of belligerent be publish could of itself and unattended by other action accomplish nothing toward the one end for which we labor&mdash;the instant pacification of cuba and cessation of the misery that afflict the island
 turn to the question of recognize at this time the independence of the present insurgent government in cuba we find safe precedent in our history from an early day they be well
 sum up in president jackson&rsquo;s message to congress december 21 1836 on the subject of the recognition of the independence of texas he say
 in all the contest that have arise out of the revolution of france out of the dispute relate to the crowns of portugal and spain out of the separation of the american possession of both from the european governments and out of the numerous and constantly occur struggle for dominion in spanish america so wisely consistent with our just principle have be the action of our government that we have under the most critical circumstance avoid all censure and encounter no other evil than the produce by a transient estrangement of good will in those against whom we have be by force of evidence compel to decide
 it have thus make known to the world that the uniform policy and practice of the united states be to avoid all interference in dispute which merely relate to the internal government of other nation and eventually to recognize the authority of the prevail party without reference to our particular interest and view or to the merit of the original controversy
 but on this as on every other try occasion safety be to be find in a rigid adherence to principle
 in the contest between spain and the revolted colony we stand aloof and wait not only until the ability of the new states to protect themselves be fully establish but until the danger of their be again subjugate have entirely pass away then and not until then be they recognize
 such be our course in regard to mexico herself it be true that with defeat the chief of the republic himself capture and all present power to control the newly organize government of texas annihilate within its confine but on the other hand there be in appearance at least an immense disparity of physical force on the side of texas the mexican republic under another executive be rally its force under a new lender and menace a fresh invasion to recover its lose dominion
 upon the issue of this threaten invasion the independence of texas may be consider as suspend and be there nothing peculiar in the relative situation of the united states and texas our acknowledgment of its independence at such a crisis could scarcely be regard as consistent with the prudent reserve with which we have hitherto hold ourselves bind to treat all similar question
 thereupon andrew jackson proceed to consider the risk that there might be impute to the united states motive of selfish interest in view of the former claim on our part to the territory of texas and of the avow purpose of the texas in seek recognition of independence as an incident to the incorporation of texas into the union conclude thus
 prudence therefore seem to dictate that we should still stand aloof and maintain our present attitude if not until mexico itself or one of the great foreign power shall recognize the independence of the new government at least until the lapse of time or the course of event shall have prove beyond cavil or dispute the ability of the people of that country to maintain their separate sovereignty and to uphold the government constitute by they neither of the contend party can justly complain of this course by pursue it we be but carry out the long establish policy of our government a policy which have secure to we respect and influence abroad and inspire confidence at home
 these be the word of the resolute and patriotic jackson they be evidence that the united states in addition to the test impose by public law as the condition of the recognition of independence by a neutral state to wit that the revolted state shall ldquo;constitute in fact a body politic have a government in substance as well as in name possess of the element of
 stability,&rdquo and form de facto ldquo;if leave to itself a state among the nation reasonably capable of discharge the duty of a state&rdquo have impose for its own governance in deal with case like these the further condition that recognition of independent statehood be not due to a revolted dependency until the danger of its being again subjugate by the parent state have entirely pass away
 this extreme test be in fact apply in the case of texas the congress to whom president jackson refer the question as one ldquo;probably lead to war,&rdquo and therefore a proper subject for ldquo;a previous understanding with that body by whom war can alone be declare and by whom all the provision for sustain its peril must be furnished,&rdquo leave the matter of the recognition of texas to the discretion of the executive provide merely for the sending of a diplomatic agent when the president should be satisfied that the republic of texas have become ldquo;an independent state.&rdquo it be so recognize by president van buren who commission a charge d&rsquo;affaire march 7 1837 after mexico have abandon an attempt to reconquer the texan territory and when there be at the time no bona fide contest go on between the insurgent province and its former sovereign
 i say in my message of december last ldquo;it be to be seriously consider whether the cuban insurrection possess beyond dispute the attribute of statehood which alone can demand the recognition of belligerency in its favor.&rdquo the same requirement must certainly be no less seriously consider when the graver issue of recognize independence be in question for no less positive test can be apply to the great act than to the less while on the other hand the influence and consequence of the struggle upon the internal policy of the recognize state which form important factor when the recognition of belligerency be concern be secondary if not rightly eliminable factor when the real question be whether the community claim recognition be or be not independent beyond peradventure
 nor from the standpoint of expediency do i think it would be wise or prudent for this government to recognize at the present time the independence of the so call cuban republic such recognition be not necessary in order to enable the united states to intervene and pacify the island to commit this country now to the recognition of any particular government in cuba might subject we to embarrass condition of international obligation toward the organization so recognize in case of intervention our conduct would be subject to the approval or disapproval of such government we would be require to submit to its direction and to assume to it the mere relation of a friendly ally
 when it shall appear hereafter that there be within the island a government capable of perform the duty and discharge the function of a separate nation and have as a matter of fact the proper form and attribute of nationality such government can be promptly and readily recognize and the relation and interest of the united states with such nation adjust
 there remain the alternative form of intervention to end the war either as an impartial neutral by impose a rational compromise between the contestant or as the active ally of the one party or the other
 as to the first it be not to be forget that during the last few month the relation of the united states have virtually be one of friendly intervention in many way each not of itself conclusive but all tend to the exertion of a potential influence toward an ultimate pacific result just and honorable to all interest concern the spirit of all our act hitherto have be an earnest unselfish desire for peace and prosperity in cuba untarnishe by difference between we and spain and unstaine by the blood of american citizen
 the forcible intervention of the united states as a neutral to stop the war accord to the large dictate of humanity and follow many historical precedent where neighboring state have interfere to check the hopeless sacrifice of life by internecine conflict beyond their
 border be justifiable on rational ground it involve however hostile constraint upon both the party to the contest as well to enforce a truce as to guide the eventual settlement
 the ground for such intervention may be briefly summarize as follow
 first in the cause of humanity and to put an end to the barbarity bloodshed starvation and horrible misery now exist there and which the party to the conflict be either unable or unwilling to stop or mitigate it be no answer to say this be all in another country belong to another nation and be therefore none of our business it be specially our duty for it be right at our door
 second we owe it to our citizen in cuba to afford they that protection and indemnity for life and property which no government there can or will afford and to that end to terminate the condition that deprive they of legal protection
 third the right to intervene may be justify by the very serious injury to the commerce trade and business of our people and by the wanton destruction of property and devastation of the island
 fourth and which be of the utmost importance the present condition of affair in cuba be a constant menace to our peace and entail upon this government and enormous expense with such a conflict wage for year in an island so near we and with which our people have such trade and business relation when the life and liberty of our citizen be in constant danger and their property destroy and themselves ruin where our trading vessel be liable to seizure and be seize at our very door by war ship of a foreign nation the expedition of filibuster that we be powerless to prevent altogether and the irritate question and entanglement thus arising&mdash;all these and other that i need not mention with the result strained relation be constant menace to our peace and compel we to keep on a semiwar foot with a nation with which we be at peace
 these element of danger and disorder already point out have be strikingly illustrate by a tragic event which have deeply and justly move the american people i have already transmit to congress the report of the naval court of inquiry on the destruction of the battle ship maine in the harbor of havana during the night of the 15th of february the destruction of that noble vessel have fill the national heart with inexpressible horror tow hundred and fifty eight brave sailor and marine and two officer of our navy repose in the fancied security of a friendly harbor have be hurl to death grief and want bring to their home and sorrow to the nation
 the naval court of inquiry which it be needless to say command the unqualified confidence of the government be unanimous in its conclusion that the destruction of the maine be cause by an exterior explosion that of a submarine mine it do not assume to place the responsibility that remain to be fix
 in any event the destruction of the maine by whatever exterior cause be a patent and impressive proof of a state of thing in cuba that be intolerable that condition be thus show to be such that the spanish government can not assure safety and security to a vessel of the americas navy in the harbor of havana on a mission of peace and rightfully there
 far refer in this connection to recent diplomatic correspondence a dispatch from our minister to spain of the 36th ultimo contain the statement that the spanish minister for foreign affair assure he positively that the spain will do all that the high honor and justice require in the matter of the maine the reply above refer to of the 31st ultimo also contain an expression of the readiness of spain to submit to an arbitration all the difference which can arise in this matter which be subsequently explain by the note of the spanish minister at washington of the 10th instant as follow
 as to the question of fact which spring from the diversity of view between the report of the american and spanish board spain propose that the fact be ascertain by an impartial investigation by expert whose decision spain accept in advance
 to this i have make no reply
 president grant in 1875 after discuss the phase of the contest as it then appear and its hopeless and apparent indefinite prolongation say
 in such event i be of opinion that other nation will be compel to assume the responsibility which devolve upon they and to seriously consider the only remain measure possible&mdash;mediation and intervention owing perhaps to the large expanse of water separate the island from the peninsula the contend party appear to have within themselves no depository of common confidence to suggest wisdom when passion and excitement have their away and to assume the part of peacemaker
 in this view in the early day of the contest the good office of the united states as a mediator be tender in good faith without any selfish purpose in the interest of humanity and in sincere friendship for both party but be at the time decline by spain with the declaration nevertheless that at a future time they would be indispensable no intimation have be receive that in the opinion of spain that time have be reach and yet the strife continue with all its dread horror and all its injury to the interest of the united states and of other nation
 each party seem quite capable of work great injury and damage to the other as well as to all the relation and interest dependent on the existence of peace in the island but they seem incapable of reach any adjustment and both have thus far fail of achieve any success whereby one party shall possess and control the island to the exclusion of the other under these circumstance the agency of other either by mediation or intervention seem to be the only alternative which must soon or later be invoke for the termination of the strife
 in the last annual message of my immediate predecessor during the pende struggle it be say
 when the inability of spain to deal successfully with the insurrection have become manifest and it be demonstrate that her sovereignty be extinct in cuba for all purpose of its rightful existence and when a hopeless struggle for its reestablishment have degenerate into a strife which mean nothing more then the useless sacrifice of human life and the utter destruction of the very subject matter of the conflict a situation will be present in which our obligation to the sovereignty of spain will be supersede by high obligation which we can hardly hesitate to recognize and discharge
 in my annual message to congress december last speak to this question i say
 the near future will demonstrate whether the indispensable condition of a righteous peace just alike to the cubans and to spain as well as equitable to all our interest so intimately involve in the welfare of cuba be likely to be attain if not the exigency of further and other action by the united states will remain to be take when the time come that action will be determine in the line of indisputable right and duty it will be face without misgiving or hesitancy in the light of the obligation this government over to itself to the people who have confide to it the protection of their interest and honor and to humanity
 sure of the right keep free from all offense ourselves actuate only by upright and patriotic consideration move neither by passion nor selfishness the government will continue its watchful care over the right and property of american citizen and will abate
 none of its effort to bring about by peaceful agency a peace which shall be honorable and enduring if it shall hereafter appear to be a duty impose by our obligation to ourselves to civilization and humanity to intervene with force it shall be without fault on our part only because the necessity for such action will be so clear as to command the support and approval of the civilized world
 the long trail have prove that the object for which spain have wage the war can not be attain the fire of insurrection may flame or may smolder with varying season but it have not be and it be plain that it can not be extinguish by present method the only hope of relief and repose from a condition which can no long be endure be the enforce pacification of cuba in the name of humanity in the name of civilization in behalf of endanger american interest which give we the right and the duty to speak and to act the war in cuba must stop
 in view of these fact and of these consideration i ask the congress to authorize and empower the president to take measure to secure a full and final termination of hostility between the government of spain and the people of cuba and to secure in the island the establishment of a stable government capable of maintain order and observe its international obligation insure peace and tranquility and the security of its citizen as well as our own and to use the military and naval force of the united states as may be necessary for these purpose
 and in the interest of humanity and to aid in preserve the life of the starve people of the island i recommend that the distribution of food and supply be continue and that an appropriation be make out of the public treasury to supplement the charity of our citizen
 the issue be now with the congress it be a solemn responsibility i have exhaust every effort to relieve the intolerable condition of affair which be at our door prepare to execute every obligation impose upon i by the constitution and the law i await your action
 yesterday and since the preparation of the foregoing message official information be receive by i that the late decree of the queen regent of spain direct general blanco in order to prepare and facilitate peace to proclaim a suspension of hostility the duration and detail of which have not yet be communicate to i
 this fact with every other pertinent consideration will i be sure have your just and careful attention in the solemn deliberation upon which you be about to enter if this measure attain a successful result then our aspiration as a christian peace love people will be realize if it fail it will be only another justification for our contemplated action
by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas by a joint resolution pass by the congress and approve april 20 1898 and communicate to the government of spain it be demand that say government at once relinquish its authority and government in the island of cuba and withdraw its land and naval force from cuba and cuban water and the president of the united states be direct and empower to use the entire land and naval force of the united states and to call into the actual service of the united states the militia of the several states to such extent as might be necessary to carry say resolution into effect and
 whereas in carry into effect say resolution the president of the united states deem it necessary to set on foot and maintain a blockade of the north coast of cuba include all port on say coast between cardenas and bahia honda and the port of cienfuegos on the south coast of cuba
 now therefore i william mckinley president of the united states in order to enforce the say resolution do hereby declare and proclaim that the united states of america have institute and will maintain a blockade of the north coast of cuba include port on say coast between cardenas and bahia honda and the port of cienfuegos on the south coast of cuba aforesaid in pursuance of the law of the united states and the law of nation applicable to such case an efficient force will be post so as to prevent the entrance and exit of vessel from the port aforesaid any neutral vessel approach any of say port or attempt to leave the same without notice or knowledge of the establishment of such blockade will be duly warn by the commander of the blockade force who will indorse on her register the fact and the date of such warning where such indorsement be make and if the same vessel shall again attempt to enter any blockade port she will be capture and send to the near and convenient port for such proceeding against she and her cargo as prize as may be deem advisable
 neutral vessel lie in any of say port at the time of the establishment of such blockade will be allow thirty day to issue therefrom
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix do at the city of washington this 22d day of april a.d. 1898 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and twenty second
 william mckinley
 by the president
 john sherman
 secretary of state

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas a joint resolution of congress be approve on the 20th day of april 1898 entitle joint resolution for the recognition of the independence of the people of cuba demand that the government of spain relinquish its authority and government in the island of cuba and to withdraw its land and naval force from cuba and cuban water and direct the president of the united states to use the land and naval force of the united states to carry these resolution into effect and
 whereas by an act of congress entitle an act to provide for temporarily increase the military establishment of the united states in time of war and for other purpose approve april 22 1898 the president be authorize in order to raise a volunteer army to issue his proclamation call for volunteer to serve in the army of the united states
 now therefore i william mckinley president of the united states by virtue of the power vest in i by the constitution and the law and deem sufficient occasion to exist have think fit to call forth and hereby do call forth volunteer to the aggregate number of 125,000 in order to carry into effect the purpose of the say resolution the same to be apportion as far as practicable among the several states and territories and the district of columbia accord to population and to serve for two year unless soon discharge the detail for this object will be immediately communicate to the proper authority through the war department
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 23d day of april a.d. 1898 and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and twenty second
 william mckinley

to the senate and house of representatives notwithstanding the add burden render necessary by the war our people rejoice in a very satisfactory and steadily increase degree of prosperity evidence by the large volume of business ever record manufacture have be productive agricultural pursuit have yield abundant return labor in all field of industry be well reward revenue legislation pass by the present congress have increase the treasury 's receipt to the amount estimate by its author the finance of the government have be successfully administer and its credit advance to the first rank while its currency have be maintain at the world 's high standard military service under a common flag and for a righteous cause have strengthen the national spirit and serve to cement more closely than ever the fraternal bond between every section of the country a review of the relation of the united states to other power always appropriate be this year of primary importance in view of the momentous issue which have arise demand in one instance the ultimate determination by arm and involve far reach consequence which will require the earnest attention of the congress in my last annual message very full consideration be give to the question of the duty of the government of the united states toward spain and the cuban insurrection as be by far the most important problem with which we be then call upon to deal the consideration then advance and the exposition of the view therein express disclose my sense of the extreme gravity of the situation set aside as logically unfounded or practically inadmissible the recognition of the cuban insurgent as belligerent the recognition of the independence of cuba neutral intervention to end the war by impose a rational compromise between the contestant intervention in favor of one or the other party and forcible annexation of the island i conclude it be honestly due to our friendly relation with spain that she should be give a reasonable chance to realize her expectation of reform to which she have become irrevocably commit within a few week previously she have announce comprehensive plan which it be confidently asserted would be efficacious to remedy the evil so deeply affect our own country so injurious to the true interest of the mother country as well as to those of cuba and so repugnant to the universal sentiment of humanity the ensue month bring little sign of real progress toward the pacification of cuba the autonomous administration set up in the capital and some of the principal city appear not to gain the favor of the inhabitant nor to be able to extend their influence to the large extent of territory hold by the insurgent while the military arm obviously unable to cope with the still active rebellion continue many of the most objectionable and offensive policy of the government that have precede it no tangible relief be afford the vast number of unhappy reconcentrado despite the reiterate profession make in that regard and the amount appropriate by spain to that end the proffered expedient of zone of cultivation prove illusory indeed no less practical nor more delusive promise of succor could well have be tender to the exhausted and destitute people strip of all that make life and home dear and herd in a strange region among unsympathetic stranger hardly less necessitous than themselves by the end of december the mortality among they have frightfully increase conservative estimate from spanish source place the death among these distressed people at over 40 per cent from the time general weyler 's decree of reconcentration be enforce with the acquiescence of the spanish authority a scheme be adopt for relief by charitable contribution raise in this country and distribute under the direction of the consul general and the several consul by noble and earnest individual effort through the organized agency of the american red cross thousand of life be thus save but many thousand more be inaccessible to such form of aid the war continue on the old footing without comprehensive plan develop only the same spasmodic encounter barren of strategic result that have mark the course of the early ten year rebellion as well as the present insurrection from its start no alternative save physical exhaustion of either combatant and therewithal the practical ruin of the island lie in sight but how far distant no one could venture to conjecture at this juncture on the 15th of february last occur the destruction of the battle ship maine while rightfully lie in the harbor of havana on a mission of international courtesy and good will a catastrophe the suspicious nature and horror of which stir the nation 's heart profoundly it be a striking evidence of the poise and sturdy good sense distinguish our national character that this shocking blow fall upon a generous people already deeply touch by precede event in cuba do not move they to an instant desperate resolve to tolerate no long the existence of a condition of danger and disorder at our door that make possible such a deed by whomsoever wrought yet the instinct of justice prevail and the nation anxiously await the result of the search investigation at once set on foot the finding of the naval board of inquiry establish that the origin of the explosion be external by a submarine mine and only halt through lack of positive testimony to fix the responsibility of its authorship all these thing carry conviction to the most thoughtful even before the finding of the naval court that a crisis in our relation with spain and toward cuba be at hand so strong be this belief that it need but a brief executive suggestion to the congress to receive immediate answer to the duty of make instant provision for the possible and perhaps speedily probable emergency of war and the remarkable almost unique spectacle be present of a unanimous vote of both houses on the 9th of march appropriate $ 50,000,000 for the national defense and for each and every purpose connect therewith to be expend at the discretion of the president that this act of prevision come none too soon be disclose when the application of the fund be undertake our coast be practically undefended our navy need large provision for increase ammunition and supply and even number to cope with any sudden attack from the navy of spain which comprise modern vessel of the high type of continental perfection our army also require enlargement of man and munition the detail of the hurried preparation for the dreaded contingency be tell in the report of the secretaries of war and of the navy and need not be repeat here it be sufficient to say that the outbreak of war when it do come find our nation not unprepared to meet the conflict nor be the apprehension of come strife confine to our own country it be feel by the continental power which on april 6 through their ambassador and envoy address to the executive an expression of hope that humanity and moderation might mark the course of this government and people and that further negotiation would lead to an agreement which while secure the maintenance of peace would afford all necessary guaranty for the reestablishment of order in cuba in respond to that representation i say i share the hope the envoy have express that peace might be preserve in a manner to terminate the chronic condition of disturbance in cuba so injurious and menacing to our interest and tranquillity as well as shocking to our sentiment of humanity and while appreciate the humanitarian and disinterested character of the communication they have make on behalf of the power i state the confidence of this government for its part that equal appreciation would be show for its own earnest and unselfish endeavor to fulfill a duty to humanity by end a situation the indefinite prolongation of which have become insufferable still animate by the hope of a peaceful solution and obey the dictate of duty no effort be relax to bring about a speedy ending of the cuban struggle negotiation to this object continue actively with the government of spain look to the immediate conclusion of a six month armistice in cuba with a view to effect the recognition of her people 's right to independence besides this the instant revocation of the order of reconcentration be ask so that the sufferer return to their home and aid by united american and spanish effort might be put in a way to support themselves and by orderly resumption of the well nigh destroy productive energy of the island constitutional power of the madrid government which to that end would grant an armistice if solicit by the insurgent for such time as the general in chief might see fit to fix how and with what scope of discretionary power the insular parliament be expect to set about the preparation of peace do not appear if it be to be by negotiation with the insurgent the issue seem to rest on the one side with a body choose by a fraction of the elector in the district under spanish control and on the other with the insurgent population hold the interior country unrepresente in the so call parliament and defiant at the suggestion of sue for peace grieved and disappoint at this barren outcome of my sincere endeavor to reach a practicable solution i feel it my duty to remit the whole question to the congress in the message of april 11 1898 i announce that with this last overture in the direction of immediate peace in cuba and its disappointing reception by spain the effort of the executive be bring to an end i again review the alternative course of action which have be propose conclude that the only one consonant with international policy and compatible with our firm set historical a truce as to guide the eventual settlement the ground justify that step be the interest of humanity the duty to protect the life and property of our citizen in cuba the right to check injury to our commerce and people through the devastation of the island and most important the need of remove at once and forever the constant menace and the burden entail upon our government by the uncertainty and peril of the situation cause by the unendurable disturbance in cuba i say the long trial have prove that the object for which spain have wage the war can not be attain the fire of insurrection may flame or may smolder with varying season but it have not be and it be plain that it can not be extinguish by present method the only hope of relief and repose from a condition which can no long be endure be the enforce pacification of cuba in the name of humanity in the name of civilization in behalf of endanger american interest which give we the right and the duty to speak and to act the war in cuba must stop in view of all this the congress be ask to authorize and empower the president to take measure to secure a full and final termination of hostility between spain and the people of cuba and to secure in the island the establishment of a stable government capable of maintain order and observe its international obligation insure peace and tranquillity and the security of its citizen as well as our own and for the accomplishment of those end to use the military and naval force of the united states as might be necessary with add authority to continue generous relief to the starve people of cuba the response of the congress after nine day of earnest deliberation during which the almost unanimous sentiment of your body be develop on every point save as to the expediency of couple the propose action with a formal recognition of the republic of cuba as the true and lawful government of that island a proposition which fail of adoption the congress after conference on the 19th of april by a vote of 42 to 35 in the senate and 311 to 6 in the house of representatives pass the memorable joint resolution declare first that the people of the island of cuba be and of right ought to be free and independent second that it be the duty of the united states to demand and the government of the united states do hereby demand that the government of spain at once relinquish its authority and government in the island of cuba and withdraw its land and naval force from cuba and cuban water third that the president of the united states be and he hereby be direct and empower to use the entire land and naval force of the united states and to call into the actual service of the united states the militia of the several states to such extent as may be necessary to carry these resolution into effect fourth that the united states hereby disclaim any disposition or intention to exercise sovereignty jurisdiction or control over say island except for the pacification thereof and assert its determination when that be accomplish to leave the government and control of the island to its people this resolution be approve by the executive on the next day april 20 a copy be at once communicate to the spanish minister at this capital who forthwith announce that his continuance in washington have thereby become impossible and ask for his passport which be give he he thereupon withdraw from washington leave the protection of spanish interest in the united states to the french ambassador and the austro hungarian minister simultaneously with its communication to the spanish minister here general woodford the american minister at madrid be telegraph confirmation of the text of the joint resolution and direct to communicate it to the government of spain with the formal demand that it at once relinquish its authority and government in the island of cuba and withdraw its force therefrom couple this demand with announcement of the intention of this government as to the future of the island in conformity with the fourth clause of the resolution and give spain until noon of april 23 to reply that demand although as above show officially make that upon the president 's approval of the joint resolution the madrid government regard the act as equivalent to an evident declaration of war have order its minister in washington to withdraw nation to reduce to the low possible point the damage sustain in time of war by peaceable trade and commerce it be true we may suffer in such case less than other community but all nation be damage more or less by the state of uneasiness and apprehension into which an outbreak of hostility throw the entire commercial world it should be our object therefore to minimize so far as practicable this inevitable loss and disturbance this purpose can probably well be accomplish by an international agreement to regard all private property at sea as exempt from capture or destruction by the force of belligerent power the united states government have for many year advocate this humane and beneficent principle and be now in position to recommend it to other power without the imputation of selfish motive i therefore suggest for your consideration that the executive be authorize to correspond with the government of the principal maritime power with a view of incorporate into the permanent law of civilized nation the principle of the exemption of all private property at sea not contraband of war from capture or destruction by belligerent power the secretary of the treasury report that the and even penal legislation an act to protect trade and commerce against unlawful restraint and monopoly be pass by congress on the 2d of july 1890 the provision of this statute be comprehensive and stringent it declare every contract or combination in the form of a trust or otherwise or conspiracy in the restraint of trade or commerce among the several states or with foreign nation to be unlawful it denominate as a criminal every person who make any such contract or engage in any such combination or conspiracy and provide a punishment by fine or imprisonment it invest the several circuit court of the united states with jurisdiction to prevent and restrain violation of the act and make it the duty of the several united states district attorney under the direction of the attorney general to institute proceeding in equity to prevent and restrain such violation it far confer upon any person who shall be injure in his business or property by any other person or corporation by reason of anything forbid or declare to be unlawful by the act the power to sue therefore in any circuit court of the united states without respect to the amount in controversy and to recover threefold the damage by he sustain and the cost of the suit include reasonable attorney fee it will be perceive that the act be aim at every kind of combination in the nature of a trust or
